We are also grateful to the Binks Trust for its financial contributions to the funding of the Edinburgh editorial team and office. The editors again express their gratitude to the British Academy, which made the Carlyle Letters a British Academy Research Project and continues to support us with an annual grant, and to the members of its Committee on Academy Research Projects and its assistant secretary, Ken Emond. The editors also express their gratitude to those private individuals who have made donations for the support of the Edinburgh Carlyle Letters office, to the University of Edinburgh Development Trust, and to Joyce Caplan and the Friends of Edinburgh University Library.

We remain extremely grateful for the advice of Paolo Mangiafico, director of Digital Information Strategy, Duke University; and we extend our thanks for early critiques of the electronic edition to David Chesnutt, formerly of the Model Editions Partnership at the University of South Carolina, and to Natalia Smith of the DocSouth project at the University of North Carolina. Volume 42 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle covers the period from May to September 1865. Of the 189 letters in this volume, 119 are from Thomas Carlyle, and 70 from Jane Welsh Carlyle, including two written by Geraldine Jewsbury for JWC when her hand was too painful for her to write. TC and JWC were apart for most of this period, so many of the letters are written to each other.

The letters of this volume dramatize the beginning of the end of the Carlyles’ long relationship. While neither TC nor JWC could know that JWC’s death (in April 1866) was so close at hand during the writing of these letters, their often melancholic tone (especially evident in the earlier letters of this volume) appears to foreshadow this coming event. The note, for example, that TC wrote later to JWC’s letter to him, 11 August, outlines his post-Frederick feelings as he visited a friend in the Lake District: “Nothing could exceed my private weariness, sadness, misery, and depression.” But he then added the retrospective comment: “Little thought it was, within few months, to be all sharpened into poignancy and tenderest woe, and remain with me in that far exceeding if somewhat nobler form” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:280). As the summer months of 1865 progressed, however, the couple experienced a welcome and surprising lightening of their physical infirmities and a return to relatively good health. With this restoration of bodily health came renewed mental well-being and a real sense of hope that, as they approached their later years (TC reached his seventieth birthday in December 1865), a healthful and productive Indian summer of their lives might be in store. Although JWC’s death clearly removed this possibility, a number of the letters written in the second half of this volume anticipate a happier outcome than that which ultimately faced them. Illustrations of this remarkable, if brief, final act of their lives as a couple are evident in JWC’s lively and witty letters that were written in the months after Dr. Russell had told her that she would be unlikely to regain the use of her right hand. This revival of bodily spirit and energy also foreshadowed TC’s acceptance of the rectorship of the University of Edinburgh (in November 1865), only a short time after his oft-repeated declarations of retirement from public life following the completion of Frederick in February 1865. These late letters in many ways reinstate the characters of two individuals that those readers who have followed the Collected Letters in sequence will immediately recognize: JWC, tender, solicitous, and intimate (“Yours lovingly” she signed the letter to TC of 11 August, quoted
above); TC, engaged with his family and Scottish friends, shrewd and often spiky. He commented to JWC, 10 August, on Edinburgh: “nay Edinr itself I find to have left Town! They have clipt & dug away every feature that used to make Edinr vernacular and interesting to me: Adieu to it also!” Their welcome return to familiar patterns of textual self-fashioning provides a pleasing and in many ways unexpected renaissance for a couple whose lives had earlier seemed played out.

The first words of a letter appearing early in this volume captured well the physical strain under which much of JWC’s life in 1865 was lived. Writing from London to TC, who was then staying with his sister Mary Austin at The Gill, JWC declared that she could not use her hand “without extreme pain” and that she had been “quite wild with the pain the last two nights and days” (JWC to TC, [1 June]). This infirmity affected not only the tone of Jane’s ensuing letters but also their physical appearance. On the page, when she was unable to employ the services of an amanuensis, her uncharacteristically unsteady handwriting offered a visible endorsement of the weakness she described (for an example of her left-handed writing, see 71). The brevity of many of Jane’s letters also offered testament to the difficult circumstances under which they were composed. Her frustrations, captured in her good-natured but pathetic salutation to the letter quoted above—“Your lamed Goody”—are easily imaginable when taking into account the pleasure and flair with which she customarily entered into correspondence. TC’s reply to this letter offered his characteristic counterpoint to her own account of pain and infirmity. While his genuine distress at JWC’s condition was evident and his solicitousness for her welfare was quite sincere (“Oh that this Note cd find my poor tormented Darling to have had some better sleep when it arrives tomorrow morning!”), he seemed drawn to take an equal part in her misery. In a line that can have done little to cheer up his ailing wife, TC opined: “Oh what a fight we have, Dear;—nothing for us but to cleave to one another, and fight side by side!” (TC to JWC, 2 June). But in this rather melodramatic aside, we have a revealing confirmation of the mutually dependent nature of their relationship. The need for TC and JWC to cleave to each other in the face of debilitating ill health (on her side), and the wearisome demands made upon a public intellectual (on his side), made the letters they exchanged vital tools for their mutual survival. With friends, and even with family, some level of polite distance needed to be retained, but between themselves the license offered by their long intimacy gave its own enduring therapy. If the benefits of this therapy are sometimes difficult to trace in the day-to-day exchanges of letters that took place when the couple was apart, they can be witnessed at those moments when the vagaries of the postal system prevented the arrival of an anticipated letter. One senses here both disappointment and anxiety on
the part of the thwarted recipient, and in these qualities we can apprehend their profound mutual need for reassurance and support.

If the lives of the Carlyles had conformed to the plotting of a conventional Victorian novel, JWC’s arrival in Scotland during mid-June would have restored her health rapidly, and likewise, TC’s return to his homeland after completing the Frederick volumes would have produced a similarly swift restorative effect. But JWC’s last visit to Scotland before her death brought little in the way of immediate restoration of her bodily strength. Her quest for health-giving sleep while staying with old friends in Thornhill (Mary Russell in Holmhill and Mrs. Ewart in Nithbank) proved in the main as elusive as it had been when she stayed with the Macmillans in Tooting during the earlier part of June; only a week into her Scottish sojourn, and despairing of the repose she sought, JWC wrote to Lady Ashburton, telling her that she longed “for home” and that she “would just rush back [to Chelsea] if it were not for the mad look of the thing!” (JWC to Lady ALLA, 25 June). JWC’s mood was further depressed during her stay in Scotland when Dr. Russell gloomily and incorrectly predicted that her “right hand [had] gone to the dogs for good” (JWC to TC, [25 July]). TC’s return to his native land following the conclusion of his work on Frederick was similarly unproductive, at least initially, in terms of rejuvenating his mind and body; in a letter written to Lady Stanley in July, he lamented: “I have lain here for these 6 weeks, the mutest, laziest & most stagnant of all the sons of men. Never in my life so tired before” (TC to Lady SLST, 16 July). But the return of JWC to London, late July, and TC’s own return a month later brought about a marked improvement in their wellbeing. JWC’s own improvement was apparently the result of a remarkable act of will on her part, as a letter written on her return to Cheyne Row testified; writing to Lady Stanley following Dr. Russell’s pessimistic prognosis about her hand, JWC recalled her imagined reply to that doctor: “I will have back my hand, say what you may,” and then, as she continued to Lady Stanley, “the Spirit of Contradiction, which seemed to rush over me to the finger ends, acted like a shock of electricity on the lamed hand, bracing it up to do or attempt things that had seemed impossible” (JWC to Lady SLST, [29 July]). Only a few days later JWC was able to write to TC of the “relief of this comparative ease after five months of constant wearing pain and helplessness” (JWC to TC, 2 Aug.). The improvement in JWC’s sleep during this period appeared key to the restoration of her bodily strength, and her claim, while staying in Folkestone in mid-August, that she had slept better there than she had for the previous three years, underpinned her subsequent comment to Jessie Hiddleston that she was now beginning to sleep “actually like a human-Being” (JWC to JH, [19 Aug.]). While this somewhat miraculous restoration of health was prone to periodic relapses into familiar weakness and listlessness during the
early autumn of 1865, the general trend in JWC’s health over this period was towards improvement.

Some of TC’s friends commented on what they felt his post-Frederick mood should be; Thomas Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton, 4 September, that although TC looked well physically, “I think the almost entire want of intelligent notice of his great work now completed must make him feel depressed. When a man has brought the full force of a colossal spirit to bear on one subject, and overcoming incredible difficulties, at last without a word of encouragement brings his labours to a conclusion, he wants something besides the consciousness of having done his duty; a few words to show that his toilsome struggle has at least been recognised would surely be not too much to expect” (see TC to JAC, 29 Aug.). But, while TC was generally pessimistic about his own health and mood while staying in Scotland, following his return to Chelsea he appeared to re-evaluate the effects of his return to his homeland. Writing to his brother John in mid-September, TC noted material improvements in his own health in an uncharacteristically optimistic register: “I am getting back my sleep agn. … My feet have not been so easy in their shoes for 10 years back; my power of walking too is considerable” (TC to JAC, 14 Sept.). In addition, in the same letter, TC confirmed his own sense of his wife’s physical and mental restoration: “Jane is doing well, too; drives abt unwearily (abt twice a week I go with her); and really seems to be better than we have seen her for a long time past” (TC to JAC, 14 Sept.). The generally optimistic mood of TC and JWC in the letters written during the latter stages of this volume appear some distance from the ill-humor that had prompted TC in early August to lament gloomily while writing to his brother Alexander in Canada: “The truth is, I am much worn out; also very old; and ought now to know well that the end cannot and even shd not be far off” (TC to AC, 6 Aug.).

With the lifting of TC’s spirits came the first signs that he might be ready to return to work. His acceptance of the offer of the rectorship of the University of Edinburgh (made November 1865, early in the period covered by vol. 43) may have been due to the improvement to his spirits following his Scottish sojourn. Indeed, TC’s self-imposed removal from the public sphere during much of 1865 can be registered in the relative lack of political argument in the letters in this volume. Those readers anticipating TC’s pronouncements here on public events—and in particular on the American Civil War, which was then entering its final phase—will be disappointed. One of his rare pronouncements on the war, in a letter written to his brother John A. Carlyle, registered his world-weary mien in the wake of Lincoln’s assassination: “(poor old Lincoln, and [thus in MS] innocent simple man, of considerable faculty & sense, the very best man I have heard of in these American murderings & massacrings for no cause!)” (TC to JAC, 1 May). What broader political commentary we do gain here indicates the ossification of his existing attitudes
rather than the emergence of fresh perspectives; in a peppery letter written to Joseph Neuberg in July, TC railed against “the old detested element, of Penny Newsprs, Philanthropy, Italian Organs, and [the] railway miracle agn,” before castigating John Stuart Mill: “A most clear, ingenuous, logically limpid soul; and of such a depth as to believe in the Suffrage of Niggers and persons that can do a sum in the Rule of Three!” (TC to JN, 8 July). Elsewhere we gain only an occasional glimpse of TC engaging with the good and the great of the day; a letter to Emerson written from Annan in mid-June reflected gloomily upon his own life and prospects before offering his old friend a more positive salutation: “I have entirely lost count & reckoning of yr enormous element, and its do affairs & procedures, for some time past; & can only wish (whh no man more heartily does) that all may issue in as blessed a way as you hope” (TC to RWE, 14 June). Elsewhere, TC admitted in a letter to his brother John in mid-September that while recent company he had kept included old friends John Ruskin, John Forster, and James Froude, there “seldom comes any one whom I cd prefer to my Racine & the fresh air!” (TC to JAC, 14 Sept.).

While TC might confess (as he did to his sister Jean Aitken in late September) that “all my Work seems done” (TC to JCA, 27 Sept.), there are glimpses in these letters of the celebrity status he continued to enjoy in Victorian society. The majority of these glimpses are offered in JWC’s wry reflections on TC’s fame and its consequences; witness, for example, the effect of TC’s presence on “ever so many young drapers” who, Mrs. Ewart’s housemaid tells her, had “run frae Thornhill to the station to get a bare look o’ Mr. Carlyle!” (JWC to TC, [11 July]). Four days later, writing again to TC after his visit to Nithbank, JWC commented, “You were immensely admired yesterday! Poor little Christie declared it ‘the proudest day of his Life’!” and Mrs. Ewart (with whom JWC was staying) proclaimed, “its made the Creturs rale happy! If Mr Carlyle isn’t the waur for’t it was worth while to gie them the chance!” (JWC to TC, [15 July]). Although this “local hero” status might be anticipated in TC’s native Scotland, JWC’s discovery of her own image in a London photographer’s shop window prompted a characteristically witty reflection to TC on her public place in his shadow: “it proves the interest or curiosity you excite—for being neither a ‘distinguished Authoress,’ nor a ‘celebrated murderess,’ nor an actress nor a ‘Skittles’ [courtesan], the four classes of women promoted to the shop windows it can only be as Mrs Carlyle that they offer me for sale” (JWC to TC, 30 July). These small acknowledgments of TC’s enduring fame are important in helping to remind us that he still attracted a level of interest that few other public figures of the day could expect. We can recognize, in these illustrations of his enduringly high regard among the public, the potential platform that still awaited TC if he chose to step out of the shadows and return to the limelight.

But while TC’s own hero status evidently remained strong into the late
1860s, it is JWC who emerges as the heroic figure in this volume of letters. Although she clearly wrote the majority of her letters in this volume while under immense physical strain, her capacity to convey real warmth and affection in her correspondence—and her ability to inspire affection in others—remained largely intact. One remarkable illustration of this can be witnessed in a letter that she wrote to Isabella Barnes Simmonds after hearing that Isabella’s young daughter had died. While JWC was then at a very low physical ebb herself, she still managed to muster a formulation of words (written with her left hand) capable of offering genuine and touching sympathy to a friend on her bereavement: “Oh try to bear up for your Husband’s sake and for the sake of the Baby unborn who is soon to come and comfort you for the little Sister taken away” (JWC to IS [IEB], 10 July). The qualities of kindness and empathy, evident in this short but moving letter, remain a feature of JWC’s letters. Evident also is the keen sense of humor with which her letters (and particularly those written on her return from Scotland) are peppered. A single choice exhibit might suffice to convey the endurance of her comic touch in this, her last summer; in a letter written to TC in early August (which incidentally provides further eloquent commentary on TC’s undiminished celebrity status), JWC reflected upon her taking the ink spots out of his writing table: “Had It been going straight to any Literary Museum, I shouldn’t have meddled with the ink , which Hero-worshipers might have regarded with a certain adoration; but for your own use, I thought you would like it better clean!” (JWC to TC, [9 Aug.]). Also evident in this volume, in which TC and JWC are physically apart for an extended period of time, is TC’s acknowledgment of the debt he owed to his wife’s selfless management of his welfare. The strength and importance of their partnership was something of which TC appeared increasingly aware during their geographical separation and JWC’s failing health. The manner in which TC opened his first August letter to JWC—who had just reported to him a brief respite in her sleeplessness—conveyed the extent to which his own spirit was lifted at the thoughts of her improving health: “Yr Letter of this morng is charming; a thing really to thank Heaven for! Oh may it continue; and our poor little ‘arm’ only soon get well!” The ending of this letter (“Oh Darling, what is this patch of paper, with iron pen & hand shaky, in face of all I had to say to thee!” [TC to JWC, 1 Aug.]), with its naked affection and pathetic tenderness, seems to take us back to the beginnings of their relationship forty years before. Those of us reading this letter can, with hindsight, see it as looking forward to the despair TC would feel in April 1866 when JWC’s death drew the curtain down on the last act of their lives together.
Jonathan Wild

div1.p: May–September 1865

May. TC writes to his brother John A. Carlyle of his sadness at hearing of the assassination of Abraham Lincoln (1). He discusses investments with John and the best way to send £20 to his sister Jenny Hanning in Canada (2). JWC tells Mary Russell, “there has been such a Sitting to Photographers as never was heard of! Woolner wants a variety of Photographs to work from; and the Photographers want a variety to sell !” (4). JWC is considering her own holiday plans once TC finalizes his trip to Scotland (4). The Carlyles dine at Dean Stanley’s (5). TC writes to his brother James Carlyle that he has arranged for Noggs to travel by train to Scotland (8) and tells his brother John that he is reading David Laing on John Knox (11). TC apologizes to John Ruskin for his over-emphatic condemnation of Holman Hunt’s The Light of the World (13). JWC writes Margaret Hiddleston’s daughter Jessie to sympathize on her mother’s death and to ask if she would like to come to Chelsea as maid (15), but then has second thoughts ([19]); she finally invites her to come as her servant in July ([24]). TC takes the train from London to Dumfries to visit his sister Jean Aitken (22). JWC stays at home, tries remedies for her painful right arm, has a plumber in to repair leaks, prepares for decorators, and is visited by several people including Charles Gavan Duffy (30). TC pays a visit by train to Thornhill to see the Russells (30). JWC’s painful arm begins to make writing difficult.

June. TC moves to The Gill, home of his sister Mary Austin (1); “my prospects are better here” TC tells JWC (2). JWC goes for advice to Dr. Quain about her painful arm and hand; he recommends that she go to Scotland. She visits the Macmillans in Tooting, leaving painting and the fitting of bookcases to be done in her absence (2). TC writes to Lady Ashburton about the Woolner bust of him that she has commissioned: “the features seemed accurately there; but the whole was a little stony and terrible.” TC writes to encourage JWC to come to Scotland and to stay with the Russells in Thornhill (5). He rides Noggs, relaxes, and enjoys the quiet (5), though eating porridge at night gives him indigestion (6). JWC’s sleep improves with the help of whisky toddy; she has Geraldine Jewsbury and Mrs. Macmillan write letters to TC on her behalf, such is the pain in her writing hand (6), but is able to add postscripts or sign the letters with her left hand (8). JWC’s horse and carriage have an accident, apparently without her ([12]). TC feels very gloomy, telling JWC that “the
world has become, in many parts, hideous to me” (13); he admits to Emerson that since finishing Frederick he is a “totally worn-out man” (14). JWC, back in London, stays with the Blunts in Chelsea Rectory while painters are busy in Cheyne Row, and then travels overnight (16–17) by train to Carlisle, then to Thornhill to stay with the Russells. TC, overjoyed, visits her (22) and begs her to stay longer, but JWC tells Lady Ashburton that the trip has done nothing so far to alleviate her pain (25). TC visits Scotsbrig to see his brother Jamie and family (26). JWC writes to her housekeeper, Mrs. Warren, in Chelsea, asking her to keep an eye on the carpenter, and to use the Carlyles’ absence to mend the sheets (29).

July. JWC, too weak to visit The Gill, takes the train to Dumfries and spends three hours with TC at his sister Jean’s (1). She moves to Nithbank to stay with Mrs. Ewart (3), still complaining of pain in her right arm and sleeplessness, and TC visits her there (6). TC’s sister Jean visits him at The Gill. TC writes Thomas Spedding asking about a possible visit to Mirehouse (8); he writes to Neuberg with answers to his enquiries about various books and offers Neuberg Noggs, his horse, as a gift (8). JWC is taking various medicines to no avail; she considers a holiday in Folkestone with Caroline Davenport Bromley while TC considers going to the Western Isles. JWC writes Isabella Simmonds to console her on the death of her child (10). TC visits JWC in Nithbank for dinner (14). JWC writes Ruskin to thank him for a book (15), gives up her scheme of visiting Betty Braid in Edinburgh en route back to London (15), and returns to Holmhill for a further week (16). TC and his brother John are still considering a trip to the Hebrides via the Orkneys and to visit Sir George Sinclair in Thurso (15). JWC writes to Lady Ashburton, “dearest, kindest of Friends,” saying how sorry she is not to see her before she goes abroad (18). TC goes to Mirehouse (17–20), back to Ecclefechan by rail, to Scotsbrig (20–22), and then to The Gill. JWC leaves Scotland (24); she is invited to stay a few days with the Stanleys at Alderley on her way home, but decides to travel directly to London with the new servant, Jessie Hiddleston, meeting TC briefly at Dumfries station en route. The trip to the Hebrides is abandoned (26) to TC’s relief; he goes instead to Edinburgh. In London JWC visits Caroline Davenport Bromley (25), and manages to see Lady Ashburton who had postponed her trip (26 and 27), and visits the Macmillans at Tooting (30). TC declines Henry Inglis’s invitation to his home near Melrose, but hopes to see him in Edinburgh (30).

August. TC is resting at Scotsbrig, visiting locally; JWC is in Chelsea in improving health, driving out daily, TC advises three hours (1), visiting a sick Forster (1 and 3) and sorting onto the new shelves TC’s numerous books that have been brought down from the attic study (7). TC visits a neglected Craigenputtoch with his brother James (5). He writes to his brother Alexander:
“I am much worn out; also very old” (6). TC and his brother John go to Edinburgh (8). JWC goes to Folkestone to visit Miss Bromley (14). TC visits Edinburgh acquaintances and goes sea-bathing in Portobello; he visits Betty Braid and JWC’s Morningside aunts (12), then goes to Stow to see Henry Inglis after all (14). He then goes to Linlathen to visit Erskine (16–19), to Keir to the Stirling Maxwells (19–22), back to Edinburgh, to Lord and Lady Lothian at Newbattle, Dalkeith, for the day (23), then back to Scotsbrig and The Gill; he returns to Chelsea (28), though JWC (who was enjoying her Folkestone trip) wishes he would stay away longer; she also returns to Chelsea (28) in order to arrive before TC.

September. TC and JWC visit the Ruskins (1). TC sleeps badly, but walks better; he still feels exhausted and nervous after finishing Frederick (10). In the hot weather JWC tells Lady Lothian, “[w]e lie about on sofas: languid, stupid, sick—physically and morally” (10). TC writes to his brother John, enclosing photographs he has just received from their brother Alexander Carlyle in Canada, and comments on how welcome must be John’s gift of £100 to help Alexander’s son Tom through difficult times. TC has many visitors, even “tho’ the Town is said to be ‘empty altogether’” (14).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 1 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: We hope to have the great satisfaction of seeing you tomorrow (Tuesday) Eevening, Thus in MS. —if only you won’t forget! Don’t please!—

The poor Wife, just abt taking wing, requests me to say, what she had herself forgotten till this morning,—that on Tuesday Evg till half past 9 o’clock we are from home; but that at ½ past 9 we will (with her own punctuality) be here, and in expectatn of yr gracious advent. Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 May. MS: NLS 517.90. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
George Cook’s weekly visit did not, yesterday when it was wanted, take place: so I cd learn nothing abt the 5 per cent Indian Bonds mentioned by you. See 41:220TC to JAC, 26 April; John A. Carlyle’s letter untraced. George Cooke was a stockbroker. But I have little or no doubt the notion you had of them was correct, and that they are guaranteed by Govt; so I shall invest there if all prove as I expect on inquiring. At any rate, I give up the Scotch stock Unidentified further. you speak of, and will not trouble you farther on that matter. If these wild disasters and seldom parallelled horrors (poor old Lincoln, Abraham Lincoln was shot by John Wilkes Booth, 14 April; Lincoln d. the following morning. Photographs of Lincoln and Booth were placed adjacently in vol. 4 of the Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, with TC writing underneath “Abrm Lincoln and his Assassin”; see 2TC to JAC, 1 May. and Thus in MS. innocent simple man, of considerable faculty & sense, the very best man I have heard of in these American murderings & massacrings for no cause!) John Reuben Thompson (1823–73; see 41:23741:biographical notes), in Britain since 1864 to promote the cause of the Confederacy, wrote in his diary, 26 April: “About two o’clock the editor of The Standard [Captain Humber] came in, bringing the startling news of Lincoln’s assassination on the night of the fourteenth in the theatre at Washington by J. Wilkes Booth. Was greatly shocked and distressed to hear it, because I do not think a shameful murder can advance any good cause, and I fear the mind of Europe will be easily persuaded that Booth was prompted to commit the horrible crime by Confederates. I was especially pained to learn that he profaned the motto of Virginia ‘Sic Semper Tyrannes [sic],’ by shouting it from the stage just before making his escape. When I returned to the West End I found the whole mighty metropolis in a state of the most intense excitement at the news. I have never before witnessed such a sensation in London” (quot: Gerald M. Garmon, John Reuben Thompson [Boston, 1979] 123). —if these and Andrew Johnson, the
Emeritus Tailor given to liquor, Andrew Johnson (1808–75), U.S. vice president, succeeded Lincoln as president. The Washington correspondent for the Times described Johnson’s behavior at Lincoln’s 2d inauguration, 4 March: “Mr. Johnson was once a journeyman tailor, and rose by industry and the possession of something like political genius to his present high position. … It is not … because he was once a journeyman tailor that every witness of the exhibition which Mr. Johnson made of himself on the day that ought to have been the proudest of his life feels humiliated at the idea that such a person should have arisen from the dregs of society, to disgrace not alone the dignity of his official position, but even the honest working classes from whom he sprang. His behaviour was that of an illiterate, vulgar, and drunken rowdy, and, could it have been displayed before any other legislative assembly in the world, would have led to his arrest by the serjeant-at-arms, if not to his ignominious expulsion by the deliberate vote of his insulted colleagues” (Times, 20 March). wd yield me back my poor American peculium [savings], There was widespread concern in Britain about the U.S. economy and the stability of its currency. in real coin, I wd invest that too in guarantee of British Govt, & so end my adventures in finance!—
Abraham Lincoln
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia

I infer from yr saying nothing that the gum is now right; they are vile troublesome things these, and yearly for years past I have had to do with
them in the catarrhal season. Last friday I got a swelled cheek (since Thursday night, you never saw worse weather, properly a dirty fit of liver issuing in cold,)—but I took severe measures & it is almost gone.—— Duffy Charles Gavan Duffy; for a photograph of him taken about 1865, see 41:222JWC to CGD, 26 April. is here from Australia; & is to dine tomorrow night—heigho! “Abt 10th May” still! Ever yours /
T.C.

ps.p: Letter &c of this morning: thanks

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 May. MS: NLS 526.27. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Ge Cook, by appointt, has been here this morning; and tells me that (fundamentally) none of the Indian things (not even the 107s) are guaranteed by the imperial Govt, but only the Indian,—whh in the long run may turn out to be a widely difft matter! The British govt. took over direct rule of India from the East India Company 1858; presumably the govt.-issued bonds to which Cooke referred were being issued by individual provinces or territories in India without the guarantee of the imperial govt. They aretherefore out of the game. Ge tells me there are quite safe “Preference shares” (or whatever the names are) whh yield 4½ per cent; and he is to leave me, this night, a Note of them,—whh I will ask yr advice upon before deciding anything. Query, Could or could not the “Brighton Debentures” & the “N. Staffordshire Prefce” (£1,000 each), whh yield only 4 per-cent, be changed into something of 4½?—

Another favour I have to ask; viz: That you will get me prepared for poor little Jenny in Canada a Paper (as once before) Their sister Janet Hanning; TC previously sent her £10 by this method May 1863; see 39:126TC to JCH, 13 Aug. 1863. whh on presentatn at the Hamilton Bank will yield her £20 (twenty pounds). I will at once pay you by a ? Word repeated at turn of page. Draught on Dumfries or on Pall Mall, whichr you like? TC recorded: “5 May 1865 / to Dr J. A. Carlyle (for Jenny at Hamilton) / £20 .. o .. o” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Or perhaps the really easiest way is for myself to go to Pall Mall, & thence to Ransom’s? Ransom, Bouverie & Co., bankers, Pall Mall; see 39:122TC to JAC, 7 May 1863. If so, bid me freely. I am but too dreadfully lazy; and shoving things upon other people only encourages the vice!—

I hope I am a little better today. There has come a change of weather, as if into Heaven out of the Other Place for all living creatures. Beautiful showers last night; and a brisk west wind blowing now, under skies not too blue, but beautifully dappled. I still hold out for “May 10 or thereabouts.” Woolner I
owe only one sitting Thomas Woolner was sculpting a bust of TC, commissioned by Lady Ashburton (see 41:203TC to JAC, 6 April). The last sitting was on 12 May; see TC to JCA, 12 May. My miserable dinners &c I shall get out of better or worse: Then pack pack! Adieu dear Brother. Rather in haste T.C.

The German yesterday was merely as pipe-match, if you hadn’t before heard of Schlüter. Possibly Andreas Schlüter (1664–1714), German baroque sculptor and architect; see Carlyle, Works 12:294; otherwise unidentified. First Article in Sy Rw The first article in the most recent Saturday Review, 29 April, concerned the assassination of Abraham Lincoln; in the previous issue, 22 April, which John A. Carlyle sent to TC (see 41:219TC to JAC, 26 April), it covered the fall of Richmond and the probable end of the war. is not by Venables; George Stovin Venables. by whom other I know not

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [2 May]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:368–69, dated 1859; Hansons, NE 525–26. Dated May 1865 by general content and JWC’s cheerful tone; Lady Ashburton was expected to call this week; see TC to Lady A, 1 May.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Come at last! Oh dearest of created Ladies, “past present and to come”! Cf. Eccles. 3:15; see 9:54JWC to SS, [11 Sept. 1836], and 17:194JWC to HW, [1 Dec. 1843]. I wonder if you have any adequate conception how your coming has been watched and waited for, by the person now addressing you, and that persons better half? From day to day, since this day week, expectation and disappointment alternating! Every day the one or the other of us has ridden or driven up to Bath House, to examine the windows and the gate; sometimes even to cross-question Hannah, Hannah Hall (b. ca. 1836), maid at Bath House. who had never more positive information to give, than that you “might arrive any day”—“Everyday”—till yesterday; just the day when ones perquisition would have had happy results! for yesterday I had to stay at Home to nurse “a chill”—and Mr C was made too late out, by an inburst of Mrs Cameron and Mr Watts (the Artist), Julia Margaret Cameron, b. Pattle (1815–79; ODNB), photographer; George Frederic Watts (1817–1904; ODNB), painter and sculptor. the former hardly to be restrained from forcing her way into Mr C’s bedroom while he was changing his trousers!!— I told her as Baillie told me; when I was pursuing Mr Heath “to the Back” with your message; “It is a dangerous affair, rather, that you are there entering on, Mam!” James Bailey (b. ca. 1809), butler at The Grange; possibly Oct. 1862 when Vernon Heath (1819/20—95; ODNB) was photographing there; see 38:248–49JWC to EFO, 30 Oct. 1862. So when your note arrived this morning it was
news that it told!— Oh my Darling! my Darling! how I love you! how glad I am—nay it is but just towards him to say—how glad we are—at the prospect of having you here tomorrow night! TC expected Lady Ashburton late Tues., 2 May; see TC to Lady ALLA, 1 May. Will you really come? Bless you for even intending it! But at all events you will arrange for my seeing you, one way or another, with the least possible delay? And Mr C is really impatient to see you, also. If you heard how eloquently he was talking of your “exquisite kindness and loveableness, and beautiful transparency of soul,” on the way home that evening, and on several occasions since, you would know whether he has the “eyes to see, and heart to understand” Cf. Deut. 29:4. which a certain young Lady Possibly Miss Dempster (see 41:196TC to JAC, 27 March), who was staying at Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, Lady Ashburton’s Devonshire house (see 41:184JWC to MR, 10 March), when the Carlyles were there in March; otherwise unidentified. would have persuaded you he had not!

Oh my Darling! my Darling! who that comes near to you, and is cared for by you can help loving you with a whole heartful of love! I am almost frightened at myself when I feel how dear, how indispensable you are become to me! I had fancied myself too calmed down with years and—other things, ever to have bother with my heart any more! Yes! I was henceforth to take just such tepid pleasures of friendship as The Gods provided me; leaving aside all strong feelings that can tend to pain and anxiety. If you were to tire of me now—! and if you were to die before me—! if you were anyhow taken away out of my Life—! why; I should fall into as great trouble as I ever was in when young and excitable about a “lost love”—
Meanwhile I shall see you tomorrow evening?
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 3 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Jamie,—Last night I had entrusted the groom with a memorandum about “Noggs,” Noggs, TC’s horse, given to him by Lady Ashburton; see 39:129–30TC to LLA, 17 May 1863. and the railway statn at Euston Square: I did not press him to time, rather the reverse; but will today mend my order; in a few days hence I expect to have all the particulars. Formerly “6 a.m.” was the only Horse-box train; the charge £5 to Carlisle,—what followed after that, I have forgotten, or did not learn.— The despatch of Noggs is evidently the first step of my own deliverance! The sooner I can get him off, I shall be the gladder, & shall follow soon.— There is a conveyance by Newcastle too (Steamboat, charge
perhaps £1 .. 10); The Tyne Steam Shipping Co. advertised steamers from Irongate Steam Wharf to Newcastle-upon-Tyne every Wed. and Sat., 6 p.m. ; “miles” repeated at turn of page. off you; and to send a man for him (if even a fit man cd be found) wd cost another 30/ perhaps;—so that we need not much or at all entertain that project. One way or another Noggs shall come shortly; and myself (I trust) close on the rear of him!— We have got beautiful weather now; after a week of the very worst. No more today. Your affecte Brother—
T. Carlyle

ps.p: ——P.S.! This was designed to have gone among the Tea; but, on going down, I find the “the Tea” what we may call “made”! Possibly TC had hoped to put the letter into the package of tea being sent to James Carlyle. TC reversed the sheet and wrote “Mr Carlyle / Scotsbrig” in the space to the right of the postscript. —

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCH [JCHA], 4 May. Pbd: Copeland 232–33.
div3.head: TC TO JANET CARLYLE HANNING

docBody.p:
D ear J enn
y ,—Two or three days ago, I saw a letter from you to Sister Jean; Jean Carlyle Aitken. which was very welcome here, as bringing more definite news of you than we had got for a good while before. I have now got done with my Book (a copy of it probably in your hands before this); The final vols. of Frederick, 5 and 6, were pbd. mid-March, with copies sent out late March and April; see 41:199TC to JF, 29 March, and 203–4TC to JAC, 6 April. and am not henceforth to be so dreadfully hampered in writing a little note to my friends from time to time. I am still in a huge fuss, confusions of all kinds lying about me, and indeed I am just about running off for Scotland (to Jean’s, in the first place), to try and recover a little from the completely shattered state these twelve years of incessant drudgery and slaving have reduced me to. But there is something I had meant, this long time and here it is—just come to hand. Inclosed is a Paper which will bring you the amount of Dollars for £20, on your presenting it at the Hamilton Bank. See TC to JAC, 2 May. If by way of “identifying,” they ask you who sends the money, you can answer with my name, and if further needful, add that the Negotiator for me with the Edinr. Bank, was Dr. Carlyle of that City. Nothing more, I suppose, if even that much will be necessary. Let me know by return that it is safe in your hand (a newspaper with three strokes will serve if you are short of time for the moment). And so with my best blessings, dear little Jenny, accept this poor mark of my remembrance.

My Jane is very frail and feeble, but always stirring about, and has got blessedly away out of the horrible torments she had (and all of you had on her account) last year. Scotsbrig, Gill, Dumfries, Edinburgh; Where TC and Janet Hanning’s siblings lived; James Carlyle lived at Scotsbrig, near Ecclefechan; Mary Carlyle Aitken at The Gill, near Annan; Jean Carlyle Aitken at The Hill, Dumfries; and, John A. Carlyle in Edinburgh. all is going in the usual average way there. To you I can fancy what a distress the removal of your poor little Mary and her Husband to the Far West Mary, Jenny’s second da., and her husband, Charles Coates Holden, were apparently moving to Iowa in the U.S midwest. must be! These things happen and are inevitable in the current of life. That your son-in-law is a good man, this should be a great joy to you. Do not you be too hasty to follow to Iowa; consider it well first.
You see what a shaky hand I have; you do not see the bitter hurry I am still in! With kindest wishes to you and all your household,
docBody.name: T. C arlyle .

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 4 May. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 5 May 1865. MS: NLS 609.708. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:250–54 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:572; Bliss, JWC 322; Surtees, Ludovisi 264; Ashton 438.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Darling. When I camein today and saw a letter from you on the table; I felt myself make as near an approximation to a blush as my sallow complexion is capable of! It was a little “coal of fire” heaped on my head! Cf. Prov. 25:22. For days back, I had been thinking how neglectful I must seem to you, making no answer to that kindest of letters and of invitations,—written too when you were ailing, and “looking at the Dark of Things”! JWC’s variant of the phrase “the dark [or “bright”] side of things.” You had still managed to look at the Bright of me; since you could believe that my presence would “cheer you”—instead of boring you! But it was not that I was really not caring to write. Nor yet, that I was giving way to physical languor (tho that has been considerable) It was, that for the last week or two, I have been kept in a whirl of Things, that made it out of the question for me to sit down quietly and make up my mind what to say. Lady Ashburton has been in Town again; and the Miss Dempster, who staid with us at Seaton, is in London for a short time; and I have had, for Lady A’s sake, to devote myself to her a good deal. And Duffy (the Irish
Patriot) is home from Australia and had to be asked to dinner. And old Sir George Sinclair Sir George Sinclair was visiting his son, John George Tollemache Sinclair, who lived in Upper Norwood, SE London; see 40:63TC to JWC, 11 April [1864]. had to be asked to a three o’clock dinner! And Mrs George Welsh Margaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George. came for “a long day.” And once I had to go out to dinner! Me!—the first time for two years and a half! And I am going out to dinner again tomorrow at the Dean of Westminsters, Arthur Penrhyn Stanley who lived at Dean’s Yard, Westminster. and all this with a running accompaniment of Sculpture and Photography! Mr C has been sitting to Woolner for his Bust— And it seems he “is as difficult to catch a likeness of, as a flash of lightening” is, so that it is a trying business for both Sitter and Sculptor. and I am afraid the Bust will never be worth the hundred guineas Lady A will pay for it! Meanwhile I have had to drive up to Woolner’s every two or three days and climb steep endless stairs; to tell what faults I see! and in connection with this Bust, there has been such a Sitting to Photographers as never was heard of! Woolner wants a variety of Photographs to work from; and the Photographers want a variety to sell ! and Mr Carlyle yields to their mutual entreaties. And then, when they have had their will of him, they insist on doing me; For John Watkins’s photographs, taken in April, see 41:213–16JWC to JOWA, 21 April; Elliott & Fry also took photographs of both Carlyles; see TC to JWC, 29 May. (for my name’s sake) And Mr C insists too; thinking always the new one may be more successful than former ones! So that with one thing and another—I have been worried from morning till night—and postponed writing till I should have got leisure to think what was to be written.

But I must not put off any longer since you are getting uneasy about me. I am not worse—indeed as to the sickness and the sleeplessness, I am rather better in both respects. But I am weak and languid, have little appetite and am getting thinner The best thing for me would be to get away—and away to you, rather than anywhere else! I know that well enough in both my heart and my head! But—one cannot do just what one likes best, and even what is best for one! I could not go with Mr C for several reasons. First having made up his mind to go off “at his own sweet will” Coterie speech; cf. Wordsworth, “Composed upon Westminster Bridge” line 12. —and having understood that I was to stay behind; he would now find it a great incumbrance to take me with him. 2d I have invited Dr Blakiston and Bessey, to pay me a visit so soon as I have a Bedroom for them; and they have promised to come for a few days. “They never came” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:252). Dr. Peyton and Bessy Blakiston with whom JWC stayed at St. Leonards, March to April 1864; see vol. 40. About the end of May is the Dr’s leisurest time at St Leonards. 3d Mr C wants the Dining Room papered and fitted up with Bookcases, from the Study at
the top of the House, which is too long a climb for him now that Frederick is done, That he expects me to “see to” in this absence. And how long it will take me to “see to it” will depend on the workmen!

For the rest; I am uncertain how long he will be away. If “months” (as he speaks of), there might still be time for me, after I had finished my business here, to rush off to Holm Hill, and stay as many weeks with you, as I staid months last year! I would so like it!

And Mr C wouldnt object, tho he would find it very absurd to be taking such a long journey so soon again. I put out a feeler the other night. Miss Dempster was pressing him to visit her when he should be in Forfarshire (he is going to Linlathen To visit Thomas Erskine. amongst other places) and I said, “I shall perhaps be nearer you than he will be! Lady Airlie was pressing me so hard today to come to Cortachy Castle, The Dempster family home was at Dunnichen in Forfarshire, about 9 mi. (14.5 km.) N of Linlathen (in Monifieth parish); Cortachy Castle is about 8 mi. (13 km.) NW of Dunnichen. that there is no saying but I will follow him North. “Indeed!” he said, not with a frown but a smile. And I added—“If he stays away long I may at least get the length of Dumfriesshire.”

I havent the remotest idea of going to Lady Airlie. I like her very well but living with her would fatigue me too much! She is for ever on the strain to be somebody else than herself! Only I thought if I accustomed him to the possibility of my going all the way to Cortachy He wouldnt think so much of my going to Thornhill. Holmhill was in Thornhill, Dumfriesshire. But till I get my workmen out of the House, and know something definitive of Mr Cs plans, I can determine nothing. Will you let me leave it open? I like so ill to say positively and absolutely “No, I cannot come this year!”— Because you see, having a charachter for standing by my word to keep up; I could not, after an absolute ‘No,’ said now, avail myself of any facilities for going to you which may turn up later. So may I leave the question open?

Oh I am grieved to the heart for that poor Margaret Hiddlestone! What a state to be reduced to, when the best wish one can have for her is that she were fairly dead and out of her misery! Margaret Hiddleston d. 4 May; the Dumfries and Galloway Courier reported, 16 May: “At 62 West Morton Street, Thornhill, on 4th inst., Margaret, relict of Mr. William Hiddlestone, tailor, aged 65 years.” And when the Queen herself could do nothing for her—give her nothing to make Life as desirable as death.

Whata fearful trial it must be for the poor Daughter; Either Margaret McCaig, the da. with whom Margaret Hiddleston lived (see 40:177JWC to TC, [10 August 1864]), or her other da., Jessie, who apparently gave up her job in Edinburgh and also helped care for her. since she has a
heart in her after all. Did you see the article in the Times, apropos of Constance Kent about young women at a certain age being all as good as devil possessed! Constance Kent (1844–1944) had just confessed to the murder of her half-brother, Francis Saville Kent (b. 1856), 29 June 1860, at Road Hill House, Wiltshire. “From twelve or fourteen to eighteen or twenty is that period of life in which the tide of natural affection runs the lowest, leaving the body and the intellect unfettered and unweakened in the work of development, and leaving the heart itself open for the strong passions and overwhelming preferences that will then seize it. Youth, it must be confessed, does not feel much; and, sad to say, it is the softer sex especially which is said to go through a period of almost utter heartlessness” (Times, 27 April). I believe there is some truth in it!

Will Jessy return to her Place in Edinr after she is no more needed by her poor Mother? Jessie was possibly employed at 8 York Place where her future husband, Robert Broadfoot, was butler. If she have no settled arrangement in her head, I wonder if she would care to come to me? and if she would suit me supposing she did? I remember thinking her very good looking, and very noisy and headlong! but I have heard you say she became a good Servant and I should like a scotch Servant so much and one known about provided she were otherwise qualified. (It is clear you will never give me little Mary!) Mary Russell’s servant Mary of whom JWC was very fond; see JWC to MR, [10 Oct.]. I wish you would take the matter into consideration—if Jessey be at liberty—and sound her about it. Most girls like the idea of coming to London, but she would need to be warned that it would be very dull for her unless she have someone she knows here, and a faculty of adapting herself to her circumstance.

I shall not keep Fanny, in any case. I didn’t like her at the beginning, Fanny came to Cheyne Row as the maid Nov. 1864. and since I had her with me at Seaton my dislike has grown to positive repugnance. Ever since that time of guzzeling and doing nothing she has been full of discontents; “Lady Ashburton’s Servants had hot butchers meat three times a day”; she is always complaining to Mrs Warren! Eliza Warren, cook and housekeeper since Nov. 1864. and “fried kidneys to breakfast and all sorts of things”! Mrs Warren thinks Butcher’s meat once a day “is much as is good for one, if there be plenty.” And so they have constant disputes, ending with Fanny declaring that she will give Mrs Carlyle warning. She doesnt mean to “leave”—only to be disagreeable and try how much consequence she is of! But I mean to not keep her. She is not so very good a servant as to make up for being so very nasty a woman! Mrs Warren continues a great success. I see no falling off in her since the first week—when my fear was that she was too charming to last!

How absurd! in telling you on the other sheet how I was—bodily— I quite forgot to mention my most serious ailment for the last six weeks. My right arm
has gone the way that my left arm went two years ago. JWC had suffered with a painful left arm during the summer and autumn of 1863; see 39:186JWC to MR, 16 Sept. 1863. gives me considerable pain—so that I cannot lie upon it, or make any effort (such as ringing a bell, opening a window &c &c) with it and if any one shakes my hand heartily I—shriek! Geraldine Jewsbury JWC’s old friend Geraldine Jewsbury; after an estrangement, their friendship was reestablished during 1863 (see 40:95TC to JWC, 9 May 1864), and she visited 5 Cheyne Row frequently. is always asking; “Have you written to Dr Russell Mary Russell’s husband, Dr. James Russell, admired by the Carlyles for his common-sense diagnoses. yet about your arm?” But what could anyone do before for the other arm? All that was tried was useless, except—Quinine, and quinine destroys my sleep— I must just hope it will mend of itself as the other did.
Mercy, what a letter for length! Love to the Dr / your ever attached friend
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 May. MS: NLS 517.91. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Thanks for yr kind punctuality. I despatched the £20 Paper to Jenny yesterday in the way prescribed; I had not time to send yr Draught of repayment, but here it is today. See TC to JAC, 2 May. Nothing can exceed the idleness, nor the miserable incessancy, of the botheratns (photographings, callers, dinnerings &c) in whh my days pass at present. The weather is delicious; balmy, windy, sunshine-&-cloud:—I shd evidently be much better in the solitude of the country,—any country! Accordingly I mean to go speedily; Noggs, I think, will whirl off for Scotsbrig abt Tuesday next; Nogg’s rider, a free man after that, will not be long behind him, I shd think! Truly I am very low; the internal machinery very considerably deranged by these 12 years of pulling,—digestion, especially, fallen very dull indeed. That first night of the violent outburst of of Thus in MS. east wind as of Greenland (with Sun as of Jamaica), I caught inflamed gums, swoln cheek (whh I never had before): cheek is now gone; but there remains ever since a wretched low-feverish cold, felt all thro the bones &c: this too is gradually abating under care;—and now, only think, I have an 8 o’clock dinner (Jane & I; “Dean Stanley & Lady” Dean Stanley’s wife, Lady Augusta Stanley. &c the hosts, not to be refused); 8 o’clock, this evg, at whh I have not the faintest prospect of any enjoyt at all,
and whh I wd give five guineas to be out of on no worse terms than I get in! I will take my utmost care. Happily it is the last, or nearly the very last, of those things at prest.

I followed yr advice about the investts: gave the whole charge of that affair this morning to G. Cooke,—who has two or 3 things whh he reckons perfectly safe, & whh yield 4½ or 4¾ per cent:—Preference shares, or I know not what; he is an expert man in his trade, and nobody can be better affected to me.— Are yr Books at Dumfries now? I am busy studying what little store of “reading” I cd bring with me? What resource may be possibly awaiting there. At prest I am out to ride, slowly for 2 hours odd; then sleep &c: ah me! Adieu /
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 7 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh my Darling! It is not fair to speak in that way of going, and staying abroad indefinitely because you are not needed and cared for here! In fact it is “a tempting of Providence” to say such things! You cannot but know in your heart, that not one woman of a thousand has as much love laid at her feet as you have! or is as important to her fellow-creatures as you are! Go by all means, and even stay away ever so long; if your health and Spirits are to be the better for it; but at least gave one the comfort of thinking that you will miss one a little; and that you will be perfectly sure of our missing you a great deal!
You will tell us when it is all fixed? I cannot give up the hope that you may be here again before starting. Lady Ashburton went to Wiesbaden, SW Germany, late July; see 41:209–10JWC to MR, 14 April.

Mr C is also in the agonies of making up his mind, and “gathering himself together” for the flight to Scotland! For Mr C; every journey is a Flight—from present evils and difficulties to evils and difficulties as certain, tho’ in the future tense. I shall be glad now when he is fairly on the road.

The Dinner at the Deanery was a great success. And I wasn’t the least bit worse for it; on the contrary I slept sounder after, than I had done for a month!! Whence I infer that my nerves have burnt themselves up! There were twenty at dinner, most of them clever agreeable people, and some hundreds, I think, came at night. So many, many, I hadn’t seen for years came and congratulated me lovingly on being alive! and I sat there, knowing (not feeling) that I was dressed like nobody else (with a black gown up to the throat and down to the wrists) and received all these sympathetic addresses, with no
more excitement than if I had been made of Indian Rubber! What a blessing!— Lady Augusta Lady Augusta Stanley. was perfectlycharming! only too charming! for it is impossible to believe in such graciousness!

I have got the Photograph mounted, and send it by this post. I think it the best likeness of Mr C that has ever been or ever will be! Probably the photograph TC described to John Watkins: “the big Head, Profile (or nearly so) with Hat. … [T]he truest likeness ever taken of me hitherto” (see above and 41:215TC to JOWA, 21 April); see 13. The more’s the pity that the negative got cracked! when only five copies had been taken from it!
Thomas Carlyle in his wideawake hat, by John Watkins, April 1865
National Portrait Gallery, London

I was reading over Lady Trevelyan’s Lady Paulina Trevelyan, wife of Sir Walter Trevelyan. letter to day—and it is amazing that I have never answered it! Will you give Henrietta Muffs Lady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence Baring’s pet name for JWC. fondest regards to her dear little Mother. Yours for ever
Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 8 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: The Horse “Noggs” will be with you on Wednesday Morning. He is to leave London tomorrow evg at 9: he courses on, all night; is at Carlisle (if he prosper) by 6½6 a.m.;—thence at Ecclefechan (I “suppose”) betn 8 and 9. It has hitherto been impossible for me to ascertain at what hour precisely: I bot a Bradshaw, Bradshaw’s Monthly General Railway and Steam Navigation Guide. & have had it tried by two people, in vain; a third (Chorley), John Rutter Chorley. still skilfuller, now has it, and his ansr, whh will reach me before this goes, shall be reported to you, if it have anything of definite. Possibly the Ecclefechan station-master John Gordon (b. ca. 1820). cd tell you this much: “Does the morning mail-train stop at Ecclefn;—and is there time at Carlisle to fasten a horse-box to it?” I shd think, yes. There is no doubt, I believe, but Noggs & his Box will be shoved on punctually to Ecclefn by the very first convenience there is at Carlisle after 6 a.m.; but that is all I can yet say. Inclosed is what the Clerk said at Euston Square here, on the Groom’s going up to ask him; nothing farther is hitherto ascertainable. Some time in the morning of Wedny (8–9 o’clock most likely), the astonished Noggs will turn up;—considerably exhausted, I shd think, for at the lowest, he will have had 14 or 13 hours of solitude witht meat or drink; and no doubt, will be very glad of a cann of water, and a lock of honest corn. But he is a very healthy fellow; and I hope will take no harm.

There will be an Address upon him, to you at Scotsbrig, written on one of my cards (I meant to enclose you a card of the same, had Carlisle been the place;—but of course at Ecclefechan, there can be no mistake): Noggs will have a saddlecloth (little white cloth under the saddle for keeping saddle fixed), also an old saddle (whh get mended for me, it is well known to you!), do bridle; and he will carry anybody quietly enough,—tho’ better sometimes for the looking to. He has an excellt appetite for victual, especially for grass: his fore-feet at prest are shod with leather under each shoe; but that is totally superfluous hence; any smith is equal to shoeing him, & his hoofs &c are perfectly good.—— Please write me a word, one word to say that the Creature is come safe to hand; & that I have done with this burble for once. At this moment my third Bradshaw man sends ansr (not quite indubitable to me); & I inclose it.— Good be with you all, & a happy arrival to Noggs!— Yrs ever /
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-PB, 11 May. Pbd: W. F. Prideaux, “Sir Charles Hanbury Williams, Sir Woodbine Parish, and Thomas Carlyle,” Notes and Queries 11th ser. 3 (4 March 1911): 163. TC’s note was written on a blank page of Sir Woodbine Parish to Peyton Blakiston, April, and sent back to Blakiston.
div3.head: TC TO PEYTON BLAKISTON

docBody.p: I have not taken any copy: Sir Woodbine Parish (1796–1882; ODNB ), diplomat, wrote to Blakiston, April: “I have long intended sending you this Volume, wh contains an unpublished despatch of Sir Chas. Hanbury Williams to the Secy of State the Duke of Newcastle in 1752, giving a very interesting account of the Court of Vienna at that time, thinking it would be of interest to your friend Carlyle; but I fear now it will arrive too late to be of any use to him, seeing that he has completed his great Work, but you may send it to him, and he is quite at liberty to take a copy of it, if he wishes for it.” Parish’s vol. was “made up of extracts from the third volume of ‘The Works of Sir Charles Hanbury Williams,’ 1822 (pp. 61–109, 208–40, and i—lxxxi), together with a MS. account of the Court of Vienna contained in a letter from Sir Charles Hanbury Williams to the Duke of Newcastle” (Notes and Queries 163). Sir Charles Hanbury Williams (1708–59; ODNB ), writer and diplomat; Thomas Pelham-Holles (1693–1768; ODNB ); duke of Newcastle, politician. but feel greatly obliged to Sir Woodbine Parish for his goodness.

It is pity the letter were not dated; the real year of it must be 1753 (not ’2); Hanbury Williams was sent to Vienna in Feb. 1753. and to German readers the chief novelty in it is Hanbury’s complete mistake as to the real purposes notions and position of Kaunitz Wenzel Anton, Prince von Kaunitz-Rietberg (1711–94), Austrian diplomat; see Carlyle, Works 16:232–33. in regard to the matters handled between them. Sharp political spectacles on Hanbury’s part, on Kaunitz’s a perfect cloak of darkness! Presumably Hanbury was unaware that while he was working to strengthen the alliance between Britain and Austria, in the face of the increasing power of Prussia, Kaunitz was working, ultimately successfully, to forge an alliance between Austria and France; see Carlyle, Works 16:381–85 and 17:13–27.
T.C. (Chelsea, 11 May [1865]).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 May. MS: NLS 517.92. Hitherto unpbd. Written on the reverse of TC’s letter from James Carlyle Jr.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,— Excuse this extremely shabby bit of Letter: but I am, as usual, in the hurry of whirling Nothings,—sharp for time; & I wish you to send this on for Dumfries station, whh will be in want of news as well as yrself. The two Photographs are for Jean,—send them especially:—the Scotsbrig document will testify the advent of Noggs in those parts, James Carlyle Jr. wrote, 10 May: “‘Noggs’ arrived safely at the Station at Ecclefechan a few minutes past 9 o’clock this morning; very hungry and very much frightened and very glad to be taken away out of reach of trains. He cannot yet go out to graze as the weather is much too cold for him, but as soon as possible we will cut some grass for him and in the meantime he has plenty of fresh oats and excellent hay. He is a favorite here already. I have had the saddle repaired so that the whole affair of the horse is now finished and you can give undivided attention to your own journey to Scotland.” & be a sign that I am myself making some attempt to lift anchor. Alas, alas, with what difficulty, weak apprehension, scunnering at railways, and one knows not what! I feel totally beaten down (that is, in imaginatn, for I don’t think my health is much worse than it used to be), and usually see no path that is inviting, or that has not lions watching on it. A waeful man!—

The Stanley Dinner went off witht fatality: a very grand affair (Lady Augusta evidtly an adventurous stirring character); Duke of Argyll, Lords Airly, Houghton, George Douglas Campbell (1823–1900; ODNB ; see 38:43TC to JWC, 29 Jan. 1862), 8th duke of Argyll, Lord Airlie, and Lord Houghton. and a cohue [crowd, mob] of all the world & his wife to succeed: we got home before 12;—and I had a go of egg-tea and toasted-bacon (having really eaten hardly an ounce picked thro the French rubbish going), whh succeeded unexpectedly well. Tonight we have to dine agn with Forster in honr of Duffy: John Forster and Gavan Duffy. —but that will be a simple matter in comparison, and that will (surely!) be the last.— I can do nothing at “gathering Books”; my own poor wits are all gone wool-gathering; and I am incapable of anything but lying idle. Whh indeed perhaps is best for me.

Our weather is rainy these two days, large floods of soft rain; everything beauty itself when the sun gets out. I have been reading in Laing’s Knox, since
Froude ended: The Works of John Knox, collected and edited by David Laing, 6 vols. (Edinburgh, 1846–64); J. A. Froude, History of England from the fall of Wolsey to the death of Elizabeth, 12 vols. (1856–70), TC presumably meant the most recently pbd. vols. 7 and 8; see 41:197TC to JRT, 27 March. thank Laing agn from me; his faithful solid accurate ways are worthy of all honour. John A. Carlyle copied out this final paragraph and sent it to David Laing, 12 May (MS: EUL).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TLC, 11 May. Addr: Morley’s Hôtel / Trafalgar Square. MS: Kathy Chamberlain. Hitherto unpbd. Theodore Ledyard Cuyler (1822–1909), American writer; pastor of Lafayette Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, 1860–90, and one of the founders of the National Temperance Society, 1865. Cuyler noted in Recollections of a Long Life (1902) that TC was one of several lions that he pursued on his first visit to London in 1842 (23); he called at Cheyne Row, Oct. 1842, and described TC’s conversation in some detail (24–25). Cuyler’s 1865 visit to London (not mentioned in his Recollections) took place shortly after he witnessed the restoration of the national flag at Fort Sumter (14 April) and then returned to New York City for the laying-in-state of Abraham Lincoln at City Hall (150).
div3.head: THOMAS CARLYLE TO THEODORE LEDYARD CUYLER

docBody.p: Here is my “Autograph”; I wish it cd do you the least shadow of good!——
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.p: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 12 May. MS: NLS 517.93. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—The Horse “Noggs” is safe at Scotsbrig since Wedny morning! That is a sign his rider is soon to follow if he luck. You will receive from John, probably by this same post, a couple of Photographs; both of whh I consider to be good and one quite excellt: along with them is some frail sketch of my indolences, dispiritments, and incipient purposes so far as these point to immediate practice. I mean, if it will at all do, to be with you next week! But the roaring tumult of the passage makes me really shudder. I have sometimes thot of going to Edinr & by sea: but, on closer inspection, that also is horrible,—more horrible. On the whole, I must and will lift anchor presently. I have been struggling to devise now some set of Books for gathering here to employ my
void hours while with you: but I am absolutely incapable of any vigorous resolution on such a matter at present; and the end, I suppose, is, I shall take my chance of Jack’s Books, See TC to JAC, 5 May. and come witht any of my own! Oh dear!— There is only one thing I must try to see done before leaving: that is “the investing” of some money, whh the Broker John George Cooke. is halfway in, and ought to end before I quit sight of him. Early next week I mean to write agn; if possible, with the day set. You will find me a very untowardly article I fear; far more worn down & wrecked into final uselessness by my 12 years of toil & torment than you have any idea of!—
Photograph of Thomas Woolner’s bust of Thomas Carlyle, 1865
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: Thomas Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton, 13 May: “I took my last sitting of Carlyle yesterday and now have only to finish it up, merely 2 or 3 days work. I am profoundly thankful to have got over my task at last, for the difficulty has been so great that it has made me feel quite ill and depressed from the constant strain upon my thoughts; but I suppose it would not have been to do so great a man adequately without something like this severe expenditure. I can only say that rather than do such work as this all my life I would be a policeman or gamekeeper or lead any life that enabled me to breathe open air. / But I am happy to say that the bust gives enthusiastic delight to most persons who have seen it, and now it is quite a different thing to what it appeared when you saw it some time back; in fact no one ought ever to see my busts done from life till finished for they are so totally different during the process from the actual finished results. Carlyle himself said yesterday that it looked ‘a most impressive thing’ and he did not think it could be better. He was never sanguine as it proceeded, so that his testimony comes more welcome at the end. I think it one of the best things I have ever done, and it is certainly the most strange and mighty looking. I have now to hope that it may have the good fortune to please your ladyship and I shall care for no other opinion to a very serious extent” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). For a photograph of the bust, see opp.above.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RO, 12 May. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD OWEN

docBody.p:
You will not write me that unrivaled Fact-Poem on Natural History;—no; and yet you cd do it as no other can: TC previously suggested Owen write such a book in 1862; see 38:211–12TC to RO, 15 Sept. 1862. and many generatns wd be the better
for it! Well, well;—& yet I think it a very great pity; and so perhaps may you, one day, when it is too late.
I am off for Scotland, in a week, being quite reduced to caput mortuum [dead head] by that hideous Book I have just got out of. May I find you busy as ever when I return. Yrs ever truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 13 May. MS: NLS 23167. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: My Horse is gone; grazes in Annandale since Wedny last; unless you will come out within a week, Ct. Ezek. 26:7. Ruskin replied, [ca. 14 May]: “[O]f course I’ll come; but could not Mrs Carlyle and you come here— You see, if I ask you to dinner my mother will make a state-matter of it—and fatigue herself with thinking of all dishes on and out of the earth— If you will come earlier, & stay dinner by surprise good; but I think the best way would be to drive over here about ½ past six—to tea, & for chat in evening . … Then I’ll come for another goodbye chat—at Chelsea.” shall have joined partnership with him there; and shall not see you for a long time. Try what you can do!

I like Aglaia John Ruskin’s “The Cestus of Aglaia” was being pbd. in monthly chapters in the Art Journal; see 41:175TC to JRU, 22 Feb.. as well as ever; my only sorrow being that I have only spoonfuls of it, instead of large draughts endless in quantity fit for a thirsty soul!

I have, on bended knees, to crave pardon of you for two things: 1° for my mad emphasis to you on that Light of the world William Holman Hunt’s painting The Light of the World (1853). the other night. Me to you on such a subject, it was greatly absurd & wrong;—and alas, 2° I yesterday saw agn, and for the first time in good light, the Picture itself; and had to say (emphasis apart, & as a sin by itself), “In many points, peccavi [I have sinned], and the mild Ruskin was intrinsically right!” Ruskin replied: “It breaks my heart to get such a letter from you—yet it is quite like you—very monumental of you— Only how could you think I did not understand your emphasis—I know how you feel things—and that what you were feeling was right, though you had not had time to see other things in the picture.” Beautiful painting (such a jewelling of that cloak, such a light from the lantern &c), the “crown” not intrinsically of thorns but extrinsically only; According to Hunt, TC’s first reaction to the painting had been highly negative; he later recalled TC speaking about it at great length, denouncing it as “a poor misshaped presentation of the noblest, the brotherliest, and the most heroic-minded Being that ever walked God’s earth” and criticizing the figure of Jesus for being “bedizened in priestly robes and a crown, and with yon jewels on his breast, and a gilt aureole round His head” (Holman Hunt, Pre-Raphaelitism and the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood [1905] 1:355). & the Xt [Christ] by no means such a ghastly
abortion as I had thot! Hunt later claimed to have used TC “furtively” as one of the many models for Christ’s head in the painting (Anne Clark Amor, William Holman Hunt: The True Pre-Raphaelite [1989] 255). For TC’s more favorable reaction to Hunt’s The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple in 1860, see 36:99–100TC to LS, 19 April 1860. Forgive, forgive;—& let me see you agn, and go with yr blessing.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-GHL, 13 May. Addr: (Fortnightly Review) / Msrs Chapman & Hall / 193 Piccadilly. PM: London, 13 May 1865. MS: Julian Browning Autographs, envelope only. Hitherto unpbd. The letter was presumably about William Maccall; see TC to WM, 17 May. George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB ), writer; known to the Carlyles since 1835; editor of the Fortnightly Review 1865–66; partner of Marian Evans (George Eliot [1819–80; ODNB ]).
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE HENRY LEWES

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JH [JHI], 15 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: R. Blunt, “Mrs. Carlyle and her Housemaid,” Cornhill Magazine n.s. 11 (Oct. 1901): 457–58; R. Blunt, In Cheyne Walk and Thereabout (1914) 288–91.
div3.head: JWC TO JESSIE HIDDLESTON

docBody.p: I have just received from Mrs Russell the news of your poor Mother’s death. See JWC to Mary Russell, 4 May. I am not surprised; She (your Mother) looked so mortally ill, when I saw her last August; and the accounts of her from time to time since had left no hope of ultimate recovery or release from pain in this life.

Good, industrious, brave-hearted Margaret! Her Children may well mourn the loss of such a Mother! But even her Children could not wish her life prolonged when it had become for herself a constant and terrible torture.

And you have the consolation, your Sister Margaret McCaig. and You of knowing you were kind to your Mother whilst she was with you; and that you did all you could to sooth the dear Life which it was not god’s will to save!

Mrs Russell tells me you will return to service, now your sad duty is paid. and that you would come to London, to me, if we can come to an agreement. That is difficult at this distance. Face to face we could get to understand each other in a few minutes; but we may write questions and answers thro’ the Post
till we are both tired; and, when all is written, there will still be much to take on trust, on both sides, and you will have but a vague idea of the ‘Situation,’ and I as vague an idea of your fitness for it.
But I will do my best to be explicit.

First, let me tell you why I have turned my thoughts on you for a Housemaid, in preference to any one here who I could transact with face to face. It is because you are Margaret Hiddlestone’s Daughter. She was known in my family for a capital Servant and a well conducted woman; and I have great faith in breed, and as great faith in upbringing. Nor does my connection with you date only as far back as your Mother and Uncle. Presumably a brother of Margaret Hiddleston; not further identified. Your Grandfather, Presumably Margaret Hiddleston’s father-in-law, with whom she and the girls lived in Thornhill for some time; see 17:84TC to JWC, 26 Aug. 1843; not further identified. when a Servant to my Grandfather, JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh. was very good to me when I stayed at Castlehill, Castlehill, in Durisdeer parish, about 6 mi. (9.5 km.) N of Thornhill, where Walter Welsh farmed at one time; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 125. a child of eight years old. No wonder I recollect him perfectly; for it was he who first set me on the back of a pony and taught me to ride! There seems thus, an old fashioned, hereditary connection between you and myself that ought (at least) to make you a kinder Servant to me, and me a kinder Mistress to you, than any servant and mistress chosen from among strangers was likely to be.

For the rest; I remember you at Mrs Russell’s—a bonnie young woman, who dashed about with great activity; but who made a noise with the fire irons, and skuttle, and doors, that kept me constantly jumping I dare say you have learned quietness and much else since then!

What my Housemaid has to do, is just I suppose what other Housemaids have to do, where there are only two Servants kept. She has to do the House work, to answer the door, to wait at table, to be the least bit of Lady’s Maid to me, and the least bit of valet to Mr Carlyle. As the house is of moderate size, and as we have no dinner-parties—and as both Mr C and myself are orderly; the work is certainly not heavy for any one who understands her business. The Washing is all given out; only the Servants wash their own clothes—there is a little garden to dry them in. I give my Housemaid twelve pounds a year and one pound ten for beer money which she may drink or save—as she likes. tea and sugar of course is given.
I do not know what wages you had in Edinr or what number of Servants you were along with. But I should not like you to come to me, if you could do better for yourself.

Neither should I like you to come, if you cannot make yourself happy
among Strangers, and at the same time have nobody of your own to visit in London. For I dislike a gloomy discontented looking servant quite as much as an inefficient one.
There!— Till I have your answer to what I have already written, I think this is enough!
It will be time enough to specify the when and how, when I know your mind to be in favour of coming. Take time to consider well.
Give my remembrance to your Sister / Yours truly
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [15 May]. MS: NLS 609.713. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I wrote to Jessie by this day’s post; and “splained and spounded” Cf. John Ross Dix, Pulpit Portraits, or Pen-pictures of Distinguished American Divines (Boston, 1854) 219. to the best of my ability. It is very difficult to satisfy oneself in writing to an uneducated person.
