The need of using only the commonest and clearest expressions, that one may be understood, oppresses one like having to write in a foreign language that one has not quite learnt. I would rather write to the cleverest best informed person of my acquaintance than compose a letter to a child or a servant maid! It is to be hoped however that Jessie will be able to extract from my letter a tolerable idea of the work I require from my Housemaid, and the wages I am in the habit of giving. I took pains to throw no rose-colour over the ‘Situation,’ that might lead to future disappointment. If she come, and is disappointed, the fault will be her own—not mine.

I should like to have asked some questions, had there been a likelihood of getting candid answers to them. Whether she had given up making unnecessary noises? whether she had left off the practice of smashing china What sort of temper she has? Whether she is impertinent when found fault with? (for that is a style of breeding I never tolerate)— Whether she is what is called willing? Does the Doctor Dr. James Russell. think she would do ?

For the rest it would surely be a pleasant thing to have a Scotchwoman for Housemaid and a Scotchwoman whose family’s name has been familiar to me since I was a Child at Castle Hill! And between whose forebears and mine there has been so much connection! if only she is a good Servant as well! I mean to inclose a Photograph for you to look at, and return. It is—Mrs Warren
my “Cook and Housekeeper”!!! For the photograph of Eliza Warren, see opp.above. It was placed in vol. 4 of JWC’s photograph albums. She is pleasanter looking in real life, and quite as like a gentlewoman. Her mouth in the Photograph is unnaturally primmed over those teeth which—she has lost!
Eliza Warren, [1865]
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

It is very extraordinary that Mr Carlyle will hang on here always declaring himself “going in a few days,” when that is what he has been saying for the last six weeks! I am kept in a perpetual meditation of Flight (his flight) and get no good of the present—everything having to be postponed till he is gone. Did the Doctor receive the lovely Gorillas Presumably Richard Owen’s Memoir on the Gorilla; see TC to RO, 12 May. I sent him?
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle
docBody.note: JWC’s last sentence and signature were written at the top of the first page. The end section of JWC to Mary Russell, 24 Feb. 1853 (see 28:52–53JWC to MR, 24 Feb. [1853]), was attached in error after the last paragraph of this letter: “and I am ready to start immediately’! Much money and no work, and a superabbundance of activity make as trying a situation I do think as a humanbeing can be placed in— / Tell me when you write if Mary Milligan continues in the Madhouse—I did not think any thing I could ever hear of that woman would make me sorry for her—but I am sorry for her now— Where is young Kirkpatrick? wont he and his Wife buy their fortune at the French Court? Kindest regards to your Husband and father ever affectionately yours / Jane W Carlyle.” Mary Milligan (1811–64) had been a servant of JWC’s mother; see 39:187JWC to MR, 16 Sept. 1863. Possibly Charles Sharpe Kirkpatrick (1811–67), 6th bart., of Closeburn, Dumfriesshire, m., 1837, Helen Stuart, b. Kirk (1815–77); the empress of France, Eugénie de Montijo (1826–1920), who m., 1853, Napoleon III (1808–73), emperor, was the grand-da. of William Kirkpatrick (1764–1837), wine merchant and U.S. consul in Malaga. Mary Russell’s father was Edward Dobbie (1773–1857).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 May. MS: NLS 526.28. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am thinking to be off abt Saturday or Monday next: I will of course write to Jean fixing day and hour; but cannot just yet, had I even more heart than I have. A little more of heart might easily be conceivable; and wd indeed be very useful at this time!

George Cooke has been almost a fortnight “investing” my things; and cannot yet tell me whh day he will have done. I signed two of his Papers this morning; but there is a third remaining, whh he “hopes will be finished in the course of Friday”: if it hang much farther, I will leave it to follow me. I am not much in love with Cooke’s investts: three separate railways;—in that written Note (whh please keep till after next Letter from me) you will see what kinds & quantities. Not having you to help me, I was obliged to let Cooke schalten
& walten [do as he liked]; and tho’ I dare say it is all quite right & well, yet in my dreary mood, the thot of it is quite uncomfortable, you cd not think how unwelcome to me!—

I have given up the notion of bringing Books; I will mainly take chance with what I find. Don’t send Knox: The Works of John Knox, ed. David Laing; see TC to JAC, 11 May. I have got the whole 6 volumes here; and have read of the 6th all that I at prest can face. By the bye, a Giannone Pietro Giannone, Dell’istoria civile del regno di Napoli (Naples, 1723). in 5 green voll 8vo (all clean & right) has actually turned up; and is standing in the shelf here,—your Book evidtly, whh neither Jim Aitken nor I cd lay hands on, last year. James Aitken, Jean Carlyle Aitken’s son, while he was still living in London. — Do you know Dahlman’s Histy of Denmark (one of the Hamburg Series, still on foot I believe)? F. C. Dahlmann’s Geschichte von Dännemark (Hamburg, 1840–1843) was pbd. in the “Hamburg series,” Allgemeine Staatengeschichte: Geschichte der europäischen Staaten [General Histories of European Countries]. I find things in it of a precise sort abt old Iceland, do Norway &c, whh I have a mind to study later. To one that reads Icelandic I think he wd be very interesting. Dahlmn I once saw (at Bonn) & have read some other Books of: Friedrich Christoph Dahlmann (1785–1860) was probably one of the professors TC met in Bonn, Sept. 1852; see 27:277TC to JAC, 9 Sept. 1852. TC had read Dahlmann’s Geschichte der Englischen Revolution (Leipzig, 1844); see 18:223TC to CKJB, 27 Sept. 1844. a precise modestly accurate man.— I will not bother farther abt Books. Wd I had once got myself there, & some kind of clothes to put on! You must tell me agn what train (I have mislaid the other Notice, tho’ it still exists). To Dumfries abt 7 p.m. was it not? Not much above 9 hours? That really is little; tho’ to the sick fancy, it is horrible!— You will come down to see me, John A. Carlyle was in Edinburgh. won’t you, soon after. If I had a place in Edinr really possible to sleep in, it wd be a mighty resource. I fancy in the course of the summer we might have a sail together &c &c. Old Sinclair is here, passionate for us both at Thurso: Sir George Sinclair’s home was Thurso Castle, Caithness. an innocent-hearted good old man; but a dreadfully wearisome!— Adieu, dear Brother: I hope to hear soon,—and even to see soon. Yrs ever
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WFP, 17 May. MS: NLS 7197. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM FREDERICK POLLOCK

docBody.p:
Dear Pollock,—I think Woolner spoke to you some time ago abt Mr Maccall; whom I will now more directly address to you. William Maccall; see TC to WM, 17 May. He has had a good deal of experience
in Newspaper Criticism, as well as in far higher matters. It strikes me he might possibly be useful in some of the operatns in the Reader, William Frederick Pollock (son of Sir J. F. Pollock) was literary ed. of the Reader, a weekly literary magazine, Dec. 1864 to March 1865. William Maccall wrote, 8 Sept.: “Mr Pollock had ceased to be Editor of the Reader, when your letter reached him. But he wrote to me with supreme politeness and cordiality,—and at the same forwarded your letter to Mr Rae,—the present Editor. From Mr Rae I have received altogether four books for review in the course of almost as many months:—and I have no reason to suppose that he is dissatisfied with my articles.” William Fraser Rae (1835–1905; ODNB ), b. Edinburgh; a qualified but nonpracticing lawyer, journalist, and later an author. —tho’ that is a Paper I have never seen hitherto. It wd give me pleasure if you examined the matter; especially if you ascertained in the affirmative! He is a man of real talents, of multifarious studies and endeavours; a man of sterling veracity withal, who will undertaken nothing for you that he will not honestly do.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.p: To Fredk Pollock Esq &c &c

ps.p: Reader-Newspaper Office
By W. Maccall Esq

div3.sourceNote: TC-WM, 17 May. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM MACCALL

docBody.p: Mr Craik’s speculation has proved useless, so far as I can judge. George Lillie Craik; see 41:174JWC to GLC, 22 Feb.. I wrote to Lewes on the matter, last week; See TC to GHL, 13 May. his answer, whh comes today, and is here inclosed, does not seem of promising nature. I make him no answer at all; you, if you like to try, have the power, but I think you hardly will. Froude is a much more promising party; TC had spoken to James Anthony Froude about Maccall in Feb.; see 41:175JWC to GLC, 22 Feb.. who really respects yr qualities, & will be desirous to find in you something suitable for him.

Mr Pollock (eldest son of the Ld Chief Baron, and a man of really worthy & kindly character and open mind), is, it appears, Editor of The Reader, since some months:* TC added a note in the margin: “*‘Woolner’ is a famous Sculptor, of his [Pollock’s] and my acquaintance”; TC hoped that Woolner had spoken to Pollock about Maccall; see TC to WFP, 17 May. I know not whether it may be worth yr while to get into communication with him; but I incline to think it may: at all events, if you care to seek an interview with him, and explain frankly what you cd and cd not do for him in that field, here is a Note that will introduce you. For TC’s introductory note, see TC to WFP, 17 May. I do not remember
any other likely person in that Departt of Affairs; with whh indeed I have next to no acquaintance for many years back.

I am greatly tired out; and hope to be off to Scotland and silence far away in a few days. With the truest wishes, if these were good for anything, I am ever, Yrs sincerely,
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 18 May. MS: NLS 517.94. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Sister,—I design to be with you on monday next: monday morning at 10 (Euston Square), that is the train I have in view; arriving at Dumfries abt 7 p.m;—let us hope all will go well!

You will receive from John, or perhaps you have already recd before this comes to hand, some preliminary details about me (of date yesterday); the next stage of matters is as above. I mean to write again before setting out.

You see how mypoor hand shakes; that has been growing on me for two years past. A wretched blockhead is visiting down stairs waiting for me, on business not of mine, but of his; Possibly Maccall, or unidentified further. —I need not continue. But this word, I thot, wd be welcome to you. Yrs ever /
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 18 May. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 18 May 1865. MS: NLS 553.280. Hitherto unpbd. TC’s letter was written on the reverse of a letter to him from Sydney Williams, of Williams & Norgate, 17 May.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—Wd you look a little into this matter of Dr Parthey, and ascertain how he has not yet got his Books, Williams wrote: “Dr Parthey the proprietor of Nicolai’s Library, writes us that for the purposes of your Frederick you have, belonging to him some books of which I give a list. … He desires us, as he presumes you have now no further use for them, to take charge of and forward them to him.— Will you have the goodness to send them to us, if convenient some time before the end of the month.” Gustav Parthey (1798–1872), philologist and art historian, grandson of Christoph Friedrich Nicolai (1733–1811), author and bookseller. TC had been offered the loan of books from Nicolai’s library in 1853; see 28:87TC to JN, 23 March 1853. The books listed were Rudolph W. von Kaltenborn, Briefe eines alten preussischen Officiers, 2 vols. (Hohenzollern, 1790); Charles-Etienne Jordan, Histoire d’un Voyage Littéraire (La Haye, 1736); Baron Heinrich Auguste de La Motte Fouque, Mémoires du baron de La Motte Fouqué dans lesquels on a inserré sa correspondance intéressante avec Frederic II (Berlin, 1788); Namens verzeichnis deren Personen [exact title or edition untraced]; Friedrich von der Trenck, Examen politique et critique d’un ouvrage [by G. H. Riquetti, Count de Mirabeau], intitulé, “Historie secrète de la Cour de Berlin, ou correspondence d’un voyageur francois” (Berlin, 1790); and Franz Ludwig Haller and Jean François Hedelhofer, La vie de Robert-Scipion baron de Lentulus (Berne, 1788). and especially when by probability
he will get them. Let us hope this may be the last bother you get, after so many, on that class of subjects!—
I have no horse for almost a fortnight past. I go on Monday morning; pray let us see you on Sunday evg if not sooner to bid me Glück auf dem Weg [Good luck on your journey].
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea 18 May [1865]

I have another Book; whh I at first thot was Nicolai’s, for his Bookplate is on it; but it appears to be my own (Brenkenhofs Leben, 1782) August Gottlieb Meissner, Leben Franz Balthasar Schönberg von Brenkenhof (Leipzig, 1782); TC’s copy: HCC. —I think of perhaps sending it nevertheless.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EM, 19 May. MS: Dominique d’Enjoy, Limoges, France. Pbd: B. Küster, “Lettres inédites de Carlyle et de George Henry Lewes à Émile Montégut,” Revue de Littérature Comparée 49:3 (1975): 475–76. Montégut’s last recorded contact with TC was in 1858; see TC to EM, 15 Oct. 1858. Insertions in sq. br. are from the pbd. version.
div3.head: TC TO ÉMILE MONTÉGUT

docBody.p: Dear M. Montégut,—It is many long months and years since I heard directly of you; tho’ you have been often enough in my mind while I went on with my late sore & seeming interminable labour, whh cut me off from almost all communication with my living fellow creatures. That is now over, thanks to Heaven; and I wd fain hear from you that nothing very evil has befallen on your side of things in the interim, and that you still remember me as heretofore. I am going for Scotland, in search of some repose after all these hideous drudgeries & slaveries; but any Letter you send hither will immediately follow me.

I have requested Herr Tauchnitz of Leipzig, who is reprinting (and does it very well, in small handy volumes) the History of Friedrich II, so soon as he is ready with it: barring accident[s,] that Work, in ten or a dozen little volum[es,] C. B. Tauchnitz’s English edn. of Frederick was pbd. 1858–65 in 13 vols. will reach you at Paris before long,—addressed “Au Bureau de la Revue des” &c; Montégut worked at the Revue des Deux Mondes in Paris. —and I shd be happy to [hear] that it was in your hands, wheth[er] ever read Küster noted that TC probably omitted “you” (476). it or not. Meanwhile I inclose you a Photograph whh is
really like me to a degree no other I have seen is. Actually a kind of feeble but authentic sight with one’s eye at so far a distance;—why not send me the like on your part, if you have anything that so truly resembles?—

I still havea little Book of yours abt Madme du Châtelet; Lettres inédites de Madame la marquise du Châelet à M. le comte d’Argental (Paris, 1806); Montégut had sent the book to TC in 1854; TC lost the original copy; the replacement is in Carlyle House, Chelsea, with TC’s note: “T. Carlyle / Chelsea, 1856 / (Must be sent to M. Montégut (of the Revue des Deux Mondes) at Paris, to replace a Copy of his which I have lost)”; see 29:5–6TC to EM, 5 Jan. 1854. perhaps other little Books, whh shall be faithfully sent, when [you say How— Hoping to hear good] news of you before very long, Montégut replied mid-June; see TC to JWC, 29 June. I remain, always with a kindly remembrance, Yrs faithfully /
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JH [JHI], [19 May]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: R. Blunt, “Mrs. Carlyle and her Housemaid,” Cornhill Magazine, n.s. 11 (1901): 459; R. Blunt, In Cheyne Walk and Thereabout (1914) 291–92.
div3.head: JWC TO JESSIE HIDDLESTON

docBody.dateline: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea Friday [19 May 1865]
docBody.p: Your letter had been posted after the first post-hour; so it was not delivered here till the afternoon, too late for being answered by return of Post. And Sunday being a blank day at the Thornhill post-office, this will not reach you till Monday Morning. I am sorry you should be kept so many hours in uncertainty. But it cannot be helped on my part.

Having studied your letter with all the deliberation I could bring to bear on it, I am come to the conclusion that my idea of having you for housemaid was more romantic than discreet. I have no doubt whatever that you would satisfy me as a servant. The stock you come of, Mrs Russells recommendation of you, my own recollection of your looks—all assures me on that head. But I have every doubt whether you would be satisfied with the Place! And your being ever so good a servant would only make the thing more disappointing, if after I had been at the expense of bringing you to London, and had invested a great deal of hope and kind feeling in you; you should find the place “not good enough” for you, and too dull to be staid in.

And, from your account of the last service you were in, See JWC to MR, 4 May. I cannot but forsee such would be the case—the trifle of difference in the wages wouldnt signify. Tho’ I have never given more than twelve pounds hitherto; I shouldn’t mind increasing the wages, if the Servant were worth more. But it is the plainness
and quietness of a house like ours that after having been “very happy” in a houseful of Servants, where your chief work was waiting, and no friends within reach to enliven your service here;—it is that which raises a difficulty which I cannot overcome for you,—or for myself.

Do you see what I mean? and agree with me; that it would be too great a risk for you to accept a place so inferior to your last in outward respects; and too great a risk for me, to bring any one so far without a tolerable certainty of keeping her.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [20 May]. MS: NLS 517.95. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—I am half thro’ my Packing (and almost half mad with it,—being in very poor stomachic case &c); and have of essential nothing worth writing on such terms, except that I hope to be with you abt 7.20 p.m. of monday, having the intentn to start from Euston Square at 10 a.m. of that day, by the Express train. Oh that I were on the Platform there, and you welcoming me! I was never lower in strength of liver, whh means of heart and of hope in my life before!

Poor Jane is very weakly, too, for almost a fortnight past: one of her arms (from neck to elbow, opposite arm from that of last year) continually plaguing her with neuralgic pain, so that she cannot sleep &c:—oh me! She is gone to Richmond Presumably to visit her aunt Margaret Welsh. today (agt her will, tho’ it will do her good); she drives every day; her poor “brougham,” poor soul, is the staff of life to her at prest. Monday 8 p.m. I ought to be sitting perhaps at egg-tea & bacon beside you!— Wish me well /
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-SW, [21 May]. MS: W. P. Albrecht. Hitherto unpbd. The letter was written on the reverse of Neuberg’s letter to TC, 19 May.
div3.head: TC TO SYDNEY WILLIAMS

docBody.dateline: To Sy Williams Esqr (Henrietta Street) Chelsea, Sunday Night [21 May 1865]
docBody.p:
By the foregoing Letter (whh please burn when read) you will see that Mr
Chapman (as indeed becomes otherwise apparent to me) is responsible for the Nicolai Books. They shd have gone abt 2 months ago. They must have been addressed to Herrn A beken (from whom I got them, & who is a Public Man in Berlin): Neuberg wrote, 19 May: “I have been caged, all this week, by somewhat severe indisposition, which has left me very weak, and unable to move about, perhaps for some days yet. / So far as I know, you sent the Nicolai Books, months ago, thro’ your Publishers, to Mr Abeken. And if the parcel went by one of the Continental Parcel Expresses, it would reach Berlin in 2 or 3 days. As soon as I am able to stir, I will make enquiries at Chapmans. I am not aware that I could do anything else. / It is just possible that the Geheimer Legations Rath [Privy Councillor] Abeken, deeply engaged with intricate Bismarck Diplomacies, retains the Books from Dr Parthey. On that supposition, a line from you to Dr Parthey, referring him to Abeken, would be the most satisfactory step.” TC noted at the top of Neuberg’s letter: “recd, 20 May 1865 / T. Carlyle (Chelsea)”; above “months” he wrote “two”; above “your Publisher” he wrote “(Mr Fredk Chapman)”; Frederic Chapman, junior partner, Chapman & Hall. Above “Mr Abeken” he wrote “‘Herrn Abeken in Berlin’ I never knew any other Address.” Bernhard Rudolf Abeken, a Prussian foreign office official as well as a scholar, had sent TC various books and the catalog from the Nicolai library; see TC to JN, 18 May. Abeken replied, 18 June, on receipt of the parcel; see TC to JWC, 23 June. that perhaps may account for the delay? Mr Chapman (193. Piccadilly) is charged to report to you by what Conveyance he sent them. I hope you will be so obliging as insist upon an answer, shd that be needful; and on the whole relieve me by finishing at once an affair so distressing to me. In haste The last lines of the sheet, presumably with TC’s signature, are cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 [22] May. Addr: Cheyne Row Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 22 May 1865. MS: NLS 617.681. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; Mon. was 22 May.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,—I have hardly a minute left, but willnot neglect a word to satisfy yr poor heart from its anxieties abt me. I had a carriage to myself nearly all the way; every kind of advantage; and but for the sad state of the liver &c, shd have been really rather comfortable: as it is, here I am, witht accidt (Jean & Jamie waiting for me &c) at the appointed hour, and nothing wrong whatever. Never came out at all except once at Preston, Preston, town in Lancashire, about 222 mi. (357 km.) from London and 120 mi. (193 km.) from Dumfries. where the longest stoppage was,—& such a storm of thunder hail & deluges of rain as I have seldom seen. I dined on my sandwiches (well), drank all my liquid (do), & it sufficed: in short all right— Poor old Scotland! it almost made me greet when I saw
it agn; & the first sound of a Scotch guard and his broad accent was strange and affecting to me— I hope to sleep: nothing can be kinder to me than they are,—we shall see

I will report shortly. Oh that I cd hear of my poor little Jeannie being improved a little; I have had a sore heart abt her all day. I will go to Thornhill, To visit the Russells at Holmhill. or it shall be worse with me. Good night, dearest
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC,23 May. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 23 May 1865. MS: NLS 617.682. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My darling, I must put you off agn with a most brief word;—in reality there is nothing to say! I did not sleep at all last night,—till towards 6 a.m, and then after not quite half an hour, the accidental bark of a dog awoke me for good. So that it has been a dies non [worthless day]. One of the finest mornings, hottest & quietest days I have had for long. And I am better than you cd expect; have managed to get abt 3 hours of sleep in the fore part of the day (after a long walk & innocently goodish breakfast); have dined on chicken-broth: and hope to do a great deal better tonight

Oh my Dearest, I tremble for yr Note tomorrow. How are you? that is the anxiety with me! As for myself, upon inquiry & investigation, I believe I shall pretty soon get adjusted to the new fittings, and do quite well for some of the warm weeks here. The House This was TC’s first visit to the Aitkens’ newly built home, The Hill, where they had moved May 1863; see 39:128–29TC to JCA, 16 May 1863. is really good, my bedroom especially, and I seldom was in a place so quiet. The utter stillness of last night, the silence of all the day, no company but mute green fields nurseries &c, and do Hills, has been agreeable & surprising to me. Never mind me; Oh that you, poor little soul, cd get into yr sleep again, and out of that sad toothache of the arm. Alas, alas!—

Jack has great store of Books here;—what you will think more questionable, he has himself arrived from Edinr to see me; poor soul, after all! Coterie speech; see 13:55JWC to JOST, [ca. 9 March 1841]. He is not to lodge here, it seems; perhaps will soon agn. Oh may God preserve my poor little Jeannie to me, in some supportable state of health; & may I hear rather better news of her tomorrow! Amen. Your own
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JH [JHI], [24 May]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: R. Blunt, “Mrs. Carlyle and her Housemaid,” Cornhill Magazine n.s. 11 (Oct. 1901): 460; R. Blunt, In Cheyne Walk and Thereabout (1914) 293–96.
div3.head: JWC TO JESSIE HIDDLESTON

docBody.p: I like your last letter; there is both Sense and Heart in it; and it has made me less apprehensive of the “Situation” proving unsuitable to you. In every human relation entered on between two people, there is always something to be risked on both sides and something to be put up with on both sides; but as far as can be ascertained at this distance, it seems to me the risk to us two in taking one another for Mistress and Servant, is too trifling to be made a final objection; and that neither of us will find the other too trying to mortal patience!

So; let it be concluded that you are to come to me:and I will send you a shilling (in shape of postage-stamps) after the good old Scotch fashion of engagement—unknown in London—but which I have always kept up; to the surprise and sometimes to the terror of the person receiving it—who supposed it might bind her to Heaven knew what,—like the shilling given to enlist a Soldier! “A retaining fee was … [i]n principle … identical with the payment of the shilling, still given in rural districts, to domestic servants on an agreement for service, and with the transfer of the queen’s shilling given to every soldier on enlistment” (John Cordy Jeaffreson, A Book About Lawyers [1867] 101).

About the when;—I am not in any haste—so you may pay your visits and make them as long as you like. Six weeks hence will be time enough! For our dining room needs to be painted; and until two visitors, JWC expected a visit from Peyton and Bessy Blakiston, but they did not come; see JWC to MR, 4 May. I expect,have come and gone, the painting cannot be set about. And when it does get commenced I must fly my own house till the smell is gone!
It will be better that you should find me at home when you come—and also that you should find something to do!
Mr Carlyle is in Dumfries at present, and is going to travel about, “all the summer” he says. And while I am here alone, and need any housemaiding, I can keep my present Housemaid.
If I could only summon courage for the long journey, I would go down to dear Holm Hill for a week or two—and then I might fetch you back with me. But all that is very unsettled as yet—

The people here engage servants only by the month. A very bad plan I think,
giving opportunity to people to fly asunder in any moment of ill humour on either side, when, had they been bound together for six months, they would have just had to make the best of it and found their account in that in the long run— For everlasting changing is not good for the Soul of either Mistress or Maid I am sure!

Our engagement then should be for the term you have been used to—six months— I will pay your journey—in the first instance. But should you take it in your head to try for something new after the first six months, I should require you to bear half the expense of your journey yourself.
I need to make this stipulation to guard against flightiness! though I don’t know—have not the least reason in the world to believe you flighty!
I will tell you the particulars of your journey when the time comes. And when I know my own movements better
I have written in a great hurry, having an appointment at some distance, and in great pain, having got something like toothache in my arm! But I think I have not forgotten anything essential.

I will just add this if on longer reflection youfeel any hesitation about taking the place just give the shilling to some poor person and write to me you have done so. I shall not be the least displeased with you.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 24 May. MS: NLS 609.709. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:255–58. Quot: R. Blunt, In Cheyne Walk and Thereabout (1914) 293; Bliss, JWC 322–23; Fielding and Sorensen 304. TC added later to JWC’s dateline: “(very end of May 1865).”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
I wonder if you will get this letter tomorrow, should it be put in the pillar Pillar box for collecting outgoing mail. tonight? Dear! Dear! should no word reach you till Friday morning you will be “vaixed”! Coterie speech; see 15:10JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1842]. and perhaps frightened besides! the Figure I cut on Monday morning was not encouraging! When I had cried a very little at being left by myself, I lay on the sofa till midday, not sleeping, but considering what to do for the best with this arm, which had got to a pitch! and was reducing me to the state of last year in point of sleep. And the result of my considerations was, first, a note to Dr Blakiston urging him & Bessey to keep their promise of spending a couple of days with me as soon as possible; and next, in the meantime, a call at Quillers Quiller’s pharmacy, 15 Sloane Sq. to order the old Quinine pills and a bottle of Castor
oil! If I am to be kept awake all night, at any rate, by the pain; I may as well have recourse to the only prescription which did any good to the other arm; See JWC to MR, 4 May. even at the cost of sleep

That first day I also called at the Carpenters. Frederick Freure. to tell him to levez [raise] himself for he “had great things to do.” Coterie speech; see 7:192JWC to TC, [26 May 1834]. — Then on to luncheon at the Gomms. Sir William Maynard Gomm and his wife, Elizabeth. Do you remember I was engaged to luncheon there? They have a beautiful, large, oldfashioned, cool House The Gomms had several homes; JWC probably visited their manor at Rotherhithe, S bank of the Thames, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) E of Chelsea. — And the Luncheon was a Sonnet done into dainties. I brought away Lord Lothians Book on America William Schomberg Robert Kerr, 8th marquess of Lothian, The Confederate Secession (London and Edinburgh, 1864). Kerr argued: “The Southerners did not secede from caprice, but from reasons which would have justified not only a secession but a rebellion. They did not provoke the war; for all the provocation … came from the Northern Abolitionists” (8). Lady Gomm, also a Kerr, was a cousin of Lord Lothian; see 41:146JWC to MR, 13 Jan. but have not yet read a word of it! nor of any thing else! not even of Mrs Paulet’s novel Elizabeth Paulet, Dharma; or, Three Phases of Love, 3 vols. (1865); Geraldine Jewsbury, an old friend of Paulet, reviewed it in the Athenaeum, 10 June: “Mixed up with these Oriental disquisitions [on the doctrines of Buddhism], there is a love-story, which is so ardent that it might almost cause a conflagration on the book shelves of the library.” nor my own Daily Telegraph!!
on my return I came upon Geraldine in Cheyne Row—and she“could not leave me” till ten at night, I “looked such a ghost”!

On Tuesday I had to take Mrs Blunt to make calls at Fulham. And then I did the civil thing to Mrs Froude. Froude was in, and talked much of your “gentleness and tenderness—of late”—and the “much greater patience you had in speaking of every body and every thing”— And I thought to myself “if he had only heard you, a few hours after that walk with him in which you had made such a lamb-like impression He expressed a wish to read Mrs Paulets Novel. And I have sent it to him.

A very curious, clever, “excessively ridiculous, and perfectly unnecessary” Book is Mrs Paulets novel!—so far as I have read in the first volume! And Mrs Paulet herself I don’t know what to make of! For I have seen her! In my saintly Forgiveness, and beautiful Pity, I left a card for her yesterday, and she came a few hours after. JWC ceased being friendly with Elizabeth Paulet in 1849 partly after their joint visit to W. E. Forster (1818–86; ODNB ) in Rawdon (see 24:123–24JWC to JN, 15 July [1849]), and then finally after Paulet reported to JWC remarks supposedly made by Harriet Martineau to Geraldine Jewsbury (see 24:283–84JWC to JAC, [10 Nov. 1849]). and Geraldine too came, and I was not left alone till half past ten; when it was too late to write.

This morning—(I don’t know by what right) I expected a letter from you, which did not come till the afternoon— And positively I was almost well-pleased there was no letter—to answer! for I had “indulged” in a cup of castor oil—and was—oh—so sick! And besides that matter had unexpectedly taken to “culminating” again! Last night there had come from Jessie Hiddleston a very nice letter—not accepting my rejection on the score of the “Situation” being “too dull” for her. But assuring me that she would not “be the least dull and discontented”; and “altogether” Coterie speech; see 16:262JWC to TC, [11 July 1843]. throwing a quite different and rosier colour on the project. I will inclose the letter, and you will read it, and tell me if you think I was right in being moved thereby to engage her. For that is what I have done this forenoon in the middle of my sorrows of Castor-oil!

For the rest; I have no doubt you will get better and do well there,—for a time. Perhaps I shall take flight myself—if my terrible nights continue too long for endurance, and this wearing pain lasts! It is pulling me down sadly and neuralgia has such an effect on the Spirits.

One thing I have to say that I beg you will give ear to! I have not recovered yet the shock it was to me to find after six months all those weak wretched letters I wrote you from Holmhill, “dadding about” in the Diningroom!—and should you use my letters in that way again, I shall know it by instinct and not write to you at all! TC apparently responded by keeping JWC’s letters of this summer in his writing case; he wrote later: “To-day (August 9, 1866) I have discovered in drawers of pedestal these mournful letters of my darling in 1865. They had lain torn in my writing-case, till their covers were all lost, and there is now no correct dating of them. I have tried to save the sequence and be as correct as I could. Here are the cardinal dates. About May 20 I went to Dumfries, thence to the Gill; and she, here at home (courageous little soul!), began doing this room (the very beauty of which now pains and amazes me). / Beginning of May her right arm took ill, as her left had done last year, and she painfully went and came between Streatham and here for some time (perhaps near a fortnight), writing with her left hand. June 17, she passed me (little guessing of her in the rail) and went to Holm Hill; very ill then too, still left hand; and thence in July to Nithbank, and after about ten or twelve days (middle or farther of July) went home somewhat better; got her room done, recovered her right hand, and went to Folkestone to Miss Bromley’s [Caroline Davenport Bromley] for a few days (which proved her last visit, little as I then anticipated). Her beautiful figure and presence welcoming me home (end of August) will never leave my memory more.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:254–55). There!
Please return Jessie Hiddleston letter. Your ever affectionate
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 24 May. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 24 May 1865. MS: NLS 617.683. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh for God’s sake write to me! I am full of anxiety about you; and was profoundly disappointed, and at first much alarmed at the no-word of this morning. God send me good news tomorrow!

Of myself I have nothing in the least worthsaying. I seem gradually to be recovering at least my old balance; sleep &c (tho’ not witht difficulties of detail); and adjusting myself to my new element. For the rest idle; idle as a dry bone, and very dreary and dull of mood in an environment naturally dull. Today Aird Thomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB ; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833), writer, ed. of the Dumfries Herald1835–63; old friend of the Carlyles. came; grown old, hoary, idle, hypochondriacal; yet with something innocent and genial-hearted,—if dull, yet with “a good dulness”! The Tempest 1.2. I walked abt 4 miles mostly with him, to his waste hermitage Aird lived at Mountain Hall, about 2 mi. (3 km.) S of Dumfries. down the river, and back by green circuitous field-paths, very green & solitary, but under a sun too hot. Now (at night) the wind has changed, and it is cold, and I have again been at walking. John mostly in abeyance. Not a word more. Oh write! I will be silentent End of word with line over it repeated at turn of page. afterward. God keep my one possessn, my own poor Jeannie! Ever yrs
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: (Wedny 9 p.m. 24 May 1865)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 May. MS: NLS 617.683. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Oh what a relief tonight by the8 o’clock mail! I have been quite distressed and at intervals alarmed & miserable all day. Had the Letter not come in at 8 o’clock, what I had hardly any hope of, I meant to write to Mrs Warren expressly for a word about you. Don’t neglect agn; and understand always that if you do miss the afternoon despatch (whh finds me here next morning), the Pillar at Cadogan Pier The pillar box at Cadogan Pier, just E of Cheyne Row. any time before 6½ a.m.) will reach me here at 8 p. m. But the morning is always better; and I am going to adopt the morning too,—were I once got steadied in my courses a little.— You say nothing abt the sore-arm and the sleep; only of the remedies (quinine & castor), nothing of the diseases:
but you write so cheerfully I feel quite relieved in comparison. Don’t bother yourself writing tomorrow; write me a word on Saturday (no Pillar or delay for that, recollect), & I shall get it on Sunday. Although there was no postal delivery in much of Scotland on Sundays (cf. JWC to JHJHI, [19 May]), in Dumfries mail apparently could be collected from the station.

My Sleeping arrangets are not yet complete, but we hope they are daily progressing: the last improvet is that of taking off the bed-roof (an invention due to a very cunning creature, not of these parts!)— I am also today upon strict diet (no dinner but curds & cream), and have had a good spell of walking, at morning & midday, with a third walk still to come. The country is beautiful, & everybody is kind: Oh I unthankful!

I dare say your Hiddlestonespeculation will do as well as any other you cd have fallen upon; very possibly better: that is all one can require for decision in such a case. Oh if you were getting well on the sleep side agn! Send a word on Saturday (before 5½ p.m): I won’t write tomorrow unless &c—. Your Letters shan’t dad; See JWC to TC, 24 May. no! Yours ever
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [25 May]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: My Darling! My Darling! My heart is full of things to say to you; and I cannot get them said for my arm ! Oh that arm! It keeps me miserable and incapable day after day! week after week! And the worst is, the pain of it has got to such a pitch that I cannot sleep ten minutes together! That morning after Mr C went away, I sat down and cried! I felt so little up to taking care of myself by myself!— I have not however suffered from Solitude, whatever else! People feel it is their duty to look me up when left alone. Especially George Cooke, who came and took Mr C to the Railway, and got him “a carriage all to himself,” and saw to his luggage; and to whom Mr C, at parting, “consigned his Wife, for protection”!! begging him “to go and see her as often as he possibly could” a request which George Cooke seemed to consider, like Lady Augusta’s marriage, “exceedingly ridiculous, and perfectly unnecessary”! Lady Augusta Stanley had been woman of the bedchamber, personal secretary, and friend of Queen Victoria; furious about Lady Augusta’s marriage to Dean Stanley, Victoria wrote to her uncle, King Leopold I (1790–1865), king of the Belgians: “my dear Lady Augusta, at 41, without a previous long attachment, has, most unnecessarily, decided to marry (!!)” (Letters of Queen Victoria, 2d ser. 2 vols. [1926] 1:113–14). TC and JWC had recently dined with the Stanleys; see JWC to MR, 4 May.

If it weren’t for my arm; I should rather like my position. But you know how a constant raging toothache in one’s arm spoils the fine weather, and the kind people and everything for one. Tho’ I suppose we suffer with a difference, the difference between rheumatism and neuralgia, Lady Ashburton suffered from rheumatism and JWC suffered from “neuralgia” rather than rheumatism; see 39:186JWC to MR, 16 Sept. 1863. whatever that may be!

Mr C called for Miss Bromley before he left, and told me she had had a Surgeon Not further identified. in the House, “dissecting the second dead puppy; to discover, if possible the cause of death, for the preservation of the remaining three”!!

A pet dog, called “Tommy” belonging to the Forsters, flew at my mouth, one day we dined there, and bit my lip, For TC’s instructions to the dog Tommy not to bite him, see 41:78TC to JF, 22 Oct. 1864. which bled, and swelled, and for several days I had uncomfortable little ideas of hydrophobia—aggravated by the Screech-owl Fanny, who was always repeating to me that “surely I ought to have had the bit cut out, and caustic applied”! I will send you a letter I received from Tommy. Wonderful the absurdities that clever men John Forster, in this instance; for JWC writing as her dog Nero, see 25:14–15Nero (JWC) to TC, [29 Jan. 1850], and 30:127–29Nero (JWC) to ETW, 30 Nov. 1855. are up to!

I am going to be delivered from the tender mercies of Fanny; and have a hereditary servant from Dumfriesshire in her stead. A young woman whose Great Grandfather served my Great Grandfather, her Grandfather my Grandfather, her Mother my Mother, her Uncle my Aunt! JWC’s maternal aunt, Jeannie; for the others, see JWC to JHJHI, 15 May. I only keep Fanny till Dr and Mrs Blakiston have paid me their promised visit. next week probably.
Then I shall have to take flight somewhere, while some oilpainting is done, I couldnt stand the smell of it while new.
But I shall take care to bein the way to see you, if you only let me have due notice when you are coming.

I thought Lady Trevelyan much improved in complexion, and she was in good Spirits. But one of her eyes was strangely small. I took her a drive on the Sunday. My Black Mare turns out well. I have christened her Bellona, Bellona was bought for JWC in April; see 41:212JWC to LLA, 17 April. and she has never stood on her hind legs but once. Poor Noggs is at Scotsbrig (Mr C’s Brother) and a great favorite. He preceded his Master by a week.

This is horrible writing but my two middle fingers have lost all power, God Bless you and wee Darling!— Do pray remind her sometimes of “Henrietta Muff,” who without any “pretending” loves Her dearly.

Miss Dempster wrote me a nice letter from her Home. Dunnichen, Forfarshire; see JWC to MR, 4 May. For a photograph of Miss Dempster, possibly taken around this time, see opp.above. TC wrote later underneath: “Miss Dempster (was at Seaforth Lodge, Devonshire, with us.” but—I don’t think I can keep upa correspondence with her—
Miss Dempster, [1865?]
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

I was invited to Luncheon at the Gomms, and went; and little Lord Dundreary Presumably JWC’s nickname for Sir William Gomm; Lord Dundreary was a character in Tom Taylor’s play Our American Cousin (1858), that had been staged in London in April 1864; see 40:66TC to JWC, [14 April 1864]. Abraham and Mary Lincoln were attending a performance of Our American Cousin at Ford’s Theatre, Washington, D.C., when J. W. Booth shot Lincoln, 14 April. skipped about, changing my plates, after the Servants were sent out—and hisyears are eighty! and he hummed opera airs and his Wife looked at him in a perpetual ecstasy!

Lady Gomm has an enthusiastic admiration for you— Always begs when I see her that I will “recall” her to your memory and say how deeply she has sympathized with you,” Presumably over Lord Ashburton’s death rather than Lady Ashburton’s problems with his family and his will (see 40:113–14TC to LLA, 5 June 1864). She is a nice woman,a little bit what Mr C would call “gigmanic” Coterie speech; TC’s word for someone whose respectability is measured by their material possessions, such as a gig; see 3:16TC to JAC, 21 Jan. 1823 [1824], and 5:298TC to JAC, 7 July 1831. — But she was brought up in Eastlothian! The family home was at Newbattle Abbey, East Lothian. where the “Gig” or what is shadowed forth thereby is paramount
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [26 May]. MS: NLS 609.710. Quot: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:323–24. For TC’s later dating of the letter, with “beging” and “june” deleted, leaving “end of May, 1865,” see above.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest! I am so sorry! Especially if my letter, posted on Wednesday night, did not reach you last night—not till this morning! But, after all, my delay in writing was not so incomprehensible as it represents itself in your mind. Time moves at a strangely different rate for the Person gone away, and the one staying at home. It was on Monday you left: and on Wednesday (the next day but one) you are already astonished at my silence! It is not by the Horse Guards clock, The “Horse Guards clock” was on the Clock Tower, Horse Guards Parade, Whitehall. or the watch in ones pocket that one measures one’s Life, but by the quantity and variety of the things one has seen and the emotions one has felt. For me; that “toothache in my arm” which keeps me day and night chiefly occupied with itself whether I will or no admits of little variety, or other emotion than endurance;—if that can be called emotion!— I have taken the Quinine now three days and don’t feel the least better for it. My nights are wretched but it is not I think the Quinine that has anything to do with the Sleeplessness as yet—I simply cannot sleep for the pain.

Dr Blakiston cannot come this week—hopes to come next week in the mean time he tells me of “a similar affection” in a man who had consulted him a few days ago—to whom he had prescribed Vera—(something Linament) Veratrine, an herbal ointment of alkaloid powder mixed with alcohol and lard, used as an external application in neuralgia and rheumatic pains. which “had procured him the best sleep he had had for six weeks.” I shall take the letter to Quiller today, and try if he can read the word and give me the thing to try. I shall also buy when I am out some made pens—to write more legibly with, than I can with those two miserably bad goose pens you are familiar with. as I have no power whatever in the two middle fingers of my right hand; it is too bad that such pens as these should be added to the difficulty of making decent writing—
Jane Welsh Carlyle to Thomas Carlyle, [26 May 1865] (detail)
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland
Geraldine is very attentive comes every night before bed time and rubs my arm for an hour—
Tho nothing has happened—nothing “tospeak of”—I could make some entertainment out of my details of life—if I had spirits for it. But really the pain takes away my wits. God bless you

ps.p: Chapman says the Books are in Berlin by this time They were sent off “a day or two” after the date of Williams and Norgates application See TC to SW, [21] May.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 27 May. MS: NLS 609.711. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:258–59 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I think, Dear, you must have lost a day, this week—must have—stop!—no!—I should have said—gained a day!— You bid me “not bother myself writing tomorrow; but send a word on Saturday”— And the tomorrow is Saturday. This day on which I am not to “bother myself writing” is Saturday I posted a letter to you yesterday at the right time. That night-post is later than you think— It was past nine when Fanny put in the pillar the letter you received the following evening at eight.

My Quinine andcastor oil has quite failed of doing the good to my right arm which they formerly did to my left. The pain gets more severe and more continuous from day to day. Last night it kept me almost entirely awake. I often wonder that I am able to keep on foot during the day, and take my three-hours drives, and talk to the people who come to relieve my loneliness; with that arm always in pain as if a dog were gnawing and tearing at it! But
anything rather than the old nervous misery which was not to be called pain at all! positive, natural pain I can bear as well as most people— But I wish Dr Blakiston would come! Perhaps he can deal with a reality like this; tho’ he could “do nothing against hysterical Mania”! “His phrase to me one day at St. Leonards—in that desperate time” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:259). — I got the thing he mentioned, veratrine linament, yesterday from Quiller—and Geraldine rubbed it in for an hour last night. But as I said; last night was the worst! Quiller also procured me an apparatus for making potash water—Soda water or any sort of water I like. It cost twenty five shillings but will be a great saving in the end; making for three hapence as much potash water as would cost sixteenpence, bought in bottles.

I lunched at Caliope’s one day. Mr Homer away in Paris and the Dilberoglues staying with her. Calliope Honière or Homere, b. Dilberoglue (b. 1835), sister of Stauros Dilberoglue (1818–78; see 40:22740:biographical notes); she m., 1858, John George Honière (b. 1814), general merchant; they lived at 4 The Terrace, Kensington Sq. Gdns. W; John George was apparently changing his name to Homere; having previously been listed as Honi?re, he was listed in the 1865 PO directory as Homere. She has four little children every one with the same great star-like eyes She had when I first saw her! I brought Mrs Dilberoglue home with me. As she and Stavros were engaged to spend the evening at Reichenbachs Oskar and Friedrike von Reichenbach. and Reichenbach had come in the morning, with a knot on his pocket-handkerchief, to ask me to meet them. I said I would, and brought Mrs Dil– home in that view. But when the hour came I was in such pain that I sent her in the carriage by herself— I bade you send back Jessie’s letter and you send instead Pollocks Presumably William Frederick Pollock. and the Jhon Mill thing which I had already read! “Jhon”: thus in MS; John Stuart Mill had written several recent magazine articles, the most likely being either “Romilly’s Public Responsibility and the Ballot,” Reader, 29 April, or “The Positive Philosophy of Auguste Comte,” Westminster Review, 1 April; otherwise unidentified.
Poor Royston continues dangerously ill— Theyare losing all hope of him— William Haylett Royston, their neighbor at 1 Cheyne Row; he lived until 1871.
When yousee the Russells remember to express regret that they would not pay me a visit. if you said nothing about it they might think you had had no part part in the invitation.

I have opened my letter JWC wrote these last paragraphs on a small piece of paper on which TC wrote later: “(27 May 1865).” to ask where in the world you put the outer key of your pigeon hole Desk—which is left flying open

With the key you gave me I opened the upper drawer in your bedroom—and found three keys but none of them belonging to the pigeon-hole desk—
George Cooke said you desired him to “come often and look after me!” “Perfectly unnecessary”— I mean the desiring.

Couldnt you fetch up Noggs to Dumfries? “My saucy little Arab (gift of Lady Ashburton)” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:259). Noggs was at Scotsbrig. So much walking in such hot weather must be tireing Thus in MS. — All good be with you
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 27 May 1865. MS: Bonham’s, auction 22509, lot 11, New York, 9 Dec. 2015. TC copied out, signed, and dated the Goethe poem, “For the tie is snapt asunder,” for an unidentified correspondent. Bonham’s noted that Sotheby’s had sold it previously, 28 Oct. 1981, lot 560. TC used the same poem for another unidentified correspondent, 7 Aug. 1865; see TC to JWC, 7 Aug. 1865 . Rodger L. Tarr and Fleming McClelland, eds., pbd. the poem with a different final line, Collected Poems of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle (Greenwood, Fla., [1986]) 91. TC’s version of Goethe’s poem and autograph follows TC to JWC, [26 May 1865] . For TC’s pbd. trans. of Goethe’s poem, see Wilhelm Meister’s Travels, Carlyle, Works 24:344. [This copy of Goethe‘s poem, pbd. at CL 44:236, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: (From Goethe)

lg.l: Trust and loving hope are fled:
Can I tell, in fear and wonder,
With what dangers round bested,Tarr and McClelland print “now,” not “round”; the printed version of the poem in Wilhelm Meister’s Travels had “bestead,” another version of “bested” [situated].
I, cut off from friend and brother,
Like the widow in her woe,
With the one and not the other,
Now my weary way must go!” Tarr and McClelland’s last line was “On and on, my way must go!”—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 May. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 28 May 1865. MS: NLS 617.684. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My poor Darling,—Yr Letters are full of saddish news to me, yet of very cheery tone; and welcome to my heart, in spite of the history they give. You are a brave little creature; that is certain; and I always persuade myself your shifty bits of industries and strength of spirit will carry you thro’. That weary arm, those weary wasteful nights! I always hope there will come better news soon, but one’s disappointments continue long too. It was surely wise to send for the B[l]akistons, to try quinine &c: I wait with anxiety to hear what becomes of the new Blakiston remedy, whh Quiller was to read and make ready:—if Blakiston, by any art, can put away that bad arm, I will call him my best benefactor just now!— One fear, however, I have: that their visit may so fuss you in yr weak state & with a Fanny for practical lieutenant, that you may get more ill of it than good. I request you earnestly to let it, for your own part, very much go as it can: take Bessy Bessy Blakiston. outto drive &c, let her do the talking, bid Mrs Warren provide and keep Fanny to her tools:—on the whole, I shall be glad to learn that the adventure is done and has left no harm behind it. Oh dear, what a feckless pair of bodies we two have grown, my Jeannie! Let us be the dearer to one another the farther down we go.

Tomorrow I think of going to Thornhill; I write a word today to announce myself to Mrs Russell. Probably John will feel called to go with me; but that is little matter. I want to have that done, as the one bit of business lying nearest me: I have then to get some materials for clothing; and then got to go down to The Gill, & “superintend the Tailoring,”—that is the figure I give it, tho’ otherwise too I want rather to be there for the prest than here. My sleep, in spite of all industries, has not quite come back to me; indeed I (miserable “I”) turn out to have the appointed instrument for rendering that grand “Bedroom”
and its flagrant upholsteries, habitable to human nature: ventilatn plus quiet & moderate darkness, all the cranks & quirks of that problem, it is poor I that have had to meet them:—and my last goodish sleep turns out to have been much the best I have yet had. But the air &c, the silent walks, the kindness of everybody do good: I really feel rather better; don’t bother [your] TC’s omission. poor head abt me at all!—
Sudden news that not “six o clock but “on Sundays 2 o’clock” is the post hour of sunday:—and that I have only 3 minutes left!
God bless thee Darling Jeannie; take care of thyself for my poor sake.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 May. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 29 May 1865. MS: NLS 617.685. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: That poor little arm,—alas, I wish it wd get a little better! Nothing seems to improve it hitherto; and the constant pain of it is sad to think of for my poor little Jeannie, heavy-laden otherwise enough. We hope Blakiston, who really has much ingenuity, may be able to contrive something. Your patience under it, your courage and spirit are worthy of all praise.

There has been nothing possible for Thornhill today, tho’ yesterday I had written of it to Mrs R. as a thing intended. But it has rained incessantly from before six o’clock this morning (after a good dose yesterday too), & is still raining,—my third walk still to execute; after two done under umbrellas this third (carrying the prest Note to Post-Office withal) will have a mackintosh to it, for I cd endure the weighty umbrella no longer. I don’t so much dislike the rain if a machintosh be forthcoming; I insisted honestly, these last two goes, tho’ the thing was wearisome, two miles out to Torthorwald Village and parish NE of Dumfries. and back, the second of them, &c &c. Being the idlest of all mortals, I am bound at least to do my walks. Sleep seems improving; I most days fish out my 6 hours in pieces somewhere from the 4 and 20; I am very careful abt diet &c; a sad functn but a necessary!

The enigmaabt my last Note is—in short, is that it must have been a minute too late in getting into the Post-Office her[e]: TC’s omission. so instead of getting it on Friday afternoon you did not get it till Saturday morning! That must be it. “Jessie’s Letter” (whh I suppose to be yr new Nithsdale maid’s) is utterly extinct; gone
as pipe-spills,—in sheer mistake! The “outer key” of the Pigeon-hole Desk in the study is simply the inner one itself: the lid shuts if you push it to; if you want to lock it, the same key fits all the locks it has. Where that lies, (if not at prest in Goody’s own pocket) I presume you know: old Templand Drawers, The desk originally belonged to JWC’s father, John Welsh; see 41:23–24TC to JWC, 14 Sept. 1864. It presumably came to TC from JWC’s mother, Grace Welsh, who lived at Templand after the Carlyles’ marriage. hidden with an ostrich cunning See John Galt, Stories of the Study (1833) 3:274. whh you have more than once admired.

But the time is hastening on; and I have a great deal of difficult shoeing (shoe-horse needed for the one water-tight pair I have; whh are new,—pity me!)—I must close at once. Oh dear, oh dear, I wish you were sitting here,—or rather I sitting there; tho neither of these wd do! My thots are very sad, Dear; but they are not so miserable either; & really I feel rather improving in spite of all. Tomorrow we agn intend Thornhill. I hope to be considerably better, were I at The Gill, given up to my own reflexions & moody ruminatns such as they are. Fry’s Photograph of you (thanks!) Seems to me far the best. JWC’s photograph by the firm of Joseph John Elliott (1835–1903) and Clarence Edmund Fry (1840–97), photographers, 55 Baker St.; TC sent this photograph to Emerson, 14 June. TC wrote later on their own copy in vol. 3 of the photograph albums: “My own Jane (very recognizable, very unfavrable Likeness)”; see opp.above. TC only referred specifically to his own sittings for John Watkins (see 41:213–15TC to JOWA, 21 April), but at about the same time that John Watkins took JWC’s photograph in April, Elliott & Fry also took photographs of both TC and JWC; see JWC to MR, 4 May, where JWC referred to Woolner wanting “a variety of Photographs to work from” and photographers (i.e., Watkins and Elliott & Fry), wanting “a variety to sell. ” God bless thee, Dearest,
T.C.
Jane Welsh Carlyle, by Elliott & Fry, [April 1865]
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 30 May. MS: NLS 609.712. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote later underneath the address and date: “early in june 1865 (beging of lameness in hand;—doing this room: ah me!” but then added on last page: “(30 May 1865;—recd 31.”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Dearest, I must stick to business today, and even in that line must “hasten to the Catastrophe.” Coterie speech; see 39:47JWC to EWAGW, [2 Feb. 1863]. For the hand I write with is as good as broken. My pain which shifts from one part of the arm to another, and back again, like Darwin amongst his Clubs, Presumably Erasmus Darwin (1804–81), friend of the Carlyles since 1835; he lived a life of bachelor leisure and was probably a member of many clubs; otherwise unexplained. has been these last two days stationary in the hand and
the shoulder. I have been making wild efforts to learn to write with the left hand, but the failure has been signal.

No word of the Blakistons yet—his remedy Veratrine linament I tried twice— Geraldine rubbed it in for an hour—but instead of finding any soothing in it; the two nights after using it were the very worst nights as to pain that I had had. So that is discontinued— The Quinine also has been discontinued! after persevering with it for a week. the only effect it seemed to have was giving me a continual headache. And now I am just waiting (the most difficult of all things to do).

I go to bed at eleven, get to sleep about twelve sleep and wake, and sleep and wake till between three and four. and then the pain lets me sleep no more. I have about just two hours of sleep per night— Enough to keep General Elliot going on all thro’ the seige of Gibralter! George Augustus Eliott (1717–90; ODNB), army general, governor of Gibralter 1775–90, defended it against the Spanish siege 1779–83, during which he and his soldiers suffered continual bombardment and severe privations, presumably including lack of sleep. The last three days I have taken the pleasing habit of sleeping a quarter of an hour in the carriage! What a blessing that carriage is to be sure. I should be dead in a few weeks without it!

Miss Baring called to thank you “most sincerely” for the two volumes, Louisa Baring, Lady Ashburton’s sister-in-law; vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick. which she had received the night before !!! Really F Chapman is unbearable! Frederic Chapman, negligent in distributing TC’s gift copies of Frederick; see TC to RWE, 31 May. Duffy came to tea last night and brought me a bracelet made of fruit stones gathered in The great Desert! Presumably in Australia. He starts for Dublin today.
I have had the Carpenter to measure the paint work of the diningroom. No use trying to make the room look decent without beginning with clean paint.

There are a hundred and ten square yards—if painted with two coats of selfcoloured paint it will cost sixpounds ten. if done in wainscot with two coats of varnish, the cost will be thirteen pounds. You had best consult James Aitken Jean Carlyle Aitken’s husband, James Aitken, was a house painter. and tell me which it shall be— I am always for the thing that is dearest and will last longest. But perhaps one should not hold on to that principle when one gets so near the end of ones needs—
Tell me soon—and also do tell me where the key of the pigeon-hole desk lies

I had a man all yesterday and part of today thundering on the front of the house, like a battering ram. Before you left I had observed water had been flowing in at the Drawingroom ceiling. What could it mean when the cistern had been new lined? I wouldnt worry you with it. But so soon as you were
gone I had the Carpenter to look—and it was found the lead pipe was all in holes! and had washed away the very lime out of the bricks— Yesterday two lengths of leadpipe were put up—and I hope at last we are watertight; oh my hand
Good by—thanks for Jane’s letter Presumably a letter from Jean Aitken, often called Jane. JWC’s letter unsigned.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 31 May. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Dumfries, 31 May 1865. MS: NLS 617.686. Quot: Bliss, TC 376.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my Darling, I am very wae for thee, if that cd help at all! That miserably shaking hand; the incessant misery; those “two hours” nightly of sleep! Things do seem going hard with us both; but we must not yield. No more of “linament” then, no more of quinine; they required to be tried, if only to dismiss them reasonably; that too is a piece of work done. Courage, courage!—

I shd be clear for the effectual (£13) kind of painting: but I cannot now listen to the project of any kind at all. Have the rooms thoroughly cleaned, and do nothing more in it till I return. “Painting” with its horrid smells, and multifarious noisy preliminaries & accompanimts, wd be enough to kill thee:—­besides I am not arranged at all as to the Bookcases (shiftable from the Study); wait till I come back, before going farther than cleaning. Those waterpipes, those miserable failures & human quackeries:—my poor Darling is not at prest equal to striving with them; it wd distress me hourly to think they were aggravating her other intolerabilities.— Let me not forget, however, to tell you where the Pigeon-hole Key is: if I can! Pull out the left hand upper-drawer of the old Templand Desk or Drawers; there, among old gloves &c, you will find a key with leather label & probably “1” marked on it; open the narrow upper (long) drawer with that, all the keys of that Desk are in it,—among others the key (a big one with hollow filed in the side of it) whh opens the general lid (or top part of Desk): lid open, you see to left hand, a small-small drawer with white paper-label on it “keys”; Pigeon-hole key is there, or I cannot tell in the least where it is! For certain, I left it in some safe place (was almost flattering myself I had given it to you) on taking out the “keys” of trunk, writing-case & carpet-bag, with the strange key attached, whh you made Fanny or somebody remove. This is all I can say: forgive my imperfections in that whirl of hurries I was in! And this is all the “busss,” is it not? Let me add that you may as well call at Chapman’s door, & make him say positively whether now all the Books (American &c) are really & truly off, or whether some do not yet lag forgotten,
to bother me agn and ever agn! It is totally absurd; and much unlike what used to be accounted busss in that house, you may add from me: but it will do no good. Duffy’s bracelet I am glad of for yr dear sake: to him a fair journey; he is very polite & good, but his prest notions and operatns are rather rather The second “rather” has been lightly struck through, possibly by TC. wearisome than interesting to me.Here is a paltry Newspaper Scrap (Glasgow Daily Something) whh if the idle wretches take to quoting Possibly the Glasgow Herald, 8 and 15 April, which quoted extracts from the final vols. of Frederick; otherwise untraced. wd be like a squirt of dirty water on me, did I read them (as I don’t): dumb Tom brot it in to me last night, poor soul; his dumb master (in their evg crack, by fingers) Jean’s son Tom, who was deaf, and his teacher (not further identified), using sign language. had given it him him. Word repeated with line over it at turn of page. Another thing I will very particularly add: namely, to try every afternoon or evg to get a little wink of sleep; were it but a 1/4 hour, it is an important addition to your small stock! Do now, try always; that has been my chief resource the majority of days since I came hither.

Yesterday betn 5 & 6 was still raining, and the wind a perfect roar; too much of ventilatn, after my weary walks the day before! I arose & shut my window (whh needs a long pole with hook) & other two in next room (this), where I smoked; and afterwds, with rug added, crept into bed agn, and almost determined to lie there all day, and call myself sick, to be out of the bothers elswhere. Strange to say, I actually, after a long while, fell into stony sleep for two hours, stony but actual; & did not appear to breakfast till after ten or near 11. The windy day was now dryish; but, for Thornhill, there was no train except 4 (4.55!) p.m. & return by 8 (8.1. I determined to go; John not to accompany: I went accordingly; and it was the event of the day: the pleasantest I may well say since I arrived here. Very pensive, my ride up was, the evg brightening into shine, old memories crowding on me. I got to Holmhill at 6; good Mrs Russell all smiles to see me, the little maid running in to name me (“by the Picture,” she said; viz. by the wide-awake Photograph); Mary, the servant, recognized TC from a photograph of him wearing his broad-brimmed (“wide-awake”) hat; JWC presumably sent Mary Russell one of John Watkins’s photographs of TC wearing the hat; for an example, see 13JWC to LLA, 7 May [1865]. the Dr speedily came in (unchanged) except in colour of hair), & directly after, 3 ladies, old two of them, and known to you, a Mrs Moffat widow from Auchan-Somethg, and a Mrs Widow of a Clergyman nearby, Mrs. Moffat, not further identified, and probably Margaret Graham (b. ca. 1808), widow of Rev. James Graham (1808–63), of Penpont; see 39:80JWC to MR, [2 March 1863]. who were come to tea; & seemed to take me as a pleast sauce in additn. We did beautifully well, for our hour and half, and my “thanks” to Dr & Wife did not want for sincerity. In fact they evidtly
like you very well;—their chief anxiety seemed to be to get you back, “soon, this summer, whenevr you cd.” Really perhaps you cd not do so well: come if you don’t get better; huddle up everything & come? We shall get some way contrived of paying them; & probably it is far the best you cd do? Twenty min. to 8, the Dr drove me up to the station; and I returned with the feeling that there had been the pleasantest two hours since I quitted home.

Tomorrow you will perhaps get nothing, Dear; tomorrow I am fairly shifting to The Gill, where, with the aid of Noggs & total solitude, I count to recover my sleep & other composure; thot sad, but silent attending me in quantity. Jean is out getting work for the Tailor: William Boyd (1811–90), master tailor, of Cummertrees, near The Gill; Jean was buying material; see TC to JWC, 28 May. poor kind soul, I can see she really wants me away,—at least till she can get rid of Jack in some good manner! Two of us are too many for anybody, arriving at once especially, the elder of us unable to sleep! So I shall be off tomorrow; & Goody will hear nothing till Saturday morng—morning always, after that, on both hands; & Pillar &c of no use to you. Write little, Dearest, while yr poor hand is (t.o.) in such a state; make a word or two serve,—tho’ I like yr words better than anything that can come to me. Jamie I Thus in MS; TC’s brother Jamie brought Noggs from Scotsbrig to The Gill. shall be with Noggs tomorrow evg or next day. Adieu, my Dearest. God keep thee.— T.C.

ps.p: The day is one of the beautifullest I ever saw; my outlook the Anandale & the Galloway Hills (two windows), & not a sound audible in Heaven or Earth. Bene, bene [well, well]!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [1 June]. MS: NLS 609.714. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:260.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—“You must excuse us the day.” Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to JWC, 30 May 1834. I really cannot use my hand withoutextreme pain. and Geraldine has not come in to write for me.

I am just going off to Dr Quain Dr. Richard Quain. since Dr Blakiston is postponed into the vague. I have been quite wild with the pain the last two nights and days. Tomorrow I will go to these good Macmillans Alexander Macmillan, his wife, Caroline, and their sister-in-law, Frances Macmillan, who lived with them in Tooting. whom you sneered at as my “distinguished visitors” Variant of the coterie phrases, “celebrated woman,” “distinguished female,” “distinguished male” (2:162, 8:10, 10:29); all were mainly used sarcastically. — None of those more “distinguished” have come to
me with such practical help and sympathy— They are quite the right distance off. Tooting is about 5½ mi. (9 km.) S of Cheyne Row. I can have my carriage come and take me home any day to look after the house, and for a drive as usual

I think you will be better at the Gill than the Hillin spite of the grand House if you can only sleep thro’ the railway The Carlisle to Dumfries railway passed about ¼ mi. (400 m.) from The Gill. And do not indulge too far in curds and cream for a dinner— God bless you

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 2 June. Addr: Macmillan Esq / Streatham Lane / Upper Tooting / London. PM: 2 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.687. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My poor lame Goody,—your Letter is indeed full of misery; and except that [of] the good Macmillans, there is nothing of hopeful or consolatory in the sad Post of Today. Blakiston—his absence at the moment may perhaps be something of benefit: the good Polly too awakens a kind of human remembrance in me: but the gaping gazing blockhead of a Moffat, Unidentified; possibly people connected with Lady Ashburton mentioned in the enclosure (untraced) sent with JWC to TC, [1 June] (see TC to Lady ALLA, 2 June); presumably not a reference to Margaret Graham or Mrs. Moffat whom TC met at Holmhill; see TC to JWC, 31 May. &c; all that is like rain from the East (such as wehave here today), whh never ceases. Dr Quain too will, as usual in yr sad case, have been either zero or worse; of course, you had to consult him: but I hope he confined himself to confirming the resolutn you had already formed. Sad, sad, that all these kind people can do nothing, tho’ with effort! With something of a real hope, however, I address this to “Streatham Lane”: The Macmillans’ address. complete change of place has generally benefited you; and in the London circle, it is impossible to do it anything like so well as thither. I need not bid you totally avoid the “seven-O’clock dinners” (never dream of such a thing!), and to beware of much talking even over tea,—but indeed you have the art of refusing to speak far beyond me, who are often seriously damaged by it. Pity you had not a better Maid than Fanny; the stupid Pig, you will reflect she is not for long; Fanny was under notice to leave; see JWC to MR, 4 May. —and the two Mrs Macmns Caroline Macmillan and her sister-in-law Frances Macmillan. have every appearance in your favour. Oh that this Notecd find my poor tormented Darling to have had some better sleep when it arrives tomorrow morning! Yes, if
they can set you up a little, and assuage yr wretchedness to the old pitch, I swear they shall not be “distinguished visitors” in any but the kindest sense, and my gratitude to the House & them will last with my life. Oh what a fight we have, Dear;—nothing for us but to cleave to one another, and fight side by side! Tomorrow I can hear nothing from you (nor is it certain I shall have a chance on Sunday); but do you inquire strictly abt the “Tooting Pillar” The postbox in Tooting. — Alas, no; I shall not hear agn at any rate, in this Country part, till Tuesday morng: you, if I can, shall on Monday morning; and, in the interim, I will agn try hope.

You areclearly of my mind that my prospects are better here; where in fact, rain & all, I feel really relieved to be. My beginning (in the sleep way) is agn baddish; but I persuade myself it is only accidental (due to bad feeding yesterday, especially I think to some very vile, perhaps overdrawn Tea,—or even to excess in excellt porridge and sweet-sour; Presumably curds and cream; see JWC to TC, [1 June]. far most likely to the Tea, whh shall be avoided henceforth):—but Oh, the blessedness of being out of noise and confusion! Yesterday I had such a work lifting anchor,—the live-long day; & then all in a hurry & a leap at the last moment:—poor kind Jean, she will be very sad today, but greatly relieved (if she durst confess it). Mary wants words to testify abt the framed Portraits JWC sent copies of the recent photographs of herself and TC to friends and relatives, including Mary Austin; see 41:217JWC to MCA, [ca. 25] April [1865]].; TC repeated Mary’s thanks, with James Carlyle’s added, in TC to JWC, 5 June. (“Aye a vera bonny young Leddy, yes!”) & has them already hanging up in good position. Jenny of Scotsbrig TC’s niece, James Carlyle’s da. is to be here today. I never heard the rail last night, such the east wind & the sounding of my own ears. I will write a Note to Ly Ashburton: Jamie & Noggs are not yet here. Adieu my poor little Dear. God keep thee for me. T. C.

ps.p: Yesterday Jean reported the arrival of Fry’s or the Sun’s “stroke of genius” in the Photograph-shops of Dumfries. “Sun-picture”: photograph (see 38:7TC to CGD, 10 Nov. 1861); Elliott & Fry’s photographs of TC on sale in Dumfries; for Joseph Brown’s engraving of TC’s profile, based on one of these photographs, see frontis.the image available on the table of contents page for volume 42. There in thewindows it openly figured; glory to us, or alas no-glory—that is all the Dumfries news my Darling will the least care for. Agn Adieu—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 2 June. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.dateline: The Gill, Cummertrees Annan N.B., 2 june 1865
docBody.p: Dear Lady Ashburton,—I have been dreadfully ill off for sleep since coming into these parts, and kept generally in such continued perturbatn, or I wd sooner have acknowledged yr beautiful little Note. Truly you are are very kind to think it a “favour” of me to have such a Bust done of me at yr expense! The honour of yr having wished such a thing wd have been compensation thrice over for all my trouble. Woolner himself had infinite botheration, and exerted every industry and faculty witht stint or grudge; but seemed to think (as do others) that he had prevailed at last. See TC to JCA, 12 May. I am a little anxious for your own first sight of the thing; but let us hope! To myself the features seemed accurately there; but the whole was a little stony and terrible!— You know into what a state my poor Wife is fallen agn; and I see (by what she incloses me today), that you do not neglect her in her sore distress. She has been continually declining, I think, since we quitted Seaforth Lodge; The Carlyles stayed 8 March to 3 April with Lady Ashburton in her new house, Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, Devonshire. still faster, as I rather collect, since she was left alone. No Doctor’s recipe appears to be of the least value. Today she is to go over to certn Macmillans who are very good people, & have a nice old-fashioned villa at Tooting, less than 4 miles from her own home, if she don’t find it answer. But I soothe myself with hopes she will; complete change (and this is really Country too, tho’ so near Town) has often a singular efficacy in these sad cases. Poor creature, poor creature; what she suffers & suffered might melt a stone! Day before yesterday I saw the old Nithsdale Doctor Dr. James Russell; JWC stayed with Dr. James and Mary Russell mid-July through Sept. 1864; see vols. 40 and 41. who did her so much good.
