If things don’t mend, she must return hither.—— This is in Annandale (within ten miles of my birthplace); yesterday I left my Dumfries Sister, and took shelter with this quieter, elder & graver one,—in my intense need of being left altogether silent: this is neat little Farm House, of humble pretensions; but the quietest and loneliest for me in all the world.

You too are ailing; & on these terms we are all getting scattered to east & west. Lady Ashburton suffered from rheumatism and planned to go abroad for her health; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [25 May], and Surtees, Ludovisi 114. I heartily wish we saw you home, with a sound heart, from these
Foreign Caixes [Climes?]! Word unclear; it looks most like “Caixes,” a version of caique, a fishing boat, which seems unlikely; possibly a very badly written “Climes.” Oh me I often dreamof a Cottage nr you at Melchet, Melchet Court, nr. Romsey, Hampshire, Lady Ashburton’s main residence. —jusqu’á lamort [until death]! Yours ever
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 June]. MS: NLS 609.715. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:261–63. Quot: Ireland, JWC 297; Surtees, JWC 264. TC wrote later on MS: “3 june (recd 5) 1865”; “(june 1865)”; “(end of May, 1865).”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Streatham Lane “Mr. Macmillan’s house (fine old-fashioned suburban villa there)” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:261). Saturday [3 June 1865]
docBody.p: You are so good about writing that you deserve to be goodly done by. So I write a few lines today “under difficulties” Coterie speech; see 27:179JWC to TC, [23 July 1852]. — Tho’ you gave me an excuse for putting off, in saying you could not hear from me till Tuesday.

When I got your letter telling me to hold my hand; it was too late! I had set my heart on doing one more stroke of work (my sort of work) fitting up one more room before I died! “Alas, and this was it: often have I remembered that word” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:261). And the Bookcases were already in a transition state and the carpets up—preparatory to painting and papering! It was all very well to say “give the room a good cleaning” But no amount of mere cleaning could give that room a clean look, with that oory dingy paint and paper— — To put clean paper without fresh paint would only have made the dirtiness of the paint more flagrant—and if the painting was not done whilst you were away, when was there a chance of doing it? I knew I couldnt sleep in wet paint—but I looked to finding a bed somewhere—and the offer of one here, came most opportunely.

The day before leaving home I went to Dr Quain, who did me at least the good of being extremely kind and eager to help me. He said I had “much fever” and gave me a Prescription for that and two other prescriptions—and when I returned from here I was to tell him and he would “run over.” I said to him that Dr Blakiston had declared I had no organic disease, but only a strong
predisposition to gout! “Quite right, he said, that is the fact.” “Then, I asked, perhaps this affair in my arm, so much more painful than what I had in the left arm, is Gout. “I have not the least doubt that is!!” was his answer. Pleasant!

Well! I came here about five yesterday and the good simple people welcomed me most honestly—and Mr Macmillan sang Scotch Songs Alexander Macmillan was b. in Irvine, Ayrshire, and his family was from Arran, island in the Firth of Clyde. which would have charmed you all the evening. The Governess Unidentified further. playing an accompaniment.

At eleven I retired to my beautiful bedroom. The largest prettiest freshest bedroom I ever was put to sleep in! And then they left me to the society of a watch dog chained under my window!!! It barked and growled and howled in the maddest manner till they set it loose about seven in the morning. Of course I never closed my eyes for one minute all the night!—and I got up this morning a sadder and a wiser woman! Cf. Samuel Taylor Coleridge (1772–1834; ODNB ), “Rime of the Ancient Mariner” (1798). — How to get away without hurting feelings? I was the wretchedest of women till I got it settled softly, that when the carriage comes for me today to take me home for an inspection of the Work it should not bring me back but leave me to sleep or wake in my own quiet bed— And come out tomorrow to spend the day, and sleep here or there after, as I liked best—the dog to be “removed to a greater distance”— So address to Cheyne Row—

Dr Quain said I must go as soon as possible to Scotland—“as it had agreed so well with me last year.” I said, I shuddered at the length of journey. He reminded me I had “made it with impunity last year when I was weaker than now—” JWC traveled overnight to Scotland, 13–14 July 1864; see 40:133–35JWC to TC, 15 July [1864].
I suppose it will come to that before long! I need have no doubt about my welcome—

Since you are not disturbed by that Railway which drove me mad, JWC stayed at The Gill for a few days on her arrival in Scotland; see 40:143JWC to TC, [21 July 1864]. you will do well at Mary’s; she is so kind and unfussing—But you must not exceed in milk diet &c! You must have mutton!
And oh take care with Noggson those hilly roads!— Oh my Dear, I am not up to more—my arm is just as if a dog had got it in its teeth and were gnawing at it and shaking at it furiously—

Love to Mary your everaffectionate /
Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: GEJ-Lady Am [KST], 3 June. MS: NLS 1797.104. Hitherto unpbd. Lady Amberley, JWC’s friend Kate Stanley, m. to Lord Amberley since 8 Nov. 1864.
div3.head: GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY TO LADY AMBERLEY

docBody.p: Mrs Carlyle does not like to leave yr letter unanswered any longer but as the pain in her right arm extends down three fingers and makes the act of writing one of great pain as well as difficulty—she has requested me to write for her—& to tell you from her that she had hoped from day to day to be able to write to you herself or that Lady Stanley wd tell you about her— Mrs Carlyle does not like dictating letters & has bid me write in my own person & tell you what she wishes me to say. Several letters this summer, mostly dictated, were written for JWC when her arm was too painful for writing. They are all included in this vol. as written at JWC’s request. I think she will be better when she gets into Scotland where Dr Quain desires her to go at once—and I hope she will be off in the course of a week. Mr Carlyle left home about ten days since & is now with one of his sisters in Dumfrieshire. The neuralgic pain has made Mrs Carlyle very unfit to do any thing & deprives her of all sleep—but it is nothing like the illness she had last year—she is able to go out driving every day, and to see her friends. the pain tho very wearing is not dangerous except as it takes all the comfort out of her life Mrs Carlyle says she is glad to hear you are reading Wilhelm Meister Goethe, Wilhelm Meister (Stuttgart, 1795–1829), trans. TC (1824–26); see Carlyle, Works 23 and 24. —she says you remind her of the French lady Unidentified. who sent for La nouvelle Heloise Jean Jacques Rousseau, Julie, ou la nouvelle Héloïse (1761); see 2:16–18JBW to EA, [Jan. 1822]. as soon as she was married & her own mistress. as a young woman she had of course been forbidden to read it—but to her great disappointment she found it so dull with its theories and disquisitions that she fell asleep over it!—

Mrs Carlyle has taken advantage of Mr Carlyle’s absence to have painters into the house & has gone out to Streatham for a few days driving in every day to see how they go on. She found a most beautiful bedroom the exact similitude of the one she slept in at Alderley The home in Cheshire of Kate’s parents, Lord and Lady Stanley; JWC visited there Aug. 1860; see 36:207JWC to TC, [26 Aug. 1860]. the three windows in a Bow & the outlook over a Park; it was perfectly lovely and she went to Bed with great hopes of a good sleep. When precisely at Midnight the dog whose Kennel was just under one of the windows commenced howling & barking & continued the same at intervals of a quarter of an hour till seven in the morning when it was quite too late to dream of sleeping
She hopes soon to hear of you or from you and the next time of writing to be able to answer you herself.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 5 June. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 5 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.688. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my Dearest, what a time of sleeplessness & tribulation you have; Letter after Letter, hope after hope, and no improvet hitherto! In my life I have heard nothing madder than that of putting a poor sick nervous creature, after every attention to her, into the glorious bedroom,—with a watchdog to bark all night under her window! I have myself heard that dog as I passed the place; and shuddered at the thot of proximity to it, even in the Garden of Eden. Of course there was nothing for you but to cut and run: nevertheless cd not you contrive politely to make it triable once agn; only hint that the watchdog must be utterly locked out of hearing; that the first hint of it agn wd spoil yr sleep for a week? They are infinitely desirous, I doubt not, to do you good; the dog lodged in their own kitchen, wd not be much of a sacrifice. By no means try it, witht annihilation of the dog & its noises. But I had set my heart on yr getting some real relief there; and am much disappointed at the issue hitherto had. Oh do try something: it is heartbreaking to think of you lying nightly in miserable pain, added to misery of sleeplessness, whh is itself so intolerable.—— For the rest, I continue to vote: Give up the painting. Unless you can manage at MacMillan’s, it is not once to be thot of. Clean the rooms really (or Mrs Warren will); let them look as dirty as they must, I care little abt their looks; also shift the Book-cases (if too far gone, for drawing back), I will see how the adjustt ansrs: by Heaven’s blessing, there will occur another fortnight when we are both away (at Melchet or somewhere) and yet able to supervise more or less. In short, you cannot do it, Dear; and must hold in for the prest. You found the Desk-key, I conclude? All right and conclude yr bits of operations on that side.

Today I was much surprised and muchdelighted by the sight of yr Note, quite unexpected,—& in a hand perfectly firm; Geraldine Jewsbury addressed the envelope for JWC to TC, 3 June, but JWC herself wrote the letter; see JWC to TC, [6 June]. Once TC knew the envelope was written by Jewsbury, he burned it; see TC to JWC, 7 June. whh was all I cd learn of it for some time; being just on the run out after bath, at too late an hour, cold, into the stormy breezes also cold & threatening to be rainy. Alas, that of the
steady hand (added to the easy-cheery spirit) was all the good news it held: Macmn grown into a watchdog. Quain full of windy hope, and Blakiston & his “gout” perfectly true! As you say, it must come to Holmhill again; & probably the sooner the better. As to railway, you will really have no difficulty: for a bribe of a 2 shgs, I got the whole huge carriage to myself (except one short stage somewhere abt Preston); I wd meet you at Carlisle (5½ p.m.), conduct you to Dumfries (7½ p.m.), where the Russell brougham wd wait; & so, before 10 o’clock, you wd be in yr nice little Lodging (new ventilator in it, the Dr shewed me) & all safe,—instead of frousy Fanny the new little Huddlestone Thus in MS; Jessie Hiddleston. waiting for you there! I believe that to be the plan.

Yesterday I cd not get a Letter despatched, or not witht a degree of trouble & uncertainty whh after weighing, I found to be quite out of proportion; & so at length candidly gave it up. You wd not have got it “this morning,” any way; the poor soul will look in the afternoon from “Streatham Lane,” & take her bit of disappointt. The sunday mail (I discovered here) is conveyed to Carlisle by a Coach betn Dumfries & that City; abt one or two p.m. it is in Dumfries; but what was the hour for Annan (had one ridden express) or whh the route, nobody had a guess. I will learn punctually this, in case of another time.

I am doing, or going every way to do, quite well well Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. here; give yr poor heart no uneasiness abt me. I have had three nights in successn tolerable quality, &, in pieces, excellt quantity of sleep; even getting my milk diet under my thumb; have no dogs or disturbance at night, & solitary walking or riding, supplemented by dull reading all day. The absence of fuss is also a welcome feature. I really cd not be better lodged anywhere in the world at prest: left alone to my own gloomy ruminations, till various things settle into sediment, & there be a slightly clearer element. This day I have had the Tailor in council: his most interesting operatn is to turn an old brown Duffle Jacket for me; yet one year of Duffle,—for it is out Presumably meaning out of fashion in Dumfries as well as London. too at Dumfries; & indeed Dumfries is become an Imitatn Londonkin, & I think will not be worth applying to for “clothes” another time. That speckly piece for a pair of winter walking trousers: tell me if you cd endure it? It is all made of wool home-spun, it and the other; but the pattern of neither is good.

On Saturday John came promiscuously Coterie speech; see 35:38JWC to GEL, 20 Feb. 1859. in; fidgetted abt for an hour and half (scoured out, however, my deaf ear by a second syringing), & then abt 3 o’clock went home to Dumfries agn for dinner. Poor soul, he really means me kindly, none more so; but by his fidgeting & nig-nagging become very troublesome. If you read Jeans Letter of this morning, it will shew you the
interior there. Independently of him, poor soul, the railway whistles (whh were at all hours & subject to no rule) wd have rendered my “old bedroom” unsuitable to me. TC previously described Jean Aitken’s new house, The Hill, as very quiet; see TC to JWC, 23 May. Not to speak of the noisy fussing, the Newspr curiosity & the various drawbacks of Dumfries.

I got on Noggs when John went, meaning to accompany him to the Station, & then go on an extensive canter to and fro. Noggs knew me very well; & the instant he had me on his back, testified such exuberance of joy, as did not indeed disturb me who knew him, but as threw the bystanders into momentary terror; poor good Noggs! This done, he rode like a perfect gentn, mostly at canter, far & wide; and I had one of the pleasantest gallops of the last 7 years. TC’s last extended holiday in Dumfriesshire, June to Aug. 1858, when he stayed at The Gill, July to mid-Aug., and rode “a big Dromedary of a horse”; see 34:16–18TC to JAC, 8 July 1858. Thro’ old hamlets & villages, by old routes & new,—now all fallen vacant. Round by all the old Hills Burnswark, Woodcockayr, Repentance Repentance Hill and Woodcockair Hill lie about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) NE, and Burnswark Hill a further 5 mi. (8 km.) NE from The Gill. (quite quiet, as if not Histy of Friedh or other immortal work had lately been got done with),—then farther off the Queensberrys big & wee, the peaks of Moffat, & round agn by Dunscore do & down to Criffell: It is not clear if TC rode around all these hills, or just saw some of them in the distance; Queensberry Hill and Little Queensberry Hill lie about 17 mi. (27 km.) NW of Burnswark, the Moffat hills are at least 10 mi. (16 km.) further to the NE; Dunscore is about 25 mi. (40 km.) SW of the Moffat hills, Criffel about 17 mi. (27 km.) S of Dunscore, and the ride back to The Gill from Criffel about 14 mi. (22.5 km.). the day was balmy, breezy; the colour ofthe fields, of of the woods (especially the fir part) and of the hedge all in fragrant hawthorn was unsurpassable:—and the meanings of it all to me were beyond all the sermons whh the united British Churches cd have preached for my behoof. Sad exceedingly, & beautiful no less: ah me, ah me!—

Yesterday wasbright as diamonds, with a glorious breeze too; but tho’ well-slept (praying only my poor Goody were as well do), I felt sore & tired of limb (milk-diet too); & sat most of the day, reading Lyell Sir Charles Lyell, The Geological Evidences of the Antiquity of Man. With Remarks on Theories of the Origins of Species by Variation (1863); Sir Charles Lyell (1797–1875; ODNB ), geologist. TC had previously been sent another book of Lyell’s, Elements of Geology (1838; 6th edn. 1865), by Ruskin; see 41:177TC to JRU, 25 Feb. (not too interesting to the soul) under shelter of a bushy Hedge. In the evg, all grey then, & threatening rain, Mary drove me round in their old Gig (pony price £6, & fully as swift as yr mare) JWC’s mare, Bellona, cost £45; see 41:212JWC to LLA, 17 April. to the end of Annan; & after tea & a short walk, I resumed my Lyell. Enough Oh dear soul; what is all this but a wasting of yr time & my
own! I am out for a ride agn; wind high, rain keeping off:—don’t fear Noggs: no danger,—less than ever, I do protest. Tomorrow I will not write; but am in hopes of a Note from Chels Chelsea: “Chels” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. how can I “hope” for good news;—but I do agn hope! Mary thanks with emphasis for her Pictures &c; Jamie thanks too (of Scotsbrig). God bless thee Dearest—
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 6 June. Addr: Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 6 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.689. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Oh my Dearest, I am a distressed man today!Not the least news from you since the date Saturday (ruin by watchdog, & flight from Streatham home); today nothing to me but Newspapers all in a huddle: “handwriting far worse agn!” I say to myself; “the two magazines thrown in witht stamps on them, &c &c;—all signs, in short, that my poor little Jeannie is still sleepless & in worse misery than ever!”—

By ill luck, too,I agn tried porridge to supper, last night; and have lost nearly all my sleep, whh seemed beautifully coming back to me:—and will come; only that my ghastly nerves for the time make everything doubly ghastly.— Oh write me one word; one line will do, if it is too painful to you.

I had such a beautiful ride too, yesterday; & had taken such pains: I shall take care of “porridge” agn; this is the third time it has served me so in these five days.— Tush, never mind all that; the sorrow of my heart, the care of cares is to know how (and even where) you are. Mary is going for Dumfries; I will agn ride, rather than read. Weather gray & breezy, not unpleast. Oh that I might have a word of goodish news! God bless thee.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 6 June. MS: NLS 609.716. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote later at the top of both the first and last pages: “beging of june 1865.”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
It is rather hard to know a letter from you will be lying at Cheyne Row at the moment, and I not to get hold of it till Mr Silvester John Silvester, livery stable owner, who drove JWC’s carriage. comes at two oclock.
It is also rather hard to think what blessings you will have bestowed on me this morning when your magazines and Papers were delivered; all charged double! Items sent unstamped were charged double on receipt. The Carlyles took several newspapers and magazines among which were British Quarterly (see 29:192TC to JF, 7 Nov. 1854), the Examiner (see 26:212TC to JAC, 18 Oct. 1851), Public Opinion (see 40:103TC to HL, [21 May 1864]), and Punch; the latter had been sent to Betty Braid’s invalid son, George, until his death in Feb. It was not entirely my fault; I made them up on the Sunday morning before I left for Tooting, having had some sleep, more or less refreshing, in my own quiet Bed, and therewith gained courage to try again my beautiful Bedroom here, under the new condition of that Dog shut up in a distant Wash House. I had no stamps with me, and on Sunday could not get any. So I laid the packets all together in a corner to have the stamps put on them when I should come in next day to inspect my painters, if indeed another wholly sleepless did not drive me home for good. At night it flashed on me that Mrs Warren or Fanny seeing the heap might take them to the post office before I came. And so I got Mrs Macmillan to write a note to Mrs Warren bidding her not to . But when the note reached Cheyne Row, the things had been already all posted by Mrs Warren when she had gone out at seven of the morning to fetch the sweeps!!! Either chimney sweeps or sweeping brushes.

I must “hasten to the catastrophe.” Coterie speech. I would not for anybody’s sake but yours, give myself such horrid pain as writing at present causes me. If by letting alone writing I could only escape the pain! but it is continual, and poig­nant even when I do nothing.

The two last nights, nothing Outward has disturbed me— A better sleeping place could not be desired now the dog is removed if only one could take advantage of its freshness and its silence. But the wretched arm awakes me like an evil conscience! These two last nights however I have made out some three hours by help of a stiff tumbler of very good whisky toddy which Mr Macmillan mixes for me and is given me after I get into bed. They are good, kind, simple people, and would take any trouble to relieve me— I will inclose a plan of treatment from Dr Blakiston but must beg you not to lose it, but to send it back in the next letter! I may need it by and by—but just yet, it would be unfair to Dr Quain to interrupt his prescriptions with a new and violent remedy—

I also inclose two Vignettes of me, Presumably more of the Elliott & Fry photographs; see TC to JWC, 7 June. which must be returned with your opinion as to which is best—put a mark on the back of the one you like best—

Froude cannot bear your bust Woolner’s bust of TC; see 18. —theonly person who has sense to think of
it just as I do I shall take this open to Chelsea in case of finding there anything to be added—
docBody.name: J W C Turn over

ps.p: 5 Cheyne Row

Here I am and have got your letter! Sh you——Muff! Mary Florence Baring’s nickname for JWC; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [7 May]; also a name for a foolish or incompetent person. The “hand perfectly firm” was Geraldine’s! and you to not know that! See TC to JWC, 5 June. Today’s letter is directed by Mrs Macmillan (in case you compliment me on my copper-plate case!)
Mr Royston continues hanging betwixt Life and Death—
I can only make plans, from day to day just now. My days are so ruled by my nights. Among so many kind people I am sure to fall on my feet.
That black and white trowser cloth is all cotton the other vulgar For TC’s questions about ordering clothes, see TC to JWC, 5 June.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 7 June. Addr: Macmillan Esq / Streatham Lane, Tooting / London. PM: Annan, 7 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.690. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:287; Bliss, TC 377.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I am delighted, my poor Dear, to understand you to be again at Tooting, and to hope you are getting a little sleep there, now that your howling foe is quashed, and safe in his wash-house! There cd not be a nearer approach to Country, had you gone 20 miles from London; and one of the surest alleviations always has been that of altogether changing place and ways. I only wish you had more completely done with Chelsea & its cares & circs in the interim: but you seem to be going on with your “painting” there just the same,—you disobedt little Cutty! And you jeer at me, and call me some name (whh I cannot quite read, but whh seems abundantly bad, and unworthy of the dignity of genius) Muff; see JWC to TC, 6 June. because I did not detect Geraldine’s handwriting, but took poor Mary’s glad word for it, and laid it by on the mantel-piece as a blessed memorial,—till this morning, when indeed it plainly enough appeared to be G.’s, and I burnt it. Oh you—!— But if you sleep a little, I will forgive you everything.

Last night, by great precautions, and by a narrow miss, I recovered my own sleep in some measure; and am no longer in the hag-ridden conditn of yesterday: cd I once fairly get assured reasonably of my 6 hours sleep (alas, poor soul, and you have to be doing with 3! as I often recollect while watching);
or if, whh is the same thing, I come fitted into my new style of diet, and shd get a great benefit here. I have continually (& silently) the kindest treatt from every soul abt me; the silence of the roads, the fields, the rides & walks, is perfectly divine. Not a sound all night, except, at stated times the grinding brief clash of that railway, See JWC to TC, 1 June. —whh, if I hear it at all, is as a lash or loud crack of that Mammon’s-whip, going at prest over all the earth on the enslaved backs of men, I alone enfranchised from it, nothing to do but hear it, savagely clashing, breaking God Almighty’s Silence, in that fatal & tragic manner, saying (not to me), “Ye accursed slaves!”— Today is charming, Sun & sky unsurpassable; Austin James Austin. going to gig me, were I done with this; nothing from Noggs till after dinner, so warm is it. Be good, & let us be thankful. Yr affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-GS [GSC], 7 June. MS: Heinz Archive and Library, National Portrait Gallery, London. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 6:11. TC wrote on the reverse of the letter: “To G. Scharf Esq, Secy &c.” George Scharf (1820–95; ODNB ), sec. of the National Portrait Gallery 1857–95. TC became a trustee of the gallery in 1857; see 32:100TC to LA, 9 March 1857.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE SCHARF

docBody.p: If the Trustees are unanimous for a Portrait of Father Matthew, Theobald Mathew (1790–1856; ODNB), Irish Capuchin friar and temperance campaigner. I could by no means think of standing in the way, by myself, of such a desire and determinatn on their part. Otherwise I must, for my own share, confess to serious doubts whether Father Mw, author merely of temporary vow agt whisky in various quarters, For TC’s encounter with one of Father Mathew’s temperance meetings, 1843, see 16:315TC to JWC, [25] July 1843; for JWC’s encounter with him at another temperance meeting, see 17:17–20JWC to JW, 6 Aug. 1843. can have solid claims to a place among the great men of the British Nation.

I dissent, therefore, or I assent, according to the already state of the matter in Committee,—whh let our noble Presidt Philip Henry Stanhope (1805–75; ODNB ), 5th Earl Stanhope, historian and politician, chairman of the trustees of the National Portrait Gallery 1857–75. please to interpret for me in my absence. Edward Daniel Leahy (1797–1875; ODNB ), artist, wrote to Scharf, 8 May, asking the trustees to buy the painting: “I painted it at his residence in Cork in Jany 1846 from the life, it is the Original & never has been copied. Exhibited in the Royal Academy in 1847. Price 20 Gs.” The painting was bought in June; on the list of the trustees in favor was written: “Mr Carlyles to be accepted favourably” (Heinz Archive and Library, NPG). For the portrait, see Mathew’s ODNB entry.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: GEJ-TC, 7 June. MS: NLS 609.717. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:264.
div3.head: GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY TO TC

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea / S.W June 7–1865 Wednesday
docBody.p: You will be disappointed tosee my handwriting TC noted later on MS: “7 june 1865 (in Geraldine’s hand).” instead of Jane’s but today it is not a matter of choice but of necessity for the pain & swelling in her hand & fingers makes them entirely helpless. & she has to feed herself with her left hand—she has just come in with Mrs Macmillan and has been selecting a paper for the Dining room she encloses the three patterns wh we all think the prettiest of those submitted to us—and she says will you please to say which of the three you like the best?— I think Jane is a shade better than when she went last Friday—but still today she is very poorly & pulled down by the pain—wh seems to increase She wd sleep if it were not for that—she does manage to sleep a little every thing she says is most charming comfortable & the Dog has been reduced to silence. My great hope is in Scotland and she seems to look forward to going wh in itself a good thing— Please to address yr next letter to Streatham Lane as they are delayed by coming here first—

closer.salute: I am dear Mr Carlyle Yr very respectful

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 8 June. Addr:—Macmillan Esq / Streatham Lane, Tooting, / London. PM: Annan, 8 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.691. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 2:287; Bliss, TC 377.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Today I try to persuade myself both that the misery may perhaps be “gout,” and also, with still more confidence, that the swelling is a sign the pain will soon abate. Swelling, I imagine, is usually the preliminary that way in all kinds of pain. Heaven grant it may prove so now! Geraldine says See GEJ to TC, 7 June. you get some fractions of sleep in spite of all; that you are comfortably dealt with, and that your watchdog is eliminated, I can well believe: but as to the “fractions of sleep,” I shd wish confirmatn in a more specific form; and fear the fractions are but very limited. Courage, my poor Dear; we are a pair of miserable creatures, but we must not lose heart!—

I am myself getting into quite an insoluble conditn as to sleep; last night agn, for no reason that I can divine, there was a vigilance too notable;—till after 6 a.m., when I rose and bathed (uncertn whether not to walk out into the breezy summer morning, had my limbs encouraged, whh they didn’t): I thereupon drank a tumbler of the purest spring water, flung on my rug—as blanket, additl, and crept into bed agn,—and gradually sank into 2½ hours of thrice-welcome sleep. Probably I shall pick up a little more thro’ the day. Something strange is going on with the liver of me; I will be at the bottom of it by degrees; “milk-diet” is not the secret of it; yesterday I lived quite as at home: coffee (excellt), mutton (tolerable but hard fried), tea (moderate & right), finishing at midnight with hot milk just as at Chelsea. For most part, I think this crisis whh is abundantly disappointing to me, means a new and improved directn to the inner man, once his old impedimenta are well washed away.

Poor Mary made an expeditn to Dumfries the day before yesterday, not hinting for what; & yesterday not to speak of new pipes, new riding switch, new towels, new excellt potatoes equal to our own,—there was standing in the room, when I came in from driving, an excellt haircloth mahogany sofa, fit for the largest figure; on whh I had a nap (after dinner yesty) & intend farther to have several. Price was “£3. .17. .6; belonged to an old Leddy in Buccleugh Street,—clean & fair as new”! Is not this a clever stroke of poor kind Mary?— The wind is up today, but all else is silent; the twilight yesterday (9 to 10 p.m.), while I walked in the Asphodel meadows of Hades In Greek mythology the meadows of Asphodel lie in the underworld, home to the disembodied souls of men who now rest from their labors; cf. Homer, The Odyssey bk. 24. (Genl Wade’s old excellt
turnpike George Wade (1673–1748; ODNB ), army officer, commander-in-chief in Scotland from 1724, implemented a program of road-making, 1725–38, as part of the process of ruling the Highlands after the 1715 Jacobite rebellion; see 22:64TC to JAC, 12 Sept. 1847. all my own), was superior to Solomon & his glory, Cf. Matt. 6:29. all of sapphire & molten gold.— — Adieu, Darling, there is no use continuing this upon thee. Oh sleep! I will forgive all pain (if it is only human), provided you can sleep: but agony of pain witht sleep: oh dear, dear! “Stout heart to staye brae,” Proverbial; see 4:325TC to AC, 19 Feb. 1828. however:—we havehad a brae or two of that kind, haven’t we, my Darling, since we took the road together! God bless thee ever & ever.
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 8 June. MS: NLS 609.718. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:324–25 inc. Letter ­written in Caroline or Frances Macmillan’s hand; writing practice at end in JWC’s left hand.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I wonder that weare not brought up to use our two hands equally, the same as our two eyes and two ears, there is no natural impossibility, and “it would be a great advantage” Coterie speech; see 35:217TC to JAC, 25 Sept. 1859. (put that in ticks), JWC’s instruction to Mrs. Macmillan. anyhow I must learn to write with my left hand legibly at least, the right having entirely struck work; for it is not now a question of pain merely; but of utter powerlessness as well. I foresaw that it would come to that! so I am not shocked as you may fancy, I dare say a quarter of an hour’s practise two or three times a day for a week or so, will deliver me from the absurd necessity of having to call in the assistance of the neighbourhood to communicate my bits of news to you; not to say that dictation is only a degree less awkward than left handed penmanship, having never tried it before in my life

You perceive that I amstill here and you will infer from that, that I find it good to be here but as it is Mrs Macmillan who is writing for me, it would be too barefaced to give any glowing description of either the pleasantness of the place or the kindness of the people; I shall only say what you will be glad to hear that I am getting into the way of sleeping for snatches, after three o’clock,
which I attribute, under Providence, to a wine glassful of essence of beef, which is placed by my bed side every night and which I take when I awake at three with the feeling of doing it for good; it is simply the juice of beef without any water at all. As for the pain I am sorry I cannot compliment myself on its being in the least better, it has been and continues more severe than I ever had it before, it wears me to fiddlestrings and takes all “good joy” Coterie speech; see 10:167JWC to TC, [9 Sept. 1838]. out of my life, but it does not take the life itself out of me as the old nervous misery did, I always said, better any amount of acute pain than that and I say so still now when the acute pain is here, I am going home in an hour or two to look after my workmen, they go on better when expecting me to drop down upon them at any hour, my further plans it may be interesting not to state, Coterie speech; see 22:186TC to RMM, 30 Dec. 1847. except just this much that I leave here on Monday but you need be under no apprehension about the paint as Mrs Blunt Frances Blunt, wife of Gerald Blunt, rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea. has given me a bedroom at the Rectory, indeed everybody is so kind to me that so far as human kindness can avail you may always feel assured that I am all right, falling on my feet like any cat. Mr Wilson of The Globe dined here last night looking as terrified at being alive as ever, twenty years have taken no effect upon his shyness. John Wilson, editor of the Globe and Traveller; the Carlyles were friendly with him in the 1830s; see 8:10TC to JAC, 12 Jan. 1835. He lived at The Laurels, Upper Tooting, near the Macmillans.

Your sentenceaboutthe photographs is perfectly unintelligible to an ordinary mind, the epithet which you could not read was simply—“Muff” See JWC to TC, 6 June. “I add no more but remain / Your obedient humble servant ” Coterie speech; the ending of a young preacher’s sermon; see “Budget of a Femme incomprise” (29:258JWC to TC, [12 Feb. 1855]) and “The simple Story” where JWC included an explanatory note (30:194JWC’s Simple Story). / Jane Carlyle
Signature in JWC’s hand.

ps.p: My kind love to Mary Postscript in Mrs. Macmillan’s hand.

Lesson 1st JWC’s practice at writing with her left hand; see opp.above.
Jane Welsh Carlyle’s practice at writing with her left hand, 8 June 1865
Courtesy of theNational Library of Scotland
I must learn to write with my left hand and then when I have learnt, perhaps I shall recover the use of my right. The surest way of getting & then of learning to become so
Jane Jane Baillie Baillie Welsh Thus in MS; see opp.above. Jane Baillie Welsh was JWC’s signature before marriage.
I wonder why we are not brought up to use both our hands equally
Lesson 2

Dearest. How do you do? I hope you are pretty well I am not. But I do not
despair of getting some later It is a very fine day. Mr Macillan sings most beautiful Whisky good. I have seen the Palgrave Traveller “Macillan”: thus in MS. JWC apparently met William Gifford Palgrave (1826–88; ODNB ), traveler and diplomat, at the Macmillans’; his Narrative of a Year’s Journey through Central and Eastern Arabia (1862–63), 2 vols. (1865), just pbd. by Macmillan & Co., was reviewed in the Athenaeum, 10 June.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 June. Addr: Macmillan Esq / Streatham Lane, Tooting / London S. PM: Annan, 9 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.692. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:287–88; Wilson, Carlyle 6:13; Bliss, TC 378; Ashton 439.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest, for the struggle you have made to get me a word of authentic tidings sent. I can read perfectly your poor little left-hand “Lessons,” See 71. & really wonder atthe progress you have made. Don’t be “impious,” however! Yr poor right hand will be restored to you, please God; and we may depend upon it, neither the coming nor the going in such cases goes by the rule caprice. Alas, what a time have we all got into! I finished, last night, the dullish thick Book (longwinded tho’ intelligt) of Lyell; and the tendency of it, very impotent, was upon the whole to prove that we are much the same as Apes; that Adam was probably no other than a fortunate Ourang-Outang who succeeded in rising in the world. Lyell’s argument in The Geological Evidence of the Antiquity of Man (see TC to JWC, 5 June) was more cautious than TC indicated. He was primarily interested in geological evidence for the antiquity of the human race, but in the final five chapters of the book, he discussed the Darwinian controversy “as to the degree of resemblance between the brain of man and that of apes.” He concluded: “Separated as a group of ordinal value, placed at the same distance from the ape as the latter from the carnivore, Man is at once too near and too distant from the higher mammalia;—too near if we take into account those elevated faculties, which, raising Man above all other organized beings, accord to him not only the first, but a separate place in the creation,—too far if we merely consider the organic affinities which unite him with the quadrumana; with the apes especially, which, in a purely physical point of view, approach Man more nearly than they do the lemurs” (475). May the Lord confound all such dreary insolences of loquacious Blockheadism entitling itself “Science”! Science, or the understanding of things worth knowing, was once a far difft matter from this melancholy maundering, & idle poking into the Unknowable (an[d] Letter omitted. apparently the not worth knowing)!— But to return.

In spite of the swelling, there is no abatet of the pain, it seems, alas, my hopes go faster than the facts;—but I still keep assuring myself that this of swelling is a preliminary to good. And you do sleep a little, if only by snatches:
thank Mrs Macmn for me; & let us both be thankful to Heaven. I will address to Chelsea after this: tomorrow it will be needless; nor is Sunday (yr Monday) a day to be depended on, but I will neglect no chance that may rise.

I am again richer by 7 hours of (piecemeal) sleep, whh is an unspeakable favour to me! I tried on porridge agn last night, having really no other resource; went to bed trembling,—and by steadiness & good luck did fall asleep. I dare not yet trust in a continuance, so kranky is all my footing and environt here; but if I cd steadily conquer sleep, it too wd surely “be a great advantage” to me. On the whole I have been sorrowfully bothered with that fundamental item ever since leaving Chelsea; & that was a point I had no doubt abt, little knowing what was ahead. Things are sombre & sad to a degree, when sleep goes, & this “Hades,” in such case, cd not call itself an Elysium by any means! The Dumfries people Jean and James Aitken and family. do not come near me; out of respect to my solitude, I do know; for I am in the tacit obligatn to give them permission & notice when I want visit.

Yesternight, before tea, a gurly windy evg with Sun gone veiled, I took Noggs a canter of 10 or 12 miles: ride swift mostly, and on roads all my own (over the place where your crazy vehicle came in two) For JWC’s carriage accident, July 1864, see 40:141JWC to TC, [19 July 1864]. round by Howes, Howes, farm 1 mi. (1.5 km.) W of Annan. and the western edge of Annan: poor old Annan, there the old Houses stood, a bleared evg Sun shining as if in anger on them; but the disagreeable mostly paltry living creatures, who used to vex me in those days, were all gone. The old “Academy House,” TC, a pupil at Annan Academy, 1806 –9, and then a teacher of mathematics, 1814–16, was not happy there; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 34, 89, and 356. The original academy, founded in 1802, was on Port St. until 1820, when new premises were built nearby on Ednam St. what a considerable stride to the new Academy I have been in for some time, & am thinking soon to quit! Presumably by “new Academy” TC meant his attempts to educate the public through his writings, which he possibly saw as completed. Good night, ye of the paltry type, ye of the lovely too; good, and good only, be with you all!— Noggs & I, after these reflexions, started at a mighty pace for Cummertrees, wind howling direct in our faces; and were there in a jiffy,—just as a luggage train was passing, amid tempests of muddy smoke, at a rate of abt 50 miles an hour, and with a shrieking storm of discord peerless elsewhere for rolling madness,—whh Noggs cd not but pause, of his own accord, to watch the passage of, with a mixture of wonder and abhorrence. The waving of the woods abt Glen & Kelhead, Glen, an estate 3 mi. (5 km.) NW of Annan, and Kelhead, an estate 3 mi. (5 km.) WNW of Annan. grandly soughing with windy sunset, soon hushed the mind both of me & Noggs to a better tone if not a much a gladder.

You see, Dearest, I have not got anything to say; and in my prest circs you will like me better reading Marie Antoinette, or trying it agn (Miss Bromley’s Book, TC possibly borrowed Caroline Davenport Bromley’s copy of Alexander Baillie Cochrane’s Historic Pictures, 2 vols. (1865). An essay in vol. 1, “The Conciergerie, 1770–93” (171–318), contained an extensive biographical portrait of Marie Antoinette (1755–93), queen of France 1774–92, guillotined 1793. Otherwise unidentified. whom please visit & make my respects to), than scribbling you stuff like this,—drawn merely from the “Cave of my Slumbers,” Cf. Milton, “Ad Patrem” line 15. whh in genl it is best to leave sleeping. Yr descriptn of poor Wilson is perfect, complete with one stroke; if you see him agn, give him my remembrances from of old. Palgrave the Traveller is said not to be such a gander as he of the Arts & Eloquences; you shall tell me of him one day. Francis Turner Palgrave (1824–97; ODNB ), anthologist and art critic; he selected and arranged with notes The Golden Treasury of the Best Songs and Lyrical Poems in the English Language (1861), published by Macmillan & Co.; he was the older brother of William Gifford Palgrave (the traveler) whom JWC apparently met at the Macmillans; see JWC to TC, 8 June. Make my respects to the Rector & that kind Lady Rector: Gerald and Frances Blunt; see JWC to TC, 8 June. may you read my next Letter there in better case than you are like to read this before changing billet. Oh me, oh me! And don’t call me that name agn, for that is not proper. “Muff”; see JWC to TC, 6 June and 8 June. As well as being Mary Florence Baring’s pet name for JWC, it also means a foolish or incompetent person. And send myblacklead. TC’s Bramah pencil; see TC to JWC, 7 June. The Photograph writing in blue meant “This Phh” (now in yr hands) “has the better pose & the better expression”;—the other I keep here on the mantel-piece. Adieu, Dearest: /
T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 June. Addr: MacMillan Esq / Streatham Lane / Tooting / London. PM: Annan, 11 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.693. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:289; Bliss, TC 378–79; Ashton 439.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My Darling,—Alas, that poor right-hand, lamed swollen, & full of pain! This morning, after a blink of bright hope, I had to take my bit of disappointt. Poor Mary, in her silent way, had despatched an Express to Annan this morning, to be in attendance at the half-hour there is of Post-Office (from 9 to 9½ a.m., letters given out, if you are there then): abt 11, breakfast done, Mary came out with a small Letter, accordingly; in Geraldine’s hand,—and with the Bramah Pencil duly in it, & the Harrow-Speeches busss, The Harrow “Speech Day” was an annual event at which extracts from the classics and modern literature were declaimed, encouraging the pupils in public-speaking skills; in 1865 it was to be on 6 July; the “busss” is unexplained; the “Speech Bill” for Harrow, 1865, listed various Greek and Latin trans., various prizes, the speech of Sir Robert Peel (1788–1850; ODNB ) on resigning office, June 1846, and the speech of William Pitt (1759–1806; ODNB ) against the slave trade, April 1792. The 1862 speeches had been focused on the French Revolution; possibly TC’s The French Revolution was used then. & nothing more whatever.
Not a stroke even, much less a word. But I deserved it all; cd understand sadly that it meant for me, “No change, especially none for the better!” And so it has to stand till Tuesday morning at soonest.

I know not that I can do you the least good by writing this word; but, if I ride to Annan before 4 p.m., it will arrive before you quit Tooting, as a poor useless salutation from me; and it will do my own heart good to take the little trouble tho’ fruitless. I am out of my Sleep-quandaries agn, or nearly so; had a fine share of not much-disunited sleep last night,—wd my poor worn wearied Goody cd have had the half of it!—and am so pointed and attentive to my eatings, to my ridings, walkings and procedures, I expect now really to begin reaping profit; & indeed seem to feel that I am already on a clearer way after my late complicated crisis. My rides are very strange, in the mood so foreign as mine. Last night (6 to 8 p.m.) was a perfect whirlwind, as the day had been, tho otherwise fair & genial: I went, for the first time, by the Priestside sands; Priestside Sands, Solway Firth, about 2 mi. (3 km.) S of The Gill. Noggs had some reluctanceto put forth his speed in the new element; stormy tempest on the right eye, on the left the far-off floods of Solway; Criffel & the mountains with the foreground of flat-sand (in parts white with salt) right ahead: but I made the dog go; & had really a very interesting gallop; as difft from that of Rotten Row Bridle path in Hyde Park, London. as cd well be. “O rugged all-supporting mother!” says Orestes, addressing the Earth. Quotation untraced; in Greek mythology Orestes murdered his mother to avenge his father, and is the subject of many plays and stories. One has now no other sermon in the world, not a mockery and a sham, but that of these telluric & celestial silences, broken by such winds as there may be.— I had meant to ride my sands earlier in the day; but just as Noggs was stepping out, arrived John & Jean. John A. Carlyle and Jean Aitken, on a visit from Dumfries. They had heard nothing, had not liked to disturb my solitude: poor souls, they were very kind & gentle to me,—all the more as they had hardly two hours & a half to stay: perhaps the best length of visit, as times now go! I strolled with them thro’ the woods to near Cummertrees; saw, as I strode back, a white handkerchief flying from a window of the next up train (Dr John’s); to whh I waved my hat in reply,—& there was finis on those poor terms. Poor, ah me; & in our haggly posture, they are the richest & best desirable: what a poverty, even in beautiful human things; whh is pathetic to think
of!— — If tomorrow after getting home, you can find anybody to dictate a little (a very little will suffice),—or if nobody is there, & yr poor left hand is equal to one word, oh send it. That left hand shall now be the dearer to me, till the other mend at least for writing. I still believe the swelling must take away the pain; that is the rule in most things, especially in “gout.” If it please God, my poor Dear’s right hand shall soon be restored to me; meantime I kiss it, with my prayers. Adieu, Dearest. All manner of thanks to yr kind Hosts. God keep you
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 June]. MS: NLS 609.720. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:265–66. TC wrote later on MS: “rec’d june 12 1865,” in error for 13 June; see TC to JWC, 13 June.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I will write before returning home. There will be neither peace nor time there. Thanks! I never needed more to be made of! I must tell you about my hand. You think the swelling more important than it is. The two middle fingers were much as now for some weeks before you left; but with the thumb and forefinger I could still do much; now the forefinger is as powerless and pained as the other two—that is all the difference. But a conclusive one for one can do nothing with only a thumb! I could sometimes sit down and cry. The pain—the chief pain—that which wakes me from my sleep is in the shoulder and forearm. Even hopeful Dr Quain does not tell me I shall soon get back my hand—only tells me blandly I must learn to write with my left, and it was he who told me to take a black lead pencil. “In pencil, with the left hand, and already well done.—T.C.” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:265). I went to him on Friday by appointmentwhen I had finished the antifebrile powders. I think they have quietened me. He gave me a bumper of Champagne was kind as kind could be. Desired me to try the quinine once more. Said Dr Blakiston’s prescription was an “admirable suggestion” and well worth my trying but as it would cause me a good deal of pain and feverishness I had better wait “till after my journey to Scotland” He does me real good by his kindness.

My visit here has been as great success so far as depended on my Host and Hostesses and I am certainly better in my general health for all the nourishing things they have put into me by day and by night. It is a place where you could fly to in a bilious crisis—quiet as Heaven when the dog is in the Wash House.

Bellona (my Mare) has given me a fine fright You would never believe she
was not safe to be left It has been the nearest miss of herself and the carriage all smashed to pieces! She has escaped miraculously without a scratch. The carriage has not been so fortunate. I am not up to writing the narrative today
Love to my dear kind Mary
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 June. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 13 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.694. Quot: Bliss, TC 379.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest! The old deaf Postman Possibly William Rule (b. ca. 1801), listed in 1861 census as “Post office Runner,” although he was around six years younger than TC. (deaf as a doornail, but very gleg met me this morning with yr expected message,—right welcome, in the bonny summer morning, to one otherwise so sick of heart. It is a mingled yarn, bad enough in parts; but on the whole better rather than worse. I am very thankful for it;—all written with the left hand too, poor little soul! It is in itself touching; wonderful too how well you have already learned to do it: I can read every word. The Streatham visit has really been of use; Quain & it have rather “quietened” matters, whh surely is importt. Courage; do not cry over your poor little right hand; it will come back to us, all the dearer for its absence; meanwhile how shiftily you at once contrive to help us with the left! On the whole, all seems to point towards Holmhill; and I own I wish I saw you there. If you find it likely to be useful, why not come off at once? There is in real truth, so far as I am concerned, nothing to detain you in that broiling noise, and dirty atmosphere of paint, one day longer. I have no care whatever abt how I may find my sitting room in Chelsea when I return. If I cd find poor Goody sitting there, as well as she returned to me last year, JWC returned to Chelsea from Holmhill overnight, 30 Sept.–1 Oct. 1864; see 41:57–59JWC to TC, 29 Sept., TC to LLA, 30 Sept., and JWC to MR, [3 Oct. 1864]. that is all I am concerned abt! You do not tell me your plans; don’t till you feel it right; but of course I am anxious enough to know.—— What is this that your “Bellona” (with a malison to her!) has been doing? I tremble to think; Had you been in the carriage,—as I trust you were not! Always take somebody with you, to open doors & ring bells;—and oh, let Silvester be careful. Out upon it; what a trick of the brute!— Speaking of “tricks,” pray hand in that mem. to the excellt Fredk: Presumably Frederic Chapman, about more delayed copies of Frederick; see JWC to TC, 30 May. is not he a man for punctuality? I begin to think, if he go on at this rate, I shall actually have to quit him by & by; and seek a more human “man of busss.” But whisper nothing of that.

I am going on better here; getting my sleep back, & I suppose doing myself
good in respect of health, tho’ still in a rather tremulous state of nerves; and altogether sombre, sad & vacant as I seldom was in my life before. The writing-apparatus, too,—you may see how detestable, with a hand given to shake:—alas, what is “shaking,” to other states we know of; if my poor Jeannie’s hand only shook!— The truth is, I am solutary as I wished to be; and do not object to the gloom & dispiritt going down to the utterly dark; if they like to rest there, let them. The world has become, in many parts, hideous to me; its highest heights no longer looks very high to me: only my poor heart, strange to say, is not very much blunted by all it has got; in the depths of silent sadness, I feel as if there were still as much love in me (all gone to potential tears) as there ever was at my earliest day. But silence as to all that. I go riding, walking &c at a great and faithful rate; am very careful of my diet: am most lovingly served, and excelltly well let alone: what more cd I wish, in my prest state of mind & body? Truly nothing.

On Saturday John & Jean came suddenly out, having heard nothing from me:—I must write today, having put it off yesterday; therefore despatch here! On sunday Jamie of Scotsbrig came, a second time; bringing over “Catherine” Catherine, Mary and James Austin’s da. (his new House Keeper) to see her people withal. He was rather cheery both times, rather entertaining,—really the most so of all I have met in these parts! A man of natural sincerity, & sense, with touches of real humour in him. He talked even abt Frk (the Great) in a way to please me for a few moments; nobody I have spoken to had as much that looked worthy & true to say abt the matter yet. It was he and I, in a Gig (not I by myself on horseback), that went to Annan with yr Letter that afternoon: the air, temperate, greyish & quiet, the roads nearly altogether vacant, not so much as a turnpike to check one’s noble rage.— I am still (languidly) in the enterprize of clothes; decided to make a minimum of it serve. Noggs & I have been twice on the sands; a most windy, dustless element, smooth as paper: even the rugged Noggs seemed kindled by it, & made some pretty galloping. I have plenty of Books; hadn’t I better have been at them than wearying you with all this? God keep thee, Dearest; if anything come to tomorrow, I will try to send a word; if not, not. Yr affecte
T. Carlyle

ps.p: Ld Stanley, I suppose, ought to be thanked? JWC perhaps enclosed a note from Lord Stanley congratulating TC on the completion of Frederick; otherwise unexplained. If you cd, thro’ any of them? Bessy Paulet is in what they call a “gushing” mood. This is probably the letter from Emilie Venturi to JWC that TC took for a letter from Elizabeth Paulet (whom JWC had met again recently after many years [see JWC to TC, 24 May]); see JWC to TC, 28 June; or perhaps JWC enclosed a letter from Paulet written after their meeting. Remember Tawell, & look twice! Presumably John Tawell (1784–1845), the Salt Hill murderer; see 24:302JWC to JF, [1 Dec. 1849]. The instruction is unclear; possibly some reference to JWC returning to London and taking omnibuses, therefore needing to “look twice” at the roadside. Tawell was caught after taking an omnibus. —

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 14 June. MS: RWEMA. Pbd:Slater, CEC 543–45; Wilson, Carlyle 6:13–15.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: Tho’ my hand is shaking (as you sadly notice), I determine to write you a little Note today. What a severance there has been these many sad years past!— In the first days of February I ended my weary Book; a totally worn-out man, got to shore agn after, far the ugliest sea he had ever swum in. In April or the end of March, when the Book was published, I duly handed out a Copy for Concord & you: it was to be sent by Mail; but, as my Publisher (a new Chapman, very unlike the old), Frederic Chapman; TC previously dealt with Frederic’s uncle, Edward Chapman. disclosed to me lately an incredible negligence in such points, it is quite possible the dog may not, for a long while, have put it in the Post-Office (tho’ he faithfully charged me the postage of it, and was paid), and that the poor Waif may never yet have reached you! Patience; it will come soon enough,—there are two thick Volumes, & they will stand you a great deal of reading, stiff, rather than “light.” Emerson replied, 7 Jan. 1866: “your letter deeply interested me, with the account of your rest so well-earned. You had fought your great battle, & might roll in the grass, or ride your pony, or shout to the Cumberland or Scottish echoes, with largest leave of men & gods. … I read [Frederick] in the bright days of our new peace. … I found in the book no trace of age, which your letter so impressively claimed. In the book, the hand does not shake, the mind is ubiquitous. The treatment is so spontaneous, selfrespecting defiant—liberties with your hero, as if he were your client, or your son, & you were proud of him, & yet can check & chide him, & even put him in the corner when he is not a good boy,—freedom with kings, & reputations, & nations, yes, & with principles too—that each reader, I suppose, feels complimented by the confidences with which he is honored by this free-tongued masterful Hermes” (Slater, CEC 546).

Since February last, I have been sauntering abt, inDevonshire, in Chelsea, hither, thither; idle as a dry bone,—in fact, a creature sinking into deeper & deeper collapse, after 12 years of such mulish pulling & pushing; creature now good for nothing seemingly, and much indifferent to being so in permanence, if that be the arrangt come upon by the Powers that made us. Some three or four weeks ago, I came rolling down hither, into this old nook of my Birthland, to see poor old Anna[n]dale Letter omitted by TC. agn with eyes, and the poor remnants of kindred & loved ones still left me there: I was not at first very lucky (lost sleep &c); but am now doing better, pretty much got adjusted to my new element, new
to me since abt six years past,—the longest absence I ever had from it before. TC last visited in Dumfriesshire Sept. 1859. My Work was getting desperate at that time;and I silently said to myself, “We won’t return till it is done, or you are done, my man!”

This is my eldest living For the death of TC’s eldest sister, Margaret (1803–30), see 5:116–20TC to JAC, 29 June 1830. TC described her in his journal, 30 June 1830, as “the best of all my sisters” (5:119–20TC to JAC, 29 June 1830). Sister’s house; Mary Austin at The Gill. one of the most rustic Farmhouses in the world, but abounding in all that is needful to me, especially in the truest silently active affectn, the humble generosity of whh is itself medicine & balm. The place is airy, on dry waving knolls cheerfully (with such water as I never drank elsewhere, except at Malvern): Spa town in the Malvern Hills in Worcestershire. For TC and JWC’s trip to take the waters in Aug. 1851, see 26:116–46TC to EC, 29 July 1851, and the letters that follow to TC to JAC, 27 [28] Aug. 1851. all round me are the mountains, Cheviot & Galloway (30 to 15 miles off), Cumberland & Yorkshire (say 40 & 50, with the Solway brine & sands intervening): I live in total solitude, sauntering moodily in thin checkered woods, galloping abt, once daily, by old lanes & roads,—oftenest latterly on the wide expanses of Solway shore (when the tide is out!) where I see bright busy Cottages far off, houses over even in Cumberland, & the beautifullest amphitheatre of eternal Hills,—but meet no living creature; and have endless thots as loving & as sad & sombre as I like. My youngest Brother (whom on the whole I like best, a rustic man, the express image of my Father in his ways of living & thinking) is within 10 miles of me; James Carlyle at Scotsbrig. Brother John “the Dr” has come down to Dumfries to a Sister Jean Aitken. (12 miles off), & runs down over to me by rail now & then in few minutes. I have Books; but can hardly be troubled with them. Pitiful temporary babble & balderdash, in comparison to what the Silences can say to one. Enough of all that: you perceive me suffictly, at this point point Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. of my pilgrimage, as withdrawn to Hades for the time being; intending a month’s walk there, till the muddy semi-solutions settle into sediment according to what laws they have, & there be perhaps a partial restoratn of clearness. I have to go deeper into Scotland by & by, perhaps to try sailing, whh generally agrees with me: but till the end of Septr I hope there will be no London farther. My poor Wife, who is agn poorly since I left (& has had frightful sufferings, last year especially) will probably join me in this region before I leave it:—and see here, This is authentically the way we figure in the eye of the Sun; and something like what yr spectacles, cd they reach across the Ocean into these nooks, wd teach you of us. There are 3 Photographs whh I reckon fairly like; these are
properly what I had to send you today, Although TC “meant merely to send two Photographs” (see TC to JWC, 14 June), he apparently sent two more later as Emerson acknowledged four, 7 Jan. 1866: “I recognized still erect the wise friendly presence [JWC] first seen at Craigenputtock. … Of your own—the hatted head is good, but more can be read in the head leaning on the hand, & the one in the cloak” (Slater, CEC 548). For a photograph of TC leaning on his hand by Watkins, see 80, and for one by Elliott & Fry, see frontis. For Watkin’s photograph of TC in his wideawake hat, see 13 (reproduced in Slater, CEC IV in a reverse image). For a photograph of TC in his cloak by Elliott & Fry, see 81; for the one sent to Emerson, see Slater, CEC V . For the photograph of JWC by Elliott & Fry sent to Emerson, see 48; Slater reproduced it at CEC IV . —little thinking that so much surplusage wd accumulate abt them; to whh I now at once put an end.
Thomas Carlyle, by John Watkins, April 1865
© National Portrait Gallery, London
Thomas Carlyle in his cape, by Elliott & Fry, [April 1865]
© National Portrait Gallery, London
Yr friend Conway, Moncure Conway. who is a boundless admirer of yrs, used to come our way regularly now & then; and we always liked him well. A man of most gentlemanly, ingenious ways; turn of thot always loyal & manly, tho’ tending to be rather winged than solidly ambulatory. He talked of coming to Scotland too; but it seems uncertn whether we shall meet. He is clearly rather a favte among the London people,—& tries to explain America to them; I know not if with any success. Conway, the abolitionist son of a Virginian slaveholder, was in a good position to argue against slavery; he came to Britain to “represent the moral and political situation as viewed by American antislavery people” (Conway, Autobiography 389). ——— As for me, I have entirely lost count & reckoning of yr enormous element, and its do affairs & procedures, for some time past; & can only wish (whh no man more heartily does) that all may issue in as blessed a way as you hope. Fat Trollope Anthony Trollope; TC did not like him very much; see 40:31TC to JWC, [15 March 1864]. (if you know Trollope Wilson printed “Milnes,” not “Trollope,” both times and added a note identifying Lord Houghton. & his fat comonplace at all) amused me muchby a thing he had heard of yrs in some Lecture a year or two ago: “The American Eagle is a mightly bird; but what is he to the American Peacock!” The lecture, “American Nationality,” was delivered by Emerson in Boston, 12 Nov. 1861 (Slater, CEC 545); Trollope reported attending the lecture in North America (1862), and quoted Emerson: “‘Your American eagle,’ he said, ‘is very well. Protect it here and abroad. But beware of the American peacock’” (1:344). He concluded his comments on the lecture: “On the whole the lecture was excellent, and that little advice about the peacock was in itself worth an hour’s attention” (1:345). —at whh the audience had exploded into laughter. Very good.— Adieu, old Friend.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14 June. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 14 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.695. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—This is no letter; this is merely a salutatn whh I send you to the Rectory, The rectory of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, home of the Blunts. —if by Heaven’s goodness you have had any sleep in yr new bed there! That will make it welcome to you: to me, it is like looking in by the drawing room door, with “Good b’ye, Dear!” before going out to ride.—— —— Today is the warmest we have yet had; but there is a fine breath of wind risen; & I have thots of riding at middle day, not in the evg as most usual. It jumbles me not a little; and surely cannot be so good. I have spent the morning (nr 2 hours of it; shame on me, but my hand shook so so, Repeated at turn of page. for a long while), in writing to Emerson: I meant merely to send him two Photographs; but the matter, spread into detail. Tush!— The Phs I sent are the big Wide-awake (Watkins, of Self) and the beautiful preferred Elliot of you: See 13JWC to LLA, 7 May, and 48TC to JWC, 29 May. I had but that one (came, 29 May; send me 2 or 3 more of it); I cd not think of sending poor Goody otherwise than with her best foot foremost into Yankee land. Adieu, Dearest; Oh for good news tomorrow!— The enclosed newspr column is nothing; a clipping sent by Holyoke the Radical, George Jacob Holyoake (1817–1906; ODNB ), freethinker and leader of the co-operative movement. He was active in campaigning for John Stuart Mill as Liberal candidate for Westminster in the forthcoming general election, 11 July; TC had already refused to support Mill’s election committee; see 41:207TC to JAC, 12 April. on what ground you will see tomorrow when I enclose you his Letter. See TC to JWC, 16 June. — Good be with my Dearest.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 15 June. MS: NLS 517.96. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—You need not keep Jenny’s Letter Probably their sister Janet Hanning. to me I have no farther use for it; Holyoakes, George Jacob Holyoake; see TC to JWC, 14 June. if it had come downtoday, I might have forwarded to Chelsea for a momentary distractn; but it is of no moment. Another of the same, forwarded this morning, I return that John or you may read it or not, but certainly burn. The impertce of dirty snaffles is considerable.

I certainly want a pair of trowsers abt that grist; & wd gladly now set Boyd to his speed, & have done there. Did not yr own Johnny’s Jean’s son John. trowsers whh you shewed me, look fully hopefuller. Suppler, I always mean; but supple cloth has become a myth. Do what you think wisest.

Since Tuesday morning there has been no word at all from Jane: I hope you wrote a legible acct of what the “Bath” Possibly a suggestion of treatment for JWC’s painful arm. was, and how; I have suggested that she might try it, but I doubt she won’t.—— I continue to sleep; walk diligently, ride do;—and if I cannot get a slight improvet out of this month of new, totally new diet & habitude, why I can’t help it— Mary is down to Annan (has shoes, bridles &c, good kind soul); I have been reading Dasent’s Introduction, an extremely gross and stupid piece; will take to the Njala after riding, & hope to find it better much. George Webbe Dasent (1817–96; ODNB ), Scandinavian scholar and translator; he dedicated one of his earlier trans. to TC (see 15:203–4TC to JAC, 25 Nov. 1842). TC had enjoyed his trans. of Norse fables, July 1859 (see 35:147TC to JAC, [14 July 1859]), and he was now reading The Story of Burnt Njal or Life in Iceland at the end of the Tenth Century: From the Icelandic of the Njals Saga, with Introduction, Maps, and Plans, ed. and trans. by G. W. Dasent, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1861). Kind love to all. Yr affecte
T. Carlyle

ps.p: Bring me some Covers when you come; same size as these

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [15 June]. MS: NLS 609.721A. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by TC’s later note on MS: “recd 16 june.”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dont mind that I write no letter in these days I cannot get on with my left hand without plenty of time and composure— And I have neither. I am very busy and bothered. and Geraldine does not come—and Mrs Blunt is not a person one can dictate to

The Rectory JWC was staying with the Blunts while the dining room at 5 Cheyne Row was being decorated; see GEJ to TC, 7 June, and JWC to TC, 8 June. is not so good a place to sleep in as one might have hoped—but I have not lain awake any whole night—
I shall be very glad to get out of the ourie little Bedroom.
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 June. Addr: Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 16 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.696. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
It grieves me, poor Dear, to hear of yr “ourie bedroom,” of yr bad sleeping arrangts:—all due to that villainous Paint-Operation; out of whh I shall never get as much pleasure, as it now, and all along since I first heard of it, gives me pain. Is not my room clear? Alas, no; there will be a proportn of paint in that too,—sorrow on it! The front room agn is too noisy. Cannot, by accurate shutting of the paint doors everywhere, yr own room be made habitable? I long to hear of you in some place where you can fairly try to sleep. You don’t “lie awake the whole night”;—woe’s me, that is a poor maximum! But what is to be done or tried? Except in yr own ingenuity, and especially the wretched Freure’s despatch, there will no light dawn on me.—— This is Friday; we will write no more (from this end) till Monday (for Tuesday morning, if it luck): last Sunday, for a journey of 20 miles, was so unproductive! I am going on really well; I have wholesome victuals (the last 2 nights even a “spark of porridge,” consummate flower of culinary art for me); I walk, read, saunter (sorrowing but not quite meanly Thus in MS. ); daily I get a really rather handsome gallop out of Noggs: if all that won’t help me, nothing. My shoes are all mended, Noggs’s bridle perfect; tomorrow Jean is coming out with the ultimata of tailorings, & I will push Snip The tailor Boyd. to a finis with that paltry matter: all goes well enough with me, if only my poor frail Life-Partner cd get any way of sheltering herself from pain & misery. For the rest, what “news” can I have? None, but such as the above: think of me so, and let my tolerable conditn be a light-point to you while so much else is dark.——— —— This Cameo of you is but a feeble thing; but the standing figure, thank you for this new Copy. Another copy of the photograph of JWC that TC had sent to Emerson. My Maidstone correspondt, Unidentified. with his “interview” & swearing of eternal friendship on the strength of an old Prussn Print, I have slipt into the fire: apparently some species of fiddler & an Irishman, more power to him! Holyoake See TC to JWC, 14 June. too is to remain unanswd; read at last, & burn. Poor Jean seems to be coming out tomorrow, probably to stay till monday: poor kind soul, the no-go of that grand “house” The Hill; TC complained of noise there and presumably did not want to return; see TC to JWC, 5 June. is a stroke to her that pains me. Adieu, Dearest; oh that I had any way of helping thee at all; but it seems I have none. God help thee & me!
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [16 June]. MS: NLS 609.719. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on MS: “17 or 18 june 1865 (enclosing Bank ‘mistake’: poor Jane had passed to Thornhill (Saty 17 june, 12 noon), 2 days before I got this.”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Be patient a little longer and when you hear youll hear!!

The people gave me the eighty 5 pounds at the Bank, TC recorded in his checkbook: “23 May 1865 / To Jane (for House & self; £5 lent me: is to pay Horse in interim) / £85 .. 0 .. 0 / till 6 Augt, only some £2 ‘left’ here!” According to a note in his checkbook, on 6 Aug. he was due £160 .. 14 from Tauchnitz, in part payment for his edn. of Frederick (see TC to EM, 19 May); (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). See also TC to JWC, 21 June. without any remark but I was struck by the long time they were about it looking up ledgers and speaking one with another
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 17 June. Addr: Mr J Austin’s / The Gill / Cummertrees. MS: NLS 609.721B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:266–67.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Here I am! as well as could be expected—after travelling all night, choked in dust! an unprotected Female, with one arm! It is no sudden thought striking me! my mind has been made up to “try a change,” Cf. Helen Mitchell’s phrase “grand change” (25:61), and “try a change,” Dickens, Pickwick Papers, chap. 21. ever since my last interviewwith Dr Quain—and to try it with as little delay as possible. But I would not tell you I was coming because it was important that I should travel by night, and for you to meet me at Carlisle would have necessitated your sleeping there (an impossibility!) or else your starting from the Gill at an unearthly hour. Kindest not to place you in the dilemma! Up to the last moment I schemed about taking the Gill on my road or Dumfries and appointing you to meet me. But I was sure to be awfully tired—just every atom of strength needed to carry me on to Thornhill—without increasing my fatigues by the smallest detours or by any avoidable “emotion of the mind” Cf. Dickens, A Tale of Two Cities, bk. 2, chap. 2. — To stay here a couple of hours and have breakfast and rest and then on, past Cummertrees with shut eyes, to the place of my destination seemed the wisest course. To
this, since my arrival here, has been superadded the sublime idea to throw out a note for you and a sixpence at Cummertrees Cummertrees station was about 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) from The Gill; the station master was Robert Leitch (b. ca. 1825). as it had suddenly flashed on me that no letter from me could reach you by post till Tuesday So soon as I am rested I will make an appointment with you to meet at Dumfries if you would rather not come on to Holmhill
To think that I shall fly past within a quarter of a mile of you presently, and you will have no perception of my nearness!
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 June. Addr: Dr Russell’s / Holmhill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 19 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.697. Hitherto unpbd. TC used a preprinted envelope to The Secretary, National Portrait Gallery, / 29, Great George Street, / Westminster, / S.W., scoring out the add­ress and readdressing to JWC at the Russells’.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, judge if I was astonished yesterday at noon! You were hardly at Dumfries when I had yr Letter. Jean’s train must have met yours nearly opposite this house; Austin TC’s brother-in-law James Austin. was down with the Gig to receive her, and found yr messenger just got on the road. What coursings abt, unexpected meetings, & whirlings to and fro we have! Friday night, till six o’clock a.m., I lay mostly awake; but figured poor Goody in her “ourie bed,” by no means shooting thro’ the world at that wild rate. Oh dear, oh dear! But it was right well done, if only it have proved well. If you have had a sleep, as I pray and hope! Tomorrow morning, it is possible, but not likely, I may hear word from you: otherwise I must wait another day, with what patience there is. At Thornhill from midnight of Sunday, the mails must awaken; but who knows if anybody will then remember it (you cannot), as I do here in regard to Annan? Thus you will get yr London Friday’s Letter, and this both at once, if I ride in the evg to Annan, when the breezes are up & the sun low. And we shall at least see each other agn at the soonest, poor souls!—

The sole purport of this is to say, that I am well enough (my Friday’s sleep adventure a mere scratch, my own blame chiefly, and all made right agn;—& that I will come to you at Thornhill any day you name. I cd fly off tomorrow; but judge it better to let you write first. Wedny will suit me very well; any day will,—only tomorrow I have to give my Snip audience, & get thro’ with those wretched tailorings of his. At noon (by yr own train on the day you fix) I can run to Thornhill (a place wholly agreeable to me from what I saw); & at 7 p.m.
there is a train for Cumertrees agn. Ask Dr R. if it isn’t so (no Bradshaw just here). Oh that I may hear my poor wearied Goody is getting sleep!— God keep you always
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 20 June. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 20 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.698. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: The Newspr has come, and the poor dear lefthand Address (interpreted by Dr R.); not a word more! How glad shd I have been cd you merely have written, “I slept,”—but too probably you cdn’t.—— I had to read the Review; and therewith content myself. The reviewer is a loose-tongued but friendly individual;—just such another is this Scotch congener of the same day, whh I got from John & will despatch you on the chance of yr reading it. Both the newspaper review, sent by JWC, and the similar commentary, sent by John A. Carlyle, are untraced. Each had presumably been pbd. recently.

I had got my newtrowsers ready for setting out tomorrow; but won’t now,—having appointed, “Not till you write.”— Tomorrow, in spite of the heat, I have some thot of trying for Scotsbrig: but I wait for a “better sleep” tonight, if I can manage it. One word as soon as you can.
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Tuesday 20 june (due out, before this).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 20 June. MS: NLS 609.722. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote later in blue pencil on reverse of MS: “abt june 19 (1865).”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Mistaken myDear! After Saturday no mail leaves Thornhill till the Monday morning. And your letter professing itself written on Sunday reaches me here not till Tuesday morning.

I had, as usual, a good sleep the first night after my long journey; fatigue triumphing over the pains in my arm. Sunday night was also an improvement on my Rectory ones; But last night was an entire failure. The pain woke me up twenty minutes before one! and would never let me close my eyes again So today I am in the depths.

When weighed yesterday, I found myself nine pounds lighter than I was before the pain came on me! JWC was weighed regularly while staying at Holmhill in 1864; see 40:220JJWC to TC, [22 Aug. 1864]; in Chelsea she was possibly weighed at the local greengrocer; see 41:85JWC to MR, 31 Oct. 1864.
