As this will not reach you till tomorrow (Wednesday) I will fix Thursday for your coming—some of us will be at the Station at half after twelve I dare say
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 June. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 21 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.699. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest, for the little word: it is not worse than I expected, tho’ surely it is bad; sleep Saturday, poor sleep Sunday, & on Monday wake at 1 a.m.,—woe’s me! But surely things will now soon improve. Mary tells me she had an arm for 5 months or more, whh seems to have been very like yours: miserable pain always, no power oftenest, swelled & then fallen, great loss of sleep from pain:—bone gone wrong, John said; remedy nowhere; at the end of 5 or 6 months it went away of its own will. Courage, Hope!

Tomorrow I will come by the train you came by; then I shall hear, & shall see! By the train whh passes (I think, but have no bill) Thornhill abt 4½ I shall have to go: some work at Dumfries abt slippers, abt &c will oblige me to pause there; sometime abt 8 p.m. from there, is a Train whh will bring me home agn to my den in the wilderness,—one of the mournfullest for me in Nature, but not unwholesome as things go.

Last night too I lost most of my sleep,—sinner that I am. I renounced Scotsbrig then; no Scotsbrig till perhaps Sunday. I have spent the whole day in adding & subtracting to make out that Bank blunder; See JWC to TC, [16 June]. & cannot from the Documts heremake it out at all. Meanwhile have sent them a new draught to fill the gap on their terms till we see farther. TC wrote in his checkbook, 11 July: “n.b. instead of ‘2 left,’ there turned out to be some £53 or ’4 of ‘overdrawn’! End of june I sent £60 as stopgap, till we got accurately counted.” He sent a check drawn on his Dumfries Bank, writing in his checkbook: “The Gill (‘Dumfries’) 1865 / To London Jt Stk Bank 69 Pall Mall / £60 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). My head is soweak I cannot even add witht error! I make an expenditure for last year of £1,128,—and threatened, on a second trial, to make it more, and them still farther in the right. So gave it up till we return.

My failure ofsleep last night, and my general pusillanimity, proceed, I am convinced, from diet. This is really like a course of Spa or Ischl, or domestic goat’s-whey; Bad Ischl, spa in Austria famous for goat’s milk diets, where John A. Carlyle stayed in 1839; see 11:126TC to TSS, 9 June 1839. & I hope will ansr as well. Bless dear Goody: ah me
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 June. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 23 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.700. Quot: Bliss, TC 379–80.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I got home witht the least impedimt or mischance; had sat smoking &c after tea at Dumfries; found Austin waiting with the Gig,—had a long walk of 3 miles after; & winding up with a spoonful of excellt porridge & half a tankardful of do milk, read half an hour, and took to bed. My sleep tho’ somewhat broken was not lost,—far better, as I often thot, than my poor Darling’s who had so much more need of it! I have done nothing else but think of you ever since we parted: my day yesterday was the only beautiful one I have had in these parts, and yet it was steeped in sadness to me. My very heart is sore for thee, poor little soul, worried with continual pain, weak, sleepless, & in a bother too abt Lodging and “cares of bread”! Coterie speech; Giuseppe Mazzini’s expression for housekeeping; see 34:116JWC to HL, [9] Aug. [1858]. Yr bits of schemes & resolutions as to that difficulty—poor wee thing, you are always so ingenious, so polite & nice. But it will not do to go home before Augt is over. Extend yr circle therefore; there are many possibilities: Edinr country, Fife, even Thurso (since you agree with travelling):—or we will take a Lodging together, and stay till we are tired. I have bethot me that the Marquis of Lothian is near Edinr; William Schomberg Robert Kerr, marquess of Lothian, lived in Newbattle Abbey, 7 mi. (11 km.) S of Edinburgh. thatI really ought to call: cd you stand anything in that directn? Or with the Erskines (with Mrs Stirling) Thomas Erskine and his sister Christian Stirling who lived with him at Linlathen, nr. Dundee. where I am due? Here is exuberant Symmington (good goose); Jean brot me his Letter and I have never yet ansd. His little Shetld Wife Andrew James Symington, old acquaintance of the Carlyle family, and Mary Symington. seemed a canty gleg little bodie;& I believe their house The Symingtons lived in Govan, Lanarkshire. is pleasant: of the glory of their welcome to us there cd be no doubt. Oh desire something; poor I am so very stupid in these cases. Here I do fear, if the lodging were even good and faultness, I fear you wd feel it utterly dull. To me the poor charm it has is that of its lonesome utterly uneventful stagnant character; and that, I can believe, wd be a serious drawback to you seeking an escape from yr worrying dog.— Dr Russell did not seem to think ill of the arm; rather well, and as a benefit in some points: at parting he said, “Here we have got all our mischiefs brot to one head.” I firmly believe in his rationality & honesty: two great qualities, and not often met with in people of his or of any professn at prest.

I do notknow what to say abt Scotsbrig for tomorrow; have not written to them, so angry is the sky, and as if charged with rain; but if it keep up tomorrow, do still intend to go. Oh if I cd hear a fractn of good news tomorrow morning (the last post till Monday agn)! But how can I hope; what real likelihood is there?— I have inclosed you a Program for Thursday: it seems to me, on study of the Time-table yr only good course; especially if you will consent to stay the 2½ hours for tea with me at Dumfries.— By the bye, if you are short for driving, why not get into the Omnibus (I believe it will come down to you for a bribe of 6d), An omnibus ran twice a day (except Sundays) from Moniaive to Thornhill stn., via Penpont; from Penpont to the stn. cost 1s. 6d. inside, and 4d. outside. TC’s suggested “bribe” would presumably bring the coach in to Thornhill past Holmhill. get into a Dumfries train, & with that & the return have driving enough? Think of that,—& do it if you can.—— Symington’s TC puts a line over the “m,” indicating a double letter, although a single “m” is the correct spelling. Letter you can burn; Abeken’s do (or perhaps I may send it to Neuberg Bernhard Abeken wrote to TC, 18 June, on receipt of books returned to him; see TC to SW, [21 May]. In the letter he also thanked TC for writing about his country’s hero, Frederick. The letter was forwarded to Neuberg, with TC writing on its reverse; see TC to JN, 7 July. if you do spare it); the Insurance one consider till we meet on Thursday, and then I will do what you bid me with it. And be of heart my little brave one; bravest of little women! Ever yr
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 25 June [1865]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Hansons, NE 532 inc. The letter is written with JWC’s left hand, in pencil, on lined paper.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh Darling! Darling! I feel as if suddenly struck deaf & dumb! My heart full of things wanting to get said to you, and my right hand gone to the dogs! so that it cannot write to my Husband even, nor cut my food, nor do anything more than an Infant can! And tho’ I strive frantically to use my left hand instead, the progress I make is contemptible, and the difficulty is heart breaking, and soul confusing!

I wanted aboveall to have said a great deal on the subject of your change of Plans. Lady Ashburton’s departure to Wiesbaden spa for treatment for her rheumatic disorders had apparently been delayed. Dr Quain seemed so grievedand alarmed at the first mention of it, that for certain he is sincerely convinced of the absolute necessity of your going—
When I told Mr Carlyle when he came to see me last Thursday, he said “I wonder if my writing to remonstrate with Her would have the least effect”? And I said “Oh do try”!
Your letter reached me here. I could not quite make out from it whether you had got the note I dictated to Geraldine Jewsbury.

I came to Scotland hurriedly because Dr Quain and Dr Blakiston advised it, and because I had stupidly taken advantage of Mr C’s absence to get some necessary painting done in the house, and because I had a wild instinct to rush away from my pain!—at least from the scene of it! Now I have been here a week without the slightest alleviation and long for home, and would just rush back if it were not for the mad look of the thing!
Please tell me what you have decided. And when and for how long you are to be in London? She left London for Wiesbaden 31 July; see Surtees, Ludovisi 116.
I never meant to stay long in this country on the present occasion Should have greatly preferred being with you at Melchet— And I must see you before you go abroad—if you go
God be with you wherever you go or stay
I can write no more my left hand protests against its new work, by taking the cramp
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: turn over

I have opened my envelope to beg you will tell me of Mr Pope Either a friend or an employee of Lady Ashburton’s; unidentified further. poor handsome goodhumoured Man who “never gave his Wife a day’s unhappiness”! God grant she may have him spared to her!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [26 June]. MS: NLS 609.724. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I’s amaist ashamed to say it, but I’s na better! Coterie speech; see 21:151JWC to JCA, [2 Feb.? 1847]. Saturday night I slept not longer but less painfully.Last night it was all horrors and tortures again. I wish I had staid at home. So far I have been decidedly worse for the “change”
As I still mean to see you “to speak to” on Thursday, I need not cramp that wretched left hand trying to write more.
I will follow your directions about the small journey

Only, please, my Dear! I would not be rude! But oh please let it be James
Austin who shall be waiting to drive me to The Gill and if it might be a cart instead of a gig I would much rather! any sort of climbing is impossible for me, as I cannot take hold
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 27 June. MS: NLS 518.1. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: We got home from Scotsbrig, after a quite fortunate journey and stay, yesternight before sunset,—on one of the beautifullest evgs for a view of one’s old cradle bed! TC was born in Ecclefechan, S of Scotsbrig, and his earliest years were spent there; here he apparently refers to passing through Ecclefechan on the way from Scotsbrig to The Gill; he then refers to his “cradle” as being in Scotsbrig in TC to JWC, 27 June. — I brot hitherd some 6 small voll. from the Doctor’s Press; John A. Carlyle apparently kept a book cupboard at Scotsbrig. & have been reading all day in one of them,—Boileau Nicolas Boileau-Despréaux (1636–1711), French critic, poet, and satirist; the most likely edition of his works for TC to borrow was Oeuvres de Boileau, ed. Berriat Saint-Prix, 4 vols. (Paris, 1830–37). whh is valuable to me. The other Book is Histre d’Espagne Possibly two vols. from Charles Romey, Histoire d’Espagne depuis les premiers temps jusqu’a nos jours, 9 vols. (Paris, 1839–50), or Jean Bernard Mary-Lafon, Histoire d’Espagne depuis les premiers temps jusqu’à nos jours, 2 vols. (Paris, 1865). (2 voll) whh also I like.

Jane will come either on Thursday or on Friday; I have had to turn it so, to give Jamie (Carlyle) a chance of meeting her here,—he is bound to Lockerby Market Weekly livestock market. Thursday, but I have still left it to Jane’s choice. Tomorrow I shan’t know for certain; therefore can only tell you that her train arrives in Dumfries 11.37 a.m. to stop 23 min. there;—& that if she don’t come on Thursday, she will on Friday at that hour. Probably you will have zeal enough, some of you, to try on Thursday,—tho’ I have to leave it uncertn. I return with her to Dumfries 4.45 p.m, she rushes on to Thornhill; I stay with you till 8.1 p.m. before returning hither. I must not quit these country silences for any kind of Town residence; nor does the solitude hurt me, tho’ it is far from promoting rise of spirits. I seem to feel myself slowly getting a little better.
On Friday then, if not on Thursday, I can hope to see you. Adieu
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 June. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 27 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.701. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Courage, Dearest; these bad news will not always continue, tho’ yr poor left hand has none other to send me as yet! The torment, if nothing else can help it, must and will burn itself out;—all maladies are a fire lighted to clear off something else that was worse, that had rendered them needful. If I cd but hear of you sleeping—but alas we cannot yet; only one night a little more tolerable, and then the next worse than before! Don’t regret however that you came: home had become intolerable; the change was suggested and recommended by every consideratn; in brief, you had to come. Nor must we give up poor Scotland its resources too soon; not till we have exhausted them, whh is yet far from being done. Please Heaven you shall return able to write with the right hand, and sleeping as before!—

The main thingI had to tell you today, in prospect of soon meeting for word of mouth is, That, if it will suit at all fairly, you must come on Friday instead of Thursday. Jamie of Scotsbrig, who wd fain see you, is bound on Thursday to a market at Lockerby; but will attend here if you can say Friday;—that is all; & on the whole, I will leave you to yr choice (only fail not to give me notice) if Thursday still seem to you the preferable day. And you shall be met by Austin, not by me (oh you of little faith See Matt. 8:26. ),—tho’ old “Sandy” the Ponyis one of the soberest not to say laziest in Nature, and an Earthquake is as likely as any fash from him. The Cart too, if you are mad enough to insist on it (but I hope and believe you won’t): the gig is far easier “to get into” than any cart;—or even, if Jamie of Scotsg be here, you may have a really handsome “dogcart,” and both the Jamies James Carlyle and James Austin. to help you in, I only waiting to open the gate for you here. Be sensible, Dearest; don’t yield to whims now, don’t.

I had a prosperous time to Scotsbrig & at and from it: all was so beautiful, so sad & silent;—and I believe I am slowly getting rather better by my rusticatn. I did a fair amount of (involuntary) talking; but nobody for an instant intruded; 3 fourths of my stay was solitude, silence, & all silent things were so much more vocal to me there among the things where my cradle stood, while the scene was still so crowded for me, instead of empty as now. Scotsbrig House (no servant in it, but Mary’s “Catharine” assisted by Mary) seemed to me in such order as I never saw it in before:—and you must know, I conceived a beautiful idea, and still have it (tho’ in utter silence, n.b. for yourself too, “silence”) that you & I might both lodge together there for a week or two; & do
better there than anywhere else! This is really my notion (no “railway trains,” no nothing,—if only Mary can get away to attend you as nurse); but don’t whisper it to anybody till we see farther.—— —— I wish I knew what kind of wine you drink; pray mentn tomorrow; we have none here, but good, of any kind, tolerably good, is attainable enough at Dumfries, or even at Annan. Now don’t be blate; but say: you must not miss any portion of yr poor diet while here; having nothing else that you can hit anywhere. Don’t fail to write tomorrow whether you have written today or not. Bless thee, Dearest.—
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 28 June. MS: NLS 609.725. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:269–71.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
I cannot make itFriday; Dear: at least could not without rudeness to a nice woman who has always been kind to me. I am engaged to dine with my sort of a Cousin Mrs Hunter Catherine Hunter, b. Brown (1820–1912), widow of John Hunter (1795?—1858), uncle of JWC’s cousin Janet Potts; see 34:242–43JWC to JPR, [ca. 23 Nov. 1858]; she now lived at Milton, an estate in Tynron parish. on Friday, having been invited for Thursday and asked to have the day changed to Friday. And last year when she had got up a dinner for me I had to send an excuse at the last hour, being too ill. Tomorrow you will now be hardly expecting me. So let us say Saturday TC wrote later: “The ‘Saturday’ in this letter must refer to the visit she proposed making us at the Gill. Jamie of Scotsbrig particularly invited. Mournfully I ever recollect the day: bright and sunny; Jamie punctually there; I confidently expecting. Fool! I had not the least conception of her utter feebleness, and that she was never to visit ‘The Gill’ more! Train passed. I hung about impatiently till the gig should return from Cummertrees Station—with her, I never doubted. It came with John instead, to say she had been obliged to stop at Dumfries, and I must come thither by the next train: ‘be exact; there will be a two and a half or three hours for us there still.’ I went (with John, Jamie regretfully turning home). She was so pleasant, beautifully cheerful, and quiet, I enjoyed my three hours without misgiving. Fool! fool!—and yet there was a strange infinitude of sorrow and pity encircling all things and persons for me—her beyond all others, though being really myself as if crushed flat after such a ‘flight’ of twelve or thirteen years, latterly on the Owen ‘comatose’ terms. I was stupefied into blindness! The time till her train should come was beautiful to me and everybody. Cab came for her, I escorting (the rest walked, for it was hardly five minutes off). Train was considerably too late. An old and good dumb ‘Mr. Turner,’ whom she recognised and remembered kindly after forty years, was brought forward at her desire by brother John. Her talk with Turner (by slate and pencil, I writing for her)—ah me! ah me! It was on the platform-seat, under an awning; she sat by me; the great, red, sinking sun flooding everything: day’s last radiance, night’s first silence. Grand, dumb, and unspeakable is that scene now to me. I sat by her in the railway carriage (empty otherwise) till the train gave its third signal, and she vanished from my eyes.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:268). TC compared his long struggle with Frederick with Richard Owen’s description of “migrative swallows” that fly more or less in their sleep by the end of their long journey; see Froude, LM 3:180–81 (also cited 39:264). Joseph Turner (ca. 1798–1872), teacher of the deaf and dumb, Dumfries. —if that does not suit
there will be time to tell me. “The wine I drink”? Oh My! That it should be come to that! But surely you ought not to be without wine setting aside me!

Don’t be bothering, making plans embracing me. The chief good of a Holiday for a man is just he should have shaken off home cares, the foremost of these a wife! Consider that for the present summer you have nothing to do with me but write me nice daily letters and pay my bills! I came on my own hook and so will I continue, and so will I go!

To beliving in family in some country place is just like no holiday at all, but like living at home “under difficulties”! Shall I ever forget the cares of meat at Auchtertool House? “In 1859: ‘Cares of bread.’—Mazzini’s phrase” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:269). The Carlyles rented Auchtertool House, Fife, 5 Aug. to 6 Sept. 1859; for JWC’s comments at the time, see 35:188JWC to JGCO, [2 Sept. 1859], and 207JWC to LST, 18 Sept. [1859]. ever forget the maggots generated by the sun in loins of mutton, on the road from Kircaldy and all the other squalid miseries of that time! For which I as Housewife was held responsible! and had my heart broken twenty times a-day! Well my worried arm is pain enough for the present without recalling past griefs! Today however I feel rather easier and I had more and better sleep last night. Thanks to Exhaustion! for the preceding night I had not closed my eyes at all!

It is such a pity but I could have a little bodily ease! For I was never more disposed to be content with “things in General!” Coterie speech; see 26:99JWC to HW, [4 July 1851]. I could really feel “happy”—if it were not for my arm—and the perfectly horrid nights it causes me!

Jessie Hiddleston is in Thornhill awaiting my orders. See JWC to JHJHI, [24 May]. The most promising looking servant you have had since her Mother! TC was very impressed by Jessie’s mother, Margaret Hiddleston, who had been JWC’s mother’s servant; see 14:60TC to JWC, 7 March 1842. I am greatly pleased with her—and so glad I had faith inbreed and engaged her. Mary Presumably Mary Russell. was eager to have her. But She was “prood to go back To The Family” The Welsh family; see JWC to JHJHI, 15 May. “The Family?” Where are they?

My Dear!Courage, Dearest; your observation of Handwritings is perfectly amazing! You take Geraldines writing for mine, Mr Macmillans for Geraldines! and now I send you a charming witty graceful little letter of Madame ­Venturis. “Madame Venturi had been Miss Ashurst, of a well-known London parentage. She had (and has) fine faculties, a decidedly artistic turn, which led her much to Italy &c. Venturi was a Tyrolese Venetian (ex-Austrian military cadet, and also Garibaldist to the bone, consequently in a bad Italian position), who had fallen in love at first sight, &c., &c.; and was now fitting up a modest English house for wife and self. Within a year he died tragically—as will be seen.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:271). with
vignettes “Maid’s writing begins.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:270); JWC’s writing ended with “vignettes”; the rest of the letter was written by Jessie Hiddleston. of Venturi sawing, and you seem to have taken it forMrs Paulet’s! TC previously commented on a letter from Paulet; see TC to JWC, 13 June; it is not clear if that is the letter referred to here, or if a more recent letter from Venturi had been sent to TC. —you could not possibly have read the letter or you could not have made such a mistake, so I advise you to read it now, with a key; “The Gorilla” means George Cook M stands for Mazzini, the sawyer Venturi, since you wish to know, I have gone back to Sherry and now good by till Saturday unless I hear to the contrary. My left hand had taken the cramp, so this is the writing of the new house-maid who takes the opportunity to assure you that she means to be a very good girl and try to please you for the sake of her Mother who liked you so well / J Carlyle
Signature in JWC’s hand.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 29 June. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Jamie,——Jane has an engaget on Friday (“dinner” to execute, whh she had shifted from Thursday first of all); & so appoints to come on Saturday, and hopes to meet you here. Come accordingly: it will be a great disappointt if you don’t.

I hope John has come safe back to you;—and that James has learned something comfortable James Carlyle Jr. was seeking work as a factor or farm manager; see 41:122TC to HI, 7 Dec. 1864. (either by Letteror perhaps by ocular survey) abt the new offer of a situatn: it wd be a great pleasure to us all that he cd find something not forbidden by unwholesomeness, & fit for the better accomplishts he is possessed of.

You must try Noggs with candour;not with impatience, but to the very bottom! I have been twice on him since I saw you; & must say I do not remember to have ridden a feller little horse, or one fundamentally with less of mischief or unkindness in him,—especially to me. Poor old Noggs!— I believe also you exaggerate his age: it was not the Horse-mercht, I now remember, that told me his age; but the Stable-Keeper, Presumably John Silvester. who was a more disinterested witness.
Saturday as early as you like.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 29 June. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 29 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.702. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,Courage, Dearest;—It shall be Saturday, then; I have sent a word to Jamie, a word to Jean; and it is all settled, if things hold good. We will endeavour to be canny with you (“Canny as eggs, for my blessing!” said the Annandale Mason Peter Easton (d. 1845); coterie speech; see 26:203TC to JCA, 11 Oct. 1851. once); and will land you at Thornhill agn, by Heaven’s blessing, nothing the worse. You shall also have from 2 to “4” (whh is the real cipher, or used to be, & shd be) glasses of pale Sherry, whh is an “elegant beverage,” & shall be poured by me today, not to rest wholly on recommendatn of “nine years in bond” & the like! Jean will be waiting for you, I suppose, at Dumfries; will at least get you a Cumertrees return-ticket: as you have to be with her till 7.22 p.m from 4.55 along with me, you need not, unless you like, crawl up the Hill & down agn for those 23 minutes of stay.

You write so cheerfully, I try to flatter myself you are perhaps slowly but actually getting a little better. If one only durst believe it;—but, for certain, these summer winds & peaceable green solitudes must do good to afflicted human nature! I myself seem to be really on the improving hand more or less, of late, in spite of all drawbacks.— Tho’ you don’t seem to take much to the Scotsbrig speculatn (whh remains dumb till I see you), I don’t give it up: your objection seems to be chiefly in respect of me, and there, I can assure you, it is not valid; I believe I shd be better off with bits of yr company & yr continual neighbd at Scotsbrig, than here in the utter vacancy & muteness of the whole day. But we shall see, we shall speak, on Saturday!— Yr new maid Jessie Hiddleston. bids fair; I am glad she is come to you, at any rate, or to yr neighbd to be within call. This morning, in ignorance of her hand, I demanded of the old deaf Postman, who had picked up for me on the Highway “another Letter you must have”;—whh not a little puzzled the poor old deaf body, till, exam[in]ing, I [saw] TC omitted letters and word. Thornhill stamped on the outside, & that it wd be all right.—— Poor Montegut’s Letter (who I thot must be perhaps dead!) was also welcome to me; so enthusiastically loyal, extravagantly grateful,—and, alas, poor soul, seemingly so miserable & dispirited. A constant “maladie nerveuse” (who knows how like yr own!) “these many years.” You can read his poor Note if you like to labr: TC enclosed Montégut’s letter of mid-June, which was both in French and difficult to decipher.
but if not,the news is, a Photograph of him is coming; item, “within 2 months” a never enough to be praised review of Frh in the Deux Mondes. Montégut thanked TC for the volumes of Frederick TC had sent; see TC to EM, 19 May. He wrote: “you know how much I love your great talent and how I esteem the sincere morality and the perfect truthfulness of character that your work shows so strongly. … I need not tell you the pleasure given me by this reading where Frederick appears so vital, with all his virile faculties of energy, of resolution, of command” (trans. eds.). That is all.

I lay all yesterday behind a grassy dike with shady hedge, reading whole masses of Boileau; who, tho’ in obsolete vein, has more merit in a page than the whole cohue of Modern French in all I ever read of them. Adieu till Saturday;—and oh a little sleep, if thou only canst, poor little soul! with my blessing ever — T.C.

ps.p: They are to try Noggs in harness on Saty (n.b. after you are gone!).— It is a thousand pities nobody in want of a right good pony will take a gift of him from me. The damaged (blemished rather, for there is no damage) knees reduce the market-price not a little, and I never rode a sounder-footed, healthier, feller, flintier “excellt little ’Oss,”—at bottom greatly attached to me too! Think over if there is nobody?—
All the Yr Round All The Year Round, weekly periodical founded and owned by Charles Dickens, pbd. 1859–95. came; won’t send it till Saty—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EW [EWA], 29 June. MS: NLS 609.723. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:326–27 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 531–32; Surtees, JWC 265.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: It is a fortnight today since I left home, and time that I should send you another word of news. At least I hope you are thinking so. For if such a kind motherly woman as you did not feel any concern about how I was getting on with this wretched arm; I should say it must have been somehow my own fault and did not tell to my advantage.

You will see before reading a word, that my right arm continues to be of no use to me! If only that were all, I could manage to get on pretty well with the left. As I am here giving you a proof! But the pain continues almost unbearable and keeps me awake, tumbling about like a wild thing, night after night thro’ one weary week after another. So that it is a perpetual miracle to myself that I am able to get up in the morning and keep on foot like other people thro’ the day! I have been much worse since I came here, than I was at Mr Macmillans. And long to be at Home again. Where, when ill one has always
the consolation of perfect liberty to be as ugly and stupid and disagreeable as ever one likes! Coterie speech; see 13:196JWC to JF, [24 July 1841].

If it were not for shame of seeming to not know my own mind, and for terror of the long journey back I would start off home at once! But I must at least, for decency’s sake make out the month I spoke of at starting.
I hope you are quite rid of the Painters—and of the smell too. Be sure to keep all the windows open—that the House may be sweet when Mr Carlyle returns and goes sniffing all thro’ it!

If you have no more pressing work it would From here the letter continued in Jessie Hiddleston’s hand. be a useful thing to dolooking through all the sheets and mending them and there might not be soon so good an opportunity please inquire for Mr Royston and tell me how he is when you write. The settlement of the Hamper Presumably the weekly hamper of produce from Lady Ashburton’s estate at Addiscombe. was very judicious but in case of any such emergence again just take counsel with yourself. I have considerable faith in your practical judgement but little or none in Miss Jewsbury’s her talent is of quite another sort than practical if the bookcases are not quite finished pray make Mr Freure get on that there may be no trace of new paint I will write again in a week but mind that you send me a few lines in the meantime
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 June. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 30 June 1865. MS: NLS 617.703. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: If on Saturday you but prove to have slept! Oh my poor little Dear!— For the rest, keep yrself perfectly quiet; we will all be canny with you to the utmost, and all, please Heaven, shall go well.

How my hand shakes! I have been cutting and billing at Austin’s poor wind-tost Trees, during and after my first smoke. All here is tempest for 24 hours back,—with the additn today of sun; whh agn cuts off the favourable promise of rain to a country very thirsty. I send you all my batch of letters for this morning: see what an interesting lot it is! Tell Jean tomorrow how impossible it is I can need any second “dinner” at Dumfries an hour after dining with you!
We will take tea from her, and nothing more. Ask her, howr, if the slippers are done; they wd be a real convenience to me.

I forgot Lady Ashburton’s Address, & cd not till a day or two ago, for my life, remember approximately “Callington”: Presumably Lady Ashburton was staying at her manor in Southill, nr. Callington, Cornwall. so have never yet written; begin to think it were perhaps impertinent!— Two words to that assiduous Mrs Holford Possibly Mary Anne Holford, b. Lindsay (1831–1901), m., 1854, Robert Stayner Holford (1808–92; ODNB ), M.P., art collector and landscape gardener; otherwise unidentified. (how charming to have seen those wonders not of Heaven betwn 10 and 11 p.m.), Unexplained. —after whh I sit silent with Boileau under the nearest scrag of bush till at soonest 4 p.m. Adieu my own dear Goody.
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 July. MS: NLS 617.704. Pbd: Bliss, TC 380–81. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:290.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Poor little soul, you will be flitting today; JWC was going to stay with Alicia Ewart; see JWC to TC, 3 [4] July. and I know not in what conditn of body and spirit, except that it is very sad to me,—pathetic, more than “Lizzie’s Flitting”! “Lucy’s Flittin’,” song written by William Laidlaw (1780–1845), first pbd. anon. in James Hogg, The Forest Minstrel; a Selection of Songs (Edinburgh, 1810) 15–17; see also 32:206TC to JWC, [27 July 1857]. Since Saty, I have sent many miserable thots after you,—poor wearied worn-out heart; I never saw you look more wretchedly tired and foredone;—and thots, especially of that kind, can do no good. Perhaps you have since got a little sleep? Hope springs eternal; Cf. Alexander Pope, An Essay on Man (1732–34). whh is very kind of it, considering that it is perpetually disappointed at this rate! But there was withal in you, from time to time that day, such a geniality and light play of spirit when you got into talk, as was quite surprising to me, and had a fine beauty in it tho’ a very sorrowful. Courage: by and by we shall see the end of this long lane, as we have done of others; and all will be better than it now is.

This morning, my deaf friend The postman, William Rule. on the road gave signal that he had nothing, not even a Newspaper: whh, I own, was good news to me, or better than any that he cd in common course have brot me, my poor Jeannie being out of the game till tomorrow. There was no postal collection from Thornhill on Sundays, so no letter could arrive on Mondays. My life here is, as usual, the nearest approach to
zero any Son of Adam can well make. I read my Boileau, oftenest lying in the grass; I saunter a minimum, ride now a maximum, take one long walk abt 10 p.m. whh is far the pleasantest part of my day,—the road being totally vacant, the Heaven and the Earth totally silent (or in bed) evgs noisy only with the song of winds: I feel to be a cleanly spirit in those minutes, not a poor defaced, molested, dirty one, as at most times, who cannot even have my own sad thot to myself, but must have others molesting me and it. Oftenest I am quite ashamed of myself; and come to the resolutn, that such utter idleness is disgraceful, & ought very shortly to end in some way. Mary is full of alacrity to go with us to Scotsbrig if you will consent & permit: poor soul, in the Press here I see since Saty a poor little Plate of short-bread, biscuit-looking things &c; whh almost made me cry!— If you will say yes, I will at any date (sooner the better) warn Jamie of it, whose zealous assent is not a matter of doubt to me.— Tell me tomorrow what day I am to come. If you say Thursday (or if you have said, Wedny, whh I hardly think), there is nothing in my way. Didn’t you bid me send “All the Yr Round?” I also inclose the Venturi Letter. I have got an excellt Pair of Slippers (for the first time in my life!); I have paid the Cumertrees Tailor (paid & ended),—and have no other Hist History TC drew a line from “Hist” to “History” to connect them; they were written in the top and side margins of the first page of the letter. since we parted. Adieu, Dearest: oh what wd I give for “good news” tomorrow, had I the least chance to get them! Patience, Courage.
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 July]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees. PM: Thornhill, 3 July 1865. MS: NLS 609.726. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
About my sleep then—? (being degenerated into a Creature that sleeps—or I should rather say that does not sleep)— That night—Saturday night—I made a rather good job of it! My sufferings of the previous night and day, my little railway journey, Jane’s “Black-faced Mutton” Jean Aitken’s mutton, from local Scottish blackface sheep. (the only morsel of meat fit to be presented to a “delicate female” that has entered my mouth since I left London) “all together” Coterie speech; see 16:262JWC to TC, [11 July 1843]. procured me two whole hours of sleep at a stretch, and three more of patchwork! So yesterday my wretched arm was less painful. Last night I lay down not expecting to sleep—and was not disapointed!
I had taken a blue pill “Blue pill,” a compound containing mercury, taken by the Carlyles for both digestive and nervous ailments; see 32:111TC to LA, 26 March 1857. (four grains) the third I had taken since I came, with the same result; that of lying awake the whole night after with no perceptible improvement on the utter stagnation of the liver for which the blue pill was prescribed. Dr Russell is extremely cautious in giving any medicine at all; so when he says it is of the greatest importance that the present wonderful phenomenon should be repressed and that I must now go on taking “four grains of Blue Pill every night till things have changed for the better”! I make no debate, but swallow, and mean to swallow a blue pill every night (Mercy of Heaven!) in spite of having got nothing but restlessness out of them hitherto.

Today I flit to Nith Bank To stay with Alicia Ewart, Nithbank, Thornhill. without any definite idea of “a glancing Future!” Coterie speech; literal trans. of Richter’s “glänzendes Leben”; see 10:181JWC to TC, [18 Sept. 1838].
I hope you will come this week—Thursday? I will know better if “the way be open” when I write from the new place tomorrow.

I am so grieved about the disappointment I had to cause to Mary and Jamie. But I could not help it! I had done the impossible in dragging myself out of Bed and getting dressed between fits of retching, and getting myself into the Train. But if I hadn’t reached Janes sofa when I did and got the bits of mutton when I did, you would have had me arrive at the Gill insensible!
Now I must go and put my things in the carpet bag
With my best love to dear Mary, and sincere wishes that I could be apleasure to my Friends instead of an ever recurring disappointment and ­botheration
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 July]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees. PM: Thornhill, 3 July 1865. MS: NLS 609.728. Hitherto unpbd. JWC’s 2d note of 3 July.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Note the second
Dearest it is all extremely right. I have had a nice wholesome little dinner and a long drive and am so much the better for it! It is a curious instance of the magic of change my wellness tonight
I have just five minutes for the night post The last collection was usually around 9 p.m.

But Mrs Ewart wants to “know soon” if you are coming on Thursday—for
bits of “household good” she has in view and she presses you to stay all night in a nice little bedroom offmine— Do stay
docBody.name: [no signature]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 July]. MS: NLS 609.727. Hitherto unpbd. TC later wrote on front of MS: “written with her left hand; right did recover soon. In such plight, she did this room, took down all my Books and made Chaos into beautiful Cosmos for me—the Heroine!” He then wrote on back of MS: “Note from Her, at Nith Bank, to Gill (discovd, 24 March 1867,—ah me).” There is a blank envelope filed with the letter on which TC wrote: “from Her (2 in july 1865)”; this may refer to the two letters JWC wrote, 3 July, rather than this letter of 4 July.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: In spite of my new bed (perhaps in virtue of it) and in spite of the daily Blue pill I slept last night more or less! from three to four hours—piecing all the bits together—a good night for me; according to the present tenor of my nights! So, today I continue better. Thank God!

I get on well here. Mrs Ewart is very kind and not bothering! She is full of cheeriness, and a queer sort of cleverness. For a photograph of Alicia Ewart, see 106; it has the same backdrop as the photograph of JWC taken by Thomas Douglas, Thornhill, Aug. 1862 (see 38:178JWC to TC, 31 Aug. 1862), and was probably taken by Douglas around the same time as JWC’s. TC wrote later underneath the photograph in vol. 3 of the Carlyle albums: “Mrs Ewart (Yorkston) of Nith-Bank? (Her last Hostess in Nithsdale).” JWC returned to the Russells at Holmhill before leaving for London. And the scene is enlivened by two Cousins Possibly grand-das. of Dr. Thomas Yorstoun, whose das., Margaret Yorstoun (b. 1774) and E. Yorstoun (b. 1791), were neighbors of Mary Russell at Thornhill (see 29:296JWC to JC, [24 April 1855], and 32:6JWC to MR, [6 Oct. 1856]); otherwise unidentified. Alicia Ewart’s maiden name was Yorston or Yorstoun. on a visit to her; Sisters, one a young girl, the other an Invalid young Widow, who has been long in the habit of spending her mornings in bed, reading your Books! They are gentlewomen—which is a comfort so far as it goes!— As for the “Cares of Bread”; They are successful here! I have plain wholesome well cooked food, which I can eat! And if my cure, as Dr Russell says, is “only to be accomplished by Time and nourishing food”; it is something to be thankful for that I have “nourishing food” to eat!
Alicia Ewart, by Thomas Douglas, [1862]
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

If you would stayall night; you are pressingly offered my Bed at Holmhill, as well as the room adjoining mine here! At all events, Dont plan to rush away by the five o’clock train. It makes such a hurry scurry of it! Now mind! I wont have it!

I amjust going for a drive— I have a nice letter from Dr Blakiston. encouraging
and sensible. Combating Dr Russells opinion that there is no help for me but in “Time and nourishment.
There is the Carriage / Good by Dearest
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 July. Addr: at Mrs. Ewart’s / Nith-Bank House / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 4 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.705. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I thank Heaven for the bit of good news you send me today! Those poor 2 hours of solid, and those 3 of broken: they are a small allowance; but how welcome to her who has so long had none! Oh me, oh me!—

I will come on Thursday at the usual hour; and go at the usual: I hope you have explained to yr kind Hostess how very little her domestic arrangts can require to be altered for me; that I dine on 6 ounces of mutton (chop or collop), and that Ude Louis Eustache Ude (d. 1846; ODNB ), chef to Louis XVI, and later to various English aristocrats; see 36:151TC to SGS, 24 July 1860. with all his aides and battéries de cuisine cd cook no other dinner useful to me. I might stay all night too; and am not witht temptation: but on the whole it wd expose me to the risk of not sleeping in my new bed, and at any rate wd give more trouble: so let us give that up for this time. Oh might I only find you doing well! The Note of tomorrow, you may judge with what interest (of “trembling hope” See Thomas Gray, “Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard” (1751) line 127. ) I shall open it. That the turn may have come,—alas, one dare not hope so much; but one does always hope. As to that of blue-pill, I fully believe in Dr R.’s caution; but I confess not to like that persistance continued in the face of such wearing and continual negatives; and strongly advise you to be yourself “cautious.” You surely have no strength to throw away.

I send you the St. James’s Chronicle, tho’ there are only fractions of it worth the least perusal. Public Opinn St. James’s Chronicle; or British Evening Post, pbd. three days a week; Public Opinion, a weekly magazine. must be lying at Chelsea yet, tho’ stamped; there are also two Magazines Fraser’s and Macmillan’s; see TC to EW, 4 July. (one of them for Auchtertool Auchtertool Manse in Fife, home of JWC’s cousins Rev. Walter Welsh, Margaret Welsh, and Mary Welsh. after me), whh need only sixpence and a new address of Place: I am thinking to send Mrs Warren a note abt them.

Just before I began writing, the voice of Sister Jean from Dumfries addressed
me throu’ the end window: John is off to Scotsbrig, “packing two Boxes of Books,” and she has run off in his absence,—bringing, what is very welcome in its way, & saves Mary a drive to Annan today, something in the form of mutton; mutton vice [instead of] boiled cock having become indispensable to me in these last days! I really believe I am pretty well, & have decidedly improved,—were it not for the perpetual gnawing, weakness, nausea & dispiritt whh prevails within, and checks one’s noble ardour. I really fancy I have had abt enough of this; and ought soon to be off, & getting my visitings finished. Spedding, Thomas Story Spedding; he lived at Mirehouse, nr. Keswick, Cumberland; friend of TC’s since the late 1830s. for three days, who is very accessible, is the first on first on Words repeated with a line over them at turn of page. the cards; but I depend on yr decisn abt Scotsbrig (n.b. there is plenty of good mutton daily at Ecclefn; & if I knew how to cook it as you do, I cd fare sumptuously every day!)— Boileau is abt done; Jean will do me good rather than ill, even if she stay over night. God be with thee Dearest
T.C.

ps.p: Jean has left on the table here (herself run into the Kitchen) a big gold locket, with really a capital Photogrh of you in it.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EW [EWA], 4 July. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: To Mrs Warren (2 Memoranda)

1°. There is a stamped Newspaper called Public Opinion, whh is usually delivered you on Friday night;—pray despatch it (either to Mrs Carlyle or me) on the Saturday, that it may arrive on Monday morning in these parts. This is Tuesday, and it has not yet come. Lastweek the St James’s Chronicle did not come at all.

2°. There are two Magazines (Fraser’s & Macmillan’s) whh reach you always on or before the first day of the month. Pray forward these two;—these; and no other Book except on order. The Macmillan needs 2 stamps; the Fraser 4: you have only farther to alter the Place (in the now Address) into “Gill, Annan N.B.”— Consult Mr Bullock John Bullock, the Carlyles’ postman. if needful.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: The Gill, Annan N.B., 4 july 1865

Mrs. Carlyle’s address since yesterday is “Nith-Bank House” instead of “Holm Hill”;—the rest all the same. She was very poorly when I saw her on Saturday last; but I hear better accounts from her since; and hope to find a considerable improvement when I see her agn the day after tomorrow.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 5 July. Addr: at Nith-Bank House / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 5 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.706. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I am thankful to Heaven for this bit of good news. Oh may the like but continue! It is such a relief to the poor little wearied Sufferer to get even “three or four hours” of oblivion from her sore misery, and see, as it were, afar off, the road out. May I find you tomorrow with as good a story to tell! For the prest I will wish no more; but be grateful & hopeful for the day of small things. See Zech. 4:10. —

Jean isstill here; goes, I suppose, this evg. She has not been in the way; accompanies me in walking, her talk not worse but better than my own gloomy musings: she is diligently sewing (a half-made shirt of Austin’s); has cleaned my gloves &c &c. John was to be back at Dumfries before this hour. Part of his errand to Scotsbrig, it seems, was to get out of an electioneering dinner yesterday, whh M’Diarmid William Ritchie M’Diarmid (1819–95), ed. of the Dumfries Courier, son of TC’s old friend John M’Diarmid (1790–1852; ODNB); see 27:39927:biographical notes. had got up for the new Candidate in these Burghs; W. R. M’Diarmid sponsored a dinner for Col. John Clark Kennedy (ca. 1836–67), who was running as a liberal independent candidate for Dumfries Burghs in the general election of 12 July; he described himself as being for “progress tempered by caution” (Dumfries Courier, 27 June). The seat was held by the Liberal incumbent, William Ewart (1798–1869; ODNB ). Kennedy was attacked and Ewart was defended strongly in the Caledonian Mercury, 1 July: “for a long time the term Liberal, like the term Whig, has been employed only as a convenient pretext to enable timeservers and schemers to discard or disregard the principles which it formerly involved; hence as a rule we apply the word Radical to all like Mr Ewart holding sound Liberal views, and employ the word Ministerial Whig, or Liberal Conservative, to all holding the opinions of Colonel Kennedy. It is as a Radical that we glory in Mr Ewart, and that the electors of Dumfries feel proud of him, and it is as a Radical that he will be returned again triumphant, as he has been so often before, by constituents who appreciate the services he has rendered them and their country, and who feel a just pride in the sterling honesty and manly independence and straitforwardness of his whole political life and character.” a gentn, and a thing, naturally of supreme indifference to the contemplative bystander a little given to dyspepsia & fond of his own ways. This morning, I got nothing but the Newspr now sent, and along with the welcomest little left-hand Letter in the world, a demand from Tailor Sampson for the price of a pair of trousers, claim whh I mean to satisfy at once. John and George Sampson, tailors and drapers, 2 Princes St., Leicester Sq., London; TC recorded in his checkbook, “11 july 1865 / To Sampson (for Trousers) / £2 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

Yesterday towards evg we had a beautiful but too brief watering of Southerly
rain. You too; for I saw it afterwards up in yr directn: Tynron Down & the Black Crag of Dunscore S and W of Thornhill; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 129. I now know well from the Solway sands,—and have in fact a great choice of nice mountains in prospect while riding there, tho’ these two at prest are much the most interesting to me. An hour after dinner I put on Mackintoshes, and had a stoury ride on Noggs. I am well enough; but since yesterday, my dietetic symptoms have broken out into plain—what shall I say: Coterie speech; see 24:171JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. —and I have resolved to dine on the concentrated soup of a mutton-chop & to refuse pudding, tho’ the thimb[l]eful of brandy not. Tomor-Tomorrow Repeated with a line over it at turn of page. I have little doubt to be in travelling order; able for the day & its duties; but as to the hour of returning home,—well, it shall be your say when you have seen me. Good be with thee, Dear, & my best blessings always.——
T. Carlyle

ps.p: n.b. “Cummertrees” is not a Post-Office: omit that; put “Annan” instead JWC had been addressing her envelopes to TC at “The Gill,Cummertrees.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 7 July. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead / London. PM: Annan, 7 July 1865. MS: NLS 553.281. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote this letter on the blank last page and a half of Abeken’s letter to TC of 18 June.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.dateline: The Gill, Cummertrees, Annan N.B. 7 july, 1865—
docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,——Here is a Note from Abeken; See TC to SW, [21 May], and TC to JWC, 23 June. whh I meant to send you (tho’ it is worth nothing at all),—by way of excuse for asking a word of news from you in return. I want to know how you all are,—you in particr, and what is become of yr hearing;—whether you are holding steady by Hampstead, or meaning to go somewhither Neuberg suffered poor health and often went to Swiss or German spas for the summer; see 40:159TC to JAC, 1 Aug. 1864. &c &c In short, the things I wd ask if we met, pony to pony, in the lanes yonder, & rode a few miles together

I quitted Dumfries 5 weeks ago for this entirely rural & solitary place;—driven by want of sleep in the first place; then tethered down by indolence & the charm there was in moping abt in silence day after day & week after week! I am now thinking to bestir myself, & do my other visits &c;—intend to be off (n.b.) in abt a week hence.—— —— I saw my Wife yesterday: she is 30 miles off (or 1 hour), & we have had several meetings. Nithsdale is not the place to
her it was last year; & she talks always of being home agn: and tho’ of late she does begin a little to improve, I think you will likely see her there before very long. She wishes to precede me a pretty space, and put all the house in order; &c.— I had an interesting letter from poor Montégut (to whom Tauchnitz had by my request sent a Friedh);—the Letter is not here, or it had been better worth posting than this. Adieu, my time is up.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 7 July. MS: NLS 518.2. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Austin’s Gig was of use last night, if not often before: we had hardly got upon the road with apron fixed & cape on,—when the storm burst out, in great struggle, lightnings very vivid, thunder still not near at all, but the rain falling as if in pails. I got in witht the least wet; and Austin declared his coat to be still holding out,—tho’ his hat (a new wide-awake of 4/) to be copiously giving way.— I slept (singular to say) very tolerably well; & have got up to the old element of confused stagnatn, with little more than the usual amount of langour, laziness & queasy misery (all from the stomach, I can perceive!)—whh, clearly, I ought, with no delay avoidable, to begin upon, in the way of remedying & ending. As the first step, I have written to Mr Erskine that I will appoint him day & terms within a week. As the second, I send you Draught for all the tagraggery of money,—£8 .. 9 .. 9, TC recorded in his checkbook: “Cumrtrees 7 july 1865 to Sister Jean (Mrs Aitken) (my Tailors Bills, &c) £8 .. 9 .. 9” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). if Johnny Jean’s son John Aitken. (as it is every way presumable!) have been right in adding and auditing:—step third is to be a blue-pill within two hours hence ina drop of mutton-broth
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TSS, 8 July. MS: John Spedding. Pbd: A. Carlyle, CS 761–62.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS STORY SPEDDING

docBody.p: I have been in these parts five or six weeks; entirely silent, stagnant (quiescent till quite tired); and now at last I am got upon forming a new Program of more active sort, with intention to begin executing in abt a week hence.

Oneof my fixed purposes, as you know, was a three days at Mirehouse,—to see you all once more! Pray tell me now what yr times & ways & wishes in regard to that are: so that, sometime betn now and the end of Augt, I may intercalate these 3 days with the maximum of advantage to myself and others. This is practically all I want today;—tho’ if you will add any other details abt Self & Household, Bacon’s varnished Biographer, Thomas Spedding’s brother James, whose life’s work was a scholarly edn. of the life and works of Francis Bacon; see 38:77–78TC to JS, [early April 1862]; “varnished” was presumably in acknowledgment of Spedding’s scholarship. &c, &c, you know how interesting they will be to me.
With kindest remembrances to Madam, Frances Elizabeth Spedding. unless she have quite forgotten me, or even if she have,—I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 8 July. MS: NLS 553.282. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 6:12 inc. where dated 8 June. Quot: Sadler, “Carlyle and Neuberg,” Macmillan’s Magazine 50 (Aug. 1884): 295.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Yr Letter came to me yesterday afternoon,—about 2 hours after I had forwarded Abeken, with a Postscript of inquiries as his main errand. I am very glad to hear you are better,—and that among other blessings the deafness is on the retreat. We must have called in the aid of an ear-trumpet otherwise; whh shall now liein reserve, for the worst that can ­happen!

Inclosed is a Paper whh will do for Trübner. Nicholas Trübner; see TC to NT, 8 July. The Tempelhof Georg Friedrich von Tempelhoff, Geschichte des siebenjährigen Krieges in Deutschland, 6 vols. (Berlin, 1794); see Carlyle, Works 17:72. is now in the London Library, completely accessible (Atlases and all, whh were meant to be Tempf’s, but unluckily are not, and are worth less or nearly so): the Anonyms of Hamburg “Anonymous of Hamburg” was TC’s name for Johann Friedrich Seyfart’s Geschichte des (seit 1756) in Deutschland und dessen angränzenden landern geführten Krieges, 4 vols. (Frankfurt, 1759–62); see 40:108TC to JN, 31 May 1864. you will find in my old garret if you search: it used to stand on the back-wall shelves (wall behind me), and latterly on the left hand as you walk up to said wall It consists of 3 hard-bound little 4tos pretty thick, leather old but firm, with some remains of gilding on the back, item with a label there of paper,—the edges of the leaves are done in red (if I remember). Better seek it out: there are several things in it whh will concern you farther on. As to the Battle Plans, they come from a great variety of sources (Tempelhof, or
French Piracies of Tempf; Kausler, Franz von Kausler, Atlas des plus mémorables batailles, combats et sièges des temps anciens, du moyen âge et de l’âge moderne, 6 vols. (Carlsruhe and Freiburg, 1831); see Carlyle, Works 12:296–97. whh I had from Earl de Grey; George Frederick Samuel Robinson (1827–1909; ODNB ), 3d Earl de Grey; see 41:162TC to HL, 9 Feb. Tielcke the Saxon Johann Gottlieb Tielke, Beyträge zur Kriegs-Kunst; und zur Geschichte des Krieges von 1756 bis 1763, 6 vols. (Freyberg, 1775–86); see Carlyle, Works 17:350. now in Ln Library; and occasionally perhaps one Müller, Ludwig Müller, Kurzgefasste Beschreibung der drei schlesischen Kriege zur Erklärung einer Kupfertafel auf welcher sechs und zwanzig Schlachten abgebildet sind (Berlin, 1785); see Carlyle, Works 17:402; TC’s copy: HCC. still in Cheyne Row, recommended in Preuss, Johann David Erdmann Preuss (1785–1868), historian much referred to by TC in Frederick; TC’s copies of his works: HCC. —with various Jominis Antoine Henri Jomini (1779–1869), Swiss-French general and historian; see 26:256TC to JWC, [9] Dec. 1851. &c &c), whh I advise you not to get into, or meddle with at all!— — This, I think, is the ansr to all yr practical inquiries.

I have now to make a special one of you! Wd my excellt little Horse Noggs, who has often ridden with you, be of the least use to you (perhaps considering the age of your excellt little Gray?); and wd you accept of a gift of Noggs from me? I have him here; & am thoroughly tired of him, and of all horses whatsoever. He was the munificent gift of the prest Lady Ashburton Dowr to me; and cost her a very long price, I have no doubt, £60, £80, I shall never know what; and now, in prest circumstances, probably I cd not sell him for £10;—and indeed shd feel greatly delivered if you wd take him from me. For tho’ his worth is not, in any respect diminished, his selling capabilities are reduced in the extreme. He is one of the healthiest of Horses, as well as flintiest and sharpest; temper joyful and friendly (only too “friendly,” if you give him beans, & ride with loose rein!)—perfectly sure-footed (tho’ he is blemished on both knees,—got it by catching his foot in a long curb rein whh I remissly had hanging over my little-finger, when he made a little stumble over some trifling thing, and intended to recover himself): finally, Sylvester, on sight 2 years ago, pronounced him to be 5 years of age; and now, they inform me, he has lost mark of mouth (as sometimes happens). These things are all true enough; but in no Horse-bargain wd they gain a moment’s belief: “a good little ’Oss, Sir” (as Sylvr always emphatically defined him); who might as well be a thoroughly bad for all sale purposes. His riding you have seen; I believe he will go in harness too; Sylvr found him unused to it (apparently), but willing, & he has bone and paces admirable for it,—tho’ he shall be tried farther by some Artist in Dumfries, if you say Yes. In short don’t say No, unless he is absolutely witht use to you. For I perceive I shall have to give him away to somebody; and you are the first I apply to,—you who deserve far other “gifts” from me (had I got them, or did you need them) beyond any other person! Ansr soon;
and say Yes; if you wd deliver me from a considerable encumbrance. Noggs is in first-rate conditn; can run here at grass so long as you like (grass plentiful &c &c), and the cost of franking That is, paying for sending Noggs to London. him to London is a mere £9, the cheapest visible deliverance to me. Enough of Noggs!—

I am speculating abt a Voyage to the Western Isles, The Western Isles, group of islands off the NW coast of Scotland, including Lewis and Harris, South Uist, North Uist, Benbecula, and Barra; also known as the Outer Hebrides. to various isles & places;—and do not intend much longer continuance in the torpid state, tho I suppose it may be found to have done me good when once I am out of it. Before Septr I am not likely to see the old detested element, of Penny Newsprs, Philanthropy, Italian Organs, and railway miracle agn. One’s view of the world gets very sad & sombre, contemptuous to a painful degree, but not angry, at this safe distance of years and of miles: view as something not in any way to be remedied or helped; fallen into the hands of the Primeval Powers and silently recording Destinies inexorably exact & just,—who will witht fail do to us and it what is best, tho’ it seem cruel as Eternal Death! Amen.

Yr acct of Mill is very curious. Strange indeed to see the peculiar Trismegistus, Thrice great; the Egyptian god Thoth was often referred to as Hermes Trismegistus and seen as a god of mysticism and alchemy. and “Thinker of Thinkers,” whom the washed portn of the English Populace has got hauled aloft at this rate. John Stuart Mill was one of the Liberal parliamentary candidates for Westminster; he was very reluctant to campaign actively as he did not believe in persuading people to vote for him, but did agree to appear at several pre-election meetings in early July to answer questions, including meetings at which working men who did not have the vote were welcome. The meetings were extremely popular. A most clear, ingenuous, logically limpid soul; and of such a depth as to believe in the Suffrage of Niggers and persons that can do a sum in the Rule of Three! Poor Mill, I found it proper (tho’ pressed to the contrary) to hold off entirely from this matter; believing that probably it will, in either event, turn out very miserable for him.— But But Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. my Paper is out, and all my time. Adieu. Yours always /
T.Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-NT, 8 July. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.Nicholas Trübner (1817–84; ODNB ), philologist and publisher, specializing in imported books from the Americas and Asia.
div3.head: TC TO NICHOLAS TRÜBNER

docBody.p:
Mr Trübner is perfectly at liberty to import the 25 Copies of Jean Pauls Siebenkäs, Jean-Paul Friedrich Richter, Blumen-, Frucht- und Domenstücke; oder Ehestand, Tod und Hochzeit des Armenadvokaten Firmian Stanislaus Siebenkäs (Berlin, 1796–97). whh have been pirated from him in America; any part of them whh
may have been pirated from me Edward Henry Noel’s trans. of Richter’s work, Flower, Fruit, and Thorn Pieces; or, the Married Life, Death, and Wedding of the Advocate of the Poor, Firmian Stanislaus Siebankäs, 2 vols. (Boston, 1863), was pbd. by Ticknor & Fields; it included TC’s memoir of Richter, first pbd. in the Foreign Review, Jan. 1830; see Carlyle, Works 27:96–159. Trübner had recently begun a monthly catalog of the most important works pbd. in America and Asia, Trübner’s American and Oriental Literary Record (London, 1865–79); the 20 July issue contained a notice of this work. he is to regard as likewise his own, in the circumstances
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: TheGill, Annan N.B. (for Chelsea, London) 8 july 1865
To Mr Trübner &c Publishers, London

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [10 July]. Addr: T[he] Gill / Annan. PM: Thornhill, 10 July 1865. MS: NLS 609.729. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I am wondering if you have taken that Blue Pill and if it have produced the desired effect? My eight have made only a just perceptible change! But Dr Russell says I must take no more for the present; but twice a day Quinine and Iron. If I find however that the Quinine produces in combination the same pernicious effect on my sleep as singly I won’t go on with it even at his bidding. I have continued having better nights tho’ not again so good a one as that I told you of; and my arm is a trifle less painful.
Mrs Ewart would not hear of my going at the end of my week, and there were inducements toprolong my stay a little

My old friend, Mrs Macdonald Elizabeth MacDonald, b. Ewart, sister-in-law of Alicia Ewart; see JWC to TC, 12 July; see also 29:296JWC to JC, [24 April 1855]. is expected on Wednesday. And the gentle young widow and her sister Alicia Ewart’s cousins; see JWC to TC, [4 July]. are soothing Company! And the more days I stay here just so many more days I stay in “the Country” As I made it understood I should stay no more than one week at Holm Hill on my return there!

But there is come a letter from The Flight of Sky Larks Caroline Davenport Bromley. wishing we would come to her at Folkstone JWC first met Caroline Bromley when staying with the Ashburtons in Folkestone, June–July 1862; see 38:105JWC to TC, [29 June 1862]. where she goes on the 15 of August; so if I find London really too hot in August—I can go to Her—and have beside her not only
the advantage of Sea air but cultivated society which has grown to be a want and tidy food, (for an Invalid a very gravewant indeed)
Shall I meet you on Friday (14th)? at Dumfries?
Couldn’t you bring Mary up with you? It would spare me some fatigue to see her at Jane’s; and I couldnt stay all night at the Gill. and see her I must! dear kind littlewoman!
I am writing dreadfully ill today—am shaking to a degree! beside the leftness!
docBody.name: Jane

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 10 July. Addr: Nith-Bank House / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 10 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.707. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest, I do hope you are still going on well,—so cheery was your last little left-hand Piece:—but I will wait with great anxiety your message of tomorrow. My own history since you last heard is quiesct in the extreme; nothing in fact, but, like your own, an adventure with the mercurial friend! The blue pill. I was delighted to hear of what I counted your signal success in that matter; the preliminary of great good, as I expect; and much to be welcomed as the finis of those “eight,” were there nothing more. I took my own one duly; and with no very marked result as yet; result good however, so far as it goes. It has excited a very considerable new activity in the mind of me at any rate, something far more like health than the dreary collapse I have been lying in hitherto; so that tho’ it has disturbed my sleep some little (nothing of loss in that particr either) I am really obliged to it: and design to take the other (perhaps tomorrow, if still found needful, for perhaps there are incipiences of import on that physical side too);—hoping always that you, poor little wretch, will take no more!— For the rest I have done with my Boileau (really a Book not disgraceful to read); I have been consulting Western-Isles Steamers; Steamers for the Western Isles left from Glasgow every Monday and Thursday at noon, calling at Oban (mainland), Tobermory (Mull), Portree (Skye), and Stornoway (Lewis) (advertised in the Glasgow Herald). meditating Linlathen; Linlathen, Dundee, home of Thomas Erskine. have written to Thomas Spedding, even to Sinclair of Thurso (in reference to Western Isles),—and am getting all my handspikes ready, in short, for the purpose of lifting anchor from this quiet cove & its solitudes. I have also wrapt up Miss Dt Bromley’s French Book See TC to JWC, 9 June. with proper sixpenny on
it; meant to send a Note too,—but cd not compose myself, as they had Noggs out in the interim, trying him in harness! So that Miss D Bry, I fear, must wait till tomorrow for her Note.

Noggs, however, Iam proud to say, returns with a new crop of laurels; runs (promises to run, seems not now applicable) like an angel; and will be really a stately gift to somebody! For I find I must give him: on sale he will not fetch the 8th part of his value; marked on the knees, & “witht mark of mouth” tho’ only 7 years old, “an excellt little ’Oss, Sir!” and intrinsically rather better than when I got him, tho no purchaser wd believe a word of my testimony abt him. “To be given, therefore!” And I have written to Neuberg offering (this is not the ansr whh you read here of Neuberg’s writing:) he had written of his own accord and of mine, twice both of us: you may read him, better than you cd the most. Him, Mrs Warren, John; they all throw glimmers of light on on Thus in MS. our affairs here.— Neuberg (to whom, poor soul, my obligations for service are uncountable) will most probably refuse Noggs; the next I mean to offer him to is Mary Welsh of Auchtertool (unless you can suggest better),—or is there no Nithsdale benefactor to whom he wd be really useful, now that he is proved capable of gig? Advise me, if you can. At bottom, it cannot be difficult now to rid myself of Noggs,—or even to keep him for summer driving in London, if you were not such a coward. Know Madam that I am very far beyond the average in horse-conduct, after such experience daily for 9 years long;—& that 2 will drive you worse where 1 will better! Thus in MS.
Bless you any way /
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IS [IEB], 10 July. Addr: 82 Oakley Street / Chelsea Walk / Chelsea / London. PM: Thornhill, 10 July 1865. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, Forum 49–50. The envelope is with other JWC to Isabella Barnes / Simmonds’s envelopes in Carlyle House.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA SIMMONDS

docBody.dateline: Holmhill Although staying at Nithbank, JWC addressed her letter from the Russells’ home, to which Isabella Simmonds’s letter was presumably sent. / Thornhill Dumfriesshire / [10th July 1865]
docBody.p:
I am dreadfully sorry for you! Your little child Ethel d. 2 July; “At No. 82 Oakley-street, Chelsea, ETHEL JANE CARLYLE, the only child of John and Isabella Simmonds, aged 20 months” (Times, 5 July). that was such a Pet! For a photograph of Ethel and Isabella, taken when Ethel was a baby, see 40:100TC to JN, 18 May 1864. Nothing worse could have befallen you under Heaven except the Death of your Husband! John Simmonds. Be thankful poor sorrowing young Mother that you are spared
that! Oh try to bear up for your Husband’s sake and for the sake of the Baby unborn Their da. Amy Constance Simmonds was b. early Sept. 1865. who is soon to come and comfort you for the little Sister taken away
I wish I were at home to go and see you very often!

I cannot even write as I should wish. My right arm and hand continue to be a perpetual torment to me. and utterly useless! I have had to learn to write and to do the things I can do at all with my left hand. But I feel it so difficult!
I am coming home in about a fortnight
Thank you darling for writing to me
I have not improved in “the Country.” The pain is constant and takes away my sleep and appetite
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 July. MS: NLS 617.708. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, As I am like to be very much bothered with a “chattery” of importunate Notes (Spedding, Mme Otthenin Jean Otthenin. not gone to France &c &c), I begin by my brief Daily to you, by way of soothing my mind. Ohone! Irish exclamation of lamentation; see 5:402TC to JWC, 4 Sept. 1831, and 5:25later vols. “Notes” were long an unbearable botheratn to me; now far worse than ever, with my shaking hand: to nobody but my poor Goody do I write except on compulsion! But brevity; that is the one remedy or palliative.

Thanks to the poor left-hand, whh really does wonders for me. Yr news I still count good,—very good in comparison. I am glad you are to be at Nith-Bank a few days longer;—and, in general, I begin to see more daylight in yr subsequent wanderings, as well as my own. This of the Lerche and Folkstone is a very good outlook: in one of those clean-looking House near that worst of Inns, JWC and TC had stayed at the West Cliff Hotel, Folkestone, with the Ashburtons, JWC from 28 June and TC from 5 July until 7 July 1862; see 38:105JWC to TC, [29 June 1862], and 113JWC to TC, [2 July 1862]; see also JWC to TC, 15 Aug. beside such a Landlady you will be as well as you cd anywhere be; and I will not dread the August of London for you with such a back-door. If the Stanleys have come to Alderley (as I suppose, but of course you will strictly ascertain), the Program for you is now very fair to me, or at least greatly improved. I have little faith in “quinine, iron” &c; but if the “eight” have produced any really “perceptible” effect, I cherish firm hope in it, the omnipotence of the liver being a thing painfully known to me for the half-century
past! The result of my 1 is like that of yr 8; barely “perceptible” (yet really so) on the beneficent side,—while it continues to make such hagglement in my sleep, I pause another day, perhaps altogr, before taking any second.

Spedding’s Letter, coupled with the Erskine Program and that of the Western Isles voyage &c induces me to resolve on doing Spedding first: “Monday next, 17th,” is the day I mean to appoint with him; I can be here agn from him by the middle of the week,—and in that way (if yr Stanleys &c are right), may see you off (poor little Pilgrim) before going north. On “Friday 14th,” I will see you at Dumfries, in the interim (may my news of you be propitious!)—Mary, much flattered by yr wish, will be with me; I had thot of that before, but said nothing till you spoke. “Mrs Macdonald” I cannot find out. I got no “Note” from Lady Ashbn, nor sent any. “Seaton for winter” is a thing that makes one shriek! Say we will wait for Melchett.— Yesternight I drove with Austin on Noggs to near Colinn: Collin, village 3½ mi. (5.5 km.) E of Dumfries. never saw a better performer in the gig.; pace like air, needs not the least driving, scours up all the Hills, did then 14 miles in 1½ hour. An excellt little Noggs,—will be a treasure wherevr he goes!— And now for my “Chattery” departt. I send you the Spedding Letter; not the Otthenn, lest the wax on it prove too heavy (n.b. yrs of this morning was “over-weight”),—burnt child dreads fire. Adieu, Dearest. Ever ­affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [11 July]. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:271–73.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest,—A regular wet day. No drive possible. Well, the image of driving you have just set before my imagination—you driving me with Noggs in London—is quite enough for one day. It melts the marrow in my bones! Nor is there much relief in turning to that other picture—little Mary flying through the air in one of his ‘explosions’ and breaking her skull! Mary Welsh, JWC’s cousin at Auchtertool; TC had suggested giving Noggs to her; see TC to JWC, 10 July. If you were to put an advertisement in the newspapers that the horse of Thomas Carlyle was for sale, there would be competition for the possession of it.

The housemaid, Marion; see JWC to TC, [15 July]; possibly Mary Hunter (b. 1833), one of Alicia Ewart’s three servants listed in 1861 Census. while combing my hair this morning, fell to telling me of
‘ever so many young drapers, an’ the like,’ that of her knowledge had ‘run frae Thornhill to the station to get a bare look o’ Mr. Carlyle! And when Mr. Morrison’ (the minister of Durrisdeer) Rev. David Morrison. ‘cam’ to his dinner yesterday, the first word oot o’ his heed, on the very door-steps, was: “Is Mrs. Carlyle still here?” He never asket for Mrs. Ewart or the ither ladies, but only for you, mem!’ I endeavoured to inform her mind by telling her, ‘Yes; people liked to see any lady much spoken of, whether for good or ill. If Dr. Pritchard “Glasgow poisoner in those weeks” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:272). Edward William Pritchard (1825–65; ODNB ), surgeon, who was convicted on 7 July of poisoning his wife, Mary Jane, b. Taylor (d. 25 Feb. 1865) and his mother-in-law, Mary Jane Cowper Taylor (d. 17–18 March 1865). Pritchard’s hanging in front of Glasgow jail on 28 July was attended by 100,000 people. had been at the station, all Thornhill together would have run to see him.’ ‘Oddsake!’ said the girl, ‘I daresay they would; I daresay ye’re richt; but I never thocht o’ that afore.’

Geraldine writes that never was such ‘emotion’ excited by a speech as by this of Mill’s. Mill held several pre-election meetings early July; see TC to JN, 8 July. This was probably a report of the meeting held at St. James’s Hall, 5 July, reported in the Morning Star, the Daily Telegraph, the Daily News, and the Times, 6 July; for the speech, see TC to JWC, 12 July. ‘Public Opinion’ came addressed to you at Nith Bank in Mrs. Warren’s “Servant here” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:272). hand. How she came to know the name Nith Bank I am puzzled to know.

I took the quinine and iron yesterday twice, and slept rather sounder than otherwise. But I had a badish headache all morning. Nevertheless I took another dose before breakfast, as Dr. Russell had ordered, and the headache is wearing off.
I adhere to the intention of Dumfries for Friday, if it suit you and Mary.
docBody.name: J ane .

div3.sourceNote: TC-TSS, 11 July. MS: John Spedding. Pbd: A. Carlyle CS 762.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS STORY SPEDDING

docBody.p:
Dear Spedding,—We will say Monday, then; “Monday 17th,” unless you hear to the contrary, whh is beyond my expectatn. People learned in “Bradshaw” tell me there is ready access by a certain train from Annan (no waiting at Penrith), and ditto return, on the same conditns. Note we get no Letters here,
after Saturday morning,—owing to desecratn of the Sabbath. Blessings on us: “Fourth Part of a Lunation” (for that is the whole mystery of it) still making such a figure at this late age of the Planet!

My Wife is in Nithsdale for abt four weeks past;—fled to her excellent old Doctor there, being agn in much suffering, from an arm that has fallen lame, painful continually, and prohibits sleep to a sad degree. She is but slightly improved, but is slightly within the last ten days. She is thirty miles from my solitude here, or one hour. She keeps her heart up wonderfully; intends home next week; and will be very sorry she cannot come with me. Adieu, then, till Monday, dearSpedding.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 July]. Addr: The Gill / Annan. PM: Thornhill, 12 July 1865. MS: NLS 609.730. Quot: Bliss, JWC 323; Ashton 437.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Just two lines, Dear, that you may not think something has happened! But Mrs Macdonald (Elizabeth Ewart that was, Sister to Mrs Ewart illbehaved Husband Thomas Ewart. who was my Uncle Robert’s Partner, JWC’s uncle Robert Welsh (d. 1842; see 14:217JWC to MW, [8 July? 1842]) was a lawyer. and we once thought my Uncle would marry Elizabeth who was very fond of him—and when she saw me last year she couldn’t speak for the tears in her throat!)—well she is expected to arrive in a few minutes with Mrs Yorston of Allington and her Brother Unidentified further. and there will be hubbub wild and dire dismay One of JWC’s phrases (see 23:242JWC to JW, [27 Feb. 1849] and elsewhere), based on Milton’s “hubbub wild,” Paradise Lost 2:951. till they leave after an early dinner.
