And then we are to drive to Durrisdeer to take early tea at the Manse. The Minister a tall handsome intelligent young man having been struck with the most passionate love for me at first sight! because I am Mrs Carlyle!! He being another of your Adorers! “Altogether” Coterie speech; see 16:262JWC to TC, [11 July 1843]. the Church of Scotland seems to be in a dangerous way! As for this Mr Morrison “it is but fair to state” Coterie speech; see 9:175TC to JAC, 21 March 1837. that his behaviour since he first set eyes upon me has exhibited every feature of a real and violent passion!

Meanwhile I take my iron and quinine, with great advantage to my appetite and my arm—but—as usual I shall have to discontinue it I fear on account
of the effects on my sleep. Last night was the worst since I came here. The first half of it spent awake, seeing crowds of faces mostly with one eye! and very white!
It is such a pity for I am sure the Quinine would cure my wretched arm, if I durst continue to take it
Till Friday then goodby!
docBody.name: J W C

ps.p: Madame Venturi sends me Mazzinis description of a Dinner Untraced. he had partaken of “A crushed Fish; Some conspicuous Bird—Goose—what shall I say? A viscous fabric, and a Pie whatever!”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 July. Addr: Nith-Bank House / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 13 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.709. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Well-done, left-hand; and thanks for the goodish news you still send me! News still rather good, compared with what there used to be: if it please Heaven, we are perhaps coming to the outlet of this long labyrinth! At any rate, we are to meet on Friday:—Friday will be yr birthday, 14 July. moreover; poor little soul!—

Nothing is wrong here either,—tho’ almost everything seems more or less to be in that predicamt: the fact is, owing partly to accidt, partly to mismanaget and impatience of my own, I lost my sleep nearly altogether last night;—and made on the whole one of the worst nights I have yet had; whh turns everything into sable. I designed, and still design, to have a ride instead of walking and gigging today, and to be very dietetic: but it is no help to me, that poor Jean, ignorant of Friday & its outlooks, has arrived to “pass the day with me”! However, she is very pa-patient, Letters repeated at turn of page. very modest in her claim, good soul; and will not stand in my way more than what is inevitable. “Writing,” however, after my six Notes of yesterday is evidently no charity to you, nor any duty to anybody.— — I send the Otthennin whh you may burn witht reading (tho’ don’t); item the John, whh is concise as a Grocer’s Bill, & has particles of news in it. The Spedding Enterprise, fixed for Monday, looks fearful today, to my agitated sense; but is not! It is rather the beginning of release from this imprisont in idle stagnancy; a thing much wanted. Mrs Warren heard of Nith-Bank from me as yr address if things were to be sent you; & has mistaken it for mine.

No news from Neuberg yet: perhaps he will accept the Noggs? He probably
were the fittest: to break poor Mary Welsh’s head with Noggs, as terrify you by driving him in London is far from me!— Mill’s Speech Mill’s election speech, 5 July; he had not sought public office, nor did he think it right attempting to persuade people to vote for him; he was adamantly opposed to the spending of money on electioneering as that led to corruption. Glad to answer any questions, he saw no point in being anything other than perfectly honest, even if that meant that some might disagree with him; speaking about the difference between Toryism and Liberalism, he aligned himself firmly with the Liberals. See also JWC to TC, [11 July]. is very honest and good (thanks for sending it),—but is not a thing to fall into “emotion” abt. I really know not, if I even loved him far more than I do, whether to wish him electn or rejectn, where he now is. Will have no hand in it at any rate!— Young Jamie Aitken (who copiously waved a white handkerchief upon us yesternight) has returned with a “collar-bone broken” (never was sich Thus in MS, TC confusing “such” and “sic.” a fellow for accidts!) James Aitken had previously broken his collarbone in June 1863; see 39:154–55TC to JCA, 14 June 1863. —otherwise well en-enough. Letters repeated at turn of page. A few words to him will suffice you on Friday (fear nothing!)— You come by the early train 11.3 a.m. on Friday. Adieu my own dear Goody, sole possessn in the world. / Ever yrs
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EW [EWA], 13 July. MS: Univ. of California, Berkeley.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: Mark this fine fellow! He is a madman, First mentioned in March; see 41:193JWC to JBUL, 19 March; unidentified further. in Chelsea (so far as I can guess), who sends me, every few months, a batch of curses (genlly unfranked),—of whh I now read only the first syllable, when they do get access to me, whh they cannot except by accidt such as this.— Mark his hand, if you can another time;—and indeed it will be safe for you to refuse everybody that demands two-pence as a preliminary. Bedlam being so populous in our day!—

I am for a brief run over to the Lake Country (for the sake of an old Friend there);—after whh there is to be (hopes my Brother at least) “voyage to the Hebrides,” to John o’Groat’s TC visited John o’ Groats, NE corner of Scotland, 22 Aug. 1860; for his account, see 36:220–212 Sept. 1860. &c &c! Till the beging of Septr, I avoid London.— If you ever see Forster, John Forster. tell him “Chelsea” as an Address will always find me before long;—and that I do much desire to have a word from him.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: The Gill, 13 july, 1865—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 July. Addr: at Nith-Bank House / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 13 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.710. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I am thankful for the quinine, Dear, tho’ you will have to allow it a pause for the sake of yr sleep. Surely, on the whole, things are looking up, aren’t they, with my poor Goody and me? If you also went to Durisdeer yesterday. I hope yr Lover Rev. David Morrison; see JWC to TC, 12 July. proved faithful;—at any rate that you didn’t dine on a “Pie whatever” with the other charming items. See JWC to TC, 12 July. — What a pen, what a hand (ready for shaking at a second’s notice), what a bit of paper! But we shall meet tomorrow; and there is no need of hieroglyph writing at present. The scrubby busss of writing Notes with my prest apparatus outer & inner is one of the miseries of life,—whole day capable of perishing in that poor function and others of the like!

I have got a good soundish sleep (wd you had half as good, poor wakeful captive!)—Jean’s attendance yesterday, whh led to double quantities of walking, was probably beneficial after all. I have to write to Erskine, & will then take to read and lounge. Poor little Mrs Symmonds! Isabella Simmonds’s da. Ethel d. 2 July; see JWC to IS [IEB], 10 July. — Keep Mérimée’s Letter for me; his 3 correctns are all good. Prosper Mérimée (1803–70), French novelist, historian, and translator; TC met him while staying with the Ashburtons in Paris, autumn 1851; see 26:188–89TC to JWC, 28 Sept. 1851, and 191–92TC to JWC, 1 Oct. 1851; presumably he sent TC corrections of Frederick. The Nash bulletin will, I fear, cost me a sovn. Possibly John Wesley Nash (b. 1813), assistant librarian of the London Lib. (see 30:68TC to EF, 15 Sept. 1855), possibly requesting a subscription; he lived at 12 Little College St., Chelsea; otherwise unidentified. The rest of my “Letters” are trash trash; zero and worse,—attack by my Chelsea Madman (unfranked & costing 4d), whh, on the first glance, went to the God of Fire; Doggerel from Manchr on Emancipn of Nigger, Unidentified. do do: ah me!— — Now, come witht mistake or mischance; and God keep thee, Dearest.
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Nothing yet from Neubg. Noggs, I have got now reason to believe, must have cost poor Lady A. abt £150! That really seems likely: good Heavens!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [15 July]. MS: NLS 609.732. Hitherto unpbd. Friday was 14 July but JWC mistook the day.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Nith Bank House Friday [Saturday 15 July 1865] TC came to Nithbank on Fri., 14 July, so this letter was written on Sat., 15 July.
docBody.p: I am afraid that you will have suffered more than I have done from yesterdays explosion of—Hero-worship! The dinner in TC’s honor; he wrote later at the end of the MS: “from Her (a second) 17 July 1866 [1865] :—ah, how beautiful she was at that dinner of Nithbank, & ever will to my sad & loving recollectn.” In his reminiscences of JWC, TC recalled their drive together and the dinner: “Waiting for me with the carriage [at the station]; ‘Better, Dear, fairly better since I shifted to Nithbank!’—the ‘dinner’ ahead there (to my horror), her cautious charming preparation of me for it; our calls at Thornhill … our long drive through the Drumlanrig woods, with such talk from her (careless of the shower that fell, battering on our hood and apron); in spite of my habitual dispiritment, and helpless gloom all that Summer, I too was cheered for the time. And then the dinner itself, and the bustling rustic company, all this, too, was saved by her, with a quiet little touch here and there, she actually turned it into something of artistic, and it was pleasant to everybody” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 184). Not that I myself had as good a night as the previous one. But I did not expect two such nights consequitively. And then those Bluepills! they couldnt be taken night after night, for ever, with impunity! This morning. They made themselves felt “rather exquisitely.” Coterie speech; see 16:198JWC to JW, [15 June 1843]. The interesting Phenomena which resulted were little improved as to snow-white innocence of colour. But one’s heart was consoled by a singular exhibition after of the purest golden liquid Bile! I suppose I may now discontinue the Blue Pills— And Time! For I feel to be getting painfully weak—and am day and night bathed in perspiration! Indeed all I seem to have achieved by my three weeks of “Country air” “milk diet” “quiet” and all that sort of thing, is to have brought myself round to be no worse than I was before I came!

Dr Russell hasjust been here and I told him you had been in the same way, and he bade me say he entreated you not to suffer that to go on but to take any number of Blue Pills that should be found necessary to stop it. Remember I have taken eight (four grainseach) without killing myself!

You were immensely admired yesterday! Poor little Christie Possibly John S. Christie (b. ca. 1818), landowner, Halleath House, Lochmaben (22 mi. [35.5 km.] from Thornhill). declared it “the proudest day of his Life”!
Mrs Ewart saidwhen we were left alone, “Weel its made the Creturs rale happy! If Mr Carlyle isn’t the waur for’t it was worth whileto gie them the chance!”

The Misstress counted it a day o’ luck (Marion the maid said to me this morning) for first the present o’ strawberries came fra Alington, For Allanton, home of the Yorstouns. when oo could get nane here! And then the grand red Book (Frederick) that Mrs Ewart has been expecting ever so long arrived just in time to lay it oot on the Drawing room table!! Ae! isnt it an awfu muckle Book!
Oh do take the Pills
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 15 July. MS: NLS 609.731. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:327–29 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.dateline: Nith Bank / Thornhill Dumfries shire / 15 July [1865]
docBody.p: It has been often in my mind that you would think me growing neglectful—so long it is since I wrote you any letter! But there was needed the prompting of your own dear letter, forwarded back from London this morning, to stir me up to undertake the fatigue which writing is for me at present and has been for more than two months back. You must know that every thing I do; even to putting the food into my mouth; has to be done with my left hand which I was not ever before in the habit of using at all! and which protests against the unwonted demands on it by taking the cramp every now and then; so that writing is really only to be attempted in cases of necessity! For my right hand and arm are entirely disabled by neuralgia! and besides having no earthly use of them, the pain—just like a bad toothache in my arm and hand, hinders me from sleeping and eating. So my London Dr Dr. Richard Quain. being unable to give me relief ordered me off to Scotland again as that had done me so much good last year.

So I came to Mrs Russells at Holmhill—where I am always welcomed like an own Child, just a month ago. A fortnight of the time I have been with Mrs Ewart of Nith Bank. But I go back to Holmhill tomorrow for another week—and then back to London!—without seeing you, my Darling!— I did not send you word when I first came for I was hoping my wretched arm might really derive some benifit from the change of air, and if it permitted me any pleasure in life I had it in my heart to proceed to Edinburgh just to see you. As for my Aunts, Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh, JWC’s three paternal aunts, living in Edinburgh. their invitations, if they give any are so little cordial that I neednt put myself to any expense or trouble for the sake of seeing them!

My idea was to ask you to find a lodging for me and my Maid Jessie Hiddleston. for a day or
two and then take the train for London. But this beautiful little scheme has been knocked on the head by the fact that my arm continues as bad as ever, making me shrink from all journeyings and changings that can be avoided and only anxious to get back to my own quiet bed at Chelsea.

It is such a dreadful pity that the journey from Edinr to Thornhill is so indirect and interrupted. I would be only too happy to pay your expenses here to see me if it werent that I know the journey would be both too fatiguing and too confusing for you! We are none ofus so young as we have been Dear!
On the 24th then I start for London—and will write or make somebody write on myarrival
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Kind regards to Mrs Duncan Possibly Mary Duncan (b. ca. 1813); see 41:166JWCto BB, 14 Feb.
Mr Carlyle is going North and will not be home till September

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JR [JRU], 15 July. MS: Yale. Pbd: Cate 111–12.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Oh howdelightful! My dear Mr Ruskin! That nice long letter and lovely little Book— Imagine! they came to me the first thing on my Birthday morning! Ruskin wrote, 13 July, enclosing a copy of his new book, Sesame and Lilies (1865). He replied, 17 July: “I am so happy about the birthday—and very proudly happy that I can give you pleasure on any day”; JWC’s birthday was 14 July. Came with all the charm of a Birthday present!—— You once gave me strawberries and cream on my Birthday—do you remember? In 1856, JWC described Ruskin driving her, TC, and Nero the dog on two outings to Ruskin’s family home, Denmark Hill, summer 1855; in one they had strawberries and cream on the lawn (see 31:38JWC to WA, 23 Feb. 1856). (I have never seen such strawberries and cream since! nor have I had any such pleasant Birth-day since! but all have passed in pain and sorrow!) I like the Book and letter far better however, because these will keep! And being superstitious a little, as a Scotch woman ought to be, I draw ever so many good omens from the Book and Letter beginning a new year of Life for me! One piece of good I clearly divine therefrom; that you are not going to forget poor me in the pressure of your avocations and distractions but will care for me, and give me flowers now and then, as long as I last!
What a talent for naming you have!
“Of Kings Treasuries!

Of Queen’s Gardens! “Of Kings’ Treasuries” and “Of Queens’ Gardens,” the subtitles of the two parts of Sesame and Lilies; they were originally delivered as lectures in Manchester in 1864; see Ruskin’s Works 18:53–108, 109–44.

The names lift me already into the sphere of the Arabian Nights! The other 1855 trip to Denmark Hill was for a dinner at the Ruskins’ that JWC compared to “what one reads of in Arabian Nights” (31:38).

Please tell your Mother Margaret Ruskin. how much I am obliged to her for her call, altho’ I was so unlucky as miss it. Ruskin wrote: “[M]y mother & I concocted a visit to you—and we got up really a nice flower—and away we went to Chelsea my mother so particular about her two cards! one to be for Mr. Carlyle’s mythic presence. So when we got there they said you were in Scotland—but couldn’t tell me where, or I should have written long ago.” And you may add, if you like, that I am sure she would not dislike me if she knew me: for, the only time I ever saw her, I felt to take to Her very much, because she said no superfluous or insincere word! And I have always found that those I take to at first sight take to me sooner or later if they give themselves a fair chance. Ruskin replied, 17 July: “My mother is very cock-ahoop too about your pretty message—but that is good for her—for she’s always snubbing me and then I say impertinent things to her—which she pretends not to mind—but does; and while she is always saying things which look as if she was the most conceited person in the world—she is really very uncomfortably humble—and glad of a bit of nice praise like this of yours.”

I cannot understand your persistence in forgetting Mrs Hawks (Madame Venturi)! She is to my mind perfectly charming! If you knew the romantic thing she once did for love of you, it would fix her in your mind for ever!

“My lamed hand”! Alas no! It is not with that I write. That is quite past making any sort of writing whatever! It is too painful to attempt using it at all. So I have had to learn to write with my left hand, which protests against the unwonted exaction in taking every now and then the Cramp! Ruskin wrote, 13 July, “I have the sorrow of knowing you wrote all that with your lame hand,” and then replied, 17 July: “I wrote ‘lame hand’ carelessly, but I had read your letter. I meant the cramp-taking left hand—not the disabled one / But you must get the hands into order—we can’t have strikes right & left like this.”
I hope to get home on the 24th or 25th.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle
docBody.note: JWC apparently sent Ruskin a photograph, as he commented, 17 July: “The photograph is very sweet in expression— Keepable, which few are.” He signed the letter: “unremissedly in affection and duty to you always your—J. Ruskin.”

ps.p: I saw Mr Carlyle yesterday. entirely sick of “Solitude” which he has got to call “Stagnation”! Heis about to start on further travels.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 July. MS: NLS 518.3 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—My notion is, after reading the Inclosed of Sir G., Sir George Sinclair. is that, directly, or in a few days, after my return from Cumberland, we shd, upon the single conditn of the weather being good, address ourselves for Scrabster Harbor 2 mi. (3 km.) NW of Thurso. & Joh Thus in MS. o’Groat’s:—by Leith Edinburgh’s port on the Firth of Forth. will probably do far best. At Thurso, with the Orkneys &c we may easily do for a week or more; thence at leisure thro’ the Hebrides for Glasgow: Erskine we can thence do by rail thro’ Edinr agn or otherwise; and that done, creep our ways home.

My address (for Wedny) is T. Spedding, Mire[house Keswick Cumberland if] Bottom of page cut off, presumably for the signature on the reverse. you have anything to say. Tell Jean I want three dozen complete of the Nibloe William Nibloe (1815–89), Dumfries shoemaker; see 37:28JWC to LAI, 24 Oct. 1860. shoe-strings: item, two dozen do of the round plaited kind (whh were likewise found perfect & have some advantages) accordg to the specimen left yesterday: after that, I will establish a little Drawer at Chelsea, marked shoe-strings; and have done, for life, with that indispensable but thrice & four times paltry departt of mycares.

Last night, by the utmost stretch of inventive art (shutting the window, opening the vent &c &c) I achieved a sound sleep in spite of the metallic screameries; and am very much less miserable than yesterday all day. Begging everybody’s forgivenness for all my shortcomings, whh are always too many End of letter and signaturecut off.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 16 July. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Jamie,—I am going off for Keswick tomorrow (leave Annan at “12.6 p.m.” Monday, just abt while you are reading this); I calculate to be back on Thursday,—and am thinking of coming by Scotsbrig (2.45 p.m. at Ecclefn Thursday) to see you all agn, and perhaps stay for a two or three days. But this I will appoint for more specially by a Note from Keswick, if it hold good. In case I come, either Jean or else Mary will be there to take care of me, and relieve you from that troublesome task.

Jane goes for London Tomorrow (Monday) week,—punctual. We Mary & I went to meet her at Dumfries the day before yesterday; she is very sensibly improved since that sad day when she missed you here. Instead I flatter myself she is now really getting better by degrees. After her departure, Jack and I are for Thurso, for John O’ Groat’s, the Western Isles, who knows where!— I have still some kind of hope, you may see Jane, by our mutual contrivance, for a little minute somewhere before she quite vanish.

Noggs proves to be one of the best Gig-horses going; “perhaps in the County none better,” thinks Austin! He went yesterday 3 & 20 miles (the final 12 of them I with him) over hill and dale in a most swift, steady and respectable manner. Austin seems to me to drive with great judgt. I am thinking to give Noggs away to some friend; sale of him, at the 4th, perhaps at the 10th part, of what he cost 2 years ago (tho’ his quality in the interim has improved, not declined), wd be impossible.
My Address (shd you unexpectedly have any use for it) will be Thos Spedding Esq / Mirehouse / Keswick / Cumberld.
OnThursday at a ¼ to 3, let me hope to be at Ecclefn, and see you all agn!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 16 July. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.dateline: The Gill, Cummertrees Annan N.B. 16 july 1865
docBody.p: My Wife,—rather improved in health, tho’ still suffering from pain in the arm and imperfectn of sleep,—is to set out for Chelsea Tomorrow week (i.e. Monday july 24th); she intends to do the whole in one day,—whh is not a thing I altogether like, if handy to avoid.

Alderley’s and especially Lady Stanley’s hospitable feelings towards us are a thing now known for a generatn past! Privately my notion is, Jane wd not dislike pausing with you for one day;—and I can publicly testify that she is far better company than I am at prest; and has a maid Jessie Hiddleston. with her, and will cost no special trouble.

I am going into Cumberland, tomorrow, for a brief visit; after whh extensive voyagings (Western Isles, John o’ Groat’s &c &c) are on the carpet; & I can give no definite acct of myself, except gradually to Chelsea,—whh I don’t expect to see agn till Septr at soonest. I have lain here for these 6 weeks, the mutest, laziest & most stagnant of all the sons of men. Never in my life so tired before. But am now to get astir agn in some measure. I was deeply sensible of Ld Stanley’s kindness in re Bullock, Lord Stanley was postmaster general in the government of Henry John Temple (1784–1865; ODNB ), 3d Viscount Palmerston, politician; Whig prime minister, 1855–57 and 1859–65; presumably TC asked him for some assistance for John Bullock, the Carlyles’ postman in Chelsea since 1857. tho’ I said nothing. I send my loving regards to one & all of you. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 July. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Annan, 17 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.711. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I am at my old trade agn, scribble-scribbling: to Jamie, to Lady Stanley, to &c &c not to poor Goody till now, sinner that I am!), Thus in MS; no opening parenthesis. —whh with a hand of this shakiness and an apparatus all do do is truly nothing of a favourite with me. But let me tell you the indispensable with brevity; for all my packing &c, and all my riding (if any), are still to do. Oh Goody dear, cd I but know that things go well with thee, how much happier were I in my own shoes (whh are none of the easiest) here,—amid the hurries of adjusting!

Fear not, howr: I slept miraculously well that dangerous Friday night. After his visit to JWC at Mrs. Ewart’s, 14 July; see JWC to TC, [15 July]. Whole glass of brandy in tumbler of hot milk, cunning arrangts before (window close shut, vent opened, &c &c), I actually fell asleep at once; did not awake till 6 a.m. with my haggard terrors and flurries much gone; and managed, after a little fugling, to sleep agn for above 2 hours,—some eight in all (far better than poor Goody, I doubt!)—and have been in a restored state ever since. It is these blue fellows mainly! Yesterday the second of them prosecuted me, as physic too, with all the rigour of law: and I really suppose, both of
them have done me essential good; but I will have no more partnership with them at prest.— It was necessary to get thro’ all this botheratn; and cut loose from my now stagnancy: Go ahead, then; from Annan tomorrow at 12.6; safe in Keswick (if we prosper) while you are sitting down at Holm Hill to dine.

Neuberg, you see, rejects Noggs;—very well; and his advice abt keeping him too had already occurred to me as a safe pis-aller [stopgap]. He becomes-omes Repeated with a line over it at start of new page. eminent ever more, day by day, as a Gighorse; did his two journeys yesterday (one to Annan on household busss with Mary), the 2d a rough 12 miles more, and behaved royally thro’out. Poor Noggs, as he looked in my face thro’ his blinders and all ungroomed after our fine performance, it seemed to me said, “Master, what is this!” in a loyal but tragic humour; and I was sorry for the poor dumb heart. He actually likes me, I perceive, and is glad when I ride him.— The Quarterly Review (see Fredc Chapman) Presumably Frederic Chapman wrote to tell TC of the review of vols. 5 and 6 of Frederick in the July edn. of the Quarterly Review. will attend you in London, if you care for it. I saw nothing, heard of nothing but what he notes.

At Keswick I must try to hold out till Thursday any way; promise goes no farther. I must duly indicate what is to be done abt a sight of you before Monday following,—or on, if that alone be feasible. Oh my Dear, my poor Dear!—

Lady Stanley is warned to warn you, “at Holm-hill, on or before Saturday,” if she do wish you to come: if she don’t, nothing is to be said by her to me or to you,—and my Note to her is an unknown transactn, completely sub rosa, by hypothesis. She will hardly get yr Letter till Wednesday; sooner than Saturday, she cannot well hit you. Let me hope she will!—

Yr news of today (you are writing today!) will not get to Keswick till Wednesday; by return at latest, I will write. My prest plan is rather to come back by Scotsbrig,—Jamie’s visit with me to Craigenputtock As the owner of the property, TC liked to visit Craigenputtoch occasionally to check that all was well; see TC to JWC, [8 Aug.]. &c:—but you shall hear. Old Sinclair is on wait at Thurso; John, in Dumfries, was deep in “Western Isles” Cap-Capabilities. Repeated at turn of page. So soon as ever the weather takes up,—Thurso will really be good, I think. Oh,Darling, how wae & weak I am!
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 July. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: Windermere, 18 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.712. Quote: Froude, Carlyle 4:290; Wilson, Carlyle 6:17.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I am sitting tremulously waiting for yr Letter (arrives at 12, ansr must go at 2): Heaven grant the news may be propitious; I am not, at prest, in the most impugnable humour. And my hand is going at such a rate as you see!—

Yesterday at 11 I left Gill,with Austin and Noggs conducting; got in at Annan; carriage empty, day fine, journey altogether fortunate (pause of ½ hour at Carlisle, at Penrith Penrith, market town about 18 mi. (29 km.) S of Carlisle. only of 6 minutes, all my 3 successive carriages empty),—a journey altogether towardly, and not unpleasant tho’ so very sad to the poor heart of me— Punctual to the hour (2.39) I was at Keswick, found Spedding with equipage attending,—who joyfully welcomed me, & a certain dark young gentn as well,—the dark yg gentn proving to be a Scotch Parson, formerly his son’s Tutor, whom he had summoned from Kilwinning Probably John Sime (1837–1904), educ. St. Andrews Univ., minister of Kilwinning, Ayrshire, 1864–66, his first position; the Spedding son was Henry Anthony Spedding. all the way to bear me compy on this occasn. A perfectly harmless yg gentn, tho’ a perfectly superfluous. My welcome was all that honest cordiality and anxious simplicity of kindness cd do. Right fain wd I, after my final drive of 5 miles, have gone to sleep in my fine bedroom, with inviting sofa: but in the circs it was not permitted; & we had to struggle on (not ill at all, tho’ they set me talking too much,—and I can’t help it!) till midnight nearly; nor, alas, were my sorrows ended then. I have the finest of 4-post beds, spacious sleeping room equally excellt; silence for, a long time, as of Elysium:—but, alas, sleep was not quite propitious! Till 4 a.m. I at least lay motionless in half-sleep; tried tobacco then, with good hope; but, well before 5, there flew down a beautiful cochin-china, whom I hear even now (but whom I intend to get imprisoned for this night and the following)! In spite of this majestic Animal, I managed at last, by clapping a finger in my ear, to sink into abt one hour of real sleep: after whh from 7 to 9½ I had to be content with sauntering in the walks & woods feeling really not ill at all, but better than usual, with nothing of the dismal old queasy feeling I hitherto had. For 2 nightsmore, I can make this kind of thing do (tho’ tonight it will probably mend); after whh I make for Annandale agn; and see my poor Goody at least before she go.

The familyhere consists mainly of 3 beautiful yg ladies Thomas and Frances Spedding had three das., Margaret, Frances, and Mildred. (children when I
was last here), and one taciturn rather gawkyish yg son, do do; and all are amiable and most polite,—including Ma & Pa most especially. Kilwinning, amiable youth, has contributed but little hitherto,—except one joke from Annan. He had seen me from the next Car-Carriage Letters repeated at start of new page. when I entered there; a gentn or gent said to a gent, “Is that Mr Carlyle?” “Yes,—& there is Mr Ewart Presumably William Ewart, just reelected as M.P. for Dumfries Burghs; see TC to JWC, 5 July. too.” “Oh, d—n Ewart; is that Cle!”— Today we are to have certn Marshalls dining (fresh from their Island in Keswick Lake); Henry Cowper Marshall (1808–84), partner in Marshall & Co., flax spinners of Leeds; TC had known the family since the 1830s; see 10:95TC to MAC, 12 June 1838. Marshall and his five surviving children, John (1840–94), Theodosia Louise (1841–92), Stephen (1843–1904), Francis Edward (1847–1922), and William Cecil (1849–1921), lived on Derwent Island in Derwentwater, nr. Keswick. won’t do much for us! Tomorrow if I might hope we shall have nobody rather.— — It is 10 min. past 12: can it be possible I am having no Letter from you today! I will go down & see; pause at any rate will be wholesome!— Yesterday I had the two Newsprs addressed to you in blue (had Keswick Post still been alive), of whh you get one today; the other I will reserve till Thursday, as a sign from Ecclefn or—Anan! Oh that there be a letter!— Post is come; and for me there is nothing: alas, alas! But I will not set my imaginatn roving. I will saunter out into the blessed blue Day, & reflect that this is the Place of Hope. See Carlyle, Sartor 121. God be with thee, Dearest. Tomorrow I surely shall hear.

Look in PublicOpinn for an admirable bit of Ruskin’s (in some miscellans column) on the house-fly & the house-dog). Public Opinion, 15 July, reprinted part of chap. 6 of Ruskin’s “The Cestus of Aglaia,” which was being serialized in the Art Journal; see TC to JRJRU, 13 May. The subject of the chapter was freedom, and Ruskin compared the life of a housefly to that of a watchdog, the former completely free and the latter bound to its owner: “Yet of the two, would we rather be a watch-dog or fly? Indeed, the first point we have all to determine is not how free we are, but what kind of creatures we are. It is of small importance to any of us whether we get liberty; but of the greatest that we deserve it.” He deplored “the infinite follies of the modern thought in this matter, centred in the notion that liberty is good for a man, irrespective of the use he is likely to make of it” (Art Journal, 1 July 1865). —
docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Oh it is, I suppose, you were so busy all Monday, flitting &c?

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 18 July. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: If you keep the day you named to me; you will be starting on Friday. Fri., 21 July; Lady Ashburton was planning to travel to Wiesbaden for her health; see JWC to Lady ALLA, 25 June. She did not leave London until 27 July; see JWC to TC, [27 July]. So I have left myself hardly more than time to reach you with a parting blessing!

I would have givena good deal to get one look of you and one kiss of you before you put the Sea between us But it has proved impossible for me to get back to Chelsea before the 24th without causing more annoyance and inconvenience than I am all worth!

Mr C isgone on a short visit to Mr Spedding at Keswick and comes here on Saturday to see me before I go. He looked any thing but improved by his beloved “Solitude” when I saw him last—and instead of Solitude he used the term ‘Stagnation’!! I got him to take a blue pill and he writes that it had done wonders for him! He is going to cruise round the Western Isles and go on Shore at Thurso!

For me I narrowly escaped an attack of jaundice since I came! the constant day and night shooting pains in my arm had induced it and I had to take eight blue pills, moi! on eight successive nights!! I am now slightly improved, arm and all, but the small gain does not repay the long journey

Writing grows always more difficult for me instead of less— The left hand with which alone I can hold a pen taking every now and then the cramp by way of protest, I suppose, at the unusualdemands made on it.
Oh what a good andbeautiful thing it would be for you and for me too, to be free of pain—for a while!
God keep you dearest, kindest of Friends! I love you— We love you more than any other living woman!— And that’s truth!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 19 July. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Windermere, 19 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.713. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:290; A. Carlyle, CS 761.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
The Letter did come, Goody dear! At seven p.m. the Butler Unidentified further. came running up with, & I read it half naked:—the goose of a Postman (or Postmaster perhap)
carried it off to Derwentwater Island, & offered it there to Henry Marshall, tho’ the Address was plain as print: Hy Marshll was to be our dinner-guest that evg; and the Letter (thro’ the rebuked Official) arrived here just a few minutes before Mll himself. I thanked Heaven there was nothing wrong after all my speculating Stupid people, they will have set you next on speculating & dubitating! But all is essentially right: I recovered my sleep yesterday & last night; went thro’ my dinner taliter qualiter [for what it was worth] (a good fellow Marshall Père; but his long lank clubnosed son & do daughter Marshall had four sons, and one da., Theodosia. who are of moiish [me-ish] type, the latter mine for the evg, had little of charm for me);—and I am now, i.e. tomorrow at 12.19 from Keswick, going off for Ecclefechan (to arrive there 2.45 p.m.), where on friday morning, sooner cannot be, let there be a word waiting for me!— I cd have staid another day; but they did not seem to press me very much; the yg Scotch Parson goes off some hours before me; and I suspect they are themselves possibly to be occupied some way: in any case, I decided 2 hours, Thus in MS; possibly TC omitted “ago.” on sounding delicately, that we wd stand by our program, and do as above. The place is one of the nicest I ever saw; so neat & yet mixed with wildness & breadth of expansion: everything nice & neat abt it (dairy, cookery, lodging rooms &c &c), simplex munditiis [simple elegance] the real title of it,—not to speak of Skiddaw & the finest mountains of the Earth. Skiddaw, mountain, 3,054 ft. (931 m.), N of Keswick; for TC’s earlier description of the hills beside Skiddaw, see 13:236TC to MAC, 1 Sept. 1841. No care or anxiety visible; but how much must there be below ground, to keep so fair a skin! Adieu to it; & glad I have been there.

No Letter from you today: but Dr Rusll’s Newspaper with two strokes The Carlyles often put pen strokes on newspapers (sent free of charge) to family members indicating all was well. (evidtly under yr dictation) shall be accepted instead. Will the Doctor positively not have Noggs? I shd be delighted so to dispose of him; and you can describe the care & say I know him to be an excellt little Horse,—whom I cannot sell for the fourth part of his value (& shd not like to sell at his full value); whh may instruct the Dr that instead of a “gift” from me it will in reality be a thrice-welcome deliverance from much bother.

Yesterday I made a wildly wide solitary ramble thro’ the country (to see the Inn I first slept in here, with Mitchell, Johnston, & two yg Churches, above 45 years ago,—of the 5 only I and one of the two Ch’s surviving), Robert Mitchell (ca. 1795–1836; see 1:6TC to RM, 30 April 1814) and James Johnston (ca. 1795–1837; see 1:4TC to TM, 24 June 1813), close friends of TC in his youth, and Johnston’s tutees, James and Duncan Church (see 1:159TC to JJ, 1 Jan. 1819). They went on a tour of the Lake District in Aug. 1818; see 1:132–33. The Churches were the brothers of Elizabeth Fletcher (1816–88; see 41:23141:biographical notes) whom John A. Carlyle visited Oct. 1864; see 41:61TC to JAC, 6 Oct. 1864. 7 miles in
all;—& returned so tired that, by aid of sherry and tobacco, I sank into 2½ hours of sleep) and much re-restored Repeated with a line over it at start of new page. my affairs. Post is just passing: adieu Dearest; may my news on Friday be good! (On Friday you have nothing, n.b.) God bless you ever
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 19 July. MS: NLS 518.4. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—I hope you may get this in good time,—perhaps tonight, tho’ I believe it has to go round by Kendal Junctn. Railway junction at Kendal, market town in the Lake District, about 40 mi. (64 km.) S of Carlisle.

I am coming home tomorrow as per program; expect to be at Ecclefechan at 2.45 p.m. with the Scotsbrig gig waiting; if you cd be there then to receive me, it wd be a comfort (as I hope you will be); but in any case Mary will appear next day (the Queensberry Bonfiring John Sholto Douglas (1844–1900; ODNB ), 9th marquess of Queensberry, sportsman, celebrated his 21st birthday, 20 July, with a bonfire and reception for tenants and neighbors at his Glen Stuart estate nr. Annan. excuses them for for Thus in MS. Thursday); after whh she can either stay for the few Scotsbrig days with me, or else return with her Jamie, Mary’s husband, James Austin, as opposed to her brother James Carlyle at Scotsbrig or Jean’s husband, James Aitken, at Dumfries. —leaving my Noggs with saddle & some other items Ishall want.
Jane goes onMonday; Craigenputtoch might & perhaps shd be “seen” before we leave: but after that, I am open to the Doctor and his Plannings for the North.
I have done well enough here: the first night was rather a miss on the sleeping score; but at this point we reckon ourselves every way successful enough.
Abundance of kind inquiries for the Doctor, with regrets that he had not come along with me &c &c
I salute everybody, & hope to find you tomorrow. Yr affectte Brother
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 19 July. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am abt ending, not unprosperously, my little Visit here; and intend to be off tomorrow (Thursday) soon after Noon,—with intention to land upon you at Ecclefechan by a ¼ to 3 (2.45 p.m.) if the railways keep their word. My stay, I think, will not be long; but till Jane go (Monday next), and John have stated our joint course northward, there is nothing more to be said.

Jean, I expect,will be out from Dumfries in the course of Thursday, probably before my arrival; at any rate, Mary and Austin will come driving over on Friday: so that one or other of them will takeme off yr hands while at Scotsbrig.
With kind salutatn to all,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: (Paper amazing scarce; at last, Paper tolerable to write on!)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 20 July. MS: NLS 609.733. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: My Dear! The Postman has been an hour beyond his time today; and Mrs Russell and I are engaged to go to Sanquhar by train to dine with the Wighams The Whigham sisters were Mary (1821–1905), farmer and coal proprietor, Jemima Lucy Maxwell (1827–80), and Elizabeth (1833–1884), who lived at Burnfoot, Sanquhar, Dumfriesshire; see 41:48JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1864, and 23941:biographical notes. and call for old Susy Johnston. Susan Johnston (ca. 1780–1881); she lived at Fingland, Sanquhar. so I have only a few minutes to write. Pobably just as well; as had there been time I might have launched out into too detailed description of my horrid nights since I returned to Holm Hill—and consequently horrid days.

Very curious! I never missed a whole nights sleep at Nith Bank— And my very first night here again I never closed my eyes! And the next night was half spent in being sick! and I know nothing even in the Diet at present to account for this. Anyhow I am glad my visit is to come to anend on Monday for I was not so bad at Home as I am here

There is a letter from Lady Stanley this morning—Quick!— It is kind enough for he
r and asks me to stop two nights! She is expecting Rosalind’s
confinement Lady Stanley’s youngest da., Rosalind Howard, gave birth to her first child, Mary Henrietta, on 20 July at Alderley Park. —the reason for not asking me for longer. It is not a letter to produce an immediate decisive feeling either for or against going. So I must take till tomorrow to think about it.

About meeting? Would it fag you to come here on Saturday, or would you like better seeing me on my way on Monday—at Dumfries or somewhere. If I went by the train Lady Stanley suggests to Chelmsford JWC meant either Chelford Station or Knutsford Station, both nr. Alderley; see TC to JWC, 21 July. at 7.35 pm—I might perhaps be able to wait a while at Dumfries If I could manage about the luggage— If I go to Alderley that “kist” of Jessie’s must be sent direct to London as luggage
Dear Dear I wish I was in my own nice bed—asleep!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: It is quite impossible Dr Russell should take Noggs he never rides on horseback—and his carriage horse is quite satisfactory Noggs couldnt draw his brougham which is a heavier one than mine
Sesame & Lilies / not Semile Kairn Kinna These words are in a heavier ink at the foot of the page; they seem more like practice writing than final (unexplained) comments to TC.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EW [EWA], 21 July. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: I keep to my intention of leaving for Home on Monday next and I have just written to Lady Stanley of Alderley declining her kind invitation to rest there on the road. I was strongly tempted to do this; but her youngest daughter is there in daily expectation of her confinement. And it would have been dreadful to plump into the midst of an affair of that sort—her first child too—

I mean to travel by day this time, so shall arrive, if all go right, about eleven or twelve at night. I would like a fire in the Drawing room put on in the forenoon to air it thoroughly, also a fire in my bedroom.
I had no sleep again last night—and cannot steady my poor left hand to write.
I pray Heaven I may have better sleep in my own bed than I get here!—
I shall need nothing but tea or negus or some such thing—and bread! I hope you will be able to get yeast—you can also have a bit of good bacon—if possible!
Jessie has trunks of the most alarming size! I wish we may get them along without difficulties!
I hope you will be glad to have me back dear woman! Yours kindly
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 July. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Ecclefechan, 21 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.714. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:291; Hansons, NE 534; Wilson, Carlyle 6:17.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Goody, oh that sleep, that sleep! I wish to Heaven you were home agn, where I cannot but perceive you wd be better. It is perfectly heart-breaking, that of lying awake in misery night after night. But courage, we are near the end:—Let me to work, and see how to settle abt monday next. As to myself, in the interim, know that I got hither witht the least mischance, tho’ across infinite bustle and bother; found Jean punctually waiting at Gretna (to pick me up, whh was her own scheme); Jamie waiting with gig at Ecclefechan Station (where we just escaped the bad thunder-shower); and in short, am alive and awake here taliter qualiter, not so ill off even in regard to sleep, of the piecemeal kind;—I mean to have a long ride of Noggs, and see the Water-of-Milk Water of Milk, tributary of the river Annan. Country so soon as I am done. My three days of Keswick are as a small polished flag-stone, whh I am not sorry to have intercalated in the rough floor of boulders whh my sojourn otherwise has mostly been in these parts.

There is no possibility of ansr, from you abt monday! I must therefore spell it out myself; and fix for us both the best I can. First, then, in any and every case, that “Kist” of yr maid’s must go by the Luggage-train: unendurable to bother yrself with an ugly matter of that kind in yr difficult Pilgrimage. Second, I hope there is not the least doubt but you will go by Alderley: I have a Letter yesterday (brot over from The Gill) from Lady Stanley, whh makes it manifest to me that she really does want you, Lady Stanley wrote to TC, 19 July: “I have written to your wife to beg of her to rest with us I am alone with the Howards expecting her confinement any day—but Mrs C will not be the least in my way I hope you will come here on your way South whenever that will be.” and will be afflicted if you don’t. Pause at Alderley, by all means; for two days, or for one, as you find it suit. Maid with you & nobody else but Lady S. and an expectt Rosalind in that big house, you will do very well surely,—and may have driving &c &c to any
length, if only you be bold enough (or as you will call it, impudt enough). As to the train you go by, and our meeting at Dumfries on monday, there will be no difficulty in that either, if you are right in fixing to go by the 7.35 p.m. train from Dumfries: but I have no Bradshaw here, and of my own light, can only guess and believe. “Chelmsford,” whh is in Essex, and above 200 miles from any part of yr route, does indeed rather stagger me, or did; but I conclude you meant Knutsford, See JWC to TC, 20 July. whh is in Alderley neighbd: besides, Jean has heard the Doctor say that, for a complete through journey to London itself, there was no train that did not involve stopping &c, but this single nocturnal one, “7.35 p.m. from Dumfries.”

The course therefore is, Jean & [I] Omitted by TC. make over to The Gill tomorrow; Jean home that night (no trains to scream me awake that evg at Gill, where I can wait till monday morning): you meanwhile to leave Thornhill by what train you like (11 a.m., the best); we all waiting for you at Dumfries (perhaps Jamie of Scotsbrig too, with an eye to Craigenputtoch next day?)—where everybody will do his best to wrap you in cotton, poor sick Dear, and keep you quiet, or how you wish and bid (a darkened bedroom, & really good degree of silence &c) till the time for launching:—God go with you, Dearest.— — This, so far as I can see, is the correct Program, tho’ the one-sided. Oh sleep, oh have some sleep in you, when we meet on monday! A little while longer, & we shall meet in our own Cell at Chelsea after all these wanderings. Good-b’ye till Monday, Dearest. Yrs ever
T. Carlyle

ps.p: A horrible accidt stopt the bonfirings at Kinmount Lord Francis William Bouverie Douglas (1847–65), mountaineer, younger brother of the marquess of Queensbury, d. in a fall, 14 July, on his descent of the Matterhorn after the first successful ascent. The Dumfries and Galloway Courier reported, 25 July: “The sad intelligence reached Glen Stuart … on Wednesday last [19 July], where there was a family gathering, and great preparations had been made for celebrating next day the majority of the noble Marquis: the scene of festivity was at once turned into one of heart-rending grief.” Glen Stuart and Kinmont were part of the same estate. yesterday, and Austin had not to wait till today for coming over

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 21 July. MS: NLS 526.29. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: DearBrother,—Jean met me beautifully yesterday at Gretna, and stept into the carriage with good omens. Nothing has gone much amiss with us here; her partial failure of sleep (not repaired like mine) the sole or principal thing.

Jane, I make out, by much spelling, is to start from Dumfries for Knutsford (near Alderley Park) by the 7.35 p.m. train: she will arrive in Dumfries by the Thornhill 11 a.m. train, and we must try to be kind to her all day; for she is agn suffering from from Thus in MS. want of sleep to a sad degree. I expect she will stay 2 days or 1 day at Alderley: and then, forward by Crewe to L[on]don. Jean I am to take over to The Gill tomorrow, and thence despatch her to Dumfries by some late train, there to be ready for Jane’s transit. On Monday I will be there myself (barring accidt), perhaps Jamie of Scotsbrig too, and on the morrow to Craigenputtoch; at all events, our Southern adventure will then be closed. That is to say, I am then ready for you, and for what you can scheme as to the Hyperborean Voyagings. Perhaps direct for Wick Wick, market town in Caithness, 21 mi. (33.5 km.) SE of Thurso. by that Granton 6 a.m. Steamer See TC to JWC, 10 July. of this day week, if we can do no better? Surely the weather is just abt mending!—

Charles Stuart, whom I once pleasantly met at his late Brother’s, Charles Stewart or Stuart, factor and local historian; for TC’s meeting with him, Oct. 1847, see 22:112TC to JWC, 3 Oct. 1847. His brother was James Hope Stewart. The family generally spelled their name Stewart; TC uses the Stuart form here and in TC to JWC, 3 Aug. I shd like very well to meet agn: perhaps we might rendezvous for an early dinner at Hillside Charles Stewart’s home, a farm 2 mi. (3 km.) N of Lockerbie. some day; I to return hither, you to—? Glen Archibald Glen (ca. 1800–1870), Glasgow businessman; see 40:152–53TC to JWC, 27 July 1864. He had apparently invited John A. Carlyle and TC to visit him, as John wrote to him, 20 July: “I do not know what our plans will be for going North to Thurso; but I will write again when I have seen my brother, and tell you if we can accept your kind invitation” (MS: NLS Acc. 5311). may stand over as a pis aller [stopgap], on the list with Symington Andrew James Symington; he lived in Govan in Lanarkshire. This was the occasion that Symington remembered later: “[TC] wanted to take a sea voyage and had thoughts of visiting Orkney and Shetland, towards which he had often looked, with longing eyes, from Sir George Sinclair’s place at Thurso. His brother the Doctor would accompany him. Would I be at the trouble to find out the sailing of the steamers, jot down the route for him, and name people who would be able to give him local information? This I did for him … and sent on the result to Dr. John A. Carlyle” (A. J. Symington, Some Personal Reminiscences of Carlyle [Paisley and London, 1886] 58–59). if needed.
No more; I am for a long ride on Noggs thro’ the brisk sunny breezes.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 22 July. MS:NLS 609.734. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:329–30 inc. Quot: Surtees, JWC 264.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I am afraid Dear that I have “made a mull of it”! Made a mess of, muddled; possibly JWC’s variant of the Scots proverb, “make a Kirk and a Mill of it”; see 3:399TC to JJO, 26 Oct. 1825. — I should have let you come here today! For there can be no peaceable meeting at Dumfries. I decided against Alderley—and must take our tickets for London here not to lose time or create bother with the luggage. So you will just have to jump in at Dumfries and go a few miles with me.

I told you I must leavethe decision about Alderley till next day. Night would bring counsel. Yes! But one knows what dark premises Deliberation starts from, and what pusillanimous conclusion it arrives at, when Night brings no sleep! And that night again I lay wholly and absolutely awake. So my ignorance of Chelford which I found indeed on the map some fourteen miles from Crew but did not know at all how far it was from Alderley Park,—and uncertainty whether they would send a Carriage for me; and the possibility of the Grand Event The birth of Lady Stanley’s first grandchild; see JWC to TC, 20 July. coming off with me in “another part of the house” the worst timed of creatures! All these objections assumed gigantic proportions over night! and the appointment of “two nights” as the utmost possible limit of the hospitality offered me, chilled my ardour for availing myself of it! not that I had ever an intention of or wish of staying longer. But I disliked not having the credit allowed me of means enough to see when I was inconvenient without needing to be told.
And so I wrote yesterday with many thanks that I could not think of plunging into the midst of the approaching Event.
I took care to word my letter kindly and gratefully. For she did do the thing as handsomely as she could!
On Monday then by the eleven o’clock train—on the Platform
docBody.name: Jane

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 July. Addr: at Holm Hill / Thornhill. PM: Ecclefechan, 23 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.715. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:291. TC wrote “Speed!—” on the envelope, probably an instruction to the post office so that JWC might receive the letter the following morning.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My poor Goody,—You have indeed made a “mull” of it; sleepless pillow is but an unsound counsellor! However, it is now settled immediately; and John Aitken TC’s nephew, youngest son of his sister Jean. is galloping far and wide to countermand the manifold arrangts of my last Letter;—is arrived here, ½ an hour ago, on the Ernhirst Pony (Ernhirst is Mary’s Margaret’s TC’s niece Margaret Stewart. place half way from Dumfries hither); he mounts Noggs instantly and makes for Scotsbrig to pin down Jamie there, who was to have waited at yr carriage abt 11.35 tomorrow and made a second attempt: Jamie Austin too was threatening to come up with me;—perhaps it is much better that you have missed all that: but I am truly grieved at yr miss of Alderley (poor wayworn soul!) and of any chance of rest for abt 11 hours.Oh me, oh me!

By taking an early train tomorrow morning (10 a.m. from this door), I will hope to await you on the Dumfries Platform, and have an interview of 5 minutes net,—there is no other stop till Carlisle, and there only a pause of 13 minutes. My poor witch-hunted Goody; oh what a chace of the fiends:—but, at least, it will end tomorrow night; and oh if you could only get an hour or two of sleep this night, what a blessing it wd be to me; enough to reconcile me almost to the hurlyburly of upset to the extensive plans I had built! I cannot now say at the moment (not till I have seen John tomorrow) whether I shall be at Scotsbrig or here on Wedny morning: Jessie Hiddleston. had better write, to yr dictatn, one word both to Gill & to Dumfries; you, if yr hand will go at all, may try me with “Scotsbrig,” on the morrow after yr arrival. Adieu, Dearest,—till our poor 5 minutes interview tomorrow—

J. Aitken is just getting Noggs saddled; he has to be back on him this evg from Scotsbrig; then to mount Ernhirst agn, and wind up by a walk to Dumfries of 6 miles. But he is a brisk yg fellow, able on horseback too; and will take no hurt. “Sport” to him, in a sense, all this whh is death to us.—— — God grant thee a night’s sleep my own Darling; & courage, courage, since we are now at the sticking place! Cf. Macbeth 1.7.
Adieu,my own Dearest.
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[DM] [DMO], 23 July. Typescript copy; source untraced. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient probably Rev. David Morrison whom JWC met recently and described enthusiastically to TC; see JWC to TC, [12 July].
div3.head: JWC TO [DAVID MORRISON]

docBody.p: It was you; wasn’t it?
I seemed to recognize your handwriting; tho’ I never saw it before, to my knowledge!

Besides, I told nobody but you and Mr Christie Possibly John S. Christie; see JWC to TC, [15 July]. about the Hymns! and Mr Christie’s handwriting is quite different from that! is like this of mine, since I was reduced to only one hand, and it the wrong one! And then, little Mr Christie is too much occupied in coming “home at een,” and seeing things he had never before seen, to have found time for such a spell of copying! To say nothing of the verses Unidentified. having neither rhyme nor reason in them, so far as my Intellect can pierce!
Write a sonnet to my Well! Presumably a well somewhere in the vicinity of Durisdeer, where JWC’s family lived at one time. All out of your own head! There would be some sense in that!
Good by! I am off tomorrow morning!
If you come to London and choose to call for me; you may!
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 24 July. MS: Castle Howard. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p:
My Wife returns you a thousand thanks, as do I,—with ­congratulations from both of us in equal number, on the joyful news she had received
today! The birth of Mary Henrietta Howard; see JWC to TC, 20 July. I saw her at Dumfries some hours ago, and accompanied her a 20 miles;—just shooting off for home at a stretch, hoping to arrive at Chelsea this night, and end her poor wanderings. TC wrote later: “Monday, July 24:—Early in the forenoon I was waiting at Dumfries for her train Londonward; got into her carriage (empty otherwise), and sate talking and encouraging as I could to Annan (which would hardly be an hour). Servant Jessie was in the same train; also Jamie Aitken, junior, for Liverpool. I felt in secret extremely miserable; agitated she, no doubt, and even terrified, but resolute—and the lid shut down. I little thought it would be her last railway journey.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:273). I cd perceive she considerably regretted not having taken you at yr kind word as to Alderley and a day of rest: but her plans had been formed, she owned to me, during a sleepless night, one post before my program reached her (for I was about in Cumberland, and did not see yr Note to me till Friday last); “and now I have made a mull of it,” said she, “and there is no remedy!” Some comfort it is that she is to get thro’ by the quickest conveyance, and have done with the thing at once

I was to send you her warmest congratulations (with my own) on the cleverness of that Fair Rosalind, and the beautiful Gift she has brot you all. May every blessing attend the Two now and henceforth! A word from Miss Stanley Maude Stanley. or some of you, on that latter point, wd be very welcome at Chelsea so soon as might be.

For myself I am now off, on Thursday or at latest Saturday morning, for the Orkneys and the Hebrides, for Edinr, Glasgow, &c &c; and to lead a wandering, chiefly aquatic life;—and do not count on returning home till Augt end. If I pass near Alderley at all, be sure I will alight.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JB [JBUL], [24 July]. MS: NLS 1797.239. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN BULLOCK

docBody.p: Please Mr Bulock to bring the letters, both Mr Carlyles and mine, to 5 Cheyne Row. Where I shall arrive to night, if all goes well.
It is best not to trust to the Servants giving you the message when you pass; for they never manage to catch you!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 July. MS: NLS 518.5. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: The Parcel Possibly the “shoe-strings” (shoelaces) ordered from Nibloe’s in Dumfries (see TC to JAC, 15 July), or a pair of shoes from Thomas Duncan & Co., 57 Princes St., Edinburgh; see TC to JWC, 18 Aug. has arrived; everything in it right, and at the due hour. Thanks to all concerned.

You are very goodand compliant to me: it is a fact also that I have lost my sleep nearly in toto last night; & seldom in my life was less adequate to forming weighty resolutions;—hardly equal to the 10th part of a tailor today! Nevertheless, it remains perfectly clear to me that the real and courageous course is to persist in the resolution for Friday morng and the Granton Steamer; let that therefore be the settled plan;—if I can but get sleep at Scotsbrig tonight, I shall be myself agn, and in better case for executing it. The 9.13 a.m. train for Thursday is the one I have in view; but if I shd not sleep during the coming two nights; the thing might be horrible & even unsafe:—yr method therefore will be to call at 67. Hanover Street John Carlyle lodged with the Misses Orrocks for many years at this address when in Edinburgh; they had recently moved to 73 George Street, and John moved with them; he wrote to his nephew James Carlyle, 18 May, from that address: “I write to tell you that [the] Miss Orrocks have removed from 62 [67] Hanover St, & I along with them today, a week before the usual term day 25th. This house was empty, & it is easier to move on any other day than term day” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). See also TC to JWC, [8 Aug.]. to see if there is any note from me; if there is none, all stands as above.
Perhaps I will write to Thurso, Where Sir George Sinclair lived. in the proper hypothetic tone, today; announcing us as probable at the beging of next week, or otherwise not at all.

I wonder if my poor Jane had more sleep than I, supposing she arrived all safe, yesternight. It is a sorrow to me that I glided off from Sister Jean yesterday witht even a farewell: she knows I send her many in the silent form. God be with you all.
docBody.name: T. C.

ps.p: I have written to Thurso

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [25 July]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N.B. PM: London, 25 July 1865. MS: NLS 609.735. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:330–31 inc. TC added his note to Jean Aitken (see below) at the end of the letter and wrote on the envelope: “For Mrs Aitken / Dumfries (to read & return.”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest. All right! that is, all as I expected! When I chose to travel by day, I knew I should have no sleep after. I sat up reading till three, it was no use, I felt to lie down—then I went to bed and lay awake, without kicking about much, till morning; at seven I rang for my breakfast and eat some, and got up at nine and have been putting my things in the drawers with the efficient help of Jessie— I dont suppose the night without sleep in my own bed can do me so much harm as that on the railway on the road down. But in the meantime I am very unfit for writing. I so hope Dr Russell may prove mistaken about my right hand having gone to the dogs for good! the loss of it hinders me at every turn! And I haven’t even the consolation of having lost it in the service of my country!

At Carlisle we waited three quarters of an hour, and Jessie was told her third class ticket was “no go”—there being no third class from Carlisle to London by that train! So she was transferred into a secondclass carriage next me, and I had to pay fifteen and sixpence difference!

I perceived on the Platform, at Lancaster—a man in grey pacing as if his foot was on his native pavement—and took him for the Station Master—tho’ looking upwards as tho’ meditating on “The Good the Beautiful and the True”— He looked at me once or twice, then stopt and—it was Mr Symington Andrew James Symington; JWC was apparently referencing the title of his most recent book, The Beautiful in Nature, Art and Life (1857), which he had sent to the Carlyles; see 34:240TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1858. (is that the name?) He was very civil with offers of raspberry tart and gooseberries “pulled that morning by his Wife—in his own garden! Mary Sanderson; they lived in Govan, Lanarkshire. He is so awfully interesting to himself that man! Symington recalled later: “When Mrs. Carlyle was last in Scotland, I happened to travel in the same train by which she returned to London. About midnight, at a station where there was a stoppage of fifteen minutes, I had gone out to stretch my limbs, and, while pacing up and down the platform, heard myself called by name. … On looking about … I saw a lady signalling me from a carriage window; her head was muffled up in a light white woolen shawl, and she proved to be Mrs. Carlyle. On reaching Euston Square Station, I saw her into her own brougham which was waiting her arrival, and accepted a pressing invitation to drink tea with her the following evening, at Chelsea” (A. J. Symington, Some Personal Reminiscences of Carlyle [Paisley and London, 1886] 26).
Mr Sylvester is to be here with Bellona at one o’clock I hope to be steadier next time.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: George Cooke was waiting for me and the great heap of luggage was got home without difficulty. Mrs Warren gave me a warm welcome and has all right—so far as it could be under the circumstances
[TC’s note to Jean Aitken]

Dear Sister,—return me this after reading; perhaps you haven’t got an announcet of yr own.— The Dr will tell you how our plans are overset! By TC’s decision not to go to Thurso and further north. Tell him I have brot all his Books hither;—& that the Fortnightly is not so uncomonly bad. It is unclear whether TC referred to the magazine as a whole, or to a specific article; possibly the article in the Fortnightly Review, 15 July, by Herbert Spencer (1820–1903; ODNB ), philosopher, “Mill versus Hamilton, the Test of Truth,” a discussion of John Stuart Mill’s Examination of Sir William Hamilton’s Philosophy (1865); see also 41:195. Sir William Hamilton (1788–1856; ODNB ), philosopher, whom TC had known and admired in Edinburgh in the 1820s and 1830s. A few days later TC commented on another article in the same issue, a review of Ruskin’s Sesame and Lilies by Anthony Trollope (see TC to JWC, 27 July), but as he was highly critical of that piece it is unlikely that he referred to it here.
ps.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 26 July. Addr: 5 Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, July 1865. MS: NLS 617.716A. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: No sleep, poor Goody; and you have to call it “all right”! Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to MAC, 30 May 1834. Well, it is better than it might have been a thousandfold; and I was right glad of yr cheery and pretty little Note (left hand as it was) before going out this morning. As Mary says, “It is the Evil speerit that puts thae black things i’ yiu’s head,”—those black possibilities of the worst, whh seem in one’s bewildermt almost likely.

You had nothing from me this morng but a Newspaper: the day of your shooting off, I was very miserable, tired &c; John & Js Aitken senr came by way of finish in the afternoon till near 10 p.m.;—and in fine I passed the night like yr poor self awake, tumbling abt very much till abt the time of yr poor breakfast (7 to 8½ a.m.); so that my subsequt day was agn rather miserable as well as busy. John’s Program for Thurso was, “Sail from Granton Pier Hotel, Friday 6 a.m., starting here at Scotsbrig on Thursday abt 7 a.m.”—this, “or
else give up Thurso &c altogether.” To whh alternative I had agreed,—with the farther promise that I wd do my best & try to start here at the due 7 a.m. when it came. All whh, Thurso voyage at the head of it, is now off agn; thank Heaven!—

Austin James Austin. & Noggs brot us all over hither in the tepid evg yesterday; my goods all & sundry, Mary for waitress & complete settlet & finis at Gill: I agn, in spite of best efforts, lost good part of my sleep last night; & felt very shy of tomorrow morning & the next, & the misscellaneous Thus in MS. plunging that was to follow: and have just, there being luckily a possibility still, given up the voyaging Islanding & Thursoing altogether; and resolved to stay here abt a week longer; by whh time John may have accomplished what he has all along declared to be impossible, the procuremt of a sleeping-room for me in Edinr; whereup[on] Letters omitted. or soon after, I intend thitherwd; then to loiter abt, sea-bathing, crossing perhaps to Fife, seeing Edinr seeables &c till “Augt 15” when the Erskine 3 days His promised visit to Thomas Erskine. (sorrow on them rather) will be accomplishable; after whh I can rush home, and at least have a quiet bed, whencesoever & wheresoever I see good. Write to me at Scotsbrig, therefore, till you hear farther: Oh that I might hear tomorrow of “a night’s sleep” at last, and of yr own “Bellona” having done you good!— By the bye, cannot you at all (it is well worth yr skill) contrive to have young Silvr instead of old for Coachman? Send for the young man over; explain to him, That you are a constancy in the stud; that it is impossible any “old gentn” can have such claims on him as you a lamed Lady; add what is true that I very specially desire it (anxious ever since that Tooting adventure), The accident involving JWC’s horse and carriage when JWC was visiting the Macmillans at Tooting in June; see JWC to TC, [12 June]. and have bidden you speak,—winding up with some delicate hint that in the negative count, I shall be so uneasy as never to rest satisfied till I have somewhere got you a quite safe driver.— In short, the thing is in itself reasonable; and I want you to apply abt it at once that there be no excuse for not doing it.

At any rate, the weather is of such a temperature, you will have to fly to Folkstone Caroline Davenport Bromley had invited JWC to visit her there; see JWC to TC, [10 July]. quàm primùm [as soon as possible]. Don’t bother abt the rooms, Dear; attend with all yr applicatn & insight to yr own regimen; therein lies the sole doctoring conceivable: and pay no regard to Dr Russell’s prophecy, That JWC would never regain the use of her right hand.
more than I do, who consider it as words spoken into the totally vague, and whh surely might as well have been spared. God bless thee, Dearest.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [26 July]. MS: NLS 609.736. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:331–32.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! my Dear! I wish to heaven I had the use of that hand again! for when I try to write or do anything with the left without great plenty of leisure it shakes and threatens to strike work like the other!

I absolutely couldnt write yesterday, and to make Jessie write would have made you think me either more unwell or more disagreeable than I was! The first night after my long journey—I lay wholly awake as I was sure to do except when I travel by night and allow myself twelve hours to subside! Indeed knowing how it would be in bed I sat up reading till three in the morning! then I made a bold venture and took before lying down thirty drops of Morphia! I used to get good of an exceptional doze of this sort! Even that couldn’t put me to sleep for a minute; but it gave me a sensation of rest instead of wildness—and I lay patiently till seven when I rung for my breakfast. Last night I slept like the angels. In waking I had lost my identity and was saying to myself “it can’t be me who have slept in this way”!
Oh I am stopt!— I will finish at night I am so sorry

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 July. MS: NLS 518.6. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I amvery happy to hear you did not go to Berwickre; Probably to visit one of his stepsons; see TC to JWC, 25 Aug. —all the more, as this, and the fact that James junr Presumably their nephew James Carlyle. wishes for himself to see you at Dumfries enables me to have a new word before going any farther. (What a hand I have; kicking abt at the rate you see!)—

Last night agn, tho’ in the best circs, I lost good part of my sleep; and awoke with gloomy views of the early start tomorrow, and the still earlier, after such hubbubs, & a bed at Granton Pier, next morning! So that now, on sight of yr Letter, I send word by James: That you are not to stir tomorrow morng or till
you deliberately like; that the Thurso &c Expeditn is quite off (so far as I am concerned); & that I want only to loiter, in any wholesome and not unpleast way, till Augt 15; then to fulfil our 3 days with Erskine; and steer homewards in finis of my rustic “recreations” so-called. This locality is much more pleast to me than The Gill, my lodging too is favourable highly, in comparison: by the help of Noggs I can well make out a week or more here; from ten days to 2 weeks is the utmost of what I cd accomplish in Edinr (one week there wd even be ample, were the lodging bad!): but one might have bathing, walks by the sea-shore, runs to Fife &c: in short, what I wish you now to try for me (abt this day week or so) is the procuremt of a sleeping-place in Edinr,—to be ready by perhaps the end of next week;—after whh the other motions wd follow of themselves. You are very tolerant of my weak ways; & will do what you can. I am persuaded, if you speak to Mrs Stirling (née Hunter), who is a judics lady, & has been our guest &c, Susan Stirling, b. Hunter (1799–1877), old friend of JWC’s; she probably visited Cheyne Row 1835; see 8:159JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835]. John A. Carlyle’s stepson Arthur lodged with her and her husband, James Stirling (ca. 1800–1876), while he was at school in Edinburgh; see 35:237–39JWC to SS, 21 Oct. [1859]. They lived at 11 Hill St., Edinburgh. she will undertake the problem for my sake. Tell her I don’t want to be anybody’s guest; that I can mess with you, &c; but that I do require, under pain of great wretchedness, a human bedroom. In short I think she can & will. At worst, we are simply in yr second Program; and will make the most of it we can, we two. Jane is safe home; but witht sleep as yet. I send Jean her Letter, who will return it. Yrs affectly
T.C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 July. Addr: 5 Grt Cheyne Row / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 27 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.716B. Quot: Bliss, TC 381; Cate 111.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I cdn’t expect any Letter today; but I longed much to have seen one, with tidings that you had slept the second night of yr fatigues, and were doing well, or better than lately. I can only rock myself in the hope that Tomorrow will bring me good news both of second night and third. Don’t forget tomorrow; you know it is the last chance we have till Tuesday next!—

All my luck seems to have gone with yr going. I cannot for these three nights get into the least routine of sleep agn; am provokingly torn up and insulted into fury by these railways (here almost worse than at The Gill, tho’ they are a mile farther off);—and was almost sorry this morning at 7 that I was not to roll off to Edinr & into the voyaging chaos,—tho’ on reconsideratn I felt I shd have made a bad figure there. John, it seems, is going off directly
to look into the Edinr Problem; expects to be ready with the Insoluble early next week. I bade him consult Susan Hunter (Mrs Stirling) for me, and it wd prove soluble. Last night, in the paroxysms of starting up, I took my third blue-pill (whh rather did me good); today I am for a solo ride on Noggs thro’ the cool winds; I also contemplate some improvets in my bed-hangings; and by genl care, will hope to subdue the cast-metal monsters tonight. Saturday night & sunday they are by nature silent: thanks to Sabbath Veneratn for that if for nothing else. And, on the whole, never mind me, Dearest; I have several strings to my bow, and shall get out unslain, one way or other.

Ruskin’s Sesame and Lillies must be a pretty little thing. Ruskin had sent a copy of Sesame and Lilies to JWC at Holmhill; see JWC to JR, 15 July; presumably TC had not yet seen it. Trollope, Anthony Trollope, reviewing Sesame and Lilies in the Fortnightly Review, 15 July, regretted that Ruskin, under the influence of Carlyle, had abandoned his role as an art critic in order “to obtain a hearing as a political economist.” In his view, Ruskin was unsuited to the role “of a great preacher,” unlike TC: “teaching such as this comes well from Mr. Carlyle, although it sometimes comes in language overstrained and with deeper denunciation of existing Englishmen than existing Englishmen altogether deserve. Mr. Carlyle has for many years been denouncing sham workmen and sham heroes, and using all the powers of his eloquence to produce true work, and, if such may be forthcoming, true heroism also. He has been recognised by us as a preacher, and almost as a prophet, and if in the enthusiasm of his wrath he has allowed himself to be carried away by the ever-increasing strength of his own convictions, we are ready to pardon the abuse he showers upon us, on account of the good that we know that he has done to us. We have sat at his feet and have been instructed. We have listened to his words, and, as we have heard them, have made some inward resolution that they should guide us. But I doubt whether many men will receive Carlylesque denunciations from Mr. Ruskin with any good to their souls. He produces them, indeed, with the grace of poetic expression and the strength of well-arranged, vigorous words; but they do not contain that innate, conspicuous wisdom which alone can make such preachings efficacious. … He has given us wonderful words on Art, which have had all the exactness of prose and almost all the grace of poetry. He has numbered his readers by tens of thousands, all of whom have seen with clearer eyes, and judged of Art with a truer judgment, because of his teaching. … As it is, it is much to be hoped that he will return to that work which he can do better than any of his compeers” (634, 635). in reviewing it with considerable insolence stupidity & vulgarity, produces little specimens far beyond any Trollope Sphere of speculatn. A dirtyish little pug, that Trollope; indescribably imbedded in commonplace, and grown fat upon it, & prosperous to an unwholesome degree. Don’t you return his love; nasty gritty creature, with no eye for “the Beautiful the” &c,—and awfully “interestingto himself,” he too
Adieu, Dearest; write tome;—& sleep oh sleep! — T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [27 July]. MS: NLS 609.737. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:273–77 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 534; Surtees, Ludovisi116.
div3.head: JWC TO TC
