docBody.p: “All goes well” still, Dearest. And this time nothing serious is manquing Cf. “manque,” French for missing, lacking; coterie speech; see 7:272TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1834.

The second night, as I expected, I slept “beautiful”! Three hours without a break to begin with!— When I woke from that I not only didnt know where I was; but didnt know who I was!!! As I got out of bed (by force of habit) to look at my watch; I was saying to myself “It can’t be me that has made this fine sleep! i must be somebody else ”!!! It was a full minute, I am sure, before I could satisfy myself that I hadn’t been changed into somebody else! Then I slept piecemeal till seven o’clock, when I was startled erect by what seemed the House falling! Jessie came at my call, looking very guilty, and explained that it was she, who had been coming down stairs very softly for fear of waking me, and having new shoes on had “slid and sossed down on her back”! Just opposite my bedhead— Luckily she was none the worse for the fall. A greater contrast than that young woman is to Fanny The Carlyles’ maid, dismissed in June. cannot be figured! So quick so willing so intelligent: Never needs to be told a thing twice! and so warmly human! My only fear about her is that she will be married-up, Jessie did not get married until after JWC’s death in 1866. away from me! Mrs Warren calls her “My Dear” and they get on charmingly together.

The person who addressed the newspaper to you at ‘Coming Trees’ For Cummertrees. was Fanny who had called to ask if I would “See a Lady” for her: and Mrs Warren being busy asked her to address the newspaper.

On Tuesday Bellona, who had been warned a week before, came round at one, and after some shopping I called at Grosvenor Street and found Miss Bromley at home. A satisfaction which I owed to the youngest of the three Pugs “Jocky,” For a photograph of another of Miss Bromley’s pugs, Spark, see 39:201JWC to LLA, 22 Sept. 1863. who was “suffering from the heat”! She was delighted to see me: most anxious I should come to her at Folkstone! and told me to my great joy, that Lady A had not started on the 21st, Lady Ashburton was expected to leave for Wiesbaden, Germany, 21 July; see JWC to Lady A, 18 July. wasnt going till Thursday (today)—was staying at Bath House Lady Ashburton’s London home. —but gone that morning to Bath for one day. I left a card and message at Bath house on the road home. Yesterday (Wednesday)
I drove to Bath House the first thing; when I went out at one; and found the Lady looking lovely in a spruce little half mourning bonnet! and so loving! and she would “if it was within the bounds of possibility” come to me in the evening “between ten and eleven.” and I went in her carriage with her (my own following) to Norfolk Street (Mrs Anstruther’s) Lady Ashburton’s sister, Mary Frances Anstruther. to see Baby Lady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence. who is going with her mother to Germany after all— I left her there, and got into my own carriage and went and bought my Birthday present—with the sovereign—at least I laid out fifteen shillings of it.— on what?— My Dear! The thing I bought was most appropriate and rather touching! I drove to the great shop in Conduit Street, where the world is supplied with “Trusses” “Laced Stockings”—and mechanical appliances for every species of human derangement William S. F. Sparks, 28 Conduit St., New Bond St., surgical bandage and truss maker. —and bought a dainty little Sling for my arm!! The mere ribbon round my neck hurt my neck and drew my head down. This fastens across the back and is altogether a superior contrivance! I dont believe in Dr Russells prediction any more than you do! At all rates there was no call on him to state so hopeless a view of the question! when I was not asking his opinion at all! It could do no harm to leave me the consolation of hope! But I will hope in spite of Him! Indeed it seems to me that ever since he said I should never get the use of my hand nor get rid of the pain there; that a Spirit of protest and opposition has animated the poor hand and set it on trying to do things it had some time ceased from doing!!

And Lady A did come last night Came at half after eleven! and staid till near one! Mrs Anstruther was left sitting in the carriage and sent up to say “it was on the stroke of twelve”— And then with Lady A’s permission I invited her up—and if it had not been for her I dont think Lady A would have gone till daylight! She said in going “My regards—my—what shall I send to Him (you)—” “Oh, I said send him a kiss!”— “That is just what I should like she said but would he not think it forward”— “Oh dear! not at all” I said— So you are to consider yourself kissed—
I am going up to Bath House now— She goes at night
Lady Stanley writes to ask how I am and to beg that you will come that way.
What a long letter!

I ought to have saidthat all this did not give me a bad night— Of course I did not sleep as on the preceeding night but better than I ever did at Holmhill—and the pain in my arm is really less since I came home—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 July. MS: Sir Allan Walker. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am heartily glad you staid still where you are! To me, who have not slept passably till last night, and have had a swoln cheek &c since my 2d day here, 6 a.m. and the Granton Steamer, For TC’s canceled voyage north, see TC to JAC, 21 July. this morning, wd have been a very bad outlook. Sit still, I advise, till you think of Edinr,—and let us contemplate no farther voyagings!— — The news from Jane, this morning, is quite superior: two successive nights of sleep, the first “excellt,” the second still goodish; and all going right with Chelsea & her London friends. Tomorrow I don’t expect so much; but in the mean time am very thankful.

I shd rather like seeing Charles Stewart See TC to JAC, 21 July. once more; but have little or no chance unless you can contrive to give me rendezvous there. Cdn’t you sleep at Newfield; Newfield farm 2½ mi. (4 km.) W of Scotsbrig, farmed by three Miss Corries and their brother John, old friends of John A. Carlyle’s; see 25:170TC to JWC, 23 Aug. 1850, and 182TC to JWC, 30 Aug. 1850. John visited them, Aug. 1864: “At Newfield I found everything going on the old way—the three Miss Curries & their brother John all very glad of my short visit” (MS: NLS 1775B.283). —or on some elaborate sofa-mattrass arrangt in this big room where I am writing? Never mind it if you can arrange nothing suitable: the ride or gig-drive to Hillside Charles Stewart’s home; see TC to JAC, 21 July. wd be rather farther than I want;—and to send my silent good-will to this excellent old Countryman (perhaps the chief of Annandalers) wd perhaps be better than the uncertn adventure of risking dyspepsia along with him for a little talk!—

Mary has nailed curtains all round my bed, except back and top; the wind too had risen & swallowed all metallic screameries for the night; not to mentn horse-exercise (Water of Milk agn, very beautiful) and utmost care of diet: so that I yesternight, tho’ not witht difficulty realised a fair modicum of sleep; and feel the cheek and catarrhal feverishness much abating, & hope to do well agn tonight & henceforth. Tonight there is still like to be wind; tomorrow & Sunday night my metallic friends lie chained in Sabbath Desecratn,—thank Heaven.

Next time any of you writes Jean ma[ke her] send me half a dozen “railway labels” (for trunks &c) if she can remember. I agn owe her sev[eral] small debts, curb-chain, & what else? If she will trust me till we meet. Yours & he[rs] affectly, with best regards to everybody,
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 July. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 28 July 1865.MS: NLS 617.717. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest, for the glorious news whh saluted me this morning, & whh I read with such pleasure before getting out of bed! Two nights of sleep, one of them “beautiful,”—I fear I must not look for an equally favourable bulletin tomorrow: but, on the whole, things do seem looking up with us. I too have at length got a night of sleep agn (thanks to precautions, and partly to the wind, whh itself drowns those murderous railways, or blesses their screaming with the wholesome sough of the woods and elements);—so that I can heartily partake in whatever good is going. Very pleasant to me, all you report of Chelsea & London,—not quite omitting the symbolic kiss of that ever bounteous Lady. Ask Miss Bromley if she did get her Book; Caroline Bromley’s copy of a book on Marie Antoinette; see TC to JWC, 9 June and 10 July. that she didn’t write, having chanced to ansr in your Note of the time all my questions, was rather a kindness Caroline Bromley wrote, 31 July: “Your kind little note with the book was very welcome. I have been bored with real Business … or I shd have thanked you before.” (tho’ this you need not tell her!)— Beautiful too is your birth-day gift; A sling for her arm; see JWC to TC, [27 July]. really nice, appropriate & pretty;—for you know how to do a thing of the kind, you little mischief, and have always had a certn grace in you, and a certain dexterity,—every inch a gentlewoman, tho’ I shd not say it! Well, I hope you will encourage that poor little arm in its spirit or contradiction to the gloomy Doctor; Dr. Russell. & that it will verily, before long, put him to the blush! Take care of Bellona’s goings, too, and act on what I yesterday prescribed. See TC to JWC, 26 July 1852. All wd be “right” then, or as right as we can ever expect or pretend that it shd be.

Yesterday I went careering thro’ the winds, a good way; whh was really beneficial. The lonely Hills & moors, all green with improved sheep-husbandry, tinkling with clear brooks, & silent otherwise as the Creator made them, were beautiful and full of touching remembrances to me. I go agn today (cloudy and windy) so soon as this is done.

John, who had been clear for seeing Shetland &c by himself since not otherwise, was all packed yesterday for the 6 a.m. of Granton Pier & this morng; but a shower of rain came pattering on the windows; & he too has given it up. To me, sleepless, and with a swoln cheek and something of cold (going off, since yesterday, don’t mind it), such a Voyage & its outlooks wd
been Thus in MS. the most charming!— I am thinking of Henry Inglis When TC wrote to Henry Inglis the previous year, asking for help in finding work for his nephew James Carlyle, Inglis urged TC to come and visit him; see 41:127TC to JF, [10 Dec. 1864]. for a bedroom-provider in Edinr. Adieu, Dearest. Heaven grant me a goodish report from thee Tomorrow.— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 28 July. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 28 July 1865. MS: letter NLS 609.738; envelope NLS 609.736. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 116.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! Please do not hold me responsible at present for any thing like a decent letter! I must have a certain feeling of calm to enable my left hand to act. And I am always in a hurry of business since I came home! and Jessie has other things to do than write for me, and I have not been able to catch any young Lady to make an amanuensis of! Then the daily letter to Mr Carlyle to be written under all circumstances! Then Lady Ashburton not gone to her German Baths only going—as yesterday, and taking such great slabs out of my time as nobody else does, or would be suffered to do! Then the Books on the floor, The dining room was now fitted with bookcases from the attic study for TC’s books; see JWC to MR, 4 May. to be got arranged before I can go to Miss Davenport Bromley at Folkstone! I dont see my way thro it all!

Mercifully I continue to sleep—not so blissfully as I did the night following that of my return: but much better than I had been doing for some months back. And I never fail to take my three hours driving—and tho the heat The Times reported, 2 Aug.: “the thermometer in the shade attained its highest point, 85 deg. [29.5 C] on Thursday [27 July]. … The thermometer in the sun rose to 149 deg. [65 C] on Wednesday [26 July].” here is said to be worse than any they have had this year I cannot say I am at all troubled with it.
On the whole I am much better. The pain in my arm nothing to speak of for the present I suppose I am only now beginning to feel the improvement I was making in Dshire Dumfriesshire.
Good by— God bless you
Tell Mrs Ewart how I am situated— Love to the Dr
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

ps.p:
I think Jessie will do well. Mrs Warren calls her “Dear” and seems quite
fond of her Today she is away at the Chrystal Palace!! with a young man!!! I neednt fear her being “Dull”! And this isnt the young man she spoke of. Unidentified further. He I suppose will take her to some other sight! It is the “Butler” Robert Broadfoot, whom she eventually married. with whom she lived at Mr Goldies Archibald Watson Goldie. The family are staying at Farnbro and the Butler with them. And Jessie had sent him a newspaper in indication of her arrival!! and a letter came immediately proposing to take her to the Chrystal Palace and they are gone an hour ago. I saw the man and dont think there is any harm in him.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 28 July. MS: NLS 609.739. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: In your letter of this morning you say you cannot hear again till Tuesday. So I went and wrote to Mrs Russell—and now, when close on one, at which hour the carriage will come, it strikes me “ why not till Tuesday?” this being Friday! and in hopes you may have made a mistake, I write a few hasty lines still, that you may have the assurance of my continued well being at the earliest possible moment, to set off against your own ill being poor Dear! I am so vexed about that sleep!— But perhaps you, like myself, will feel for the first time that you have got good of your wanderings when you have ended them in your own bed. For me; I am so much better since my return home! I dont indeed go on sleeping as I did that blessed second night!—but every night has been blissful compared with those horrid nights at Holmhill; and, as follows in course, the pain of my arm is greatly abated.

I am going off just now to report myself to kind Dr Quain. He knows I am come home— Lady A said he had been asking at her about me. I spent half an hour with her at Bath House just before she started yesterday afternoon For Wiesbaden. —
I haveno more time left so goodby—ever so little good news is better than a great plash of—bad or indifferent.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], [29 July]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: I am afraid that all this pain and sleeplessness is impairing my Intellect! Just conceive the absurd stupidity of me! You said in your kind note; to bid somebody about me write and tell you how I was! now, certain young Ladies who were good enough to write to my dictation, before I left London, Geraldine Jewsbury, b. 1812, wrote letters for JWC (see GEJ to Lady Am [KST], 3 June, and GEJ to TC, 7 June), as did one of the Mrs. Macmillans, b. 1821 and 1824, (see JWC to TC, 8 June); JWC may also have been thinking of Maggie Welsh, b. 1821, who wrote many letters on her cousin’s behalf, Feb.–April 1864; see 40:11MW to LLA, [6 Feb.? 1864]; JWC was using a certain poetic license as none of them could really count as “young Ladies.” have gone in different directions; and there has been really nobody about me that I could employ. What would have occurred, then to an ordinary mind under the circumstances, would have been to just write myself, after such fashion as I could! And, will you believe me, the possibility of such a solution never entered my head till this hour! But I have waited, waited for the “coming” amanuensis, that never came!!

My left hand gets on worse than usual, after that day of shaking on the railway! So pardon its imperfections! There is no imperfection in the thanks I feel to you, for you offered help towards smoothing my difficulties No adverse accident befell! I did not even lose any part of my luggage! Only—I sat up reading till three of the morning, on reaching home! and then lay on my bed awake till the servants got up, when I rung for breakfast. I never manage to sleep a wink after so long a railway journey! But the next night! Didn’t I sleep like the Angels! or Dr Pritchard Edward William Pritchard, Glasgow surgeon and poisoner, executed 28 July; see JWC to TC, [11 July]. On waking after three or four hours of that wonderful unbroken rest, I had not only lost knowledge of where I was; but of who I was! My first thought was delightfully Irish! It was; “this cant be me who have had such a nice long sleep! I must be somebody else”!

My arm has been less painful since that blessed sleep—than any time these two months back! And yesterday I cut my own food, and—put on my own stockings!! a triumph of female W ill ! For the night before I left Scotland my Dr, without my asking him any questio[n] took the curious idea to inform me that the neuralgia pain in my arm would “probably wear itself out—in time! But that I might lay my account with the stiffness and painfulness of the hand, (in which there was gout) continuing” “You mean, I asked, that I am to lay my account with having no use of my right hand any more in Life?”— “Well!
yes!”— “Well, then, no ! I wont lay my account with any such thing. I will have back my hand,” say what you may!”—and it is curious; but the Spirit of Contradiction, which seemed to rush over me to the finger ends, acted like a shock of electricity on the lamed hand, bracing it up to do or attempt things that had seemed impossible. And so I have arrived at putting on my own stockings &c &c!

I shall be so glad to hear of the other event having been transacted as successfully! The imminent birth of Lady Stanley’s next grandchild; her da. Kate gave birth to her first child, John Francis Stanley Russell, 12 Aug.; for the birth of Lady Stanley’s first grandchild, see JWC to TC, 20 July. How delighted you must feel with these wee bits of Infants Bless them! and the sweet young Mothers!— Yours faithfully /
JaneCarlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HI, 30 July. MS: NLS 1796.105. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY INGLIS

docBody.p: I have been hereabouts for 7 or 8 weeks; endeavouring, not with brilliant success, to find some rest and recreation for myself, after the long pull of 12 years in harness, mostly at a dead lift. This week some time, I intend for Edinburgh, there to loiter abt for certain days,—at my own sweet will so far as possible.

I remember well yr kind invitatn to the Melrose region; Inglis’s home, Torsonce, Stow, was 24 mi. (39 km.) SE of Edinburgh, with Melrose a further 12 mi. (19 km.) SE. tho’ at present I am so brittle a piece of goods, I fear much that will not be possible for me. But if you are in Town; and if you cd, in yr house there, Inglis previously lived at 16 Queen St., Edinburgh, where he still practiced law. or by yr resources otherwise, provide for me a human bedroom (i.e., sleeping-place, nocturnally quiet and well-aired),—bedroom, and nothing more whatever of the hospitable sort,—it wd be a real and memorable kindness to the worst Sleeper in the world! Any way, I of course calculate on seeing you, at more length than for a long time past.
Pray let me have a word from you by return of post. I remain always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 30 July. MS: NLS 609.740. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:277–79.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I will write tonight, Dearest, while the way is open to me. Tomorrow I shall be busy from the time I get up till Bellona comes for me; and after driving, there is no time; as I take the three hours at least; every day. It is such “a privilege” (as Maria’s Mother Maria Chamberlayne, the Carlyles’ maid 1861–62, and her mother, Ann Chamberlayne, whom JWC met Sept. 1863; see 39:187JWC to MR, 16 Sept. 1863. would say) to have a carriage and a Bellona “all to oneself”! Coterie speech; see 13:284JWC to TCH, [22 Oct.? 1841]. independent of all agricultural operations. I dont feel it too warm a bit when I havn’t to walk on the hot pavement; tho they are celebrating the thermometer at 85 in the shade! But anyhow, Miss Bromley is irresistably pressing, Caroline Davenport Bromley wrote, 28 July: “I go to Folkestone on the 1st of August for 5 weeks I have taken one of those houses opposite to the West Cliff Hotel Is there no chance of you and Mr Carlyle being able to pay me a visit there? You would be very quiet & comfortable.” and I have promised to go to her about the twel[f]th; whether my work here is done or not! She will write to you, to urge your joining me—which you will do—wont you? if I on surveying the premises can promise you a tolerably quiet bedroom. Of course I shall take Jessie—as I can’t put my clothes off and on yet without help. I think of staying about a fortnight.

I am sorry you gave up the sailing andThurso— Sailing agrees with you, and you had good sleep at Thurso. TC stayed with Sir George Sinclair in Thurso 4 Aug.–7 Sept. 1860; see vol. 36. “The Good the Beautiful and the True” Andrew Symington; see JWC to TC, [25 July]. came last evening—“to inquire how I was after my journey, and to tell me who knew nothing about it and cared less, how he had written letters of introduction for Dr Carlyle and sent them to the Captain of some steamer &c &c and how his Wife had set her heart on having a lock of your hair and mine set in a brooche, and he had promised her to try and complete her wishes! and it ended—for happily every thing does end—in his begging and receiving the last pen you used—to be kept under a glass case! Symington later wrote: “Among my treasured relics, I may name—a lock of Carlyle’s hair, a MS sheet of ‘Frederick,’ the quill pen with which he wrote the last chapters of that work (given me by Mrs. Carlyle, on July 15th [29], 1865)” (A. J. Symington, Some Personal Reminiscences of Carlyle [Paisley and London, 1886] 26–27). I have seldom seen a foolisher Heroworshipper! But the greatest testimony to your fame seems to me to be the fact of my photograph—the whole three, two of them very
ugly, (Watkins’s) For Watkins photographing JWC, see 41:216JWC to JOWA, 25 April, 217JWC to MCA, [ca. 25 April 1865], and JWC to MCR, [ca. 25] April [1865]; the photographs of JWC are untraced. stuck up in McMichael’s shop window!! James McMichael, bookseller and stationer, 151 King’s Rd., Chelsea. Did you ever hear anything so preposterous in your Life? and what impertinence on the part of Watkins! He must have sent my three along with your nine Of the nine taken, TC liked three of Watkins’s photographs and asked him to “annihilate” four others; see 41:213TC to JOWA, 21 April, and 41:216JWC to JOWA, 25 April; for more examples, see JWC to LLA, 7 [May], and TC to RWE, 14 June13, 80, and 41:214–15. to the wholesale man in Soho Square. Probably Marion Auguste & Co., 22–23 Soho Sq., wholesale and retail stationers, importers of foreign goods, and photographic publishers. without leave asked! But it proves the interest or curiosity you excite—for being neither a “distinguished Authoress,” nor a “celebrated murderess,” nor an actress nor a “Skittles,” Nickname of Catherine Walters (1839–1920; ODNB ), courtesan; see 34:123JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1858]. the four classes of women promoted to the shop windows it can only be as Mrs Carlyle that they offer me for sale.

I continue to sleep on the improved principle, and my arm continues less painful, and my hand if not more capable is at least more venturesome. I saw Dr Quain on Saturday. JWC was also visited by James Aitken Jr., Sat. 29 July; John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., [3 Aug.]: “Please tell your uncle [TC] that yg Jamie Aitken was at Cheyne Row last saturday night & found his aunt looking very comfortable on the sofa, staid two hours till Miss Jewsbury came in” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). And he “approved highly of my present course of treatment—that is, taking neither quinine nor anything else”! I told him what Dr Russell had said and his answer was “how could he know? That is what nobody could say but God almighty!”—

I drove to Streatham lane today and saw the Macmillans—also Mr & Mrs George Craik (“Muly Molock”) “Miss Mulock once, now a current authoress of John Halifax, &c. &c.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:279). Dinah Maria Craik, b. Mulock (1826–87; ODNB ), writer, known to JWC since 1852, m., 29 April, George Lillie Craik (1837–1905), a Glasgow-trained accountant, nephew of the Carlyles’ friend George Lillie Craik; see also 41:218–19JWC to MCR, [ca. 25] April [1865]. Mr Macmillan is greatly delighted with him as a junior partner. They did not look at all ill-matched. His physical sufferings have made up in looks the ten years of difference He has got an excellent imitation leg and walks on it much better than American James Henry James Sr. (1811–82), American philosopher and author; see 17:236JWC to JW, ca. [9 Jan. 1844]. — God keep you—
docBody.name: Jane

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 31 July. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 31 July 1865. MS: NLS 617.718. Pbd: Bliss, TC 382 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I thot perhaps there might be a Newspaper this morning (despatched on Saty); more I cd not look for; and it wd have told me little. I must hope that Tomorrow will bring me news; pray only that they be good! The weather, to judge by what we have of it, is bright and airy, not unduly hot, and ought to be very wholesome. The shining transparency of our element, the definite purity of all things in earth and air, surprises me every morning: very pleasant to see the old Hill tops re-emerge all round me, as if in welcome & adieu, as I climb the Dairlaw Hill Darlaw Hill, about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) N of Scotsbrig. upland before breakfast;—pleasant, yet sad & touching. Indeed my main delights here are merely topographical; Noggs (much better cleaned than at The Gill, & in scenes whh are far more memorable to me) gallops beautifully abt; and there cd be elsewhere no such riding for me,—for the few days till I have seen everything. The inanimate friends; almost the only kind I have now remaining! Poor Jamie has grown very sad & saturnine; much bereaved & lonely in his old days; TC’s brother James’s wife, Isabella, d. 1859; his da. Jenny was married and now living in Birmingham. and indeed very sorrowful, I can perceive, tho’ he complains of nothing; and is outwardly prospering. It is seldom I can engage him in any fruitful conversatn; tho’ sometimes I do; and the two Lads, James and John Carlyle. especially Jamie junr, seem to be intelligt well-condited creatures. Mary is the most assids of valets; her Daughter an excellt silent diligt young Lass; Mary’s da. Catherine was housekeeper at Scotsbrig; see TC to JWC, 13 June. & has the house in better order than almost any house like it. In short, I have recovered my sleep, Dear (Oh that you cd say as much); and am well off here for the few days that are still ahead!

John makes no movet towards Edinr; is all agog just now abt a dinner with Stewart of Hillside (for self and me), in whh, tho’ I like old Stewart, my participn is by no means certn. I have written to Hy Inglis; refusing his invitatn to “Stobo” TC miswrote Stobo for Stow; Stobo is nr. Peebles; Stow is nr. Galashiels. (or some country-place he has), but suggesting the great favr of a sleeping-room (per se) in Edinr;—whh will perhaps bring a solutn of the “impossible.” To creaky Foxton, Frederick Foxton wrote to TC, 26 July, from Rhayader in Wales: “I expected for some weeks after I wrote to you that you would have sent me a few words to say when you would come to me, or given me your Scotch address to enable me to write to you. … It will now give me the greatest possible pleasure to see you here whenever it suits your convenience, & I shall only be the better able to entertain you in this wild place, if you will give me a week’s previous notice of the day of your arrival.” wearisome tho’ kind, I have not
not Word repeated at turn of page. yet written: I almost fear I shall have to give him up in coming home; so haggly, changeful, seems the road to him to be. Here, Darling, are abundt details surely, and all abt one thrice-importt man!—

Poor John here (ill of a suppurated ear just now, but a good young soul) begged of me a “Carte of my Aunt, if he have any!” I had just one (a Watkins, & not the best); this he got, with a wide-awake of myself: Mary then reminded me of two couples that were wanted in Canada for her two Households there, Mary’s da. Grace and her husband, William Yeoward, were in Canada; the other household is unidentified, unless that of TC and Mary’s sister, Janet Hanning, and her husband, Robert. For a photograph of TC in his wideawake hat, see 13. —whereupon I had to produce two (small) of myself, and, for Goody, to bequeath two (baddish Heads) that have stood on the mantelpiece at The Gill all this while, & had been left there. Recd with thankfulness excessive. To Jamie junr, I gave one copy of the Daguerrotype (much recognised here as a Likeness); so that now one other copy of that is all I have left. Are not here an interestg set of details—written in vacuo [in a vacuum]? I may at least give over!—
If you will say only “I am sleeping well,” I will forgive you everything. Alas, I am reckoning witht my host, all this while; & ought not to hope,perhaps, as I do! God bless thee
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CS, 1 Aug. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES STEWART

docBody.p: I shd regret muchthat your kind purpose on my behalf were frustrated, and that I didn’t see you before leaving Annandale.

Tomorrow (Wednesday) my Brother and I purpose to appear, if we may, at Hillside some time abt (before, I rather guess; but know not the Bradshaw, as yet, to a minute.) 2 p.m.; and to be at yr disposal till past 6,—my Brother being due at Lockerby for the return train whh leaves at 7. I shall have some kind of Gig, and can drive him both down and up.
Hoping this little Adventure will succeed, & that we shall find you well, I remain (in haste),
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 Aug. Addr: Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.719. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—Yr Letter of this morng is charming; a thing really to thank Heaven for! Oh may it continue; and our poor little “arm” only soon get well! Dr Quain’s “prescriptn” in regard to it is just what mine wd be; and his eloquent ansr to the Russell Prophecy altogether ditto. Drive abt yr due minimum of 3 hours, and take every care of regimen &c &c: it is really all that the wit of man or woman can do;—and I do not doubt of the result sooner or not so soon. Yr late sufferings will have taught new lessons of Patience any way.— I sent Dr Russell yesterday the two Fortnightlys; a cheap reminder whh he wd understand. Indicating that all was well; see TC to JWC, 19 July. To Thurso there was no going: the swoln cheek is hardly yet away; and in matter of sleep, tho’ now quite still, I was eiry in the extreme! I think of being off northward in abt a week. Hy Inglis says (you observe) there may be a sleeping-place discoverable. Continue writing hither till you hear more. Tomorrow (i.e. friday for you) I almost fear you will get nothing, poor Dear: I am in for a Charles Stewart rendezvous at Hillside (10 miles off Scotsbrig), with prospect of John from Dumfrs, “a drive up Dryfe Water” Dryfe Water, tributary of the Annan River, flowing past the Hillside estate. (dale), dinner at 4, & John off for Dumfrs agn at 7 p.m. & I withinan hour of Scotsbrig. Enough for that matter!

I noticed Miss Laurie’s marriage & yr stroke at it. Margaret Laurie (b. 1834); see 39:120JWC to MR, [6 May 1863]; grandniece of Sir Peter Laurie (1778–1861; ODNB ), saddler and politician; old acquaintance of TC’s; see 25:47TC to SPL, 12 March 1850. She m., 25 July, Captain James Augustus Grant (1827–92; ODNB ), soldier and explorer. Presumably JWC sent TC a newspaper containing a notice of the marriage. These Watkins Photogrs are an impudent transactn surely;—but at bottom they can do us “neither ill nor guid,” as the old Laird said. Coterie speech; see 4:369TC to MAC, 20 April 1828. Yesterday our weather was tempests northwind, & actually cold: I had such a gallop thro’ the winds far & wide;—and Noggs is agn waiting for me. Oh Darling, what is this patch of paper, with iron pen & hand shaky, in face of all I had to say to thee! Adieu
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 Aug. MS: NLS 526.30. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO John A. Carlyle

docBody.p:
I intend tobe at Lockerby tomorrow (Wedny), as near the time of yr “12~1 train” as I can (minute not known to me, nor discoverable as yet,—not even
the minute to be aimed at, tho’ Jas thinks he can discover that in the Course of the day!)—but you must wait at the statn, and I will wait (at least till yr train come); I shall have a Gig, and can drive you both up, and down for 7 p.m.
I have written to Chs Stewart (not a quite joyful operatn to me, with a hand so little under rein!)—I said we shd appear at Hillside “some time abt” 2 p.m., & cd stay till after 6.

The news from Jane are good; I too have recovd sleep. If you cd bring me a ¼ lb of the mixed kind of Dumfrs tobacco you smoke, it wd be better than any I cd get here. I think of leaving this soon,—and am in treaty with Henry Inglis for a sleeping-place;—but nothing isyet certn.
In great haste (with my kindest regards to Sister Jean and everybody)
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 2 Aug. MS: NLS 609.742. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 332–33 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:18; Hansons, NE 534.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: What belated your letter that it didn’t arrive till the two o’clock post—after I was gone out? Getting no news in the morning and being up to the eyes in The Books, See JWC to MR, 28 July. I felt justified in passinga day—on the pretext of not being quite sure of your whereabout.

I must now beconcise and to the purpose; the day being too short for all the affairs I have on hand! First, of my sleep:—I really begin to sleep like a human being!— If this would last a week or two, my arm would be cured and even my hand already the pain is so much diminished that I don’t dream of it in my sleep! and I can do a lot of things with my hand:—can put on my stockings! can lift a spoon to my mouth! can tie on my bonnet! &c &c—
Oh the reliefof this comparative ease after five months of constant wearing pain and helplessness!—

Mrs Forster Eliza Forster. has been ill in the same sort of way—only her Pain has been more general and more diluted and sooner over— Poor dear Fuz John Forster. himself had a violent attack of British Cholera British or simple cholera, a kind of gastroenteritis most common in summer. lately, and is at present in great misery with some new cold caught in his face. I saw him yesterday (by his own request) stretched among pillows on the sofa of his Library, bemoaning himself—in his usual obstreperous way—and with palpable reason—his face was
swelled and discoloured frightfully—an abscess forming in the cheek his Wife said— He himself said he was “dying—not a doubt of it”! But he was far too impatient and unreasonablefor being arrived at that stage.

I have found his Correspondence between Gray and Mason The Correspondence of Thomas Gray and William Mason, to which are added some letters addressed by Gray to the Rev. James Brown, ed. Rev. John Mitford (1853). —and taken it back to him also a J omini with A Sterlings Sir Anthony Coningham Sterling; for Antoine Henri Jomini, see TC to JN, 8 July. name on it—that also is returned. and a Library Book (I forget what) is still here!?
I have nothing more to tell—and things waiting for me
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 Aug. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 3 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.720. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Darling,—Yr Letter is agn a great blessing to me. What a change, to be getting something like actual “human sleep”; with the sore arm and all miseries, as is natural, gradually abating! Only continue that for a week or two, and all will be well again, & Dr R’s prophecy no better than a Dr Cumming one! Rev. John Cumming (1807–81; ODNB ), minister of the Scottish Presbyterian Crown Court Church in Covent Garden 1832–79; noted for his prophetic fervor, he predicted the Second Coming would happen in 1867, a subject on which he expounded in many publications, including The Destiny of Nations as Indicated in Prophecy (1864). Well done.—— The reason of no delivery till 2 p.m. must be that somebody undertook, having an errand at Ecclefechan, to post yr note there;—and did post not “before 6 p.m,” but only before 10. I will try to prevent the like agn.

Yesterday (whh makes yr blank today) I did the small Charles Stuart adventure; witht difficulty of any kind, being borne on by Jamie junr to Lockerby, then by John to Hillside, in “one’s own gig”; and meeting the old gentn, now near 80, still very fresh, and one of the cleverest of living Annandalers, a little in advance on the road looking out for us. I saw Dryfe Water (clear as Olive oil) Dryfe Valley, clean, trim, green and happy-looking; drove to Hook Heuk or Hook House, Applegarth parish, 2 mi. (3 km.) N of Hillside, home of the Johnstones; see below. (a mile or two up); had many bits of pleast enough weak talk and passivity; a brightish sauntering clattering kind of day;—but bot it all rather dear when it came to the sleeping place. For in fact I had been rather beguiled, and met with more than I bargained for. Only guess who proved to be my neighbr at
dinner: no other than Mrs Duncan Stuart, Duncan himself, John Duncan Alexander Stewart, younger brother of Charles Stewart, and his wife, Harriet, known as Mrs. Duncan Stewart. grown old, ugly and deaf, sitting right opposite! Ach Himmel, these were not people I longed to see; Mrs D. in particr, all full of flash fashion, was a strange ingredt in the Annandale broth. She is a veteran female-rake, really expert at her busss; grown old and gouty (right arm lamish & clearly “swoln by gout”); played off all her artillery upon me at a mighty rate,—witht perceptible effect. Is marrying her daughter to an innocent-looking Hanoverian, Pauline Harriet (“Harty”) Stewart, m., 8 Aug. 1865, Baron Otto von Klenck, lieut.-col. in the Hanoverian garde du corps and an aide-de-camp to George V (1819–78), king of Hanover and duke of Cumberland. —who was likewise prest at one part of the day, and wistfully left me 2 excellt cigars. Oh dear, oh dear. I did at last get some sleep however; and the thing is not to do agn. What I best remember of the day is Hook, a pretty country solitude, & Mrs Johnston Adelaide Mary Wentworth Johnstone, b. Sinclair (1822–73), m., 1845, George Gordon Hope Johnstone (1820–66). there (the Sinclair fastish Lady whom we dined once): her Husband is absent sine die [indefinitely] princi[p]ally an insolent rule-less creature), & she has to stay there with the children, They had four children, Charles (b. 1846), Evelyn (b. ca. 1848), Constance (b. 1850), and William (b. ca. 1856). “Princi[p]ally”: the word is unclear; if “princi[p]ally,” TC omitted the “p.” on funds from his Father & hers: His father was John James Hope Johnstone (1796–1876), M. P. for Dumfries 1857–65; Heuk House was on his estate; see 36:181TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1860. Her father was Sir George Sinclair. a most impatt female,—reminds me of an imprisoned antelope (or perhaps more carnivorous specimen, devoured with ennui. Nothing but dogs in variety for a solace to her.— I got home at 8½, thro’ the clearestand coldest autumn sunset I almost ever saw.

It almost seems as if I shd not get to Edinr till Tuesday next, John is in such a coil; but you shall hear tomorrow. And don’t you forget tomorrow (whh means my saturday, and my last Letter for the week!) I am deeply sorry abt poor Fuz; tell him so in appropriate terms & report agn. Miss Bromley’s Lr I will ansr: how? To Farie nothing—except, if you like, a card from Bellona some day. Robert Farie helped find JWC’s gray horse and brougham (see 41:71TC to JAC, [ca. 12 Oct. 1864], 41:74TC to RF, 17 Oct. 1864, and 41:84JWC to MR, [31 Oct. 1864]); perhaps he also helped find JWC’s mare, Bellona (bought in April; see 41:209JWC to MR, [14 April], and 41:212JWC to LLA, 17 April). Adieu Dearest.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA, 4 Aug. MS: Morgan Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN

docBody.p: Tomorrow (Saturday) morning, Jamie TC’s brother James Carlyle. and I are to be off for a look at Craigenputtock, and hope to see some of you on the Platform abt 10 a.m.,—when the Lockerby train comes in. To Dumfries. You in particr we wish to engage for us an effective Gig & Horse (please convince yrself abt the quality of both): it ought to be ready at 10,—but need not be quite standing waiting for us at the station. We do not return from The Hill The Aitkens’ home in Dumfries. for Lockerby till 8 p.m. so that there will be time enough for everything we have to do. And for all the domestic news we bring, if any!—
Cordially saluting everybody
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 Aug. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 4 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.722. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:291.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
“Nothink for Craigenpk today Ma’am!” Coterie speech; see 19:209JWC to TC, [23 Sept. 1845]. — Well, I must just hope that nothing has gone awry; and that Tomorrow (don’t forget “Tomorrow,” our last friend, last of the week!) will bring me confirmation of something good. Continuance of what the last tidings were is all I can wish. My own life here is quiescence itself; ride upon Noggs thro’ some old long-remembered little tract of earth, this and the three walks are all the events of a day. Noggs, in this land of foreign exile and mere novelty, manifests the liveliest adherence to me his sole friend & remaining connexion with things known,—poor little four-footed wretch. I think it will certainly be Tuesday when the Doctor will announce, “Eureka, a room in Hanover Street; for Edinr this morning at 9.13 from Ecclefn!” Whh I shall really be rather loth for; but must obey. My sleep is agn mine; I am the idlest and most contented of men, wd things but let me alone, and Time stay still! The clearness of the air here, the old Hilltops and grassy silences: it is with a strange acquiescence that I fancy myself as bidding probably farewell to them for the last time. Annandale is gone out for me; lies all stark and dead,—as I shall soon do too: why not? — Tuesday morning, re-
collect: in fact, you had better direct yr Monday Letter, “Care of Dr Carlyle / 67 Hanover Street Edinburgh”; I shall be surer of finding it at once there,—so far as I can yet speir out what is to be expected from John tomorrow. Item if you like to send me anything on Sunday, put it into the Cheyne Walk Pillar before 7 p.m., and I shall get it next morning here.

I have not accepted Hy Inglis’s Stow, but probably shall,—at least if hard up in Edinr. Tomorrow Jamie and I are for Craigenputtock (a kind of duty if one cd but do it!)—there is no difficulty except the early hour of the morning, & the haggle lasting till “Ecclefn 9.30 p.m.” agn. “Fais quelque chose pour toi-même, grand Duc; fais-toi la barbe!” Cf. Alexandre Dumas, Mademoiselle de Belle-Isle (1839), scene 5. I ansr Miss Bry Caroline Bromley wrote, 31 July, that JWC had promised her a visit: “I write to say that notwithstanding the inconveniences of a Lodging-House I think I could promise that you should be very quiet & comfortable if you would join us there!—the house I have got is on the West Cliff so if you are tired of the sea there are the Downs & rather a pretty country inland.” in the affirmative vague. Endless other little Notekins to write. God keep thee, Goody dear! Ever
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 4 Aug. MS: NLS 609.743. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my dear a line will be better than nothing—but I have only time for a line! I have been so busy ever since I got up at eight o’clock: and have taken no account of the time; and now suddenly I was horrified to find it a quarter to four o’clock and at four Bellona comes to take me to Streatham to dine with the Macmillans by appointment.

But, beyondthat I go on in the same tolerable style. I have nothing of any moment to say and that can be said in one line! There need be no reflections here for want of coolness; for the last three days we have had plashes of rain and less heat than I could wish!

Three nights ago, having gone to bed with my window half a yard open and two blankets I awoke like a lump of ice! Afraid that the chill would be hurtful to my arm, I got up and closed the window all but an inch and then went into the Drawingroom for whisky Even that bringing no heat, I went for Miss Bromley’s Eider-down quilt—and at last came alive. I put another blanket next day.
I called for Forster yesterday and found him with his face all muffled up—and bemoaning himself like—like—anything! Coterie speech. but just going outfor a drive—

A nice modest admirer has sent you with the enclosed note The unidentified admirer wrote, 1 Aug.: “One of Mr Carlyle’s many debtors on account of his life of Frederick the Great begs permission to offer for his acceptance … a small memento of Frederick which, tho’ of next to no artistic or intrinsic value, may possibly nevertheless be regarded by Mr Carlyle as of some curiosity & interest. The writer picked it up the other day in a London curiosity-shop, but it is, he believes, of Dutch manufacture, & made for a tobacco-box. … The lid has a portrait of Frederick, & the under side a rude representation of several of his chief battles.” without name or address—so that no thanks are even possible a little brass box the same as the one Gilchrist Alexander Gilchrist (1828–61; ODNB ), friend and former neighbor of the Carlyles; see 38:28038:biographical notes; both brass boxes untraced. gave you but in better condition

There is a paper begging subscriptions for Heraud John Abraham Heraud (1799–1887; ODNB ), writer and critic; known to TC in the 1830s; see 5:362–63TC to JWC, 24 Aug. 1831; his most recent work, pbd. Feb., was Shakspere: His Inner Life as Intimated in his Works (1865). —shall I send it—
Bellona is come
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 6 Aug. MS: MUL. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:228–30 inc; Marrs 741–43. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:18; Surtees, JWC 265; Ashton 439.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I came down into these parts in the end of May, with a view of resting myself, and trying for a little recovery of strength and health, after the long deadly tug of pulling (12 years long!) at that last Book of mine. Hitherto I do not feel as if the duration had been very successful; I have had a great deal of bother abt sleep &c, and often enough have been low and dreary in this dear old Birthland now so changed and solitary to me: but perhaps on getting home, I shall really find that I have got some little benefit;—at any rate the thing had to be done; for almost five years past I have always been saying to myself, “Were this sad labour finished, I will see poor old Annandale agn and the friends I still have there!”— Most of my time has been spent at The Gill, whh was the quietest and much the loneliest place, where indeed I was left almost altogether to myself, to saunter about with such thots as you in my own head, and the sorrow and gloom of one’s mind cd go to its full length and be as sorrowful as it liked. The truth is, I am much worn out; also very old; and ought now to know well that the end cannot and even shd not be far off. For the last two weeks I have been at Scotsbrig; am for Edinr in the course 
of two days (John, who is at Dumfries all this while, has appointed to accompany me thither); in and abt Edinr we calculate to loiter perhaps a fortnight more; after whh I am for home agn,—then to set my house in order a little, and see what farther I will do. Before leaving Scotsbrig I had long resolved to send you some kind of Letter dated there; and this at last is it,—in spite of a shaking hand, and other impediments whh render writing disagreeable to me just now. I inclose a Photograph whh represents me pretty truly, well on in my 70th year:—your Photograph I have safe in my bedroom at Chelsea, and a great treasure to me it is (very recognisable to me, and not so changed as one might expect);
TC probably referred to an earlier photograph of Alexander; for a photograph of Alexander and Janet Carlyle in old age, see 221TC to JAC, 14 Sept.
 in me & over all the kindred there is an eager desire and expectatn of getting a good few others representative of the seniors & juniors in that Canadn Household we have all such an interest in. See that you don’t disappoint us in this!—

Our kindred here may be described as going on in a singularly equable manner; prosperous, all of them, rather than otherwise; and being not spared hitherto in the contstant ravagings of Time. In Ecclefechan there are hardly three people alive whom I can remember at all from my young years. A country changed wholly; nothing but the old localities now left,—the sight of whh has been a continual interest to me, sad and strange, in my ridings up and down. Day before yesterday, for instance, I rode by Sandbed, Whins &c, Sandbed, farm in Middlebie parish; Whins, farm 1 mi. (1.5 km.) S of Ecclefechan. and home by “Jean’s Bar” Possibly a toll-gate; unidentified further. (“Jean” quite vanished with much else): at Sandbed I remembered to have passed the place, on some Mainhill Pony, almost 50 years ago; under the quiet sky, in the old house still standing, poor old “Sandbed” was making worship, & I heard the sound of his psalm: John Carlyle (ca. 1742–1835), father of TC’s father’s first wife; TC’s remembered ride probably took place in late May 1825; see 8:102TC to JAC, 30 April 1835. only once since, in a drive you once took me from Ecclefn, cd I remember to have passed that place. Ah me, ah me!—

Jamie has grown old, grave and sad, in comparison with formerly; but for the rest, is prosperous & diligent in the new mode of Husbandry now introduced in these parts,—that is to say in raising cattle & sheep at higher and higher prices, for the Liverpool & other manufacturing Stomachs; that of grain-husbandry being almost wholly abandoned by those that have a little money for shifting into the new course. Grain (such the extent of import from Foreign Countries) was never seen so cheap in man’s memory, nor butcher’s-meat &c a third part so dear. Perhaps abt 3 each way may pretty much express the astonishing change of prices since these “free-trades” and raging railways
began running. The repeal of the Corn Laws, 1849, and improved transport by rail and sea led to large quantities of grain from the U.S. and eastern Europe being imported into Britain, considerably lowering prices. People that cannot change (poor Jock of Stennybeck, John Blacklock (ca. 1807–75), farmer, of Stennybeck, or Stoneybeck, farm ½ mi. (800 m.) N of Scotsbrig; see 14:178TC to JWC, 3 May 1842. for instance) are reduced to bitter straits; all the others are prosperous as never before— Jamie’s daughter is married to his mind (at Birmingham to one Scott some kind of Draper or Dealer, & has just had a son); Jenny, her husband, William Scott, and their son, John James. both his Sons are with him,—Jamie anxious to become Farm-Overseer or Factor somewhere, the merchts desk being absolutely unwholesome to him. James and John; James Jr. had worked in the offices of William Baird & Co., ironworkers in Glasgow, but left due to ill health; see 41:122–23TC to HI, 7 Dec. 1864. One of Mary’s Daughters Catherine Austin. keeps house here; what seems to be an immense improvt on the late state of things: Mary herself is now here taking care of me till I have gone my ways. Jean, I daresay, will herself have written to you, and mentioned how her two Boys are both in good Clerk employment, James and John Aitken. her good man at the top of his trade, and finding good profit in it: fine new house &c &c.—— —— Yesterday I was at Craigenputtock (Jamie & I by railway and gig, from Scotsbrig & back): ah me, what a place of reminiscences for both of us, for me much more! There it lay, the poor old scene; sleepy, overgrown with wood and indolent neglect: the Tenant, one Common, John Common (ca. 1827–89); see 34:99–100TC to JWC, 6 Aug. 1858. pays just abt yr old rent (Jamie tells me) & mutton is 3 times the price, and wool abt 4, that you were used to! So that Common lives in more clover; & being an idle fellow, roams the country and leaves things at home a good deal to themselves. Whitsunday come a year, Whitsunday (28 May), one of the Scottish quarter days, the traditional times for leasing of farms and hiring of workers. he will have to walk his ways, & very much alter all that! We found yr old Cattle-House, Alexander managed the farm at Craigenputtoch while TC and JWC lived in the main house, 1827–31; for the cattlehouse, see 4:422TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1828. still standing by the the Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. woodside in the hollow, walls still standing entire, roof long since gone; for the rest, solitude, silence, and innumerable thots that no word cd really utter. God forever bless you, my dear and faithful Brother. We are widely parted in this world; but while alive, nothing can entirely part us. With blessings & regards to Jenny, Tom and everybody. Yr affectionate—
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 8 [7] Aug. Addr: Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 7 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.721. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dear Little Goodykin sends nothing but a Newspaper today,—all really that was needed from the poor hurrying soul: besides it was very well addressed, and as seemed to me with the right hand (bravo!)—so that, with the two strokes, I will take it to mean that all is going smoothly, the old good course not essentially altering.

Tomorrow 2.48 p.m. I am for Edinr; & shall hope to find something definite in Hanover street See TC to JAC, 25 July. from you. Tomorrow actually to get under way;—and not the least thing yet packed; the horror of all that still glaring in upon the lazy soul of me: my words here must be brief. John joins me at Lockerby we don’t arrive till 6 p.m.; no time for a Letter: but I will put in a Public Opinn (the same you sent), in sign that I am safe there, as I hoped to be. With Hy Inglis’s Stow I do not mean to tackle at all (unless the Lodging be sleepless), or at least not till perhaps the Saty & Sunday coming. Directly after that, Erskine is due, and my beggarly “engagets,” whh have hung so tedious upon dates, are at an end in these parts.

On Saturday Craigenputtock was done, as per program,—from 7 a.m. till 9½ p.m home agn, the busss lasted, and was not of an exhilarating nature, tho’ nothing miswent, & the country, especially the drive from Irongray to Stroquhan, Irongray, village about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) NW of Dumfries; Stroquhan, estate and farm formerly owned by the Anderson family, old friends of JWC and TC (see 12:326–27TC to JAC, 16 Nov. 1840), was a further 6 mi. (9.5 km.) NW. was altogether beautiful: but on the whole I had lost most of my night’s sleep by starting at 7 (woke at 4!) and lost do of the next night by the fussing & fidgetting I had had,—such a giant of a fellow am I! However, all that is rectified, and straight agn for two nights: and I am very glad I went; for the sad old Hermitage was full of memories & interests to me; & there were some practical things that altogether did require looking into. The poor place is woodier, darker, sleepier-looking than ever; and was lying much in litter
and neglect in all external particrs. The Tenant has it, I believe, abt £100 too cheap; and seems to be an idle fellow, continually gigging abt the country instead of plying besom at home. Whitsunday come a year, he will find himself pulled up to the due tightness, or sent walking elsewhither:—and as for the pressing & stringent point of the untended woods I have (with effort) hit upon a scheme for having that satisfactorily done,—and “the good many hundreds” of dead larches faithfully cut away, & changed into money. Poor old Puttock, ah me, ah me!— But enough Dearest; you shall hear from Edinr, if I prosper. God keep thee.—
T.C.
TC autographed and dated eight lines of poetry by Goethe, 7 Aug., and sent or gave it to an unidentified correspondent (MS: Swann Galleries, NYC, auction, 6 Nov. 1997).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 7 Aug. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 7 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.744. Quot: Froude, LM 3:279–80; Bliss, JWC 325.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Just a line to say that all goes well with my health— I continue to sleep better—almost to sleep well! and the pain is greatly gone out of my arm—and I use my hand a little—this charming penmanship is from my right hand!—

But I have no time for elaborate writing— I was never busier in my life—about three thousand volumes have had to pass thro my hands and be arranged on the shelves by myself. Nobody else could help me—
The new room is getting finished and will strike M C dumb with admiration when he comes!

Jessy is in no danger of feeling dull—decidedly! that “Butler” Robert Broadfoot; see JWC to MR, 28 July. of the Goldie’s Possibly the Goldies were visiting his widowed sister-in-law, Mary Ann Goldie, who lived at 149 Berkeley Gdns. was here again this morning before breakfast was well over, to take her out for the day!!—to the Zoological Gardens London Zoological Gardens, Regent’s Park, begun 1828 as a center for scientific research; opened to the public 1847. —! Jessie had the grace to be ashamed to come to ask my leave—but let Mrs Warren come— I thought it rather exorbitant—and said so—but that as she would be no good here if she were not let go—and so she might go! I took her out in the carriage yesterday to show her the Parks—and invited one of Miss Murray’s maids Margaret Murray (b. ca. 1791), b. Edinburgh, retired governess, who lived at 33 Alford Pl. W., Kensington; the 1861 census lists four servants; the servant that Jessie Hiddleston (age 30) met was probably one of the two younger servants, Jane Sturmer and Frances Sellars (age 22 and 25 respectively). Miss Murray was a friend of Mary Russell (see 35:28JWC to MR, [ca. 8 Feb. 1859]) and previously the governess of Jemima Whigham (see 39:118JWC to MR, [6 May 1863]). to take tea with her and take her a walk in the evening and they went to visit some
mutual acquaintance—So this larking off today again seemed too much of a good thing and I let her see I did not approve of it!

I suppose she is engaged to this Butler—and in that case she should have staid in Scotland beside him— For the rest I find her a capital servant and a nice creature to have beside me— But if she is to have a heart always in that Butlers pocket—and go away to be married in a year or so—I shall rather regret the expense of bringing her away

Oh!— I was again near forgetting!— Would you the first time you call at Nith Bank ask Marion Marion, one of Alicia Ewart’s maids; see JWC to TC, [11 July]. if she saw in any of the glass drawers in my bedroom—a standing pebble seal—with a little gold setting about it— The seal is of no great intrinsic value; but it belonged to John Sterling John Sterling, the Carlyles’ close friend. and was sent to me after his death.

I remember sealing a letter with it at Nithbank—and dont remember ever seeing it again— It was in my bedroom that I used it—and perhaps I laid it on the Mrs Ewarts JWC inserted “Mrs Ewarts” above “the” and “writing.” writing stand which I used to take in— I dare say I have seen the last of it; but it can do no harm to ask Marion about it—

I go to Folkstone this day week— Love to the Dr Yours affly /
JaneCarlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 8 Aug. MS: Trevelyan Papers, Robinson Lib., Newcastle Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
It was a good moment when I received that letter from over the Sea It does intensify strangely the feeling of separation when a great tract of Sea lies between! especially for a rare Individual like me who has never seen beyond this Island— You seem hidden away from me ‘over the Water,’ not only hidden from my bodily eyes but from the eyes of my Imagination I cannot picture you out in a Country where I have never been—as I can in an English or Scotch House! and so I will be mortal glad to know you at Bath House again or even at Melchet! But if you get good of your foreign sojourn—no matter how badly I weary for you! Mr C is still in the North—at Edinr this day I believe; and to be at Linlathen on the 15th. Where his stay will be of the shortest I fancy—judging from what I hear of the persons invited to meet him. Miss Bromley wrote inviting him to Folkstone; and he had answered, she says, “in the vaguest possible
manner.” I go to Her at Folkstone on Monday next (14th). That Place will be sad for me at first. The only time I was ever there before was when I went to You! And Lord Ashburton was well then, and so kind to me!—but when was He ever other than kind to me? And Miss Bromley was a Stranger for me; whom I there made friends with! For JWC’s arrival in Folkestone, 29 June 1862, see 38:105JWC to TC, [29 June 1862]. And I did not know then, old as I was, what the human body was capable of in the matter of suffering! A terrible revealation Thus in MS. was lying ahead of me, and I had no fear—thought nothing could befal me worse than Death! Yes! I shall have many thoughts in bath-chairing about Folkstone again!

But it will be well to have the dust I have been gathering in sorting about three thousand volumes of Mr C’s books with my own hands Coterie speech; Edward Irving’s phrase; see 39:247JWC to MCA, [20 Nov. 1863]. (or, I should say hand) blown off by sea breezes! It is wonderful how little “others” however well-meaning can help one! Madame Venturi and her husband, one of Garibaldi’s Majors, Emilie and Carlo Venturi; see JWC to TC, 28 June. came to give me a forenoon’s work at these chaotic book-heaps—and they did work like a house on fire—but it took me two whole days after to reduce the confusion of their arrangement to order! Then Count Reichenbach Count Oskar von Reichenbach. would “help” me. and the help got from him, was to have him for three or four hours standing about reading the Books!! It is all right now however! And if He isn’t content with his down-stairs Study when he comes,—he will be very ungrateful!—that’s all! I called for Mrs Quain Isabella Agnes, wife of Richard Quain, JWC’s doctor. today. She told me they were going to Lady Franklin’s Jane, Lady Franklin, b. Griffin (1792–1875; ODNB ), traveler, widow of Sir John Franklin (1786–1847; ODNB ), arctic explorer. She lived at 2 Upper Gore, Kensington Rd. this evening “to meet the Queen”!—so their invitation was worded (Queen of the Sandwich Islands Emma (1836–85), queen consort (now queen dowager) of King Kamehameha IV (1834–63) of the Sandwich Isles (now Hawaii) from 1856 to his death. She was visiting England “with the purpose of interesting the friends of English Church missions in the welfare of the Christians among her own people”; for her portrait, see opp.above. (Illustrated London News, supplement, 12 Aug., 141). See also JWC to EW, [9? Oct. 1865] (see vol. 43). who is living in Lady Franklin’s House!) When Mrs Quain had called the other day Lady F’s Servant told her “Her Majesty would be home in an hour if Mrs Quain chose to wait”!!
Emma, Queen Dowager of the Sandwich Islands
Illustrated London News
The best blessings one can wish on the dear wee travelling companion, Lady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: A nice hamper came from Mr Cross Joseph Cross (b. ca. 1830), head gardener at Addiscombe. last Saturday I have written to tell him I am to be away for aweek or two

TC TO
JWC

docBody.p: Miss Orrock / 73. George Street / Edinr
I have got yr Newspaper; but no Letter is yet forthcoming
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [9 Aug.]. Addr: Miss Craik’s, / 73 George Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 10 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.745. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:333–35. JWC has misread “Orrock” as “Craik” in TC to JWC, [8 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Again you have had no letter Dear! But, in compensation, all the ink-spots are out of your writing table!! Had It been going straight to any Literary Museum, I shouldn’t have meddled with the ink , which Hero-worshipers might have regarded with a certain adoration; but for your own use, I thought you would like it better clean! It has never been cleaned, that poor table, TC’s writing desk, originally belonging to JWC’s father, Dr. John Welsh; see 41:23–24TC to JWC, 14 Sept. 1864. since I used to do all the Housemaid work myself! And it is a wonder of Heaven that I should be up to such work again—after all! and I cannot better express my thankfulness than in working while I may! So I fastened on that table after breakfast this morning, and rubbed at it the whole time till the carriage came at two! Of course Jessie could have waxed and turpentined the table better than me; but no one but me, I flatter myself could have shown the patience and ingenuity necessary for extracting all that ink!—

You will infer that I am going on well as to my arm, my sleep, and all that. I have really had not one downright bad night since I came home—except the first. The pain is almost entirely gone out of my arm and hand. But the stiffness continues—and is easy to bear! I can use some of my fingers—a little. I am now writing with the lamed hand! JWC’s right hand; her handwriting in this letter was back to her usual style. But I cannot take hold; nor could I raise my arm to my head if it were to save my life.

If it were not that almost everybody I know is “out of Town[”] I should
rather regret having promised to go to Folkstone on Monday. But it is to be hoped that the Sea breezes will blow the dust of those Books off me! Two of the Pug-Puppies and their amiable Mama have been placed “at Hampstead for change of air”; and only Spark and the youngest Spark and Jocky; see JWC to TC, [27 July]. accompany us to Folkstone.

Another proof of wellness I am going alone! I find I can now do everything, in dressing, with my left hand, except twisting up my back hair and putting the comb in; and Miss Bromley’s House maid can do that much for me in one minute. Jessie sees a great deal of cleaning needed, and will get at it better when the regular work of the House is not going on— T hen ; sufficient for the day is the running up and down thereof! Cf. Matthew 6:34. Besides, She will learn the ways of London Servants fast enough, without my hastening to initiate her therein!

In mydearth of company, I drove out to Denmark Hill yesterday to return a call old Mrs Ruskin made here in my absence. See JWC to JR, 15 July. But I am decidedly unluky at that House— Mrs Ruskin and son were changing the air at the Norwood Hotel! Queen’s Hotel, fashionable hotel in Upper Norwood, Croydon, 10 mi. (16 km.) S of London; see TC to JAC, 2 Sept. JWC ate dinner at the hotel, 1860, where it was unidentified; see 36:236JWC to TC, [9–10 Sept. 1860]. He writes to offer himself for Friday evening. Ruskin wrote, 8 Aug.: “I am used now to have everything go as I wouldn’t have it—and everybody come when I can’t see them—but we are unlucky in these Denmark Hill visits. / May I come on Friday, or Saturday, evening?”
Such a fright Dr Carlyle’s hand-writing on the address gave me! Presumably TC to JWC, [8 Aug.]; envelope untraced.

Forster is better and off on his Inspecting. Forster’s work as a lunacy commissioner took him traveling around the country. You wont forget to go and see my Aunts! Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh, JWC’s paternal aunts living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh. And do take a cab and go and see poor dear Betty! Stenhouse close by Greenend Betty Braid lived at Upper Stenhouse, near Greenend village; see 35:206JWC to TC, [16 Sept. 1859]. Anybody can tell you which is the house JWC enclosed a separate scrap of paper in the handwriting of John Edward Jones (ca. 1824–93), asst. librarian at the London Lib., writing at the end: “I have returned to the Library all these Books!! J C.” Jones listed five books: “Joseph der Zweite 12o 1786 / Lebengeschichte Trenck / Hofleben Maria Theresia Khevenhuller 1 Vol / Duke of Cumberland’s Life 1 Vol / Political Poems & Songs 2V.” David Christoph Seybold, Joseph der Zweite, eine Skizze (Leipzig, 1786); not cited in Carlyle, Works; Friedrich von der Trenck, Nähere Beleuchtung seiner Lebengeschichte (Lausanne, 1787); TC previously denied all knowledge of this edition of Trenck; see 41:173TC to JEJ, 21 Feb.; Adam Wolf, Aus dem Hofleben Maria Theresia’s: nach den Memorien des Fürsten Joseph Khevenhüller (Vienna, 1859); TC also previously denied all knowledge of Wolf’s book; see 41:173TC to JEJ, 21 Feb.; Andrew Henderson, William Augustus, Duke of Cumberland (1766); TC had a copy of this book, which was lent to Lady Ashburton but apparently never given back; he then asked John A. Carlyle if he had a copy he could borrow, and apparently got one (see 37:170TC to JAC, 2 June 1861, 37:173TC to JAC, 7 June 1861, and 37:176TC to JAC, 24 June 1861), but he must have also borrowed a copy from the library; cited in Carlyle, Works 16:80; Thomas Wright, Political Poems and Songs relating to English history, composed during the period from the accession of Edw. III. to that of Ric. III, 2 vols. (1859–61); TC previously had an earlier volume, Thomas Wright, Political Songs of England from the reign of John to Edw. II. (1839), borrowed from Peter Cunningham (1816–69; ODNB ), writer; see 28:324TC to PC, 25 Nov. 1853. All these books are listed in Catalogue of the London Library (1865).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 10 July [Aug.]. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 10 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.723. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdates. JWC wrote a note to herself about the train time for her trip to Folkestone, 14 Aug., on the back of TC’s envelope: “4-20 Jeffrey [?] / Charing Cross / a little after four / The Junction”; the name (possibly Jeffrey) might be of someone meeting her; otherwise unexplained. Folkestone Junction was the nearest station for the West Cliff; see 38:119JWC to TC, [4 July 1862].
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Orrock’s Lodgings 73. George Street, Edinr, 10 july [August] (Thursday) 1865
docBody.p: For pity’s sake, one word of tidings Dear! I am becoming a prey to inquietudes; have not had the scrape of a pen from you since Saty (except a Newspaper address, instead of a Letter, on Tuesday), and know not how to reconcile it with both yr wellbeing & yr punctuality. Bad was my luck that gave you, first, instructns to write to Edinr lest you might miss me at Scotsbrig, and, secondly, a wrong address of “67. Hanover Street” here! 67. Hanr Street, it seems, has not been the right address for long; the now right address I sent you instantly (you wd get it Wedny afternoon still in time for the post), and agn on a Newspr yesterday; but it helps nothing;—nor can wrong address be the reason of yr silence; for the Newspaper was forwarded from “67,” as any letter wd be in the course of some hours; and in fact the poor Maid-Servt Unidentified further. has been running incessantly both to “67” & to 3 or 4 other, supposable misaddresses, witht the smallest result. For Heaven’s sake, write me instantly; unless you are [having] some kind of relapse or mishap, it is nothing like fair-play! But I struggle to hope agt hope.

Of my own doings hereI have not the heart to say a word. Nothing is essentially wrong with me; I snatch a modicum of sleep out of baddish accommodatn; am on my feet all day, running abt; bathing at Portobello; Portobello, seaside resort, about 3 mi. (5 km.) E of Edinburgh. seeing seeing Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. —whom? Nobody of the least moment, or that cd give me the least satisfactn; old localities have been hitherto my chief entertaint. “Everybody is out of Town,” they say; nay Edinr itself I find to have left Town! They have
clipt & dug away every feature that used to make Edinr vernacular and interesting to me: Adieu to it also! John goes abt with me everywhere; strives touchingly to be hospitable and harmless. Henry Inglis I did not find on calling; am to try agn tomorrow at a set hour. The Otthenins Jean Otthenin and her das., Margaret and Irma. I found—to be extremely wearisome! Yr Aunts & Walter Possibly JWC’s cousin Rev. Walter Welsh, Auchtertool, Fife, was visiting Edinburgh, as TC did not intend to go to Fife; or in error for Betty Braid, whom he did visit. I mean to try for. On Tuesday next we go to Erskine, and so end this stupid hurlyburly. Adieu, Dearest; God grant me a word of news tomorrow morning, and above all that the news be good. Yr disconsolate Affecte
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [11 Aug.]. MS: NLS 609.747. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:280–82, where dated 12 Aug.; Fri. was 11 Aug. Quot: Bliss, JWC 325.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest! it all came of you being moving, TC wrote later: “Brother John and I, as I now recollect, were in and about Edinburgh, Stowe, Newbattle (I solus for a call); then Linlathen both, for some days; whence to Stirling of Keir (dreary rail journey, dreary all, though in itself beautiful and kind); thence to Edinburgh (John’s bad lodging there, &c.), after which back to Dumfriesshire—to Scotsbrig, I suppose. Before this I had been three days at Keswick with my valued old friend, T. Spedding; walked to Bassenthwaite Ha’s. (Seen five-and-forty years ago and not recognisable!) Nothing could exceed my private weariness, sadness, misery, and depression. Little thought it was, within few months, to be all sharpened into poignancy and tenderest woe, and remain with me in that far exceeding if somewhat nobler form.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:280). Bassenthwaite Halls, a small group of buildings at the NE tip of Bassenthwaite Lake, visited by TC in 1818; see 1:150TC to RM, 27 Nov. 1818. and me sitting still! I didn’t know exactly when and where a letter would find you, and was occupied enough to avail myself of the shabby excuse for spending no time in writing— Besides, the time is always much longer for the Person on his travels than for the one at home. And your right address did not reach me in time for that days post. It came to hand at tea time, as did yesterday’s newspaper. So I could only answer at night to be ready for the post of yesterday. Today I send a line or two, remembering that Sunday you can get nothing.

Jessy and I arealone just now Mrs Warren having petitioned for “her Holyday.” No age exempts people here from the appetite for holydays! She left on Wednesday afternoon and does not return till Sunday in time to see me off on Monday. As that new journey comes near I shudder at it considerably! “Stavo
bene—” Cf. “Stava bene, per star meglio, sto qui!” [I was well; but trying to be better, I find myself here!]; an old epitaph; see 18:109TC to JWC, 6 July 1844. If you cannot be at the trouble to go out to Betty’s: do send her a line, telling where and when she can come to you. She will read in the newspapers that you are in Edinr; The Scotsman reported, 15 Aug.: “Mr Thomas Carlyle is at present on a visit at Torsonce, the residence of Henry Inglis, Esq. He is in search of relaxation and rest, his ‘Life of Frederick the Great’ having involved the investigation of years, and well nigh the health of the illustrious author.” and break her poor old heart over it if she gets no sight of you “I did go” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:281). She has already had one bad disappointment in not seeing me when I was so near!

We had a great thunder storm last evening; and the air today is delightfully fresh. I had poor little Madame Reichenbach at tea with me and her Husband Countess and count von Reichenbach. came late to take her home, and the thunder burst and the rain fell! and the lamp was burning dim! And the dingy little Countess from time to time made little moaning speeches in English—unintelligible—“upon my honour”! Coterie speech; see 24:171JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. and—Reichenbach as usual sat with crossed arms and knitted brows, silent as the tombs! and to let them walk home in such pouring wet seemed too cruel! and they had no shilling to take a cab—and I would gladly have paid a cab for them but of course dared not! The Reichenbachs were in reduced circumstances, their hopes for a financially successful emigration to the U.S. having failed. And “altogether” Coterie speech; see 16:262JWC to TC, [11 July 1843]. the situation was “rather exquisite”! “‘Pang which was exquisite.’ Foolish phrase of Godwin’s in his Life of Mary Wollstonecraft” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:282); coterie speech; cf. 16:198JWC to JW, [15 June 1843].

And now I must conclude and prepare for Bellona. That poor Beast behaves quite well at present. Of course old Silvester never quits the Box. See TC to JWC, 26 July. I couldnt have the heart to complain about his having grown old!—
I will send my address—or stop—“Tuesday next”— Perhaps better send it now
care of Miss Davenport Bromley / 4 Langhorne Gardens / West Cliff / Folkestone
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Blundered with the paper! JWC began her letter on the last page of a folded sheet insteadof the first.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 Aug. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 11 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.724. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Not for years have I been gladder of a Letter than I was of yrs this morng. All is right then, after all, you careless little Cutty; Old Scots; affectionate term for a mischievous girl; cf. 34:147. and I have been tormenting myself for no reason. Oh you—! Don’t you deserve that I shd do as I have been done to, Cf. Matt. 7:12. and have You go off to Folkstone witht one word for six days? In considern of yr good news, and perhaps of other circs, I (really in the very greatest haste, & having just dined) jot down for you the following.

We arejust on the point of setting off for Morningside To visit JWC’s aunts. (John incessantly bothering & hurrying abt omnibuses &c), and will take our chance of being in time for the Tea. We have been at Comley Bank No 2 (poor old place, as clear-looking as ever, and very affecting to me); 21 (not 2) Comely Bank, the Carlyles’ first home together, 1826–28; see 186. “Comley” was the spelling used by the Carlyles; see 4:28JBW to MAC, [25 Jan. 1826].
21 Comely Bank, Edinburgh, lithograph by T. R. Way
New Letters and Memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle
2dly we went (what is the grand daily busss) to Portobello for a bathe,—weather decidedly wettish;—and on the road made a call on one Sterling a goodish old Welsh-Doctor acqce of mine. James Hutchison Stirling (1820–1909; ODNB ), doctor and philosopher; he had been the medical officer at Hirwaun Ironworks, S. Wales, 1844–51, but coming into money on the death of his father gave up medicine in favor of philosophy. He first wrote to TC 1840 (see 12:149TC to MAC, 20 May 1840) and visited the Carlyles in London 1857 (see 33:127TC to JHS, 29 Nov. 1857). His wife, m. 1847, was Jane Hunter, b.
