Mair; they had two sons and five das. and lived at 2 Stuart St., Piershill, Edinburgh. He wrote to a friend about TC’s visit: “The great author has decidedly aged; but he still seems pretty strong. He talked very hearty and cheery—a long time to my wife. … T.C. and the Dr were going to bathe at Portobello, whither I accompanied them. They forgot their pipe-cases at my house, and I had to send William up with them. He was asked in, talked with, and in going away, T.C. said to him, ‘Tell your papa I am very glad I called on him’” (A. H. Hutchison, James Stirling Hutchison, His Life and Work [1912] 172). Before going, I saw Hy Inglis & intend going out to him at 3.20 The 3:20 p.m. train to Stow. tomorrow aftn, to stay till Monday: he was really very kind & good; & promises the gentlest and calmest treatt in nature. Here I do always sleep some, in parts, 5 or 6 hours; but with what difficulty. For the rest, in genl health, I am perhaps really a little better— Yesternight we sat an hour with Blackie & Wife: John Stuart Blackie (1809–95; ODNB ), classical and Scottish Gaelic scholar, and his wife, m. 1842, Eliza, b. Wyld (1819–1908); they lived at 24 Hill St., Edinburgh. TC and Blackie had corresponded since 1834, although they did not apparently meet until 1848; see 24:23–24TC to JSB, 16 April 1849. good
souls really; the Wife especially and very fond of one another. On Monday, coming back from Inglis, I am perhaps within reach of Lady & Ld Lothian? Lord and Lady Lothian lived at Newbattle Abbey, house and estate nr. Dalkeith, 7 mi. (11 km.) SE of Edinburgh, 19 mi. (30.5 km.) N of Stow. We shall see. You write tomorrow;—after that, Monday Evg the first Instant you have, care of Erskine (Linlathen, Dundee) (mind now) I add my blessings only, best of Goodies.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady L [LLO], 13 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11439. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.dateline: Torsonce / Stow / Midlothian TCwrote on Inglis’s headed notepaper. 13 Augt, 1865—
docBody.p: Thousandthanks for yr promptitude in kindness:—alas, that the inexorable Bradshaw shd now turn out to put his veto on it; “tomorrow no trains possible,” he says!— Tuesday I have to go to Forfarshire To visit Thomas Erskine. for three days; shall be back at Edinr, with face set southwd, abt the end of the week: it is then that I will agn try all I can, if there be a possibility for me from the Edinburgh side.

My poor Wife cd get no farther than Dumfriesshire; & has returned home some three weeks ago,—still in poor health, tho’ I hope rather improving, especially ever since her journey ended. Yr gracious remembrance will be a pleasure toher next time I write. With many regards,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [14 Aug.]. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 14 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.748. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I havent a minute to spare Dear!—this is only to tell you I have found my seal!! See JWC to MR, 7 Aug. and am so sorry to have troubled you to inquire about it! and another
thing—to send you a mulberry leaf—you recollect you asked me what it was like? This is an unusually large one off an old old tree— Probably taken from the mulberry tree in Cheyne Walk; see 37:143TC to LS, 6 April 1861.
In ten minutes I start for Folkestone— Alone— Jessy will clean the House In my absence
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14Aug. Addr: Miss Davenport Bromley / 4. Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Edinburgh, 14 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS617.725. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I have just returned from my Three-days of Henry Inglis; a genial and interesting, tho’ confused and pluistery kind of thing (first night sleepless till 6 a.m. &c &c); and am glad to be back agn into the possibility of writing to you in silence (tho’ only on a window-sill, in my old bedroom here). My second sleep, last night’s [merely], Word unclear. was good and valid; Inglis & Household rather more than fulfilled expectatn; many regards to you for one thing among others hearty and honest John A. Carlyle wrote to their nephew James Carlyle, 14 Aug.: “Your uncle has just come back from … a visit to Mr Henry Inglis. … He took an opportunity of speaking about you very emphatically; & I have no doubt but Mr Inglis will do all he can to get you a place as Factor” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). TC previously wrote to Inglis about a post for James, Dec. 1864; see 41:122–23TC to HI, 7 Dec. 1864, and 41:127TC to JAC, 16 Dec. 1864. (of whh when we meet);—and, for another thing, Inglis eagerly accepts Noggs from me as a Gift, and will really be proud & careful of the poor quadruped; “never, to sell him,—shall die when his hour comes, only by sudden powder & ball.” Whh also ends comfortably an embarrasst of mine.

On the Saturday, before starting, I took cab with Jack, and on pleast terms drove first to Betty then to yr Aunts. Of the latter we saw only Elizth & Anne, “Grace out visiting the sick”; Anne was slightly invalid but recovering, Elizth in her average figure; and both were very cordial & honestly glad, with many inquiries abt their amiable Niece, who knows that they really have an affectn for her. But Betty, poor old faithful Betty, she was the interesting object; set me really almost crying; and indeed is, I shd say, the notablest human figure I have anywhere seen in these parts. She was paring potatoes when we drew up: oh her surprise, and joy shining thro’ her old pale face; how she at once shoved the potatoes aside, flung on an old black shawl, & had the little kitchen made into a drawing-room, and talked more interesting things all the time we staid. Husband and some Guest they had were out; Betty is a little, little
not much, dull of hearing; very old sad and pale, but with all the old keenness of eye & geniality of tone; a peasant heroine whom I know not the match of at present. What she said of yr Father, of yrself, &c I shall never forget, I think.— But space is done here, and so is time. I can only bid you write at once on rect of this; it will not be till after yr first night:—come home agn at at Word repeated with line over it at turn of page. once, Dear, if you find it not to suit! My Address, you know will be Erskine’s (Linlathan Dundee),—at once now, were it only a word! The “Lothians” (see inclosed Note) Untraced. I cd make nothing of, owing to trains. God keep my Dearest .
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 15 Aug. Addr: Linlathen / near Dundee / N.B. PM: Folkstone, 15 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.749. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:335–37 inc; Simpsons 276–77 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.salute: Here I am Dear! Safe and Slept!
docBody.p: I arrived last evening about seven. Miss Bromley had gone for a walk with the girl staying with her Unidentified further. and they had lost their way! So I had ample time to unpack all the things into my drawers, before I was called upon to dress for dinner.

It is a nice House—for Sea-Lodging—but I am afraid you would find the same fault to it as to the West Cliff Hotel Also in Folkestone; see TC to JWC, 11 July. viz: “an eternal ripple-tippling of venetian blinds! Also there is a terrible super abundance of—earwigs! They are found in your hair-brush! in the Book you are reading! in fact I defy you to say where they will not be found!

But the “Flight of Skylarks” is always charming to live beside! and the air of the West Cliff is understood to be all one could wish! And “Change (Dr Blakiston wrote to me the other day) is for illness like mine the one available Medecine”! So, I suppose it is all right!— Certainly my sleeping facilities were nothing like so great here last night, as they were at home; nevertheless, in spite of “ripple-tippling,” and too much light, and the sense of novelty, I patched together Sleep enough to be called a goodish night.

It is blowing hard today with a dull grey sky, and skiffs of rain; so I see no prospect of “Varrying the Schene”! Coterie speech; see 31:189JWC to TC, 23 August 1856. as there areno carriages but open ones.

Oh my Dear! I could tell you something that would make you die of laughing,
if I hadnt to dilute it in ink! And I was solemnly charged to “not tell Mr Carlyle”! Lady William Lady William Russell; see also n. 10. told me, that Mr and Mrs Grote Harriet Grote, b. Lewin (1792–1878; ODNB ), writer, and her husband, m. 1820, George Grote (1794–1871; ODNB ), historian and radical politician. TC borrowed books from Harriet Grote for his work on Frederick; see 39:122–23TC to HG, 7 May 1863. having lived to the respective ages of 72 and 74, in the expression of the most outrageously George-Sandish opinions George Sand, pseud. of Amandine Aurore Lucie Dudevant, b. Dupin (1803–76), French novelist who advocated women’s rights; her name was often used to describe a philosophy of the supremacy of love over fidelity; see 29:184–85TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1854. had tried the thing in practice and found it “no go”!— “Yes, my dear Lady! Mr Grote, sad to say, has committed——an infidelity!! George Grote’s infatuation was with the sculptor Susan Durant (1827–73; ODNB ), who had been commissioned to do a medallion of him in the early 1860s; their liaison apparently ended in 1865. And poor Mrs Grote so far from agreeing that a grand passion is omnipotent, and showing the generosity of Jacques, In Sand’s novel Jacques (1834), the hero Jacques, rather than challenging his wife’s lover to a duel, went off to die in the Alps. has fallen ill about it and had to go off to the Continent for her health”! Harriet Grote later confided to Kate, Lady Amberley, who noted in her diary, 14 March: “Mrs. Grote told me, when here yesterday, the cause of her illness, her depression of spirits and nervous system. I was very much startled by hearing it was that Mr. Grote had conceived a passion for a woman and had made an old fool of himself, and then that she had remonstrated, his reputation being dearer to her than anything else, and then an estrangement and coldness had grown between them, which had made her miserable. This was in the winter of 1864— to 65. … [T]his summer of 1865 [her health] gave way and she was very ill and has not recovered yet. … I felt very unhappy for her and much shocked. She was so tender on the old Grote and said it was common for old men to have deep passions late in life, she had known several cases of it. … She also said it only belonged to the highest and most refined nature to love at that age, and not to coarse and sensual ones. She was a curious mixture of admiration for his refined nature and vexation at the trial it had been for her. I cd. not understand talking of it so dispassionately at all. … Strange bad complicated world it is” (Bertrand and Patricia Russell, eds., The Amberley Papers [1937] 1:477–78).

I did hear from George Cooke that Lady Trelawney Lady Harriet Jane Trelawny, b. Tremayne (ca. 1822–79); m., 1842, Sir John Salusbury-Trelawny (1816–85; ODNB ), 9th bart., politician and diarist. Lady Amberley reported in her journal that Mrs. Grote “only told Lady Trelawny … but that Ly W. Russell had found it out” (Amberley Papers 1:478). had taken Mrs Grote to Paris and then returned immediately—“Mrs Grote for all her strong-mindedness not being equal to crossing the sea alone and Mr Grote couldnt accompany her”!
Please, when Linlathen will no longer do for an address to send word yourself to Bulock.

An intimation reached me yesterday that poor General Veitch (Hamilton
Veitch) has died in India Hamilton Veitch (1804–65), JWC’s schoolfellow and admirer; see 32:210JWC to TC, [30 July 1857]. The Haddingtonshire Courier announced his death, 11 Aug.: “At Dacca in the East Indies, on the 11th June last, Major-General Hamilton Vetch, of the Bengal Service.” — He had gone out again for “just one year, to settle his affairs” Again I have blundered with my paper See JWC to TC, [11 Aug.]. —
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EW [EWA], 16 Aug. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: I got here safe at a quarter before seven, after a pleasant journey; for nobody was in the carriage but myself, and the country was looking beautiful with its wheat sheafs and hop-fields, and the way was not too long.

Miss Bromley having gone for a long walk and lost her way; I had leisure to put my things all in the drawers before having to dress for dinner at eight o’clock. If I could have taken Jessy out of my black leather bag to help me in dressing, and put her back again when no longer needed I should have been thankful! for I grew so nervous at the notion of never getting down in time, that I could hardly tie a string or put in a pin! But on the whole it was best that I left her behind, to do her own work. These sea-bathing quarters are too limited for extra maids; especially as Miss Bromley’s own Ladys maid is a very large and very mighty Woman Possibly Minna Müller, b. ca. 1837 in Germany, listed as Miss Bromley’s lady’s maid in the 1871 census; otherwise unidentified. who would have found Jessie too nice, and pretty; and shown her no kindness.

I forgot nothing of moment, I think, except to leave my address for you and the Postman. Catch Mr Bulock as soon as possible, and tell him to forward any letters for me to the address at the head of this note. And any (not circulars) that arrive for Mr Carlyle let him forward to
Thomas Erskine Esq
Linlathan
near Dundee
Scotland
till further orders—
I slept pretty well, considering it was my first night, and that I am given to lying awake in new situations.

I forgot tospeak about the curtains, and get the binding for them. You will
have abundance of time to do them while I am here. So just look how the Drawingroom ones are finished at the top; and do the Diningroom ones the same; only making the four curtains into two. The binding I think is a penny a yard and sold in pieces of twelve yards, or by the yard. You can get it at Roope’s in Sloan street I dare say or at all events at Herveys in Knightsbridge. Charles Roope & Son, linen drapers, 144 Sloane St.; Harvey Nichols & Co., linen drapers, 8–16 Lowndes Terr., Knightsbridge. take one of the the small pieces to match the colour with. Tell Jessey to write me a little letter. Wishing you both well
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 17 Aug. Addr: Miss Davenport Bromley / 4. Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Dundee, 17 Aug. 1865. MS:NLS 617.726. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest! for yr punctual good news! That you are safe somewhere, and that you are getting sleep: the world can tell me nothing so comfortable from any other point of its circumference. But beware of those earwigs! Two of them present successively in my bed (what is even worse than one’s book) bit me in the most venemous way, no bug or other malison comparable; enough to have set yr poor thin skin into a flame; keep a sharp and sharpest outlook!— — I am here restricted to minutes—under pain of perhaps losing you a London Post, or day at Folkne;—therefore, brief is the word.

We got hither, as perhaps the Newspr despatched the instant I got to land wd tell you: good old Erskine was waiting for us on the Pier of Broughty Ferry, Town and port 4 mi. (6.5 km.) E of Dundee, 2½ mi. (4 km.) S of Linlathen; TC and John A. Carlyle traveled by sea from Edinburgh. tho’ the day was altogether a slop of draggly wet; an old white-bearded friend of the friendliest; and really looking 5 years younger than when I last saw him 5 years ago. TC last visited Erskine Sept. 1860; see 36:233TC to JCA, 9 Sept. 1860. Writing a Book or something of the kind, The next book Erskine pbd. was The Purpose of God in the Creation of Man (Edinburgh, 1870). I dimly understand. Nobody is here; but Mrs Stirling, Mrs Paterson, Thomas Erskine’s sisters, Christian Stirling and David Paterson. and another old Lady (English, called “Mrs Batten,” Caroline Batten, b. Venn (1798–1870), widow of Rev. Samuel Ellis Batten (1792–1830); she and her da., Emelia Russell Gurney, b. Batten (1823–96; ODNB ), campaigner for women’s higher education, were old friends of Erskine’s. whom it seems I “saw before,” a kind of Flatch,
but harmless, except that she presides at breakfast, & is a friend of the tepid); so that we are very quiet, social, get bathing, wholesome perfectn of Scotch victual; and I have such a bedroom (known to me before) as you cd wish! Silent as Eternity; looking out on trees and green spaces; where I can sleep,—and even smoke it needful. Excellt all: nevertheless we have to go Saturday morning,—“Mrs Schwabe” Julie Salis Schwabe (1818–96; ODNB ), philanthropist and educationist; known to the Carlyles since 1849; see 38:260JWC to LAI, 10 Nov. [1862]. (Himmel und Erde [Heaven and Earth]!) “with Five” Presumably some of her seven children, who included Harriet (b. 1839), Edmund Salis (b. 1841), George (b. 1844), Frederick (b. 1845), Julia Rosetta (b. 1848), and Catherine Marianna (b. 1850). being on the advent one hour behind us. There are plenty of other invitatns &c &c, as you see; but for want of time, or of will, I have to reject them,—all except perhaps the industrious Lady Lothian’s (and this only perhaps), whh I can convert into a call of 4 or 5 hours, with luncheon and despatch homewards the same evg. I must ansr Lady Ashbn from here; that will be tomorrow. Hitherto no appointt abt addresses: you, if you write at once (not otherwise) may still find me Tuesday morning at Edinr 73 Ge Strt; that afternoon I think to be at Scotsbrig;—& then only for a day or two, whence straight Chelsea-ward, I shd rather guess. Foxton I rather doubt of, item Alderley, the direct sweep home, home to my own safe den, is so tempting. Ah that ripple-tippling: ah!— Come you home, if it trouble. What a Farce-tragedy that of the Grotes! Adieu, ­Dearest
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir WSM [WS], 17 Aug. MS: Glasgow City Archives. Hitherto unpbd. William Stirling became Sir William Stirling Maxwell on the death of his uncle Sir John Maxwell, 6 June, but was sometimes still styled William Stirling of Keir, M.P.; see TC to JWC, 18 Aug. TC continued to refer to him as William Stirling.
div3.head: TC TO SIR WILLIAM STIRLING MAXWELL

docBody.p: We leave this pleast place on Saturday; with only a few days more left for me in Scotland. But the sight of Keir and you,—and of the new Treasure Stirling m. Anne Maria Leslie-Melville, 26 April. you have got in Keir!—will be very welcome to me, as well as to my Brother who is here, Stirling Maxwell wrote, 16 Aug., “I am glad to hear that you are not only in Scotland, but so placed to the north of Keir, that it is highly improbable you can get south again without passing that spot, where your presence, tho’ often desired, has never yet been obtained. / It will give my wife & me very great pleasure, if you will pay us a visit as you pass. … It will also be a great pleasure to me to make my wife known to you, who are already so well known to her. / Pray say to your brother, that I hope he may be able to come too, tho’ as he lives in Scotland he is less of a ‘rare bird’ than you are.” Keir was about 55 mi. (88.5 km.) SW of Linlathen. and bound for Edinr very soon.

We have decided, therefore, to postpone Edinr till Monday; and mean to start for Keir on Saturday abt Noon; “are to be at Bridge of Allen,” Stirling Maxwell wrote: “the Bridge of Allan is the best station there being plenty of conveyance, & the distance being … a trifle over a mile.” it seems, “at 2.46 p.m.”;—and shall hope soon after to drop anchor under cheerful omens.
My talent for sleep is unhappily rather inconsiderable; but the beneficent Lady perhaps knows it, or you can tell her in the proper diplomatic manner.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 Aug. Addr: Miss Davenport Bromley / 4. Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Dundee, 18 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.727. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote his letter to JWC on the reverse of David Masson’s letter to him, 14 Aug.; David Masson (1822–1907; ODNB ; see 16:312JWC to TC, [24 July 1843]), prof. of English lang. and lit., University Coll., London, 1853–65, and of rhetoric and English lit., Univ. of Edinburgh, 1865–95.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: If there bea Post-delivery on Sunday you may still get this as supplement to yesterday’s;—Erskine wanting yr address, this may go along with it, Thomas Erskine wrote, 18 Aug.: “Beloved Mrs. Carlyle— I suppose you could not have come here—& yet it is with some sorrow, that I accept this arrangement, as I scarcely expect to have another sight of your dear face on this earth— One might ask, what good, would come of it if I had it— I can only answer that ever since I have known that face, it has been a cordial to me to see it.— I am happy to think that you are getting better & recovering a little strength, after that long suffering. … I am glad to see Mr Carlyle so well after passing through such a process. … I have a fellow-feeling with him in many things, & love his singleness of heart & purpose more than I can express.” at any rate.

I am well, Dear, if I but knew that you were sleeping. Oh be sure to write; at once, “Edinr 73 George Street”! I shall be for Scotsbrig directly after that, and homeward after these vague wanderings. We to go to Stirling’s, it wd seem; tomorrow and till Monday; nobody but some Scotch Laird people there,—it will be quieter sleeping than in Edinr, most likely, & no worse for diet. Enough! After that some run to Newbattle for luncheon (not for the night, I think); and then all is achieved,—what an “acht”! “achievement”! Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. But
I am getting four pairs of new shoes TC recorded in his checkbook: “23 Augt 1865 / Duncan, Edinr / Shoes / £3 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). too; of the most perfect fit,—to judge by the pair already tried;—that really is something. I have had, and have still, a daily bathe in the Sea too. Weather lovely now; nothing but placidity (called dulness or not) with friendliness, wholesomeness, umbrageous greenness, and a time too good to last!— I rather think of omitting Foxton; do Alderley; where Kate, too, I see, has got a child. John Francis Stanley Russell. Beware of the earwigs, of the riple-tiplg; and sleep, do sleep, or else come home to me agn. Kindest regards to Miss B. Heaven keep my Dearest.—
T.C.

ps.p: You needn’t read that of Masson, David Masson asked TC to support his application for the chair of Rhetoric and English Literature at Edinburgh Univ.; he wrote, 14 Aug.: “Tomorrow I expect to send in an application, accompanied with copies of the testimonials which procured me my present post in University College. From the similarity … of the posts, these may still be partly relevant. But thirteen years have elapsed since then, & people have had opportunities of judging better or worse of me. … No testimony could be stronger than that which you gave me thirteen years ago, & of which I enclose a copy. I have always remembered it as your supreme kindness to me; & that is saying much. Is it too much to ask that you will write a few words … simply to say that you do not recant, & would like me to get the new post?” TC’s previous testimony for Masson’s application to University College, London, was included in Professorship of Rhetoric and English Literature in the University of Edinburgh. Testimonials in Favour of Professor Masson. I. Reprint of Testimonials of 1852 (1865) 15. TC apparently added nothing for printing in Additional Testimonials in Favour of Professor Masson. II (1865); there was one from John Stuart Blackie, prof. of Greek, Edinburgh Univ., “in continuation of previous testimonial in 1852” (6). It also included testimonials from William Stirling of Keir, M.P., 19 Aug., praising Masson’s Life of Milton (see 16:312JWC to TC, [24 July 1843]) and his critical essays (8), and from George Grote, in his capacity as treasurer of University Coll., London, from Baden-Baden, Germany, 20 Aug.: “His manner of teaching, based upon copious and critical knowledge of English Literature, has been found alike popular and instructive” (4). nor that of Stirling, unless you are quite idle. I will now put cover & “address” for E.’s behoof; then write to Lady A. & perhaps sleep. Adieu

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 18 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Yr Letter hit me here the very morning after I arrived;—to the great joy of us all, or all of us that had the privilege of partaking, viz. Erskine, both the
Sisters, & Self, who all boast to be warm friends of yr Ladyship. Erskine and Lady Ashburton were old friends, Erskine particularly commending the Carlyles to Lady Ashburton on her marriage; see 34:232JWC to MR, [30 Oct. 1858]. They had heard nothing definite for a good while, and were not a little interested with this line from yr own hand.

You seem to be very lonely at Wiesbaden; but perhaps it may be well so, or best of all; & one ought not to be sorry, but the contrary. A little interval of absolute silence and solitary contemplatn seems to me most salutary for all mortals (tho’ so few of mortals now ever have it); the jumble to one’s poor mind ceases; mud becomes sediment, & lies safe at the bottom; the element, we are rejoiced to find, is agn become transparent, clear as water from the spring! Never mind those Lansdownes Henry Thomas Petty-Fitzmaurice (1816–66; ODNB ), 4th marquess of Lansdowne, politician, and his 2d wife, m. 1843, Emily Jane Mercer-Elphinstone, b. de Flahault (1819–95). and their foolish prepossessions: abolish, even in yr own thots, that wretched matter, TC possibly refers to the furor surrounding Lord Ashburton’s will; see 40:113–14TC to LLA, 5 June 1864; otherwise unexplained. whh has so vexed you, and I fear still vexes; in very truth, it is worth nothing but one’s sorrow & contempt,—one’s oblivion, so soon as may be; whh will come, tho’ it does not all at once. Yr bonnie litle Mary’s company is better than any of human elsewhere; you are becoming Guardian too (whh is right well done); and, for “Society,” you have the whole Universe and its silent intimations, and its small still voices, when those of foolish mankind please to fall dumb for a time. We hope you will go sensibly improved to Vevay; Vevey in Switzerland, on the NE shore of Lake Geneva. and return to us do; and in fine that, some time early in October, we shall all be rendezvoused agn, and looking in one another’s faces, thankful more or less for what we have had, and for what we hope.

My own days, since you heard from me & till abt 2 weeks ago when I came to Edinr with my Brother, were among the most silent I ever lived; idle totally, and given up to silent musings & saunterings; sombre, stagnant, not to say torpid;—useful, I do believe, tho’ as sorrowful as need be, for most part. My chief “company” was old Localities and their memories: they still there under the eternal skies; all else that was once in them for me gone its ways,—fled from me forever. God still has it: that I do know! In Edinr it is much the same; much of elegiacally beautiful, but elegiacally alone. I will say no more of all that. I am for Chelsea agn in a few days; not to wander farther, I think, this year.

My Wife is gone toFolkestone to Miss Bromley, the other day; she greatly improved from the time you saw her; and still reports a degree of sleep &c from Folkne,—tho’ indeed her Letter reaches only to the second day there.
Here everything is well; Erskine 5 years younger (really looks so) since I saw him last; Mrs Stirling still the the Word repeated at turn of page. busiest & kindest of Hostesses; Mrs Paterson much beyond her courage, they all say, while this fine weather lasts. We quit tomorrow; go round by Keir, to Edinr after 2 days; then a call or two to make, and home to Scotsbrig, to my Brother’s, the preliminary of Chelsea in a day or two more. Adieu dear Lady; kiss Marykin (symbolically or otherwise) for her pretty little kiss! Yrs ever
T. Carlyle

ps.p: Noggs has been charming; carried me thro’ many pretty rides in Annandale;—& now I have found a home for him in these parts: an old friend’s Henry Inglis; see TC to JWC, 14 Aug. to whom he will be sacred (un sell able &c &c till death) formy sake and yours.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WGP, 18 Aug. MS: Strouse. Text: typewritten copy. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient conjecturally identified as Walter Greenock Patterson (ca. 1821–97), bookseller, 4 North College St., Edinburgh.
div3.head: TC TO W. G. PATERSON

docBody.p: I am sorry to disappoint yr obliging hopes: but the few hours, which are all now that remain for me in Edin(burgh), TC certainly wrote “Edinr,” which was then transcribed as “Edin(burgh).” will not admit of the least attemptat compliance on my part.
Wishing you good success otherwise,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Mr. W. G. Paterson
Edin(burgh)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JH [JHI], [19 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt. Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Folkstone, 20 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Reginald Blunt, “Mrs. Carlyle and her Housemaid,” Cornhill Magazine n.s. 11 (Oct. 1901): 461–62 inc; Reginald Blunt, In Cheyne Walk and Thereabout (1914) 297–300 inc. Quot: Manawatu Standard, vol. 40, no. 6929 (New Zealand) 12 Feb. 1901; West Gippsland Gazette (Warragul, Victoria, NZ) 26 Feb. 1901.
div3.head: JWC TO JESSIE HIDDLESTON

docBody.p: Thanks, dear Jessie, for your note, which might have been longer without fatiguing my attention! And without exhausting your news I should say!

I continue to like my present quarters; and no wonder; for I have slept more since I came here, than I have done in any given week thro’out the last three years!—have slept actually like a human-Being; without needing to have recourse to Lucifers, Matches, for lighting a candle, and a kind of jelly made from beer. or essence of beef, or any other of those melancholy inventions of Sleeplessness! It is rather mortifying, however, that sleeping so well, I don’t feel the least bit stronger for it! Twice that I have tried walking, about as far as twice the length of Cheyne Walk, I have had to get myself brought home ignominiously in a Donkey-Cart! And though I dine twice every day,—once at two oclock, under the name of Luncheon, and again at half after eight under the name of Dinner; I don’t think I eat, putting it altogether as much as would keep a couple of rabbits nay—one rabbit, plump and sleek! I miss the oat-cakes; and I miss Mrs Warren’s coffee, oh most dreadfully! And I need excessively to have my hair combed!— Tho’ the pain is quite gone out of my arm, it is stiffer, I think, than ever! And then the Housemaid Possibly Miss Bromley’s lady’s maid; see JWC to EW, 16 Aug. is so ugly!—I cant bear her to come within a yard of me! so I take an hour to dress myself every time, and look untidy after all.

Well, one of the twoweeks I gave myself is past, and the other will soon be over too; and Heaven grant Mr Carlyle mayn’t plump down on you in the meanwhile! He was to be back from his visits, on the other side of the Forth, next Tuesday I mean—back to his Brother’s in Annandale—whence he would “start homewards, he said in one day or two.” That sounds as if he might arrive at Cheyne Row about Thursday or Friday. I have written to beg him not to be in such desperate haste, exactly at the wrong moment! but to at least stop a day or two at Alderley Park (where we should have stopt but for the Baby!) and so reach home in a calm state of mind, instead of driven distracted by the long journey all at one rush.

And then I held out the inducement that I should be there after Monday 28th to welcome him. But—I don’t know—man is born to contradiction—as the sparks fly upwards! Cf. Job 5:7. The very persuasion that he should absent himself a few more days may give him an unconscious but irresistible impulse towards home!— Any how Mrs Warren and you will not be found like the foolish Virgins, with lamps without oil! Cf. Matt. 25:3. And besides, you may be sure of his giving you due warning. Have his bedroom all right—and the upstairs room fit to be seen, and no other preparations need be made till the hour and day of his coming has been announced to you by himself. I still hope he may not come till I myself am home first! but—if he should,—there is one thing that you must attend to, and which you would not think of without being told! that cat!!—I wish she
were dead. but I cant shorten her days! because—you see—my poor dear wee dog liked her! Nero, JWC’s dog, Dec. 1849–Feb. 1860; see 24:308JWC to JAC, [10 Dec. 1849], and 36:66–67JWC to LLA, [12 Feb. 1860]. For Nero’s friendship with the cat, see 34:206JWC to JAU, [30 Sept. 1858]. Well! there she is! and as long as she attends Mr C at his meals (she doesn’t care a snuff of tobacco for him at any other times!) so long will Mr C continue to give her bits of meat, and driblets of milk, to the ruination of the carpets and hearthrugs! I have over and again pointed out to him the stains she has made—but he won’t believe them her doing!—and the Diningroom carpet was so old and ugly, that it wasn’t worth rows with one’s Husband about! Now however that nice new cloth must be protected against the cat-abuse. So what I wish is; that you would shut up the creature when Mr C has breakfast, or dinner, or tea. And if he remarks on her absence, say it was my express desire. He has no idea what a selfish, immoral, improper beast she is! nor what mischief she does to the carpets!
My bed had better be slept in occasionally.
Kind regards to Mrs Warren
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 Aug.]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / Scotland. PM: Ecclefechan, 21 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.750. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:282–85.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest It will be surest to direct to Scotsbrig. one might easily fail of hitting you on the wing at Edinr! But I wish you could have brought yourself to go for a few days to the Lothians “To Newbattle, where I spent a day” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:283). their patience and perseverance in asking you deserved a visit! And it is rather perverse this sudden haste to get home while I am not there to receive you! Don’t you think it is?— For your own sake however I do entreat you to break the long journey by either stopping at Alderley or making out that visit to Foxton. “Frederic, my old German fellow-tourist: his cottage ‘near Rhayader’ was of route too intricate for me” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:283). Alderley which you know, and are sure of a fine quiet bedroom at, would be best. It is such a pity to arrive at home, entirely fevered and knocked up with that journey, as always happens, and then you take it to be “London” that is makingyou ill!

Then, if you staid a few days at Alderley; I could stay out the fortnight I undertook for here, and be home in time to give you welcome. I should go home on Monday week (Monday the 28th) in the course of nature— I suppose
this place is good for me; I have slept so much!—more than in any other week for the last three years! But I dont feel stronger for all this sleep—nor more able to eat, or to walk! One day that I tried walking about as far as from Cheyne row to the Hospital, The Royal Chelsea Hospital, home for old and disabled soldiers; see 7:215TC to JAC, 17 June 1834; about 900 yds. (1 km.) E of Cheyne Row. I had to come home ignominiously in a donkey cart! But the Drives don’t tire me; especially since Miss Bromley had her own carriage and horses sent down. Nor need there be any reflections for want of “simmering stagnation”! There is not a human creature to speak to! out of our own house. and in it, the Pugs have the greatest share of the conversation to themselves!
I cannot forgive Thomas Erskine for taking up and keeping up with such a beast of a woman as Mrs Schwabe! letting you be driven out by Mrs Schwabe!
I am so glad you went to see dear Betty, it will be something good for her to think of for a year to come!

Do writedistinctly the when and the how of your homecoming What do you think? I have exactly two sovereigns in the world!—enough to pay the servants here and my railway fare, home!! And no more!! Yet I have not been extravagant that I am aware of!

I had to pay Silvester before I went to Scotland 16 pounds eleven and fourpence—and to ditto after my return five pounds . . seventeen shillings. And Freure “The Chelsea carpenter” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:284). couldnt get on without “something towards the work” and paid I him ten pounds—

making up in all one half of my house-money— Then, Your being away makes no difference on the Rent taxes, servants wages and keep, &c— And for my being away myself, I certainly have to pay to other peoples servants more than it would cost me for individual “living’s cares”!

I had indeed, besides the House money, my own fifteen pounds—of which the two sovereigns above mentioned are the sad remains!— But when these pounds came to hand I owed for my summer bonnet and cloak. and I had some little presents to buy, to take with me to Scotland, besides a gown for myself. The only part of my own money I can be said to have spent needlessly was a guinea and a half for——you would never guess what!—for a miniature
of—You!! Such a Beauty! Every one who sees it screams with rapture over it!—even Ruskin!
But my hand can do no more—
Miss Bromley bids me say “that four footed animal” Presumably the dog Spark. sends his respects (“and put that in inverted commas please!”)
She is good as possible to me
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EW [EWA], 21 Aug. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on Keir headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: Good Mrs Warren,—I got yr Packet at Linlathen, all right. Nothing since. But if you had anything, perhaps it will be lying for me at Edinburgh tomorrow when I arrive there. Any way my Address henceforth is to be
“Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan N.B”
till you hear agn. And I expect to be home at Chelsea soon!
This is all.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 21 Aug. Addr: Miss Davenport Bromley / 4. Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Dunblane, 21 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.728. Hitherto unpbd. Written on Keir headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Keir near Dunblane, N.B. Monday 21 Augt 1865
docBody.p:
Oh my Dearest, I am a bewildered wearied old man! Six days of incesst ever-talking never interesting company; days of late dining, of considerable obligato [obligatory] drinking &c (else one can get no sleep),—above all of continual talking and bothering abt among one’s wearisome fellow-creatures. I wd have given £5 on Saturday to have been going Edinr-ward (as originally settled) into at least silence; but as it was unalterable, I fared on hitherwd, to new and more tumultuous scenes of the foregoing kind:—and today (owing to the urgencies of Stirling, much caudled into unsufferable puddle by Br John’s incessant managing) I am, at length abt noon (an hour ago), again settled to be here till tomorrow,—and, with a ride in the afternoon, amid the beautifullest
scenes in the world, and under nearly the saddest heart, once more take my destiny, and drink as I have brewed. Proverbial; cf. Ben Jonson, Every Man in his Humour (1601) 2:1; see also 34:254TC to JCA, 28 Dec. 1858. God grant I may hear good news of you tomorrow at Edinr: no other pleast thing can I expect there; except to be let alone, and make final arrangets for the south! Ah me— But yet I have always had my sleep, my &c &c; and unkindness of all forms has been as if banished & buried from me; weather too is good; & the Ochill Hills, Stirling Castle, and Vale of Forth, From his windows TC would have seen the Ochil Hills to the E, and Stirling Castle and the Forth valley to the S. look in upon me thro’ my windows (bedroom, the best otherwise almost in nature)— Really I ought to cease grumbling; & write the few words that are absolutely necessary to my poor little Bairn, whom God preserve for me, as the sum of any riches I have!— Our company (of whom when we meet) is all gone today except a pretty little “Lady Emily Hamilton” (Sister of the new “Lady Anna” Lady Emily Eleanor, b. Leslie-Melville (1840–82), m., 1864, John Glencairn Carter Hamilton (1829–1900), politician; she was Lady Anne Stirling Maxwell’s younger sister. that is here), and—Sir Anthony Stirling, Sir Anthony Sterling. of Knightsbridge, who wd have expected that? We have the most gorgeous House in all Creation; never saw the like of it, outside or in,—“most expensive”! Coterie speech; see 15:86JWC to JW, [12 Sept. 1842]. And poor W. Stirling is most unwearied, placid good. This is all I will say.

The day before leaving Linlathen I got a big Packet of Letters from Chelsea: all trash, Sir G. Sincr, begging Letters &c;—of them I took not the slightest notice notice; Word repeated with line over it at turn of page. TC also wrote “(2)” at the top of the new page. I did not even write to Chelsea, so wearied was I; I hope they may have forwarded to Edinr anything of consequence that came: I do write by this Post that “Scotsbrig” is to be the next place,—mark it, you, And Oh write thither on the instant. You shall hear from me agn tomorrow afternoon (perhaps Thursday it will reach you) if all go well. Farther, it is certn I shall have 4 pairs of shoes to try on; perhaps a call from Gordon John Gordon (1797–1882), school inspector; old friend of TC’s; see 4:201TC to AC, 29 March 1827. He lived at 3 Bellevue Cres., Edinburgh. to sustain, a do to make at Newbattle (on what terms is not yet clear),—after whh, Adieu & Southward ho!— A gong is growling in the deeps far down, signal that Lunchn is; of whh I must run for something of pudding nature; mustn’t I? Oh that you were here, to guide me viva voce, & cheer me with the voice I love!
My poor prayers are with and for my own poor Goodykin. Except respects to yr fair Hostess, I add not another word. God keep my Dearest ever. Yours lovingly/
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 Aug. Addr: Miss Bromley / 4. Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Edinburgh, 22 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.729. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I am just arrived safe; delivered into silence agn, whh, tho’ it be with dingy garret lodging ground, and out of magnificence Sir William Stirling Maxwell’s home, Keir, was a large 18th century country house, considerably improved and extended by Stirling, which contained his magnificent collections of paintings, prints, and books. as of the Incas into squalor in comparison, is altogether welcome to me. Had I but found a Note from you, to say, “Well or tolerably; I am sleeping!” But there is not one word, you careless little wretch! Nothing but an old St James’s Newspaper; St. James’s Chronicle. addressed with the right hand, in flowing enough characters, and with two strokes visible,—on whh I must keep hoping, till Scotsbrig rise on me agn! No other shift. The day is draggly, muddy, rainy; hope and tobacco are all that remain to one.

I am abt writing to appoint a call at Newbattle, for tomorrow,—luncheon there (whh shall be my dinner) & return in the evg: that will be one thing done The 4th pair of shoes will also finish (I hope) tomorrow; after whh, if laziness prevent not, rin towards Scotsbrig, and in a two days or 3 farther southd. Oh dear, I wish I were home agn and at rest.

Yesterday after writing I rode with Stirling to the Town called by his name; where he goodhumouredly dragged me (on foot) thro’ all the sights of the poor place: some 47 years ago, I saw it with poor Edwd Irving and others now away; In the summer of 1817 TC went on a walking holiday through the Trossachs with Edward Irving, John Pears (1790–1866; see 2:200TC to AC, 13 Nov. 1822), and James Brown (1786?—1830; see 1:3JBW to MWE, 19 Nov. [1812]); see 1:105TC to RM, 5 July 1817, 108TC to JJ, 25 Sept. 1817, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 230–31. —it is now all in a scream with railways, hardly one feature except the Castle recognisable to me. Sir Stirling Sir Anthony Sterling. had been walking (very sore of feet, it appears) to Brig of Allan with John: an incurable old specimen, not witht interesting points. W. Stirling is the best of landlords; his Wife a mild soft creature of the upper Scotch Gig class Coterie speech; see JWC to Lady ALLA, [25 May]. (Gig hardly perceptible), . .ble, End of word repeated with a line over it where TC inverted his first page and wrote his last lines at the top. and fair amount of wits; whom, unless you refuse, you are likely to see with yr eyes before long. Adieu, unkind Goody ever-loved. God bless thee.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady L [LLO], 22 Aug. Addr: Newbattle Abbey / Dalkeith. PM: Edinburgh, 22 Aug. 1865. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY Lothian

docBody.p: I have only just returned to Edinr; and have but a very little while to stay.

Not to miss you altogether, I propose coming out to Dalkeith, See TC to JWC, 11 Aug. by the 12.15 train tomorrow (Wednesday);—I arrive at Dalkeith (not Eskbank) Eskbank, station about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) W of Dalkeith. 12.45 p.m.; and if one of yr Grooms Possibly James Moffat (b. ca. 1815); otherwise unidentified. were waiting for me with a Gig, I shd be at your and my Lord’s disposal all afternoon (yr luncheon my dinner); and have choice of trains to return by in the evg.
Hoping this will prove possible at Newbattle, as it shall on the Edinr side, except for accidts,—I remain, with many regards,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [22 Aug.]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N.B. PM: Folkstone, 22 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.751. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Dearest—All the letters I have had from you here have arrived shortly before eight—the dinner hour—so there has never been time for answering by return of post. Today the dear little letter was lying for me, when we returned from our drive at six! So I address a few lines to Scotsbrig, where a longish letter is waiting for you already, hoping they may not be too late.

I am vexed at the notion of your being home before me. But unless you take my advice and stay a night or two at Alderley, I dont see how, in your present impatient mood, you are to be held in, till after Monday! And it would be uncivil to the SkyLarks Caroline Davenport Bromley. —who has been adorably kind to me—if I broke off “quite promiscuously” when I had engaged to stay a fortnight at the least. Especially as already she has had to put up with the disappointment of your refusal to come here.

For the rest; I think the most good to be got of my sea change has been
got and over with it! Tho’ I continue to sleep in the most unprecedented manner—this affluence of sleep does me no good seemingly. I feel every day more and more weak, and listless! have “lost my happetite”! Coterie speech; see 18:87JWC to TC, [26 June 1844]. And yesterday a very short walk taken at Dover brought on a headach and sickness like what I had the day I should have gone to you at the Gill. Happily I had brought a vial of Brandy with me: and with that in the early morning and fasting ever since and a quiet drive this afternoon I am better again, but not exactly to be called glowing. Well I will tell you something more amusing— The Dowager Duchess of Somerset Margaret, b. Shaw-Stewart (d. 1880), dowager duchess of Somerset, 2d wife, m. 1836, of Edward Adolphus Seymour (1775–1855; ODNB ), 11th duke of Somerset, scholar. called for Lady Waldegrave Almost certainly Frances Elizabeth Anne, b. Braham (1821–79; ODNB ), political hostess, widow of George Edward Waldegrave (1816–46), 7th Earl Waldegrave, her 2d husband, 1840–46; she continued to call herself Lady Waldegrave despite two further marriages; her 4th and final marriage, 1863, was to Samuel Fortescue (he became Parkinson-Fortescue shortly after their marriage) (1823–98; ODNB ), politician. Presumably not the more respectable Sarah, b. Whitear (1803–73), widow of Vice-Admiral William Waldegrave (1788–1859), 8th Earl Waldegrave. the other day, and was refused admission as “her Ladyship was in bed with Sciatica”! “With who cried the Duchess? Another of those dirty Italian fellows, I suppose”!
Now goodby. I must go to my dressing which takes me always upwards of an hour!! but then I get no help whatever.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TW [TWO], [23 Aug.]. Pbd: Woolner 264. Dated by JWC’s return to Chelsea Mon. 28 Aug.
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: How nice! I have no doubt it is lovely! The Woolners’ da., Amy, b. 21 Aug. 1865. Such a Mother! And such a Father! Pray give it a kiss for me, a whole shower of kisses. I hope to see it with my bodily eyes before long. I return to Chelsea on Monday next till then I am here with Miss Bromley and the Pugs.

Mr. Carlyle too is longing for home. Can know no rest till he gets there! Poor despised Chelsea has risen in value of late I should not wonder, so great is his impatience to get back to London (!!!) that he will start off without awaiting my return, and plump down on those terrified servants all by himself!
this week! My arm continues free of pain, and I can use my hand to a certain small extent, for example I write this note with the lame hand! and since I have been here I have knitted a pair of what shall I say? Garters! Upon my honour.
Dear love to the pretty wee Wife,
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 23 [24 or25] Aug. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: Dumfries, 26 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 609.752. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:285–88. JWC apparently misdated; given her references to TC’s arrival at Scotsbrig, 24 Aug., she probably wrote either Thurs. 24 or Fri. 25 Aug.; the postmark implies this.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I am again going to make an attempt, at putting on paper the letter that has been in my head for you, Dear, ever since I came to this Place. I had even begun to write it two or three days ago, when at the first words my conscience gave me a smart box on the ear, reminding me that I hadnt written one word to Mrs Ewart since I left her—after all her kindness to me! whereas to you I had written once and again— So my pen formed, quite unexpectedly for myself, the words “dear Mrs Ewart,” instead of “dearest Mary.” To be sure there have been leisure hours enough since! Life here is made up of “leisure hours”; But just the less one does, I long ago observed, the less one can find time to do! I get up at nine, and it takes me a whole mortal hour to dress:—without assistance. At ten we sit down to breakfast, and talk over it till about eleven. Then I have to write my letter to Mr Carlyle. Then I make a feeble attempt at walking, on the cliff by the shore. which never fails to weary me dreadfully; so that I can do nothing after, till the first dinner (called Luncheon) which comes off at 2 o’clock. then, between three and four, we go out for a drive, in an open barouche, with a pair of swift horses and explore the country for three or four hours. on coming home we have a cup of tea, then rest, and dress for the second dinner at eight (nominally, but in reality half past eight!) At eleven we go to bed. Very sleepy generally with so much open air! There is not a soul to speak to from without! But Miss Bromley and I never bore one another—when we find nothing of mutual interest to talk about, we have the gift, both of us, of being able to sit silent together without the least embarrassment! She is adorably kind to me, that “fine Lady”! and in such an unconscious way! always looking and talking, as if it were me that was kind to her, and she the
one benefitted by our intimacy! And then she has something in her face, and movements, and ways that always reminds me of my Mother—at her age!

I am sorry that Mr Carlyle after all his objections to my returning to London in August should have taken it in his head to return to London in August himself! I find it so pleasant here, and am sleeping so wonderfully, that I feel no disposition to go back to Chelsea already; Miss Bromley having taken her house for five weeks, and being heartily desirous I should stay and keep her company. But a demon of impatience seems to have taken possession of Mr C. and he has been rushing thro’ his promised visits as if the Furies were chasing him! Every thing right seemingly wherever he went! The people all kindness for him, the bedrooms quiet and airy! Horses and carriages at his command; and behold! it was impossible to persuade him to stay longer than three days with Mr Erskine of Linlathen!—ditto with Sterling of Keir! and just three hours (for Luncheon) at NewBattle with the Lothians. And by this time he is back at Scotsbrig (if all have gone right) to stay “one day or at mosttwo” preparatory for starting for Chelsea!

It is really so unreasonable this sudden haste, after so many months of dawdling that I do not feel it my duty to rush home “promiscuously” to receive him— I promised to stay here “a fortnight at the least,” and the fortnight does not complete itself till Monday next— So I have written to him that I will be home on Monday—not sooner—and begging him to break the journey, and amuse himself for a couple of days at Alderley Park See JWC to TC, [22 Aug.]. —and then he would find me at home to receive him, since he won’t do as Miss Bromley and I wish, and come here—for a little sea-bathing to finish off with!

It really is miraculous how soundly I have slept here! tho’ I take two glasses of champagne—besides Mansinilla Manzanilla, a pale dry sherry from Andalusia, S Spain. every day at the late dinner! It couldn’t have been sound that champagne of poor kind Mrs Ewarts or it wouldn’t have so disagreed with me—here it always does me good! And the pain is entirely gone out of my arm! I cant move it any better yet—but that is small matter in comparison! I can do many things with my hand—write (as you see) knit, I have knitted myself a pair of garters I can play on the piano a little and do a few stiches with a very coarse needle—
Kindest love to the Dr
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 25 Aug. MS: NLS 518.7. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I am very quiet here, this blessed bright day; have good news from Jane; and intend to be off on Monday straight home. Annan wd do for my train and me: but how can I think of leaving witht a sight of you and the Hill Household agn? I am considerably at a loss; but feel as if there wd be no method, except to pack finally up tomorrow afternoon; get over to The Gill with Mary and all my goods in the Evening, and embark for you by the 10½ p.m. train,—stay till monday morng, & there embark. If you hear or see nothing more, consider this to be the course of things,—tho’ alas, I am sweer to quit the silent sunshine here, and try foreign beds agn, even witht the whistles while I stay.

You will see the Dr Their brother John A. Carlyle. safe tomorrow, I hope; and can tell him I had an excellt ride. Hotchpotch Vegetable soup with boiled mutton. wd be my favourite dinner on Sunday; & perhaps the Dr wd yield me my old bed.
With love to all
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 Aug. Addr: Miss Davenport Bromley / 4. Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Ecclefechan, 25 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.730. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:293.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Thanks, Dearest! At the Ecclefn Station yesterday afternoon, James junr handed me yr two bonnie little Notes, jud[g]ing Letter omitted. that they, beyond all others, wd be welcome to me, & were worth carry in his pocket: he had even taken the precaution to mark whh was foremost of the two; and I as was natural, read the latest first. What a relief, to be assured that you were sleeping &c! Never mind that weariness, that languor, inability to walk, and the rest of it: all that is the natural consequence of recovering sleep; & is like wealth steadily coming in, true tho’ as yet not in the money shape, and going into one’s barns, not into one’s pocket. Neither shall you bother yr poor little heart abt quitting Folkestone to receive me: “Monday 28th,” as happens, is the very day I had set for rushing home at a stretch: if you are doing, or are like to do, any good
at Folkne, don’t come on Monday, nor till you yourself like; nay if this weather continue, and you can pronounce that my chance of sleep is really fair, I feel as if I shouldn’t mind coming down myself for a few days, to have a little farther swashing in the sea (with touches of Lark Referring to Caroline Davenport Bromley. melody), and bring you home in triumph! Meanwhile, I reinforce yr poor extinct purse (poor little soul, after all!) with a £25 of cash, TC recorded: “25 Augt 1865 / (to Jane at Folkestone £25 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; NLS 20753). MS: to keep away the dismals on that side;—and in all other respects, I bid you be quiet, never mind me, and do what is best for yrself, whh will be the best way of obliging another self withal, and the only right way at prestt.— My own plan, after unravelling a multitude of bothering circs and unwelcome contradictions, continues to be, No Foxton Foxton wrote, 29 Aug.: “I cannot tell you how much I am disappointed at not having you here after so much long-deferred hope. Shall I ever see you now? What ‘better time’ is ever likely to come? For myself, every succeeding year brings with it a heavier burden of infirmities. … Let me still hope that, after a few weeks rest in your honest ‘fourposter’ at home, you may be tempted to encounter the shorter railway trip from London to this place. … Will it be dishonouring to you to suggest a creature comfort as an inducement to you to come to me? I have got, under my windows, fetlock-deep in grass, the prettiest Ayrshire cow (distinct from an Ayrshire cattle show) now to be found in the principality. As your milk appears to be all being poisoned in London by the cattle-plague, & as this and to be an important article in your diet, I throw in this fact as a make weight to add to the sum of my inducements.” (an intolerable ride for length and complicacy, a night of attempt at sleeping on the road; and at the end of all nearly as far from London as if I were here!)—no Foxton; no Alderley (a haggle and an uncerty of hitting trains thro’ Manchester; and then the two “children of glory,” The two children recently b. at Alderley. the &c &c,—not to say that I have not now any possibility of ansr from Alderley in time for Monday)—nothing for it but getting into the express train, either at Annan or Dumfries, on Monday 28, betn 11 a.m. & noon, in the hope of reaching home that night abt 10, and ending all this toss of miscellans jumblings! That is it. I said “Dumfries or Annan”: Mary is here (came yesterday to take charge of me);—and how to see Jean agn in the Sabbath sleep of railways; that is one of the burbles that are not yet cleared up, but shall not concern poor you. John ran to Berwickshire (on some sorry Watt errand), Having to do with one of John A. Carlyle’s stepsons; see TC to JAC, 26 July. is to be at Dumfries today,—and I will settle the Dumfries & Annan questn “some way or other.” I ought to see poor Jean agn: but the truth is, I have nowhere been so comfortably lodged as even here just now: silence, sleep procurable, and indeed a kind of feeling that I am a little better really since quitting home; all this added to the loveliest skies I ever saw (clear as diamonds this day), and an earth all lying white
to the harvest, with monitions in it agt human gloom: all this is here but as usual it can only last for a day.

My Edinr—Keir &c fortnight was not witht profit perhaps; tho’ the interest it cd have to me was only small. Not a single loved face there,—ah me, so few anywhere at this date! The physiognomies all Scotch looked curious to me; the changed streets and businesses:—the horrors of the railway statn called “Waverley,” The main stn., Edinburgh. where John often had me, are a thing to remember all one’s life; perhaps the liveliest emblem of Tartarus Tartarus, in Greek and Roman mythology the lowest part of hell; TC often uses this as a metaphor for railway building; see 40:79TC to JWC, 25 April 1864. this Earth holds. Erskine’s tolerance of that unlovely Schwabe is not to be praised of him; indeed the good old Saint Thomas seemed to me sometimes to have grown more secular in these his last years; eats better, drinks do, and is more at ease in the world,—very wearisome, and inclined to feel distressed & be disputatious on his new theories abt “God,” when Sinner Thomas TC himself. will have nothing to do with them. We met on our walks one day, a big reddish-coloured phenomn who seemed to start as he passed, tho’ I did not the least mind him: Erskine whispered “Do you know who that was?” Not the least. “That is Gilfillan the great!” George Gilfillan (1813–78; ODNB ), author and Presbyterian minister in Dundee; he and TC were initially friends (see 17:40TC to JWC, 12 Aug. 1843) but later fell out; see 29:236TC to JCA, 12 Jan. 1855. Very good: needed to be “cut tact”; and it cd not have been better done.— I know not whether you will take to “Lady Anna Stirling,” if she shd to you: she is modest, good, a gentlewoman; and I think will have more gumption than perhaps she shows at once. It is such a House for “ornament & grandeur,” Coterie speech; see 19:135JWC to TC, [7 Aug. 1845]. of every kind, as I have nowhere seen. Poor Stirling looks a good deal happier too;—& I am glad to have kept my old promise to him.

The visit of day before yesterday to Newbattle was perfectly successful, one may say, tho’ as sad as cd well be for such a thing. A braw Coach stood waiting me at Dalkeith statn, 1 p.m.; carried me back abt 7,—tho’ except for the honr of the thing, Coterie speech; see 31:116JWC to MR, [3 July 1856]. I had better have walked,—station being close on the Marquis’s Park, and the paths and woods there altogether eligible. The House is fine of its kind, and finely Scotch; nobody there but the two poor inmates, and an idle-looking goodhumoured Painter doing a Portrait of the Lady. John Leslie (1822–1916), pre-Raphaelite painter, politician; his portrait of Lady Lothian, completed 1866, now hangs in Blickling Hall, Norfolk. The Lady took me out to walk; talked like a sad, serious, inquiring & intelligt soul,—the saddest, thin, kindly anxious face you cd anywhere [see]. Word omitted. The
poor Marquis did not appear till lunchn: a truly beautiful yg man, body and mind; but weaker than ever, hands now shaking, eyes beginning to fail, but heart as lively as ever. Lord Lothian had long been in very poor health; see 39:167JWC to MR, 9 July 1863, and 187JWC to MR, 16 Sept. 1863. We had a great deal of innocent, cheerfully reasonable talk; and I daresay my advent might be a kind of relief, like a tree in the Steppe, in the melancholy monotony of such a life. Had you and my Lady been fairly acquainted she wd have liked you well, and a visit from us there (whh I was always trying at, during those Nithsdale times) might have ansd beautifully to all parties. His Lp gave me his Book on the Confederates, Confederate Secession (1864); JWC already had a copy of this book; see JWC to TC, 24 May. whh I read yesterday in the raily; and found really clever & even amusing. I send it to a certn Lady, in revenge for that wicked hoax she played me yesterday in regard to the Dublin Exhibitn; The Dublin International Exhibition of 1865; hoax unexplained; possibly the book was sent to Caroline Davenport Bromley. —too bad! You can also prest my “respects,” if so it must be, to that enviable “four-footed creature.” Spark; see JWC to TC, [19 Aug.]. —

And now, enough Dearest: when did you get so lengthy a Letter;—fool that I am! Oh keep well! Miss Bromley (I suppose, or the Owner of the House) can get you yr 25 sovns at any Bank in Fne. A Letter for me at Chelsea, mind that! And God be with thee, Dearest. Ever /
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 26 Aug. Addr: 4 Langhorne Gardens, West Cliff / Folkestone. PM: Ecclefechan, 26 Aug. 1865. MS: NLS 617.731. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,—I am toshove off this evg (Saturday) to Cummertrees, with Mary, poor kind soul, and with all my goods finally packed,—for the purpose of getting to Dumfries by the last train tonight (arrive there abt 11 p.m.); of staying there till Monday morning; and thence of shoot shooting “Shoot” badly blotted and repeated with a line over it at turn of page. off direct for Chelsea by the train you went by, See JWC to TC, [25 July]. —arrive in Chelsea abt 10 p.m. of Monday night, don’t we? If my Goody be already there, after all, of course it will be abundantly cheerfuller: but she is not by any means to leave Folkne on that acct;—tho’ I ref[l]ect Letter omitted. since yesterday that perhaps she wishes and has herself decided to come? To whh possibility I have only to add another, that Miss Bromley may have provided herself with new society, in that anticipatn,—and
that I myself, in any case, shall perhaps not feel up to more railwaying after my approaching 350 miles of it all in a piece. Yesterday I was hopefuller: but then I was at rest; and now the hateful hour is come of flinging oneself out agn into a taste of the Whale’s Belly See Jonah 1:17 and Matt. 12:40. —Ach Gott, cdn’t they let me lie and and slumber here? No,—off with you, sirrah! I feel well, and improved generally (in some sort): yet it is certain I wd rather give 5 guineas, than not be left lounging & reading & lazily half sleeping today as yesterday!—
I will write to Mrs Warren tomorrow, supposing you have not warned her. Adieu, dear Jeannie mine; God give us a glad meeting soon. Ever yr
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EW [EWA], 27 Aug. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: To Mrs Warren (Chelsea)
I am coming home Tomorrow (Monday); to start by the same train Mrs came by from these parts,—whh I think, if all prosper, ought to land me at Chelsea abt 10p.m.

Perhaps my Mrs herself may be at home by the hour of my arrival; but this I do not know at all;—at any rate, the good Mrs Warren will know well enough what to have ready for me (aired bedroom &c &c) without farther directn of mine.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EW [EWA], [27 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Folkestone, 27 Aug. 1865. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA WARREN

docBody.p: I shallbe home tomorrow (Monday) before dinner. As Mr Carlyle is to be looked for by the ten at night train it will be best there should be a few hours between our arrivals—“Best to be off with the old trunks before one is own Thus in MS. with new”! So please provide some dinner for me, to be ready at four o’clock. As I have been accustomed to two dinners in the day here, I should take ill with being starved. But my aspirations soar no higher than a stewed mutton chop—or the like!

If Mr C had not been seized with this sudden impatience for home; I should have been glad to stay another week. I have kept on sleeping so wonderfully well! And Miss Bromley is so unwilling that I should go!— Except Lady Ashburton there is no woman that I like as well to live beside. She is so perfect a gentlewoman in all her ways, besides being clever and kind, and—what I for one, must consider a high merit—extremely fond of me ! A phrase of JWC’s mother, Grace Welsh; see 9:169JWC to EA, [ca. 6 March 1837].
Now go and help Jessie to shake up my bed!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: P S—Be sure you catch the Postman and tell him to bring all letters to Cheyne Row now—for both Mr C and me

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Aug. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 744–45.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Here I am; safe out of the enormous jingling whirlwind; arrived (40 min. too late) abt 11 p.m.; found Jane to have come in the afternoon; considerably improved since I last saw her, and with a House all shining in apple-pie order round her. I have got some sleep (not quite enough), and feel up to the work of at least unpacking, and beginning the work of order. John A. Carlyle wrote to their brother Alexander in Canada, 31 Aug., enclosing TC’s letter: “Our brother Tom left us on Monday (28th) & got safely home the same day. … He staid in Scotland a little more than three months. … He looked much better … than when he arrived here in May, has no disease upon him except age; and it seems to me wonderful that he got through his twelve years of hard unremitting labour without any other injury than immense fatigue, in itself dangerous when carried to such extent. He has done no work since his task ended in February. … [JWC] has had no return of her disease of last year, but an attack [of] rheumatic gout in the right arm which seems to be now well nigh gone too” (Marrs 746). Woolner commented on both Carlyles to Lady Ashburton, 4 Sept.: “I saw the Carlyles on Thursday evening [31 Aug.]; she looks despite her hand better than I had seen her ever since her illness a year and ¾ ago; he did not seem to me in the great Niagarian flow of spirits as he is wont, but he looks well physically; the ruddy bronze of a summer sun brightens his face and his step is more elastic and firm than I have seen it for years past. I think the almost entire want of intelligent notice of his great work now completed must make him feel depressed. When a man has brought the full force of a colossal spirit to bear on one subject, and overcoming incredible difficulties, at last without a word of encouragement brings his labours to a conclusion, he wants something besides the consciousness of having done his duty; a few words to show that his toilsome struggle has at least been recognised would surely be not too much to expect” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). I am on the ground floor, as perhaps you know, Books &c all abt me, & a room, or 3 rooms, so smart & lively you wd not knowthem agn.

Till Carlisle I rode quite alone with the fresh Winds: we staid ½ an hour in that City; and then in spite of my precautions my compartt was invaded,—two Glasgow bodies, an Edinr do; harmless touring people with “return tickets,” for some time there was a lank sleepy-looking cockney youth of the same trade: but all were harmless, good-natured; I persuaded them to let down a bit of their window by & by, whh they loyally kept so; & we had smoking ad libitum, & peace in our borders, amid the outside noises. But it was a big train; crowded, & had the usual accompant of Chaos animate & inanimate. I drank by degrees every drop of the brandied water; but, dining well at Preston, Preston, Lancashire, railway junction about 89 mi. (143 km.) from Carlisle. had no need (or none till this morng) of Jean’s fine chicken sandwh. At Carlisle the guard asked us all, “Dine at Preston?” but kept his telegraphing strictly to himself. Enough!——

“Nobody” is here, I suppose; my own head (& heart) is still sounding with the sad and kind thots natural to the hour of Parting. God bless you all, you ever kind & dear souls whom I so grieved to quit. Ever affecte
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Sept. MS: NLS 526.31. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Yr 3d Note unluckily did not quite reach me yesterday till past five p.m. We had gone off, Jane & I, to call on Ruskin & his mother, “at Queen’s Hotel Norwood,” See JWC to TC, [9 Aug.]. on the stroke of 2;—so that yr good news had to lie waiting. We did not find Ruskin either, only his good old mother; who sufficed us; aided by a pleast long drive in the brightest of days. Not the least of “rain” here; night or day the finest weather, no fault but that it is too hot!

Butler’s Acct, stamped by yr verdict upon it, Charles Butler, TC’s American stockbroker, wrote to John A. Carlyle, 17 Aug.: “Inclosed I hand your statement brought up to the lst August, 1865, showing the state of your brother’s affairs in my hands at that date. Since the previous statement the exchange has declined very much, and I think we may count on its continuing to do so. / I concluded to invest the balance in hand by the purchase of two bonds of $1,000 each at 8% which I regard as very favorable. The interest of these two will be now added to the account. Their purchase required a small advance over the amount standing to the credit of the account, which will be reimbursed to me out of the accruing interest in Feby next. I shall write your brother shortly not only on the termination of the war here in this country, whereby commercial relations are left to return to their usual & natural condition, but also on the termination of his great work, the History of Frederick, whereby his peace of mind must be restored & himself freed from a great burden” (LeRoy Elwood Kimball, “Thomas Carlyle and Charles Butler of Wall Street,” Essays and Studies in Honor of Carleton Brown [New York, 1940] 293). is surely an excellt occurrence!
And I will not detain you an hour farther from answering that good obliging Gentn, in the most obliging terms you can find. Tell him from me that I am altogether satisfied, and very grateful;—and indeed quite ashamed at the pious trouble he has taken in regard to that small matter. That I shall be delighted to hear from him, & then to write to him. That I am verily glad of the huge change from War and Madness to Peace & Sanity;—and shall be well pleased with the sight of gold instead of greenbacks, as one small token of that blessed consumatn! For the rest that in regard to “transmitting of interest on tolerable terms” or “reinvesting it,” I leave Mr Butler, as I ought, sole judge;—and in fine that I beg him to accept the inclosed Photograph, Either one of Elliott & Fry’s or John Watkins’s photographs of TC, taken late April; copies were sent to friends and family in May; see TC to RWE, 14 May. that he may really “see how I look” nowthat Friedrich is done. Enough!— —

Many thanks for yr former Notes, for the ill-deserved affectn you all always show me. I have been rather queasy and confused all week, never yet got into my old gravings agn—stomach in particr refusing to put up with this sudden change of element & ways. All well & right otherwise. Many thanks & approvals for that £100 to poor Alick’s Tom. Tom, Alexander Carlyle’s eldest son. John A. Carlyle wrote to their brother Alexander, 31 Aug.: “Several months ago I sent off a letter to Tom … asking him to send me word if he found difficulty in paying the instalment due this year for his farm; and I have got no answer—from which I infer that there is difficulty. I enclose an order for £100 … and request you to aid him with whatever part of it is necessary, and apply the rest to help his brother [Alexander] … to become a scholar” (Marrs 745). Well done, surely & wise: “What I spent I had; had; Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. what I gave I have” Said to be the epitaph of Edward de Courtenay (1357–1419), 3d earl of Devonshire, quoted by Edmund Spenser in “May Glossary,” The Shepheardes Calendar (1579). —even so! My love to Jean & them all. Ever yr affecte
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 3 Sept. MS: NLS 553.283. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I hear you are in Wales, but not for long. Let me see or hear of you so soon as ever you return. I came last Monday; the huge tract of railwaying has considerably confused me ever since. There was extensive surface and underground railway construction between Chelsea and Hampstead during the 1860s; see Whitbread’s Map of London 1865.

The inclosed I believe to be some impertinence in faint ink; I have not read one syllable of it; nor need you unless quite idle. A man must be a snob and a fool who writes such a hand and with such ink;—from Manchester too! Writer and letter untraced; cf. also TC to JWC, 13 July.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC [JOCO], 11 [9] Sept. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH CROSS

docBody.p: Oh Mr Cross!I can do no more about these dreadful “Empties” than I now do! If they still pass from a fortnight to three weeks on the road, somebody else than me must be accountable for it hereafter!

The last hamperwith all its boxes, directed by my own hand, JWC was sending back to Addiscombe the empty hamper that had arrived full on Sat. 5 Aug.; see JWC to Lady A, 8 Aug. I took myself the day before yesterday (Thursday 9th) Thurs. was 7 Sept. in, or rather on my carriage, to the Railway Office in the Regent Circus and consigned it there with an admonition! The Head man assured me “Empties” were just as carefully forwarded as fulls! So we shall see what the suppression of one Carrier will do!

Another thing!— I had only 8d (porterage) to pay for the last hamper so you must have prepaid it—and I had made it an understood thing with Lady Ashburton that I should pay the carriage of the hampers myself.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 10 Sept. MS: NLS 518.8. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—Nothing has gone wrong here; tho’ we are but in a feckless way, nearly burnt up by the hot windless weather; The Times, 9 Sept., pbd. a letter from John Gorham, 7 Sept.: “This has no doubt been an exceptionally hot day in all the south of England. As it may interest your readers to compare their experience with ours, I send you the temperatures of this, our hottest day of the year so far, the 21st of June only being excepted … maximum some time between 1 and 2 p.m., 87.2 deg. [30.6 C].” and can give no details of work done or victories achieved, even on the small scale, since my return hither.
Doubtless the roasting weather (all a perfect oven, night and day) may have a good deal to do with it: but I myself privately surmise, a still graver cause (in my own case) is—in fact is, the want of any right supply of Potatoes hitherto (whh will not now last long)! The fact, at any rate, is certn, I have never yet got into a secure footing in regard to dietetics; and for one point, have hardly made a single unexceptionable sleep since arriving here,—you know what that means, till once it alter. Alter it will and must; but occasionally, looking back on the last 15 or 16 weeks in that point of view, my poor thots are not of an exhilarating character! However, I can walk rather well; a good deal better than when I left home; perhaps I really am in essentials “a little better,”—at any rate, I am, and ought to be, satisfied that I tried my best; and I do intend to begin regulating, arranging, & setting my poor remnant of life in order,—so soon as this misery of heat and indigestn will give me a chance. “Steady!” Coterie speech; see 1:292TC to AC, 5 Dec. 1820.

John will have written to N. York for me, John A. Carlyle wrote to Butler, 4 Sept. He quoted TC’s remarks about Butler (see TC to JAC, 2 Sept.), then continued: “My brother came to Scotland in May, & staid rather more than three months, leaving us only last Monday. … When he came here … he looked considerably shaken & worn by his long labour, but had gained strength & much better health when he started again for Chelsea. Mrs C. also was in Scotland for almost the whole of July, & then at Folkstone for some weeks. She has had no return of last year’s illness, but had swelling of the right arm from what the doctors called rheumatic gout, which took away her power of writing. She is now nearly well again, can write freely, & was at home when my brother arrived there. On the whole it seemed to me that both got wonderfully well through the long tear & wear of Frederick, which I often feared might prove fatal to both.
