The photograph was taken in May last. … The likeness is better than usual in photographs” (MS: EUL). perhaps is doing so this very day: thank him kindly. I will write agn so soon as matters are in train abt abt Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. me; if they even continue stagnant & as they are, I will write before long. Adieu; & my blessing to one & all of you!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 10 Sept. MS: NLS 609.753 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p:
My Darling Betty! It is a shame that I should have let myself fall in your debt for two letters! And I have not even the excuse I had for many weeks of not being able to use my Right hand; for, since my return to London I have been able to write with it, better or worse, and to cut my food with it, and knit (!)
with it, and play the piano with it and do with it ever so many things which for two or three months had had Repeated by JWC. either to be done with my left hand, or other people’s hands or—not done at all.

The night before I left Holmhill JWC left Holmhill 24 July. Dr Russell was giving me certain medical directions, and said, without any question on my part. “The pain in your arm, being pure neuralgia, will, I hope, wear itself out—as you get stronger (how was I to get “stronger” I should like to know, with a pain that left me no rest by day nor sleep by night?) It may be a long time first, but I think it will wear itself out ultimately; but as to the stiffness and pain in the hand, that being complicated with Gout, I think you must lay your account with its continuing”! “Do you mean to tell me I asked that I shall never have the use of my right hand again in my Life?”— “Well! I think, said he, you would do well to calculate on that, and on having pain in it always—more or less!”— I made him no answer aloud, but I said inwardly; “Well then I wont! wont calculate on it! I will get back the use of my hand please god—and you shall see!”

Next day I returned to Chelsea, at one stretch, and arrived about eleven at night. I knew that fevered as I was with the fatigue I should not be able to sleep a wink; so I sat up reading till three of the morning then I ached so all over that I thought it better to take my clothes off and lie at least on my bed. But I couldn’t lie; I was in such a state of nervous restlessness! So I bethought me to take a doze of morphia, which long ago, before my terrible illness, used to give me rest in such emergencies. The morphia did not put me to sleep, but it quietened me; so that I lay peaceably till my Maids got up between six and seven, and made me some breakfast. I was on foot all day after, unpacking and sorting up, and out in the carriage for necessary shopping; and, strange to say, the pain in my arm did not make itself felt! I MS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady L [LLO], 10 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11437. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.p:
It was a real gladness to me, your kind letter “all to myself”! I had not seen your handwriting nor seen your face for so long! not since just before I fell ill of long, terrible illness! A year and half passed in the Valley of the Shadow of Death Ps. 23:4; for the coterie speech “in the valley of the shadow of Frederick,” see 37:108JWC to MR, [1 Feb. 1861]. had given me a foretaste of separation from all living!—from those
near and dear, as well as from the farther off! When again I could see friends and acquaintances—could even enjoy the joy of seeing them; it was like beginning Life afresh, with the warm feelings of a young girl queerly mixed with the sad knowledge of Age!
Excuseso much of myself; but it is that you may understand something of the pleasure I felt in seeing your handwriting come back to me in the old kindness—after all that dark time!

I wish you could also understand how completely my Husband has considered the “Thanks” were due from him to you; and not from you to him! He enjoyed that glimpse of you and Lord Lothian in your Home, more, I think, than anything that happened for him all the three months he was away. Certainly he both wrote to me about it at the time, and has spoken to me about it since his return, with a quite unusual enthusiasm! rather in the style of a Fairy Tale or of the travels of John Buncle Thomas Amory, The Life of John Buncle, Esq., 2 vols. (1756–66), fictional autobiography in which the hero embarks on a series of improbable adventures and remarkable encounters. assuring me over and over that “the glorious beauty of Lord Lothian’s face was a thing one could never forget”! and of you, he has said over and over; “indeed my Dear that Lady seems to me a person to be admired and even loved! really something very noble about her”!
I think the next time he goes to visit you, he will be in no haste at all to run away!
The weather is sopreternaturally sultry here that Mr C has had no chance with it to show himself better for his wanderings. We lie about on sofas: languid, stupid, sick—physically and morally.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI], [13 Sept.]. MS: NLS 20767. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p:
I am so sorry about you! and so anxious! The Times, 13 Sept., reprinted a Dundee Advertiser report about an accident to the countess of Airlie: “On Wednesday [7 Sept.] the Countess of Airlie … paid a visit to Lady Glamis, at Glamis Castle, and while driving down the approach to the castle one of the horses stumbled, throwing off the postilion. Finding themselves without any check, the horses set off at a furious rate. In attempting to jump out, a part of the carriage caught the dress of the Countess, causing her to fall to the ground, fortunately clear of the wheels. The horses continued their career, but on approaching the castle they were observed by the medical attendant of the Earl of Strathmore … who boldly seized them and put a stop to their career. … We understand that the Countess, who was dragged for some distance, received such a severe shock as to render her unable to return home until the next day.” Charlotte Lyon-Bowes (1797–1881), Lady Glamis, widow of Thomas George Lyon-Bowes (1801–34). Their son Thomas Lyon-Bowes (1822–65), 12th earl of Strathmore, d. 13 Sept.; his medical attendant is unidentified. Cortachy Castle, Lady Airlie’s home, was about 8 mi. (13 km.) N of Glamis Castle, Angus, the Strathmore seat. Will you do me a great kindness?
Will you, if you be still too shaken to write yourself, bid your maid write me a few lines, to tell the real truth of how you are? Both Carlyle and I will be grateful to you. “Poor, dear Woman! he says, if only she was not engaged in any private operation of her own, Lady Airlie was pregnant with her youngest child, Griselda Johanna Helen Ogilvy (1865–1934); the child was b. safely, 20 Dec. at the time; no harm will be done; for she is a fine strong healthy young woman! with no particular nerves to shake! But if she was—bringing anything to maturity—the shock may have seriously hurt her!— And I should like to hear that no scratch of any consequence has befallen that bonnie face of Hers!”

Oh my dear Lady Airlie, I too could cry at the idea of any spoiling of the “bonnie face”! But I won’t admit it, on the mere word of a newspaper paragraph!— They always make the worst of everything Besides one ought to be thankful you were not killed! Such a horrid accident it was as one reads it!

It was that Prussian Graf Probably Count Oskar von Reichenbach. Lady Airlie’s last recorded visit to Cheyne Row was Oct. 1864; see 41:77JWC to MCA, [18 Oct. 1864]. who terrified you out of the house by his silence the last day you were here, who brought me the newspaper; looking awfully grave and pointing the paragraph with his finger—“Don’t be too much upthrown , he said, there is no very bad end! but is not that the same ?” “The same what”? I asked snatching the paper. “The same Lady whom I saw here”! He had nevertheless seen dozens of Lady’s Thus in MS. here, first and last!
Do make them tell me!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 Sept. MS: NLS 518.9. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:231.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Thanks for yr Letter to Mr Butler, & report of same, as for all the kind services you are always eager to do me. I meant to write you a word one of these days; but here, since last night 10 p.m., is a Canadian Note with inclosures, whh prescribe that it be done at once.

Poor Alick, how touching his old Physiognomy is to me here! His tenderness, the old vein of melancholy, of pathos, and affectionate sorrow, this was always a trait that I loved in him. Doubly interesting in the fiery indignations and manifold sarcastic ruggednesses of a character like him. He seems to be well enough;—and for the rest I cd not but reflect how opportune yr £100 will be in the kind of economic element he describes. The Photographs, at least that of Tom, you will circulate among the kindred; after that, the Jenny & Alick Alexander (Alick) possibly sent an individual photograph of himself; TC had asked for photographs of Alick and his family (see TC to AC, 6 Aug.); “Jenny & Alick” may be the same photograph of the older Alick and his wife, Janet, as that put by their son Alexander into photograph album 6, subheaded “Father & Mother”; see 222above. “Tom” was their eldest son; for a later photograph of him, see 223above. one are for Jean (as you see), & the Tom one to be returned hither, & hung up beside the copy of the other whh is in my bedroom (with Jean Presumably Jean Aitken. close by), & whh speak to me, more or less, almost every morng while I am putting on my first garnitures for the new day.
Alexander and Janet Carlyle, n.d.
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
“T. Carlyle ‘(Alick’s Tom)’: Canada 1870”
Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Of news I have nothing here; only assurance that all goes in an average way, and abt as well as one cd expect. I am getting back my sleep agn,—in spite of the burning baking windless weather we have.— I am as idle as it is possible; merely reading (Racine Jean Racine (1639–99), French dramatist; TC earlier recommended Racine as “worth a serious re-perusal, after one has come to the years of discretion”; see 38:257TC to LALA, 5 Nov. 1862. chiefly in the shade of the backyard), musing many sad things, sad but quiet and very fit for the circs I am got into. My feet have not been so easy in their shoes for 10 years back; my power of walking too is considerable, and this deliverance from the duty of riding is welcomer than you can possibly imagine! Jane is doing well, too; drives abt unweariedly (abt twice a week I go with her); and really seems to be better than we have seen her for a long time past. We are not witht company either, indeed have more than I want; tho’ the Town is said to be “empty altogether.” Ruskin, Twisleton, Edward Twisleton. Spedding, James Spedding. Forster (the last two just abt departing); Froude too is coming soon, &c &c: in short there are enough; & seldom comes any one whom I cd prefer to my Racine & the fresh air!— Since I began writing, that Dymock-Lushington Dymock-Lushington epistle unidentified. Lushington is Vernon Lushington (1832–1912; ODNB ), writer and barrister, who had helped TC with his work 1856–57; see 32:56–57TC to VL, 19 Dec. 1856, 32:69JWC to MCA, 2 Jan. 1857, and 33:95–96TC to VL, 5 Oct. 1857; his twin brother was Godfrey Lushington (1832–1907; ODNB ), civil servant, and their father was Stephen Lushington (1782–1873; ODNB ), judge. epistle came (no ansr); last night the Adam White Adam White (1817–78; ODNB ), naturalist and author; he retired as assistant in the zoological branch of the dept. of natural history at the British Museum, 1863, and now lived in Scotland; see also TC to AW, [late Sept.?]. (do, I shd
think): in fact 9/10; of the Letters I get are (dreary to say) abt nothing at all. Tauchnitz TC’s Leipzig publisher; see TC to EM, 19 May. has sent some copies of the last Half of Frh; & now I don’t know who had copies of the former! I fear you can throw no light on it? I write to Liverpool to ask Jean’s Jim if he had not one.— Enough dear Brother. A wordfrom some of you on Sunday? My blessings on all.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [22 Sept.]. Roslyn Park / Hampstead. PM: London, 22 Sept. 1865. MS: NLS 553.283, envelope only. TC’s letter of this date is lost.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 27 Sept. MS: NLS 518.10. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Yr Monday-morning Note was very welcome, as they all are: and brought me kindly in mind of you all,—all the more as they come gratis, and don’t bully for an ansr till the time serve. I did design to write some word or two on Saty; but looking at the clock, found it inexorably too far on, & that my afternoon’s walk (and probably night’s sleep) was forfeited if I did. I am totally idle,—that is to say, do nothing except read &c &c;—but my aversion to the pen is equal or superior to what it ever was; and indeed I shudder to write the smallest line, and never do it when I can avoid. “Work” is far, far from me; all my Work seems done; and generally I am well enough content it shd be so,—in such a thrice-beggarly workshop as this terrestrial one of ours has now grown. Full of mere railway Screameries, Penny-Newspaperings, and the voice of doleful creatures, from pole to pole. “Dinna speak o’t!” as poor Byron used to say of his lame leg, in the young Aberdeen days. George Gordon (1788–1824; ODNB ), Lord Byron, lived in Aberdeen with his mother, Catherine Gordon (1765–1811), until 1798; for the phrase, see Thomas Moore, Letters and Journals of Lord Byron: with Notices of His Life (London, 1830) 1:10; for TC’s earlier use, see 7:276TC to JSM, [18 Aug. 1834].

For the rest, we are both of us well; Jane very especially,—if it will only last. She misses no day to drive out 3 hours; takes her meals along with me; and sleeps generally much better than has been common. The weather is still what you wd call “excellent”; still in general too hot, but with occasional
gusts from the N. East whh are of quite another character, and drive one into thicker clothes, soon to be quitted agn for thinner. I care little abt my “reading”; but the privilege of following my own moody contemplatns and being well let alone, is for the prest a welcome tho’ a sad one. Chorley John Rutter Chorley. is come back (called on John at Edinr, but couldn’t find), and has seen me twice,—with small profit to either!— Froude is coming soon; and he, tho’ the best, won’t do much for me, I fear. The railways are grown rather dreadful round this spot; go squalling and mewing all night, like gigantic cats (shut out, and demanding in vain to be shot), but happily, what with curtains, what with position under screen of streets, they are scarcely troublesome at all in the bedrooms,—thank Heaven!

I do not inclose the Hanning Photograph; Presumably of Janet Hanning. the fact is, I sent it yesterday to Scotsbrig, and you will get it from there,—with perhaps a little message abt oatmeal; whh let me now explain beforehand, shd it actually come. Our Nithsdale maid Jessie Hiddleston. being excellt at cakes, poor Jane daily eats them, as do I sometimes with a bit of cheese: whereby yr little Gift of meal is within an ounce or two of done. Yesterday I wrote to Scotsbrig for 4 stone (no less!)—but said, If they had not yet gone to mill Probably Satur Mill; see 41:62TC to JAC, 4 Oct. 1864. with their really best, they were to send you word, and a little interim Paper-bag wd perhaps come from you. That is all.—— Item, ask James junr, if I did or did not give him a small (Leipzig) copy of Friedrh voll. 1.—7? For if so, I have got a sequel for him. I myself wrote, “7 Price Strt Birkd”; Her son James Aitken’s address in Birkenhead, across the river Mersey from Liverpool. but can get no answer. Item last, there are here two copies of a big 4to Pinkerton’s Geography, John Pinkerton, Modern Geography; a description of the Empires, states, and colonies, with the oceans, seas and islands in all parts of the World, 2 vols. (1802). —whh I am sure the elder James Jean’s husband, James Aitken. wd find to be instructive and interesting; tell me if he will have it & by what way it can be sent (for I have lost yr Parcels Coy agn)!— I will write to the Dr shortly. God bless you all!—
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Sept. MS: NLS 518.11. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I designed to write to you at greater length; but, as too usual, time is wanting. Time: and all day I have nothing earthly to do, but sit reading Books that
are of neither profit nor interest to me; and to go sauntering abt, nearly the idlest of all men! It is very true; and more or less shameful, I fear. And, what is worst of all, there is little prospect for me of its altering for the better. I abhor all work, of the writing kind; and the truth is, I am incapable of it. That twelve years of tugging has quite finished me, I often think,—that and Time well might!—and it is indisputable my health is still miserably bad; liver totally deranged, sleep very bad, spirits do &c &c: in short nothing to be tried but lie quiet; and see whether fate does mean anything farther with [me]. Word omitted. I ought also to be silent abt it, you may well think;—and that is a reason why I am so sweer to write; that being the topic withal whh concerns me most! Enough of it. I am not very unhappy; not more than I used to be, surely; and if this villain of a liver wd behave itself a little, I shd be sensibly less so.

Nothing occurs here that is worth writing. The weather is cooler agn; the Town still empty,—or for me as good as empty. Yesterday Neuberg drove me a long way, by Wilsden, Harrow Road &c; kind, but wearisome. Chorley I have seen twice; he has balanced my Bank-Books for me On the back of the check stub for “25 Septr 1865 (to Jane, House &c) £75 .. 0 .. 0.” TC wrote: “Books balanced (by Mr Chorley &c) Septr 28; found correct; of mine in the Bank, at that date, £27 .. 18 .. 11 [273 crossed out by TC] n.b. no, not at all! The real sum is £163 .. 18 .. 11 (certn!)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). (all right, as you made them); he has tried to find you in Edinr as I said; but wanted nothing—is in fact as jangle-jingly as usual, very unhappy himself, and of no use as compy. Fuz is gone to Wales; tant mieux [so much the better] for the time being.

You, I am very happy to hear, are doing well at Dumfries. The street of Brompton Place is a greatly improved place; all new numbered; so that I cannot yet make out the old “No 48,” John A. Carlyle lodged for many years with Mrs. Thirza Kingham, 48 Brompton Row, when staying in London; see 41:82–83JWC to MCA, [25 Oct. 1864]; various streets, including Brompton Row and Brompton Place, were now incorporated into Brompton Rd.; Mrs. Kingham’s new address was 174 Brompton Rd. as I pass! I know not if you ever think of trying London agn for a variety? It is not for me, who like it so little, to invite you hither. The room here, you know is empty, tho’ I fear it will not be quieter than when you last occupied it. If you ever do think of coming, it wd be a landing-place for you, with a welcome waiting. Jane’s health is a great deal better than it was; that is one considerably favourable point.

I get almost no Letter that is not worse than none “Hy Inglis” being mentioned in the Newsprs once, See JWC to TC, [11 Aug.]. abt half a peck of dirty scribbles (all impertinent to me, & from ourie wretches) have followed me that way, & continue to follow;—the pink of all whh has arrived this morning; and looks as if it had come from the heart of Bedlam! Read, & Jean and you try yr hand upon it! After
some guessing, I can only imagine to myself that possibly the late “Thomas Carlyle, Thomas Carlyle (1803–55; ODNB ), apostle of the Catholic Apostolic Church and German scholar; see 6:132TC to MAC, 18 Feb. 1832, and 16:237–38TC to CKJB, 7 July 1843. Angel to Hy Drummond,” Henry Drummond (1786–1860; ODNB ), banker and politician; one of the founders of the Catholic Apostolic Church; see 5:340–41TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831, and 16:24TC to HD, 20 Jan. 1843. may have once had a Brother The apostle Thomas Carlyle’s parents were William Carlyle and Margaret Heriot; possibly they had a second son, James Coulter Carlysle (b. 1809), whose parents are listed as William and Margaret “Harriot” on FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/) (where Thomas and his father, William, are listed as Carlel, and Margaret as Marget Haret); otherwise unidentified. who went mad; and that this poor clart of a girl Unidentified; Thomas Carlyle had a da., Alice (b. ca. 1845), who m., 1878, her cousin Henry Grey Graham (1842–1906; ODNB ), minister and historian. may be the Brother’s? Jean as denizen of Dumfries can perhaps make out, as the solution of a ridiculs riddle.— For the rest, if you wd write half a word to the poor (innocent) creature, it might be charitable. I cannot well.— At any rate, pray tell Jean she need not send any meal: Scotsbrig John has written that theirs will be ready in a week; and we can perfectly well wait.

A son of Edinr Repp’s Moses Steven William Hamilton Repp (1842–1918), son of Thorleifus Gudmundson Repp (1794–1857); librarian and linguist; asst. in the Advocate’s Lib. in Edinburgh 1825—34 (when he was dismissed); author of a Danish dictionary used by both TC and his brother; see 4:207TC to NHJ, 15 April 1827, 5:338–39TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831, and 39:116TC to JAC, 29 April 1863. has left cards here; & (t.o.) last night wrote, asking that I wd appoint him a time of interview. Slit into matches instanter,—or I wd have sent it to you. “Steven Repp Esq,”—is come over here (as if he were quite a citizen of the country) to “stand for the Civil Service,”—and is busy even now, as he candidly says, with a “Crammer.” The British govt. instituted a rigorous qualifying examination for entry into the civil service beginning 1855. More power to him! Steven Repp was listed as a clerk in the corn trade in the 1861 census; he was to be listed as a “pauper-patient” in an institution in York in the 1901 census, and as a “shepherd” on his death notice. —

div3.head: TC TO JULIA MARGARET CAMERON

docBody.p: We cannot come to-morrow but there will another day arrive (other days, with the sun in them, and a studio nearer hand), and you shall have a stroke at my face if you persist in wishing it. There is no record of Cameron photographing TC before 7 or 8 June 1867; see TC to JMC, 9 June 1867 . Depend upon that, and let us (as the Latins say) “hasten slowly.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-AW [AWH], [late Sept.?]. Pbd: Glasgow Herald, 11 Oct. Tentatively dated late Sept. by TC’s reference to White, TC to JAC, 14 Sept., and on the assumption it would take about a week to be sent, presumably by White, to the Glasgow Herald. It might also be dated early Oct. In its introduction, the Glasgow Herald stated that “he proposes to introduce the teaching of natural history into boarding-schools and private families.” A copy of the article is in HCC; on the reverse TC has written: “Octr 1865 printed witht leave / (t.o.).” [To preserve the correct order established by the editors, this letter has been assigned a document date of 30 September 1865.]
div3.head: TC TO ADAM WHITE

docBody.p: For many years it has been one of my constant regrets, that no schoolmaster of mine had a knowledge of Natural History, so far at least as to have taught me the grasses that grow by the wayside, and the little winged and wingless neighbours that are continually meeting me, with a salutation which I cannot answer, as things are! Why didn’t somebody teach me the constellations, too, and make me at home in the starry heavens, which are always overhead, and which I don’t above half know to this day? I love to prophesy that there will come a time, when not in Edinburgh only, but in all Scottish and European towns and villages, the schoolmaster will be strictly required to possess these two capabilities (neither Greek nor Latin more strict!), and that no ingenious little denizen of this universe be thenceforth debarred from his right of liberty in these two departments, and doomed to look on them as if across grated fences all his life! For the rest I cannot doubt but, one way or other, you will by and by make your valuable indubitable gift available in Edinburgh, either to the young or to the older, on such conditions as there are, and I much recommend a zealous and judicious persistence till you do succeed.— Believe me, yours very sincerely,
docBody.name: T. C arlyle

div1.p: Abeken, Bernhard Rudolf (1780–1866; see 27:333TC to JAC, 15 Oct. 1852), Prussian scholar, educational theorist, and foreign office official, living in Berlin.

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921; see 26:30226:biographical notes), 5th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–1881; see 26:28926:biographical notes), 5th earl; for their children, see 37:26137:biographical notes. They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–1888), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–1887) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–1836 and 1855–1856), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–1871), who worked in a mercantile house in London from 1858, then moved to work in Liverpool ca. Nov. 1864; Thomas (1841–1869), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186), but was apparently now living at home; and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–1895), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.

Amberley, Katherine (Kate) Louisa (1842–1874; ODNB ), viscountess, radical, and suffragist; m., 1864, John Russell (1842–1876; ODNB ), viscount, politician, and writer; son of John Russell (1792–1878; ODNB ), 1st Earl Russell, politician, and Frances Anna Maria, b. Kynynmound (1815–1898). Their son, John Francis (Frank) Stanley, was b. 12 Aug. 1865.

Anstruther, Mary Frances, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1819–1913), sister of Lady Louisa Ashburton, m., 1838, Philip Anstruther (1802–1863). For their 11 children, see 38:273–7438:biographical notes. The family lived at 17 Norfolk St., Park Lane, London.

Ashburton, Lady Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903), m., 1858, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB ; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron, politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. They had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). Lady Louisa was the da. of Mary
Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB ), chief of Clan Mackenzie, and James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage (1817) the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. JWC expected not to like Louisa, but was swiftly won over. Lady Ashburton lived at Melchet Court (see 38:8), a country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire; she also owned a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon. Lord Ashburton’s first wife, m. 1823, was Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–1857; ODNB ; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix—xv26:introduction); they met the Carlyles, 1839, and became close friends. Lord Ashburton’s brother Francis Baring (1800–1868; see 36:27636:biographical notes) became 3d Lord Ashburton; his sisters were Louisa (1804–1888) and Lydia Emily (1814–1868). Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–1888), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–1878), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (b. 1833), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Ontario; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (1844–1908), who m., 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).
Baring; see Ashburton.
Barnes; see Simmonds.
Barnet; see Blakiston.

Blakiston, Bessy, b. Barnet (ca. 1810–1891), m., 1862, Peyton Blakiston (1801–1878), M.D.; they lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Blakiston’s first wife, m., 1825, was Frances, b. Powell (d. 1858); their sons were John Richard (1829–1917), Peyton (1831–1865), Douglas Yeoman (1832–1914), and Matthew Folliott (1835–1906).

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–1899); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944) and Elaine Mary (b. 1862). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, in 1860.

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82 and 24:221); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. Three sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831); their son George (1827–1810 Feb. 1865) survived into adulthood but suffered ill-health. Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127), they moved, 1858, to Upper Stenhouse, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–1891), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m.,
1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton’s, she became a close friend of JWC’s. The Carlyles called her “Lark,” “Die Lerche,” or “Flight of Skylarks.” Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St.

Bullock, John (1815–1890), from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter carrier, who had succeeded John Piper as the Carlyles’ postman; see 33:64TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1857. His son was John Joseph Bullock (b. 1846), listed in the 1861 census as an errand boy and in the 1871 census as a letter sorter.

Butler, Charles (1802–1897; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to default on their bonds; met TC Nov. 1853 and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments. He m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–1878); they had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–1856), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–1891); they had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–1884), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819. An unidentified son (1832–1833), Margaret (1835–1836), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–1854) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and TC’s writings.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–1890), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their children were James (Jr., the younger) (1835–1871), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; m., 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–1841); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–1874), m., 1864, William Scott (b. ca. 1829), draper from Birmingham; their son, John James Carlyle, was b. July 1865.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor”) (1801–1879; ODNB ), TC’s brother, physician, and translator. He m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–1854), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–1848), from Leek, Staffordshire, with four sons; she d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn. John A. Carlyle assumed responsibility for his stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–1862), went to sea in 1856 (see 32:29), went to Australia, 1861, and d. on his return (see 38:115); Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121), m., 1863, Jane Wilson, b. Hunter (1837–1908), da. of John A.
Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–1869; see 8:161JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835]) and of Helen, b. Vary (1804–1885); Arthur (b. 1840), joined the civil service 1862; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, from 1858.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.
Chapman, Edward (1804–1880; ODNB ), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, [5 Feb. 1842]); he m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–1895; ODNB ), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman & Hall; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (d. 1866); they had one son, Frederic.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–1867; ODNB ; see 19:135TC to JWC, [early Aug. 1845]), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 34:146TC to HL, 18 Aug. 1853).

Conway, Moncure Daniel (1832–1907), American Unitarian minister, abolitionist, and author; m., 1858, Ellen, b. Dana (d. 1897); they had two sons, Eustace (b. 1858) and Emerson (1861–1864). Friend of Ralph Waldo Emerson, who introduced him to TC. He came to Britain 1863; pastor at South Place Chapel, 11 South Pl., Finsbury, London, 1864–1884; they lived at 28 Notting Hill Sq., London.

Cooke, John George (known as George Cooke) (1819–1880), stockbroker; he had met JWC in 1856 (see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 18 May 1856) and became a close friend. She described him in 1864: “a man between thirty and forty; tall, strong, silent, sincere; has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!!” (41:65–6). He lived at 18 Pelham Place, Brompton. He had five sisters, including Charlotte (b. 1811), Margaretta (b. 1815), and Louisa (b. 1817).

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB ; see 8:207JWC to SS, [20 Sept. 1835]), author, prof. of English lit. and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–1866; friend of the Carlyles’ since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856; see 10:159JWC to TC, [30 Aug. 1838]). They had one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (1827–1909), Isabella (1829–1842; see 15:221JWC to JW, [8 Dec. 1842]), and Georgiana (1831–1895), novelist. Mary came to St. Leonards, July 1864–July 1864, to be JWC’s nurse.

Dickens, Charles (1812–1870; ODNB ), novelist; friend of the Carlyles’ since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–1879); separated from her in 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858.

Duffy, Charles Gavan (1816–1903; ODNB ), Irish nationalist, lawyer, and politician; emigrated to Australia 1855; known to the Carlyles since 1845; see
19:64–66. He m., 1847, as his second wife, his cousin Susan, b. Hughes (1826–1878); they had six children.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–1882; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB ; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters who lived with him: Christian (1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.
Ewart, Alicia, b. Yorstoun or Yorston (b. ca. 1789), widow of Thomas Ewart’s (d. 1831), m. 1828; friend of Mary Russell’s, living at Nithbank, Thornhill; see 40:193–4JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1864].
Fanny, age 28, the Carlyles’ maid at 5 Cheyne Row Nov. 1864 to June 1865.
Farie, Robert (1813–1882; see 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846), translator of German works, old friend of the Carlyles’.

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–1876; ODNB; see 6:118TC to JHLH, 8 Feb. 1832, 11:7TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839, and TC to JF, [25? Jan. 1839]), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–1855; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–1861, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles’ since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–1894), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB ); from late 1863 they lived at Palace Gate House, Kensington.

Foxton, Frederick Joseph (ca. 1807–1870; see 28:162TC to JCH, 6 June 1853), lapsed clergyman, writer; accompanied TC on his visit to Germany 1858; their last recorded meeting was in London Oct. 1863; see 39:226TC to JAC, 23 Oct. 1863.
Freure, Frederick (b. 1835), Chelsea carpenter; also listed as a builder in 1865 PO directory. He m. Ann (b. ca. 1830).

Froude, James Anthony (1818–1894; ODNB ), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–1874; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–1860); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–1879). He m., second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth Warre (1824–1874); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 6 Clifton Pl., Hyde Park. Henrietta’s father, John Ashley Warre (1787–1860), had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline (1809–1886).
Garibaldi, Giuseppe (1807–1882), Italian patriot and revolutionary.
Gomm, Sir William Maynard (1784–1875; ODNB ), army officer; m., 1830, Elizabeth Ann, b. Kerr (1807–1877); they lived at Rotherhithe Manor, SE London.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–1897), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840), who m., 1864, Charles Coates Holden (b. 1836). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.

Hiddleston / Hiddlestone, Jessie (1835–1904), the Carlyles’ maid 1865–1866; she m., 1866, Robert Broadfoot (ca. 1833–1890), butler to Archibald Watson Goldie (1793–1872), Writer to the Signet, and his second wife, Henrietta Townsend, b. Hare (d. 1904), m. 1860. Her mother was Margaret (ca. 1800–4 May 1865), widow of William Hiddleston, tailor; maid to JWC’s mother at Templand; see 14:160TC to JWC, 21 April 1842; and her sister was Margaret (1831–1904), m., 1855, Joseph McCaig (1829–1876), cabinetmaker, living at 62 W. Morton Street, Thornhill.

Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–1885; ODNB ; see 9:8TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9–10TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840), 1st baron, author, and politician; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties and championed progressive causes, such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–1874); they had two das. and a son; see 37:27037:birographical notes.

Howard, Rosalind Frances, b. Stanley (1845–1921; ODNB ), m., 1864, George James Howard (1843–1911; ODNB ), artist and politician, only son of the Hon. Charles Wentworth George Howard (1814–1874) and Mary Priscilla Harriet, b. Parke (1822–1843). Their first da. was Mary Henrietta Howard (20 July 1865–1956).
Hunt, William Holman (1827–1910; ODNB ), Pre-Raphaelite artist.

Inglis, Henry (1806–1885), Writer to the Signet, Edinburgh lawyer at 16 Queen St., whom the Carlyles had known since the late 1820s; see 5:12TC to HI, 31 March 1829. He m. Marianne (b. 1816) and they had four children, Andrew (b. 1832), Kate (b. ca. 1836), Fanny (b. 1838), and William (b. 1840); they lived at Torsonce House, Stow, Midlothian.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB ; see 1:92TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–1880; ODNB ; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles’, particularly JWC’s, since 1841. She lived at 41 Markham Sq., London. She met Walter Baldock Durant Mantell (1820–1895), politician and naturalist, late 1856, and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close; he lived in New Zealand; see 33:276–7733:biographical notes and 37:27037:biographical notes.
Kerr; see Lothian.

Lincoln, Abraham (1809–1865), lawyer and politician; 16th president of the U.S.
1861–1865. He m., 1842, Mary, b. Todd (1818–1882), and they had four sons, only one of whom survived into adulthood. Lincoln was shot by John Wilkes Booth (1838–1865), 14 April, and d. the following morning.

Lothian, Lady Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901), marchioness, m., 1854, William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–1870), 8th marquess, a noted bibliophile, and an invalid for much of his life. They lived at Blickling Hall, Norfolk, and Newbattle Abbey, Dalkieth.
McCaig; see Hiddleston.

Maccall, William (1812–1888; ODNB ), impoverished writer, Unitarian preacher, and lecturer; m., 1842, Alice, b. Haselden (1813–1878); they had one da., Elizabeth (b. 1843). See K. J. Fielding, “Carlyle, Charles Dickens, and William Maccall,” Notes and Queries n.s. 1 (1954): 488–90.
Mackenzie; see Stewart-Mackenzie.

Macmillan, Alexander (1818–1896; ODNB ), publisher, m., 1851, Caroline, b. Brimley (1824–1871). They had five children, Malcolm Kingsley (1852–1889), George Augustin (1855–1936), Margaret (b. 1857), Olive (b. 1859), and William Alexander (1864–1966). After the death of his brother and business partner, Daniel Macmillan (1813–1857; ODNB ), his sister-in-law Frances Eliza, b. Orridge (1821–1867), and her four children, Frederick Orridge (1851–1936), Maurice Crawford (1853–1936), Katherine (b. 1855), and Arthur (1857–1876), came to live in his household. They lived at The Elms, Streatham Lane, Tooting.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–1872; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839 and 28:xiii—xiv), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active Italian resistance to Austrian domination. His photograph, 39:64, is incorrectly captioned.

Mill, John Stuart (1806–1873; ODNB ), utilitarian philosopher and economist; m., 1851, Harriet Taylor (1807–1858), who strongly influenced his thinking. Mill met TC in Sept. 1831 (see 5:398TC to JWC, 4 Sept. 1831); they remained on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1833), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage. Elected Liberal M.P. for Westminster 1865.
Milnes; see Houghton.
Montégut, Jean Baptiste Joseph Émile (1825–1896), critic and translator; his last recorded contact with TC was in 1858; see 34:217–18TC to EM, 15 Oct. 1858.
Morrison, Rev. David (1838–1911), minister of Durisdeer Parish Church, Penpont, Dumfriesshire, 1865–1872.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–1867; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839), Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British 1845, and retired from business 1849–1856; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced
to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). From 1856–1863 Neuberg lived at Oakley Villas, 25 (renumbered 140) Adelaide Rd., with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) (ca. 1816–1898)—who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–1856; see 32:32TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856)—and her two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856). In 1863 he moved to Roslyn Park, Hampstead. After Frankau’s death, Neuberg managed Frankau’s company, which imported meerschaum pipes and fancy goods, at 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St., London.

Otthenin, Jean, b. Johnston (1807–1870 according to a French genealogy website, but she must have been born earlier as TC had left the school in Ecclefechan by 1806), known to TC in her childhood; her mother, Margaret Carlyle (d. 1830), fled with her from a brutal husband, James Johnston (d. 1809), to France. Jean m., 1832, Nicolas-Julien Otthenin (1785–1845), a French cavalry officer, who d. in a carriage accident; see 20:18–19TC to JWC, 8 Oct. 1845. Now living at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh, with her das. Margaret (the elder), who was ill, and Irma (1838–1897).
Owen, Richard (1804–1892; ODNB ), naturalist and paleontologist, known to TC since 1842; see 38:211TC to RO, 15 Sept. 1862.
Paterson; see Erskine.
Paulet, Elizabeth, b. Newton (1806–1879; see 13:189TC to JWC, [19 July 1841]), wealthy liberal, feminist, and former friend of JWC’s and Geraldine Jewsbury’s.

Pollock, William Frederick (1815–1888; ODNB ), lawyer and author, m., 1844, Juliet, b. Creed (1818–1899). His father was Sir Jonathan Frederick Pollock (1783–1870; ODNB ), 1st baronet, judge, lord chief baron of the exchequer 1844–1866; m., first, 1813, Frances, b. Rivers (ca. 1787–1827); m., second, 1834, Sarah Anne, b. Langslow (1815–1895); see 29:33TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1854.

Quain, Richard (1816–1898; ODNB ), physician; specializing in heart diseases, with many wealthy and influential patients; he lived at 67 Harley St., London. He m., 1854, Isabella Agnes, b. Wray (1828–1891); they had four das. He treated the Ashburtons and JWC.
Quiller, Charles Rowett (b. 1829), pharmacist, 15 Sloane Sq., London.

Reichenbach, Oskar von (1815–1893), Silesian landowner, liberal deputy to the Frankfurt parliament 1848–1849, exiled to London in 1850. Friend of the Carlyles’ since the 1840s. His wife, m. 1842, was Friederika or Fredrike (called Hedwig in error before vol. 39), b. Plattnauer (b. 1817), sister of Richard Eduard Plattnauer (b. 1814; see 41:23441:biographical notes); and their children were Elisabeth (b. 1843), Hedwig (1844–1892), and Oskar (b. 1845). They emigrated to the U.S. in 1853, but returned to London in 1863. In 1866 Reichenbach visited Prussia to assist Otto von Bismarck in the drafting of
a constitution for the North German Confederation, which formed the political basis of the later German empire.
Royston, William Haylett (1822–1871), m., 1847, Isabella, b. Harris; they had a son, William Haylett (b. 1863), and a da. (b. 1864); theylived at 1 Cheyne Row.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB ), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–1897); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–1896; ODNB ], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). His father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), had been a wine merchant. Ruskin was J. M.W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Elizabeth Ann, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), widow of Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), soldier and diplomat; she had two sons, Arthur John Edward (1825–1892), M.P. for Tavistock 1857–1885, with whom she lived at 2 Audley Sq., London, and Odo Leopold William (1829–1884; ODNB), diplomat. She was always known as Lady William Russell; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187.
Russell, John; see Amberley.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–1875; see 6:145TC to AC, [7 April 1832]), close friend to JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).
Silvester, John (b. ca. 1799), livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865); they had a son John (b. ca. 1829) and a grandson William (b. ca. 1857).

Simmonds, Isabella Emily, b. Barnes (b. 1837, d. by 1899), became close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859; see also 35:188JWC to JGCO, [2 Sept. 1859]. She m., 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829, still alive in 1899), barrister; they lived at 82A Oakley St., Chelsea. Their first child, Ethel Jane (1863–1865), d. 2 July; their second child, Amy Constance, was b. early Sept. 1865. Her father, Dr. Alfred Brooke Barnes (ca. 1802–1867), physician, lived at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; previously JWC’s doctor in Chelsea, he had been ill for some time (see 40:123TC to LLA, 25 June 1864, and 6:198TC to MAC, 31 July 1832); m. Susannah (ca. 1804–ca. 1855); they had three other children: Laura Susannah (b. 1829, now dead), Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), and Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–1926 Sept. 1865).

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19TC to SGS, 24 July 1855), politician; living in Thurso Castle, Caithness. He m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–1863). Their son, John George Tollemache Sinclair (1825–1912), m. Emma, b. Standish (1827–1889), and lived at The Mount, Upper Norwood, nr. Croydon, SE London; they had three das. (see 36:28636:biographical notes).

Spedding, Thomas Story (1800–1870; see 10:32TC to TSS, 17 Feb. 1838), m., 1839, Frances Elizabeth (previously called Emily in error), b. Headlam (1811–1896); their children were Margaret Emily (1842–1873), Frances Ellen (1843–1900), Maria Isabella (d. in infancy 1845), Henry Anthony (1846–1887), and Mildred Eyre (1848–1918). He lived at Mirehouse, nr. Keswick, Cumberland. A lawyer, he devoted his life to local interests in Cumberland. He and his brother James Spedding (1808–1881; ODNB ; see 8:196JWC to JCA, [Mid-Aug. 1835], and 19:205TC to TSS, 20 Sept. 1845), literary editor and biographer, had been friends of TC’s since the late 1830s. James lived in WestbourneGrove, London.

Stanley, Arthur Penrhyn (1815–1881; ODNB ), dean of Westminster 1864–1881. He m., 1863, Lady Augusta Bruce (1822–1876; ODNB ), da. of Thomas Bruce (1766–1841; ODNB ), 7th earl of Elgin, former lady of the bedchamber and secretary to Queen Victoria. He was 1st cousin to Edward John Stanley.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–1895; ODNB ), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–1869; ODNB ; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), Whig politician, who succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire; their London home was at 40 Dover St. Both were friends of the Carlyles’. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:264). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903; ODNB ); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915; ODNB ); John (Johny) Constantine (1837–1878); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925; ODNB ); Katherine (Kate) Louisa (see Amberley); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (see Howard).

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–1871; ODNB ; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67 and 19:9); they lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–1844; ODNB ), writer, had been a particular friend of TC’s; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); for John Sterling’s children, including Julia Maria Sterling (1836–1910), see 35:264–6535:biographical notes.

Stewart (Stuart), Charles (ca. 1791–1875), factor and local historian; he lived at Hillside, a farm 2 mi. (3 km.) N of Lockerbie. His older brother was James Hope Stewart (1789–1856; ODNB ), factor and natural history illustrator, of Gillenbie Rig, Applegarth parish; see 11:167. His younger brother, John Duncan Alexander Stewart (1805–1869), merchant, m., 1829, Harriet Everilda, b. Gore (ca. 1804–1884), socialite, known as Mrs. Duncan Stewart; they had eight children; see 24:200TC to AC, 18 Aug. 1849.

Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–1874), m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–1869),
farmer from Hollybush, now living at Ernhirst (Ironhirst), about 5½ mi. (9 km.) SW of Dumfries; see 38:19TC to JWC, 1 Dec. 1861; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861), and a son, William (b. 1863).
Stirling, Christian; see Erskine.

Stirling, William (1818–1878; ODNB ), art historian, book collector, and politician; known to TC since 1848. On the death of his uncle, Sir John Maxwell of Pollock (1791–1865), 6 June 1865, he succeeded to the title and became Sir William Stirling Maxwell, 9th bart. He m., 26 April 1865, Anne Maria, b. Leslie-Melville (ca. 1825–1874), da. of David Leslie-Melville (1785–1860), 10th earl of Leven, and Elizabeth Anne, b. Campbell (1804–1863). They lived at Keir, 3 mi. (5 km.) NW of Stirling.
Stuart; see Stewart.
Sylvester; see Silvester.

Symington, Andrew James (1826–1898; see 34:240TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1858), Glasgow merchant, poet, and biographer; old acquaintance of the Carlyle family; he m., 1860, Mary Sanderson, b. Edmonston (1832–1917) from Shetland; they had a son, Andrew James (b. 1863). They lived at Govan in Lanarkshire.

Tauchnitz, Christian Bernhard (1816–1895), Leipzig printer and publisher; he began the Collection of British and American Authors series, 1841, which included The French Revolution, 3 vols. (Leipzig, 1851). He also pbd. Neuberg’s trans. of Carlyle’s Selected Works (as Ausgewählte Schriften, 6 vols. [Leipzig, 1855–1856]) and of Frederick the Great, 13 vols. (Leipzig, 1858–1865).

Trevelyan, Sir Walter Calverley (1797–1879; ODNB ), naturalist; m., 1835, Paulina, b. Jermyn (1816–1866; ODNB ), art patron; they lived at Wallington Hall in Northumberland. Lady Trevelyan was a close friend of Lady Louisa Ashburtons’.
Trollope, Anthony (1815–1882; ODNB ), novelist and post office surveyor; see 37:183TC to JAC, [8] July 1861.

Twisleton, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd (1809–1874; ODNB ), close and respected friend of the Carlyles’ (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); he m., 1852, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–1862), from Boston, Mass., JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’ Account). He lived at 3 Rutland Gate, London.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–1888; ODNB ), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–1888; friend of Tennyson’s and of Thackeray’s, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–1850).

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–1893; ODNB ), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB ; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily m. to Sydney Hawkes,
whom she divorced in 1861; see 30:21530:biographical notes and 235. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–1866). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and JosephMazzini: A Memoir (1875).
Warren, Eliza (ca. 1816–1905), a widow with adult children, the Carlyles’ cook and housekeeper at Cheyne Row Nov. 1864–July 1866.
Watkins, John (1823–1874), photographer, originally from Raglan in Monmouthshire; he and his brother Octavius Charles Watkins (1836–1882) had a studio at 34 Parliament St., Westminster, 1851–1865.
Watt; see John A. Carlyle.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–1864), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).
Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–1867), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67 and 16:219), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853]), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–1853), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie (see Chrystal), John (1820–1860), Margaret, and Mary.

Welsh, John Amelia (“Jackie”) (ca. 1812–1864), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott (b. 1782). Jackie had lived in Haddington with her mother and her aunt Jane Scott (1787–1863).

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–1888; see 13:44JWC to MW, [Late Feb. 1841], and 20:128JWC to MW, [Feb.–March 1846]), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–1859; ODNB ; see 15:37JWC to MW, [ca. 20 Aug. 1842]), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58JWC to MR, 25 March? 1859).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool, Fife, with her brother Walter; was JWC’s nurse, Dec. 1863–May 1864.
Welsh, Mary (1823–1879), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool, Fife, with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843]), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John;
minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary, lived with him.

Woolner, Thomas (1825–1892; ODNB ; see 26:37TC to TWO, [21 Feb. 1851], and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845), da. of George and Mary Waugh. Their da., Amy, was b. 21 Aug.
